Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday, 18 June 2014

Speaker: NA
Text: The SPEAKER (Hon. Bronwyn Bishop) took the chair at 9:00, made an

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledgement of country and read prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS

Speaker: NA
Text: World Trade Organization Agreement on Trade Facilitation

Speaker: Mr ROBB
Text: Goldstein-Minister for Trade and Investment) (09:01): by leave-It is with

Speaker: NA
Text: pleasure that I table the World Trade Organization Agreement on Trade Facilitation and

Speaker: NA
Text: accompanying national interest analysis for parliament's consideration. The agreement on

Speaker: NA
Text: trade facilitation was concluded by the 159 members of the WTO at the Ninth Ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: Conference on 7 December 2013 in Bali. As with all proposed treaties, the parliament's Joint

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Treaties will now review the agreement and, in due course, provide

Speaker: NA
Text: its report.

Speaker: NA
Text: This agreement is designed to deliver practical measures to strengthen global trade and

Speaker: NA
Text: economic growth. At its heart, this agreement is about cutting red tape. It is about removing

Speaker: NA
Text: the regulatory and procedural burdens that our traders face when conducting international

Speaker: NA
Text: trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the agreement targets regulatory barriers and border bottlenecks often overlooked in

Speaker: NA
Text: international trade negotiations, the benefits to Australia will be significant. With its focus on

Speaker: NA
Text: harmonising and streamlining global customs procedures the agreement will markedly reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: the length of time and the number of documents it takes Australian exporters to get their

Speaker: NA
Text: goods across borders. By requiring more transparent and predictable regulations, the

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement will also assist Australian businesses, large and small, in making international

Speaker: NA
Text: business decisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: For Australian exporters, implementation of the agreement will mean marked

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements in the manner in which their goods are treated in offshore markets. In fact it

Speaker: NA
Text: has been estimated that full implementation of the agreement could reduce the costs of trading

Speaker: NA
Text: across borders by up to 10 per cent for Australian traders. For example, provisions on advance

Speaker: NA
Text: rulings will mean that Australian traders will be able to obtain precise and binding rulings on

Speaker: NA
Text: the tariff classification their good will receive upon arrival at a foreign border. This will help

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's smaller exporters in particular, who will know how their goods will be treated by

Speaker: NA
Text: an overseas customs authority before sending them off on the long voyage from Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The agreement also mandates the quick release of perishable goods, which will reduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of Australian agricultural exports left to rot while waiting for clearance in foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: ports. Provisions allowing for the submission of import documentation prior to the physical

Speaker: NA
Text: arrival of goods, and for the clearance of goods prior to the final determination of duties and

Speaker: NA
Text: charges, will speed up the process of getting Australian goods to market. This will reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: business costs for Australian exporters and make their goods more affordable to overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: consumers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Small Australian exporters will also benefit from new requirements to publish relevant

Speaker: NA
Text: procedures and forms for importing goods on the internet. This simple but highly valuable

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment from WTO members will make it much easier for our SMEs to navigate customs

Speaker: NA
Text: procedures and launch themselves into new export markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: The agreement complements our efforts in development assistance, and will deliver

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial benefits to our developing country partners. The full implementation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement by developing countries will boost their economic growth and create millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs. Globally, the agreement will provide a major boost for jobs and growth, and it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated that this agreement could add up to US$1 trillion to the world economy and create

Speaker: NA
Text: 21 million jobs. We stand ready to assist developing countries to implement the agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: and to undertake the necessary reforms to facilitate trade. We are already providing assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: of this nature, including to our Pacific Island neighbours. More recently, and in partnership

Speaker: NA
Text: with the World Bank, we have committed to support global efforts to help developing country

Speaker: NA
Text: partners undertake trade facilitation reform.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the first major agreement concluded since the establishment of the WTO in 1995, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Agreement on Trade Facilitation is a significant milestone. It shows that the multilateral

Speaker: NA
Text: trading system is continuing to deliver outcomes with significant benefits and global reach.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia remains committed to advancing WTO negotiations to bring the Doha Round to a

Speaker: NA
Text: close. We are currently working with WTO Director-General Azevedo and other members to

Speaker: NA
Text: develop a productive and forward looking post-Bali work plan, which will deliver economic

Speaker: NA
Text: growth and jobs for Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: In just over a month I will chair the second G20 trade ministers meeting. One of the aims

Speaker: NA
Text: of the meeting will be for G20 member countries to identify actions to improve the efficiency

Speaker: NA
Text: of trade flows within global value chains-that array of activities involved in creating,

Speaker: NA
Text: producing and delivering a product that stretch across countries and regions. Income from

Speaker: NA
Text: global value chain trade flows doubled between 1995 and 2009. I will be strongly

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraging my G20 colleagues to agree to implementation of the Agreement on Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Facilitation quickly as an effective action towards harnessing the power of the global

Speaker: NA
Text: economy, boosting trade and creating jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government is committed to a trade agenda that increases the prosperity of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. Negotiating outcomes like the Agreement on Trade Facilitation will substantially

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce trade barriers and minimise red tape, making a significant contribution to Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: economic future. Australia's acceptance of this agreement will further build on the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's recent accomplishments in concluding free trade agreements with Korea and

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan. We expect that upon the agreement's entry into force, we will see substantial benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: beginning to flow for Australian exporters from reduced red-tape at the borders of our key

Speaker: NA
Text: trading partners.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an agreement that took a long time to negotiate, and I commend the achievement of

Speaker: NA
Text: officials from various agencies led by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend this agreement to parliament, and hereby table the WTO Agreement on Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Facilitation with its national interest analysis.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask leave of the House to move a motion to enable the Deputy Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: to speak for six minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr ROBB
Text: I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Deputy Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition speaking in reply to the ministerial statement for a period not exceeding six minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: Ms PLIBERSEK
Text: Sydney-Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (09:08): Labor welcomes

Speaker: NA
Text: the finalisation of the World Trade Organisation Agreement on Trade Facilitation. We believe

Speaker: NA
Text: the trade is critical to Australia's future prosperity. Trade provides new markets and new

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for our exporters. It boosts economic growth, it improves competition and it

Speaker: NA
Text: gives our consumers access to a wider range of goods at lower prices. This agreement builds

Speaker: NA
Text: on the work undertaken by the previous Labor government and our commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: progressing the World Trade Organisation's Doha Round negotiations. We particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome this agreement as the first major agreement concluded since the establishment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: WTO in 1995.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Agreement on Trade Facilitation will assist in removing red tape and other regulatory

Speaker: NA
Text: and procedural burdens. It will streamline approvals and transactions for exporters,

Speaker: NA
Text: dismantling some of those barriers that exist behind a country's borders that can be hidden

Speaker: NA
Text: impediments for business. Estimates have previously suggested that this WTO Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Facilitation Agreement will account for 44 per cent of the total prospective benefits of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Doha Round, with two-thirds of these benefits accruing to developing countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: The benefits of this agreement to developing countries cannot be underestimated. Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: facilitation reform will boost economic growth and assist in the creation of millions of jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: for our developing country partners. Some of the important reforms contained in this

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement will benefit our exporters, and they include, as the minister said, the harmonisation

Speaker: NA
Text: and streamlining of global customs procedures. This will assist exporters by reducing the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of documents needed to be filled out to move their goods across borders. Also, very

Speaker: NA
Text: importantly, the release of perishable goods will be welcomed by Australian exporters, who

Speaker: NA
Text: often face costly delays on agricultural exports while awaiting clearance on foreign wharves.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister noted that this is an agreement that took a long time to negotiate, and he

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulated the officials of the department. I add my congratulations to those officials. I

Speaker: NA
Text: note with disappointment, though, the minister's failure to acknowledge the efforts of previous

Speaker: NA
Text: ministers who laid the groundwork required to deliver this outcome at the WTO's Bali

Speaker: NA
Text: ministerial conference last December. In particular, Labor would place on record the

Speaker: NA
Text: important contribution made by the former Prime Minister Julia Gillard and former trade

Speaker: NA
Text: minister Craig Emerson set separate to the finalisation of this agreement. It was Craig

Speaker: NA
Text: Emerson's articulation of new pathways to the Doha mountain top which saw WTO members

Speaker: NA
Text: agree to divide up the Doha Round into separate negotiations. Prime Minister Gillard

Speaker: NA
Text: spearheaded this approach through the 2011 meetings of the Commonwealth Heads of

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, the G20 and the East Asia

Speaker: NA
Text: Summit. The principle was eventually adopted by America, China and the World Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Organization. It played an important role in reviving the momentum needed to bring this

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement on trade liberalisation to completion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor would also like to acknowledge, as I said earlier, the efforts of officials of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in concluding this agreement. It would have been a

Speaker: NA
Text: long haul for them, and we appreciate their efforts. We welcome the finalisation of this

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement and will review the treaty through the joint committee process over coming weeks.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Services and Other Legislation Amendment (2014 Budget Measures No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1) Bill 2014

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Andrews.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Menzies-Minister for Social Services) (09:13): I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill introduces a package of measures from the 2014 budget in the Social Services

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 2014 budget is a key part of the government's Economic Action Strategy to build a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong, prosperous economy and a safe, secure Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government's welfare reforms encompassed in the budget are aimed at increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: everyone's ability to contribute to the economy-everyone who can contribute, should

Speaker: NA
Text: contribute.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government will continue to provide assistance for families, seniors, people with

Speaker: NA
Text: disability, carers and those most in need. The 2014 budget includes $146 billion of welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: spending-or 35 per cent of total budget expenditure. This includes pensions, family

Speaker: NA
Text: payments, unemployment benefits and childcare support.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, our population is ageing, and government spending has been growing faster than

Speaker: NA
Text: the economy. This is placing greater pressure on our welfare system. We want government

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to be targeted towards supporting the most vulnerable Australians, while

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraging those who are able to work or study, to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: Firm and decisive action is required to put the budget back onto a secure and sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: footing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget measures

Speaker: NA
Text: Seniors supplement and energy supplement

Speaker: NA
Text: To help ensure that payments to senior Australians remain targeted to those who need them

Speaker: NA
Text: the most, the first budget measure in the bill will cease the seniors supplement, currently

Speaker: NA
Text: received by holders of the Commonwealth Seniors Health Card (or the Veterans' Affairs Gold

Speaker: NA
Text: Card) after the June 2014 payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, other benefits will continue to be available to cardholders, including discounts

Speaker: NA
Text: on medicines under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, health safety net thresholds, and

Speaker: NA
Text: lower fees on medical services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recognising the government's commitment to abolish the carbon tax, while keeping in

Speaker: NA
Text: place the associated payment increases, this bill will rename the former clean energy

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement as the energy supplement, and maintain it at current levels from 1 July 2014 by

Speaker: NA
Text: permanently removing indexation of the supplement.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The new energy supplement will be available to people who formerly received the clean

Speaker: NA
Text: energy supplement in association with their main income support payment, family payment or

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans affairs payment, or through being a holder of the Commonwealth seniors health card

Speaker: NA
Text: or an eligible holder of the gold card.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indexation and rates

Speaker: NA
Text: Several changes and pauses to indexation for Australian government payments will be

Speaker: NA
Text: implemented. These measures will help reduce our debt, but pausing indexation will not

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: These measures include pausing indexation of the income and asset-free areas for all

Speaker: NA
Text: working age allowances (other than student payments) and for parenting payment single for

Speaker: NA
Text: three years from 1 July 2014.

Speaker: NA
Text: Family tax benefit income thresholds (for the maximum rate of family tax benefit part A

Speaker: NA
Text: and the lower income earner threshold for family tax benefit part B) will stay at current levels

Speaker: NA
Text: for three years from 1 July 2014.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will also ensure parenting payment single is indexed only against the consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: price index from 20 September 2014.

Speaker: NA
Text: Disability support pension

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will also introduce changes to help young people with disability to enter the

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce if they are able to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: From 1 July 2014, certain disability support pension recipients aged under 35 will

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake compulsory work focused activities, such as a program with an employment service

Speaker: NA
Text: provider, work experience, or education and training, to help increase their chances of finding

Speaker: NA
Text: and keeping a job.

Speaker: NA
Text: A targeted review will also be undertaken of disability support pension recipients aged

Speaker: NA
Text: under 35 who originally accessed the payment under less rigorous impairment tables in

Speaker: NA
Text: operation between 2008 and 2011. Recipients will have their level of impairment reassessed

Speaker: NA
Text: against the current impairment tables, and will also have their work capacity reassessed.

Speaker: NA
Text: People with a manifest disability or with a work capacity of zero to seven hours a week

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be reviewed under this measure. Recipients assessed as having an ability to work at

Speaker: NA
Text: least eight hours a week will be provided with the support needed to allow them to develop

Speaker: NA
Text: their work capacity, while still receiving the disability support pension.

Speaker: NA
Text: Workforce age and student changes

Speaker: NA
Text: As part of a package of changes to simplify the social security system, and strengthen the

Speaker: NA
Text: incentives for young unemployed people to participate in education, training and

Speaker: NA
Text: employment, the bill will apply the ordinary waiting period of seven days for all working age

Speaker: NA
Text: payments from 1 October 2014.

Speaker: NA
Text: A further measure will ensure that, while a student can currently continue to receive

Speaker: NA
Text: payment even while they are overseas on holiday, students will continue to receive payments

Speaker: NA
Text: while overseas, from 1 October 2014, only in certain circumstances such as when studying or

Speaker: NA
Text: in a family emergency.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Family payment reform

Speaker: NA
Text: Several reforms were announced in the budget to improve the sustainability of family

Speaker: NA
Text: payments, while ensuring they continue to support those most in need of assistance.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government will continue to provide payment assistance to families to supplement

Speaker: NA
Text: their incomes. In 2014-15, the government will provide around $19 billion in family tax

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit. However, the payment should provide assistance to families who need it most, and

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage everyone who can work, to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendments in this bill, effective from 1 July 2014, will maintain the standard payment

Speaker: NA
Text: rates of family tax benefit parts A and B at current levels for two years until 30 June 2016.

Speaker: NA
Text: Social and Community Services Pay Equity Special Account

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will also make a non-budget amendment to add the Western Australian Industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations Commission decision of 29 August 2013 as a pay equity decision under the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: and Community Services Pay Equity Special Account Act 2012. This amendment will allow

Speaker: NA
Text: payment of Commonwealth supplementation to service providers affected by that decision.

Speaker: NA
Text: Conclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: Our welfare system must be sustainable and it must be fair. It needs to provide a safety net,

Speaker: NA
Text: whilst ensuring we are delivering a work-ready, not a welfare-ready, nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our welfare system is complicated and costly and, in the budget measures introduced by

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill, we begin the work of making it strong for the future. I commend the bill to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Services and Other Legislation Amendment (2014 Budget Measures No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2) Bill 2014

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Andrews.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Menzies-Minister for Social Services) (09:20): I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the second bill in the Social Services portfolio to introduce measures from the 2014

Speaker: NA
Text: budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: This second bill follows up the reforms to indexation and payment rates, supplements,

Speaker: NA
Text: disability support pension, and student and workforce age payments already introduced in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Services and Other Legislation Amendment (2014 Budget Measures No. 1) Bill 2014.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indexation and rates

Speaker: NA
Text: Several further changes and pauses to indexation and deemed income arrangements for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian government payments will be introduced by this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indexation of the income and asset-free areas for student payments, and student income

Speaker: NA
Text: bank limits, will be paused for three years from 1 January 2015.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Indexation of the income and asset-free areas for all pensions (other than parenting

Speaker: NA
Text: payment single), and the deeming thresholds for all income support payments, will be paused

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1 July 2017 for three years.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Social Services and Other Legislation Amendment (2014 Budget Measures No. 1) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2014 introduced amendments to ensure parenting payment single is indexed only against the

Speaker: NA
Text: consumer price index from 20 September 2014. This second budget bill will similarly ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that all other pensions are indexed only against the consumer price index, from the later date

Speaker: NA
Text: of 20 September 2017. This will help ensure the age pension in particular is sustainable, while

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions generally still keep up with the cost of living.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government will also change the level of a person's financial assets at which a higher

Speaker: NA
Text: return is deemed. From 20 September 2017, the social security and veterans' entitlements

Speaker: NA
Text: income test deeming thresholds will be reset to $30,000 for single income support recipients,

Speaker: NA
Text: and $50,000 combined for pensioner couples. The deeming threshold amount for a member of

Speaker: NA
Text: a couple other than a pensioner couple will be $25,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Disability support pension and carers

Speaker: NA
Text: From 1 January 2015, recipients of the disability support pension who travel overseas for

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 28 days in a 12-month period will need to reapply for the payment on their return

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia. There will be some exemptions-for example, for people with terminal illness

Speaker: NA
Text: who are returning to their country of origin to be with family, or people with permanent and

Speaker: NA
Text: severe disability and no future work capacity.

Speaker: NA
Text: This budget has delivered $3 million in funding to honour the government's election

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to set up the Young Carer Bursary Program, which will provide support for

Speaker: NA
Text: young carers in Australia who look after people with disability, people with physical or

Speaker: NA
Text: mental health issues, or older people in need of care.

Speaker: NA
Text: The responsibilities of young carers can have a significant impact on their personal lives

Speaker: NA
Text: and educational opportunities. The Young Carer Bursary Program will help reduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: financial burden on young carers by providing around 150 bursaries annually that will allow

Speaker: NA
Text: them to continue their studies.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill will support the new program by excluding from the social security and veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlements income test any payments made under the program from 1 January 2015.

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth seniors health card

Speaker: NA
Text: A measure affecting the Commonwealth seniors health card will include untaxed

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation income received in the form of an account-based income stream in the

Speaker: NA
Text: assessment for the card. This will ensure people with similar incomes are treated consistently,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether they are being assessed for a payment such as the age pension or for the health card.

Speaker: NA
Text: Superannuation products purchased before 1 January 2015 by existing cardholders will be

Speaker: NA
Text: exempt from the new arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: Related to this measure, holders of the commonwealth seniors health card will benefit from

Speaker: NA
Text: an extension from six to 19 weeks in the length of time they may be absent from Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: without having to reapply for the card on their return.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Workforce age and student changes

Speaker: NA
Text: From 1 January 2015, young unemployed people aged 22 to 24 will no longer be qualified

Speaker: NA
Text: for Newstart allowance or sickness allowance, and instead will be able to qualify for youth

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance (student) or youth allowance (other) until they turn 25 years of age.

Speaker: NA
Text: The changes simplify the social security system, and strengthen the incentives for young

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed people to participate in education, training and employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: A six-month waiting period and time-limited income support payments will give young

Speaker: NA
Text: people stronger incentives to earn or learn. Young people will have access to a full range of

Speaker: NA
Text: supports to help them become work-ready, including employment services, training and

Speaker: NA
Text: relocation assistance. Exemptions exist for those with limited capacity to work, who are

Speaker: NA
Text: undergoing study, who have a significant disability, or who have parenting responsibilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: In recognition of the importance of education and training in preventing future

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment, young people returning to full-time school, vocational education or university

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be subject to the waiting period.

Speaker: NA
Text: For every one year of work history, one month will be discounted from their waiting

Speaker: NA
Text: period, pro-rated for part-time or casual work, to a maximum of five months' discount from

Speaker: NA
Text: the waiting period.

Speaker: NA
Text: Also from 1 January 2015, the current relocation scholarship assistance for students

Speaker: NA
Text: relocating within and between major cities will be removed, as will the education entry

Speaker: NA
Text: payment and the pensioner education supplement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Family payment reforms

Speaker: NA
Text: Several further reforms will be implemented from 1 July 2015 to improve the sustainability

Speaker: NA
Text: of family payments, while ensuring they continue to support those most in need of assistance:

Speaker: NA
Text:  The family tax benefit part B primary earner income limit will be reduced from $150,000

Speaker: NA
Text: to $100,000. Families with primary earner income over $100,000 will not be eligible for

Speaker: NA
Text: family tax benefit part B.

Speaker: NA
Text:  The large family supplement will also be better targeted, by being directed to families with

Speaker: NA
Text: four or more children.

Speaker: NA
Text:  The family tax benefit parts A and B end-of-year supplements provide additional assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: at the end of the year when family tax benefit is reconciled against tax return incomes. The

Speaker: NA
Text: supplements will be revised to their original values of $600 and $300, and indexation will

Speaker: NA
Text: cease.

Speaker: NA
Text:  Payments of family tax benefit part B will be available to families until their youngest child

Speaker: NA
Text: turns six. Transitional arrangements will apply for two years to families already receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: the payment for children aged six and over.

Speaker: NA
Text:  The government recognises that single parents have greater difficulties balancing work and

Speaker: NA
Text: caring for their children. This bill will provide low-income single parents with extra

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance of $750 a year. This will be provided to single parents on the maximum rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: family tax benefit part A, and not receiving family tax benefit part B, for each child aged

Speaker: NA
Text: six to 12.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text:  The per-child add-on that currently applies for each child after the first under the income

Speaker: NA
Text: test for the base rate of family tax benefit part A will be removed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pension age

Speaker: NA
Text: Building on the move by the former Labor government to increase the pension age to 67

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1 July 2017, this bill will continue the gradual increase in the qualifying age for the age

Speaker: NA
Text: pension, and the non-veteran pension age, to 70 by 1 July 2035. The bill does not change the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension age for veterans.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians are living longer, and our population is ageing. Between 2010 and 2050, the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of people aged 65 to 84 will more than double, and those aged 85 and over will more

Speaker: NA
Text: than quadruple.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will present challenges for economic growth, living standards and fiscal sustainability.

Speaker: NA
Text: The change in the pension age will encourage greater self-provision. Those who cannot fully

Speaker: NA
Text: support themselves before pension age are protected by the social security safety net, subject

Speaker: NA
Text: to meeting relevant eligibility criteria.

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans' Disability Pension

Speaker: NA
Text: In the last budget measure, the bill will remove from 1 January 2015 the three months'

Speaker: NA
Text: backdating of disability pension under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

Speaker: NA
Text: Conclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: The government is committed to ensuring our welfare system is sustainable and fair. I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: National Health Amendment (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2014

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Dutton.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: Dickson-Minister for Health and Minister for Sport) (09:30): I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The National Health Amendment (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill 2014 implements the

Speaker: NA
Text: decision announced in the 2014-15 budget to increase patient co-payments and safety net

Speaker: NA
Text: thresholds for the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) and the Repatriation

Speaker: NA
Text: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (RPBS).

Speaker: NA
Text: It is another example of this government's work to protect the best interests of Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: in making the decisions necessary to improve Australia's budget position into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: The PBS and RPBS are key components of our health services and are a major investment

Speaker: NA
Text: in the health of Australians. In the ten years to 2012-13, the cost of the PBS has increased by

Speaker: NA
Text: 80 per cent. At a current cost of around $9 billion per year, and with annual growth over the

Speaker: NA
Text: longer term expected to be between four and five per cent, these schemes will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainable without responsible management.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Why the Changes Are Needed-PBS Costs and New Listings

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's health system is demand driven. The pressure to provide access to more

Speaker: NA
Text: services, more medicines and more expensive technologies is always increasing.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a continual pipeline of complex and expensive new medicines delivering more

Speaker: NA
Text: targeted and more personalised treatments. Since coming to government, the coalition has

Speaker: NA
Text: listed or expanded the listings of some 181 medicines on the PBS. Medicines are being listed

Speaker: NA
Text: twice as fast as under the former Labor government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The additional cost of advances in treatment, together with the ongoing cost of medicines

Speaker: NA
Text: for chronic conditions, means expenditure for our health system is growing faster than

Speaker: NA
Text: government and taxpayers can sustain.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the PBS is to grow in a sustainable way, we need a whole-of-community approach and

Speaker: NA
Text: we all need to contribute-something successive governments have recognised since co-

Speaker: NA
Text: payments for the PBS were first introduced in 1960.

Speaker: NA
Text: Earlier this year, this government approved new listings for medicines with an expected

Speaker: NA
Text: cost to the PBS of $436 million. These listings include treatments for breast cancer,

Speaker: NA
Text: melanoma and multiple sclerosis, some of which cost tens of thousands of dollars per patient.

Speaker: NA
Text: At its March 2014 meeting, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC)

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended a further $550 million in new listings. In July this year, the PBAC will consider

Speaker: NA
Text: applications for new PBS listings worth up to a further $3.6 billion. Funding for new listings

Speaker: NA
Text: is not factored into the forward estimates. It is new money that this government must find

Speaker: NA
Text: every four months to provide access to those medicines, something we have committed to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: But we cannot do that and contain spending without more help, a greater contribution from

Speaker: NA
Text: all Australians who benefit from the PBS.

Speaker: NA
Text: The changes proposed in the bill are expected to contribute savings to the government for

Speaker: NA
Text: the PBS and RPBS of around $1.3 billion over four years. They will provide a check on the

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of growth in PBS expenditure. Importantly, they do not cut funding for the PBS.

Speaker: NA
Text: We still expect that the PBS will grow, but more sustainably, from $9.2 billion in 2013-4 to

Speaker: NA
Text: $10.2 billion annually in 2017-18.

Speaker: NA
Text: Changes to Co-payments-General Patients

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the changes commencing 1 January 2015, there will be a one-off increase in patient

Speaker: NA
Text: co-payment amounts for pharmaceutical benefits prescriptions. This increase will apply in

Speaker: NA
Text: addition to the usual annual consumer price index (CPI) adjustment which occurs on 1

Speaker: NA
Text: January each year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The co-payment for general patients, which is currently $36.90, will increase by $5 in

Speaker: NA
Text: addition to CPI. On average, general patients use two PBS subsidised prescriptions per year.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, for an average user, the additional cost from 2015 would be $10 per year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under Co-payment General Patient Prescriptions

Speaker: NA
Text: The increase in the general co-payment will not affect the cost to consumers for many

Speaker: NA
Text: commonly used medicines. Because the co-payment amount is the maximum that a person

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to pay under the PBS, when the price of a prescription is less than the co-payment, the

Speaker: NA
Text: consumer pays the lesser amount.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicines priced at less than the general co-payment already account for more than 40 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of PBS listings, and over 70 per cent of general patient PBS prescriptions. By the time

Speaker: NA
Text: the co-payment changes come into effect, more than 55 per cent of listings are expected to be

Speaker: NA
Text: below the general co-payment amount. These include listings for medicines used to treat high

Speaker: NA
Text: blood pressure, high cholesterol, type 2 diabetes, gastric ulceration, and skin conditions. As

Speaker: NA
Text: competition in the market continues to bring prices down, those reductions are reflected in the

Speaker: NA
Text: prices paid by consumers, as well as by the government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Changes to co-payments-concessional

Speaker: NA
Text: For individuals and families who access pharmaceutical benefits at the concessional level,

Speaker: NA
Text: including veterans and their dependants under the RPBS, the co-payment, which is currently

Speaker: NA
Text: $6, will increase by 80c in addition to the CPI.

Speaker: NA
Text: People with concessional benefits use, on average, 17 prescriptions each year. So under

Speaker: NA
Text: these new arrangements, they will pay an extra $13.60 per year for their subsidised medicines.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government is asking concessional patients to contribute an extra 80c for prescriptions

Speaker: NA
Text: which cost on average $43.50. It will also be only an extra 80c for medicines such as the

Speaker: NA
Text: cancer treatments, everolimus and dabrafenib that cost over $5,500 and $8,700 per

Speaker: NA
Text: prescription respectively.

Speaker: NA
Text: Along with the co-payment changes, there will be parallel changes in PBS safety nets.

Speaker: NA
Text: Safety net arrangements help to protect people who require a lot of medicines from high

Speaker: NA
Text: out-of-pocket costs. For all users of the PBS and RPBS, once the safety net threshold is

Speaker: NA
Text: reached, the co-payment amount is reduced for prescriptions required for the rest of the

Speaker: NA
Text: calendar year. For general patients, the co-payment reduces to the concessional amount, and

Speaker: NA
Text: for concessional patients, the co-payment is reduced to zero.

Speaker: NA
Text: Changes to safety nets-general

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the proposed changes, the general safety net, which is currently $1,421.20, will

Speaker: NA
Text: increase by 10 per cent of the safety net plus annual CPI indexation on 1 January each year

Speaker: NA
Text: from 2015 until 2018. From 1 January 2019, only annual CPI indexation will apply.

Speaker: NA
Text: General patients who are high medicine users will pay around $145.30 more in 2015 before

Speaker: NA
Text: reaching the new safety net threshold-and thereafter will only pay the concessional co-

Speaker: NA
Text: payment to access subsidised medicines for the remainder of the calendar year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Changes to safety nets-concessional

Speaker: NA
Text: The concessional safety net, which is currently equivalent to co-payments for 60

Speaker: NA
Text: prescriptions, or $360, will increase by two prescriptions on 1 January each year from 2015 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 2018. The resulting concessional safety net thresholds will be 62 prescriptions in 2015; 64 in

Speaker: NA
Text: Concessional patients who are high medicine users will pay around $61.80 more in 2015

Speaker: NA
Text: before reaching the new safety net threshold-and thereafter will receive all their PBS and

Speaker: NA
Text: RPBS subsidised medicines for free for the remainder of the calendar year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Operation of safety nets-and family example

Speaker: NA
Text: Importantly, the same general or concessional safety net applies to individuals, couples and

Speaker: NA
Text: families. The safety net can be tallied separately for an individual or combined where the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of medicines for couples or family members needs to be met from the same household budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, in 2015, a low-income family of two adults and two children, who hold a

Speaker: NA
Text: concession card and obtain 72 prescriptions per year between them, will pay $61.80 more

Speaker: NA
Text: than in 2014 before they reach the safety net threshold. But, once they reach the safety net,

Speaker: NA
Text: they will get the rest of their PBS prescriptions for that calendar year for free-that is 10

Speaker: NA
Text: scripts for free-whether it be the $43.50 medicine, or the $5,500 medicine, or the $8,700

Speaker: NA
Text: medicine, it will be provided to them at no cost.

Speaker: NA
Text: Changes to concessional contributions for closing the gap

Speaker: NA
Text: The changes in the bill will also apply for patient contributions charged at the concessional

Speaker: NA
Text: rate for the closing the gap PBS co-payment measure. Under the closing the gap

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements, eligible Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander consumers, who would otherwise

Speaker: NA
Text: pay the general co-payment for PBS prescriptions, pay at the concessional rate. Eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: concessional patients receive their PBS medicines for free.

Speaker: NA
Text: Patient contributions as one element of effective PBS management

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has inherited an enormous debt from the former Labor government and is

Speaker: NA
Text: determined to ensure that health services are sustainable, are used efficiently, and are

Speaker: NA
Text: available for future generations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The PBS model requires that medicines undergo evidence based assessment of clinical and

Speaker: NA
Text: cost effectiveness, be listed only on the recommendation of our expert advisory committee,

Speaker: NA
Text: and be subject to comparative and competitive pricing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Good management of the scheme also relies on the innovative products supplied by a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong medicines industry, and the quality care provided by Australia's wide network of

Speaker: NA
Text: community pharmacies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since 1960, successive governments have continued to recognise that patient contributions

Speaker: NA
Text: are part of responsible management of the PBS. Indeed it was a Labor government that

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced a $2.50 patient contribution for pensioners in 1991 and a Labor government that

Speaker: NA
Text: increased the co-payment for general payments by 100 per cent from $5 to $10 in 1985.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has been fair in the past, and it is fair now, to slightly increase the cost for consumers,

Speaker: NA
Text: given the increase in the cost of the PBS over the last 10 to 15 years and the number of very

Speaker: NA
Text: expensive drugs which will be listed in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Conclusion-Savings for new listings and the medical research future fund

Speaker: NA
Text: Demand for the PBS will continue to grow, and we want to list medicines quickly. The

Speaker: NA
Text: expense of the latest treatments is a major cost driver for the PBS. Recent PBS listings

Speaker: NA
Text: include medicines with a cost per patient per year of up to $110,000 for the treatment of

Speaker: NA
Text: melanoma; around $38,000 for advanced breast cancer; $27,000 for prostate cancer; and up to

Speaker: NA
Text: $17,000 for macular degeneration. As more high-cost medicines are listed, and more patients

Speaker: NA
Text: require access to these treatments, the cost to taxpayers will increase.

Speaker: NA
Text: By asking consumers to share in that cost, we can build a sustainable PBS that can continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to make otherwise prohibitively expensive treatments affordable for all Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Importantly, this measure will also help to support future development of the types of

Speaker: NA
Text: innovative medicines people are seeking today. We will always be looking to prevent and

Speaker: NA
Text: treat illness and manage conditions that challenge us now.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: And our medical researchers have led the way, from Howard Florey to Sir Gustav Nossal

Speaker: NA
Text: and from Fiona Stanley to Ian Frazer. Australians have, through research and innovation,

Speaker: NA
Text: saved millions of lives, not just here but around the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: Savings will contribute to the $20 billion capital protected Medical Research Future Fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: When fully mature, it will add $1 billion to the resources available for medical research each

Speaker: NA
Text: and every year for generations to come. The fund will provide more opportunities for world-

Speaker: NA
Text: class Australian researchers to undertake basic and applied research and to test their results in

Speaker: NA
Text: clinical trials in this country. This investment is a huge step forward for Australia and will

Speaker: NA
Text: bring considerable health and economic benefits to our nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The changes in this bill will strengthen the PBS while preserving all the features that make

Speaker: NA
Text: it such a valued part of Australia's health system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Carbon Farming Initiative Amendment Bill 2014

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Hunt.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Flinders-Minister for the Environment) (09:42): I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Carbon Farming Initiative Amendment Bill 2014 provides the framework for

Speaker: NA
Text: administering the Emissions Reduction Fund. At the recent election the public voted to repeal

Speaker: NA
Text: the carbon tax and to introduce the Emissions Reduction Fund as the heart of an incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: based approach to reducing Australia's emissions and to cleaning our air and land.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Emissions Reduction Fund is, therefore, a fundamental election commitment and the

Speaker: NA
Text: key element of the government's policy to respond to climate change.

Speaker: NA
Text: Through the Emissions Reduction Fund, the government will work in partnership with

Speaker: NA
Text: business and the community to achieve a cleaner environment through practical actions that

Speaker: NA
Text: will achieve real, measurable results.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government accepts fully the science of climate change. However, we reject the carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: tax because it is an ineffective mechanism and an unfair mechanism to deal with the challenge

Speaker: NA
Text: at hand.

Speaker: NA
Text: The carbon tax was a $7.6 billion hit on the economy in its first year, yet emissions were

Speaker: NA
Text: but 0.1 per cent lower. In short, it fails to do the job. The carbon tax has led to higher

Speaker: NA
Text: electricity prices, higher gas prices and it has increased the cost of living. It is estimated by

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury that repeal of the carbon tax will reduce average Australian household bills by $550

Speaker: NA
Text: a year. It is, therefore, an unnecessary burden on Australian businesses, a drag on our

Speaker: NA
Text: international competitiveness and an unfair and ineffective hit on Australian families. For

Speaker: NA
Text: these reasons the government has moved to abolish the carbon tax as a fundamental priority

Speaker: NA
Text: since coming to office. The bills to abolish the carbon tax were the very first bills introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: into this House by the government by no less a person than the Prime Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The Emissions Reduction Fund will therefore be a better way to reduce emissions than

Speaker: NA
Text: imposing a carbon tax that increases energy costs for businesses and households.

Speaker: NA
Text: In short, the carbon tax is an electricity tax, a gas tax and a refrigerant tax, and in the end

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost is always borne by Australian families.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Emissions Reduction Fund, by contrast, is a major environmental program with

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits for air quality, land management and agricultural productivity and a program to

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce emissions. It can be supported whatever one's views on climate issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: Funding for the ERF is already allocated in the budget. This bill sets out the administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to assist in implementation. Industry and farming groups strongly support

Speaker: NA
Text: implementing the Emissions Reduction Fund through the approach set out in the bill of

Speaker: NA
Text: building on-and streamlining-the existing Carbon Farming Initiative and using other

Speaker: NA
Text: existing government mechanisms and processes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unlike the approach under the carbon tax, the Emissions Reduction Fund will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: positive incentives to help Australian businesses and households lower their energy costs,

Speaker: NA
Text: improve their agricultural productivity and increase their efficiency. It will do this by building

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Carbon Farming Initiative approach of supporting practical projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill will implement the ERF to replace the carbon tax and provide a transition for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Carbon Farming Initiative. It will do this by amending the Carbon Credits (Carbon Farming

Speaker: NA
Text: Initiative) Act 2011 and related acts.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Emissions Reduction Fund

Speaker: NA
Text: The objective of the Emissions Reduction Fund is to reduce emissions at lowest cost and

Speaker: NA
Text: help Australia meet its emissions reduction target of five per cent below 2000 levels by 2020.

Speaker: NA
Text: To put that into context, on the most recent advice I have received from my department,

Speaker: NA
Text: when you look over the period from 1990 to 2020, Australia and the United States achieve an

Speaker: NA
Text: almost identical net reduction over the course of a generation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government is therefore making a significant investment in the fund. The 2014-15

Speaker: NA
Text: budget sets out an initial commitment of $2.55 billion, with further funding to be considered

Speaker: NA
Text: in future budgets. The Clean Energy Regulator, importantly, will be able to commit the full-

Speaker: NA
Text: I repeat, the full-amount of funding in emissions reduction contracts from the

Speaker: NA
Text: commencement of the Emissions Reduction Fund. There will be no barrier to the full amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of contracts being written from day one. We have made a significant change: whereas these

Speaker: NA
Text: had to be phased out over a four-year period, they can now commence in full without

Speaker: NA
Text: restriction from the moment of passage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Existing Carbon Farming Initiative participants will be well placed to bid in and access

Speaker: NA
Text: these funds to support their existing projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: Three simple principles have guided the design of the Emissions Reduction Fund. These

Speaker: NA
Text: principles are embedded in the framework that is established by this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text:  First, the fund will encourage projects that deliver lowest cost emissions reductions.

Speaker: NA
Text:  Second, emissions reductions will be genuine and go beyond 'business-as-usual'.

Speaker: NA
Text:  Third, administration of the fund will be streamlined and cost-effective.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: In short, the Emissions Reduction Fund will not create any significant new government

Speaker: NA
Text: architecture. Instead, it will use existing structures and processes that are understood by

Speaker: NA
Text: industry whilst also streamlining them.

Speaker: NA
Text: In particular, this bill does four key things to establish the Emissions Reduction Fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: Expanding the Carbon Farming Initiative

Speaker: NA
Text: First, this bill expands the Carbon Farming Initiative to enable crediting of emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction opportunities across all sectors of the economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Expanding the scope of the Carbon Farming Initiative will allow businesses from all over

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to bring projects forward and receive Australian carbon credit units for the

Speaker: NA
Text: emissions reductions they deliver through their projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the Carbon Farming Initiative, farmers and land managers are able to earn carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: credits by storing carbon or reducing greenhouse gas emissions on the land. These credits can

Speaker: NA
Text: then be sold to people and businesses wishing to offset their emissions. The Clean Energy

Speaker: NA
Text: Regulator has registered more than 130 Carbon Farming Initiative projects and issued over 6

Speaker: NA
Text: million Australian carbon credit units since the program commenced in late 2011.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the Emissions Reduction Fund, this Carbon Farming Initiative approach will be

Speaker: NA
Text: expanded so that other parts of the economy can access the system. This includes areas like

Speaker: NA
Text: energy efficiency, waste coal mine gas, cleaning up power stations, the transport sector and

Speaker: NA
Text: large industrial facilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: The expansion of the Carbon Farming Initiative will be achieved by amending existing

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, which establishes the Carbon Farming Initiative, and amending the administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: and reporting arrangements that support it, including the National Greenhouse and Energy

Speaker: NA
Text: Reporting Scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: In particular, the Carbon Farming Initiative Amendment Bill 2014 amends the Carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: Credits (Carbon Farming Initiative) Act 2011, the National Greenhouse and Energy Reporting

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 2007, the Australian National Registry of Emissions Units Act 2011 and the Clean

Speaker: NA
Text: Energy Regulator Act 2011.

Speaker: NA
Text: Empowering the Clean Energy Regulator

Speaker: NA
Text: Second, this bill empowers the Clean Energy Regulator to conduct auctions, enter contracts

Speaker: NA
Text: and purchase emissions reductions.

Speaker: NA
Text: It provides for the Clean Energy Regulator to run regular reverse auctions or other

Speaker: NA
Text: procurement processes. This will allow the government to simply and efficiently buy the

Speaker: NA
Text: lowest cost emissions reductions across the economy from new projects, as well as existing

Speaker: NA
Text: Carbon Farming Initiative projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: The projects with the lowest cost per tonne will be selected, and the Clean Energy

Speaker: NA
Text: Regulator will enter into contracts to purchase the emissions reductions from these projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: These contracts will give businesses confidence and certainty about the payments they will

Speaker: NA
Text: receive and provide genuine incentives and support to improve energy efficiency and

Speaker: NA
Text: agricultural productivity.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Clean Energy Regulator will publish information after auctions about auction

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes to help businesses understand the opportunities available to them under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Emissions Reduction Fund. This is full public transparency, as it should be.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The competitive nature of this process will ensure that the Emissions Reduction Fund

Speaker: NA
Text: achieves the best value for taxpayers' money. Payments will be made after emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions are achieved, but under a contract for delivery. Therefore, the emissions reduction

Speaker: NA
Text: providers have the bankable certainty of a contract with the Commonwealth, with periodic

Speaker: NA
Text: payments. The taxpayer and the Commonwealth have the security that they need only pay for

Speaker: NA
Text: actual abatement and actual emissions reductions as they occur and are verified.

Speaker: NA
Text: Streamlining processes

Speaker: NA
Text: Third, the bill streamlines existing processes from the Carbon Farming Initiative, removing

Speaker: NA
Text: red tape to make it easier to register projects and receive credits.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fewer project registration steps will see projects approved more quickly.

Speaker: NA
Text: More flexible reporting arrangements will improve cash flow.

Speaker: NA
Text: A risk-based approach to audit means that lower-risk projects will have fewer obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The simplified eligibility requirements around property rights will make project

Speaker: NA
Text: aggregation easier.

Speaker: NA
Text: Importantly, the bill will remove the exclusive 100-year permanence requirement, which

Speaker: NA
Text: has been a significant barrier to landholders increasing carbon stores in soils and vegetation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Landholders will now have the option of storing carbon for 25 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Approving estimation methods will be quicker and easier than under the Carbon Farming

Speaker: NA
Text: Initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: An independent expert body established under the current scheme will be broadened in

Speaker: NA
Text: scope and renamed the Emissions Reduction Assurance Committee. It will advise the

Speaker: NA
Text: government to ensure methods are consistent with the scheme's focus on genuine emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions. The complex and time-consuming process of assessing every activity against the

Speaker: NA
Text: common practice test under the Carbon Farming Initiative will be removed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Transitioning the Carbon Farming Initiative

Speaker: NA
Text: Fourth, this bill provides transitional arrangements for existing participants in the Carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: Farming Initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Landholders and businesses with existing CFI projects will be able to transition smoothly

Speaker: NA
Text: into the Emissions Reduction Fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: Existing Carbon Farming Initiative projects-such as projects to manage savannahs, plant

Speaker: NA
Text: trees or capture methane from piggeries-will be automatically registered under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Emissions Reduction Fund and will be well placed to secure contracts at auction, subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: lowest cost, that will deliver them a guaranteed revenue stream from their existing projects on

Speaker: NA
Text: a bankable, periodic basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: Existing Carbon Farming Initiative projects will also benefit from less red tape, and

Speaker: NA
Text: simplified reporting and audit processes under the new scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, the bill defines the roles and responsibilities of the Clean Energy Regulator. The

Speaker: NA
Text: regulator has established a genuine reputation as an effective, fair and independent body since

Speaker: NA
Text: its establishment, and has the required expertise to administer the Emissions Reduction Fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Safeguard mechanism

Speaker: NA
Text: The fund also includes a safeguard mechanism to ensure that emissions reductions paid for

Speaker: NA
Text: by the government are not displaced by a significant rise in emissions elsewhere in the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The safeguard mechanism will commence on 1 July 2015 and its detailed design will be

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to extensive consultation by industry and will, after that, be given effect by a final

Speaker: NA
Text: legislative package.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consultation and opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: In preparing this bill, the government has consulted widely with business, environment and

Speaker: NA
Text: community representatives from across the Australian economy. I know, in my own case,

Speaker: NA
Text: over the course of the period since 2 February 2010 I have held over 250 meetings with

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, community, environment groups and experts.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to acknowledge the more than 300 organisations, businesses and individuals

Speaker: NA
Text: who have taken the time to contribute their expertise and ideas on the design of the Emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: Reduction Fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: This feedback has made it clear that there are genuine, significant, low-cost emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction opportunities across Australia that can be unlocked through simple, positive

Speaker: NA
Text: incentives from the Emissions Reduction Fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fund is, therefore, both an emissions reduction program and-I want to stress this-a

Speaker: NA
Text: major environmental program. It is also about substantial co-benefits to improve both

Speaker: NA
Text: economic and environmental outcomes.

Speaker: NA
Text: It can be supported as an environmental program whatever one's position on climate issues

Speaker: NA
Text: and the need to reduce emissions.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are many types of projects that, for example, could be supported under the Emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: Reduction Fund. Possible examples include:

Speaker: NA
Text:  Cleaning up Australia's waste sector by capturing the methane for flaring or generating

Speaker: NA
Text: electricity, thereby improving local air quality.

Speaker: NA
Text:  Emissions reductions from the transport sector-covering air, sea, road and rail activities-

Speaker: NA
Text: from technology activities, low-emission vehicles and operational changes-

Speaker: NA
Text: only last evening, I spoke with a former member of this place and close personal friend, Pat

Speaker: NA
Text: Farmer, and he inquired about the potential for the fund to engage with low-emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: transport opportunities. I can specifically confirm to Mr Farmer and to others that are

Speaker: NA
Text: interested that it is expressly designed to offer opportunities for emissions reduction in the

Speaker: NA
Text: transport sector. Again, this offers real opportunities to improve local air quality and reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: dangerous particulate pollution.

Speaker: NA
Text:  The capture of coal mine gas, which could be flared or used to generate electricity.

Speaker: NA
Text:  Using alternative waste treatment facilities to stop the waste being deposited in landfills in

Speaker: NA
Text: the first place. This is an approach widely supported in many places across Europe for

Speaker: NA
Text: generating clean electricity while avoiding noxious fumes. It has a significant local

Speaker: NA
Text: community benefit.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text:  Capturing methane from waste water facilities, whether it is at abattoirs or chemical

Speaker: NA
Text: processing facilities, with, again, significant air quality benefits for neighboring

Speaker: NA
Text: landholders and residents.

Speaker: NA
Text:  Improving industrial energy efficiency at large energy-using facilities through large-scale

Speaker: NA
Text: changes-such as installing more efficient process heating and the replacement of boilers

Speaker: NA
Text: and furnaces-or pulling together smaller incremental improvements that aggregate up to

Speaker: NA
Text: large savings at power stations, cement and aluminium production facilities, and oil and

Speaker: NA
Text: gas extraction plants.

Speaker: NA
Text:  Energy efficiency improvements in the commercial building sector, including offices, retail

Speaker: NA
Text: chains and educational facilities. This could include partial and full retrofits of existing

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial buildings, installation of energy efficient lighting or fans, or the installation of

Speaker: NA
Text: coand tri-generation-

Speaker: NA
Text: this is a particular opportunity for state and local governments, with the large administrative,

Speaker: NA
Text: educational and medical facilities which they own and operate-

Speaker: NA
Text:  Improvements in the efficiency of household electricity consumption through aggregating up

Speaker: NA
Text: individual changes across a large number of households, thereby reducing household energy costs

Speaker: NA
Text: and electricity bills.

Speaker: NA
Text:  Projects to destroy the methane that is generated from manure in piggeries and dairies-

Speaker: NA
Text: again, with local air quality improvements for neighbours-

Speaker: NA
Text:  Projects to reduce emissions by feeding dietary additives to milking cows, with productivity benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text:  Projects to manage fires in savanna grasslands, supporting Indigenous land management and

Speaker: NA
Text: communities.

Speaker: NA
Text:  Revegetating land to improve water quality, and reduce erosion and salinity-

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the long process of reversing land degradation in Australia, as we adapt our farming

Speaker: NA
Text: practices to the needs of this continent after two centuries of settlement; a fundamentally

Speaker: NA
Text: important approach to improving land management, land health and the recovery of degraded

Speaker: NA
Text: areas-

Speaker: NA
Text:  Replenishing the carbon content of soils to improve the health and productivity of Australian farms.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a major opportunity with profound implications for productivity and soil health over

Speaker: NA
Text: the coming decades and generations, and one which I believe will be fundamental, going

Speaker: NA
Text: forward.

Speaker: NA
Text: Conclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, I wish to make a series of thank yous. I first want to thank, amongst my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues, the Prime Minister for his support over a period of four years. He has been

Speaker: NA
Text: unwavering in his view that we need to take action to reduce our emissions and, in particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: to have the co-benefits to clean up our environment. I also want to thank the minister at the

Speaker: NA
Text: table, the Minister for Trade, Andrew Robb. He has been involved in this project from the

Speaker: NA
Text: outset and was fundamental in design issues prior to the release of the first policy. He has

Speaker: NA
Text: provided tremendous personal support throughout the last four years; it is a very strong,

Speaker: NA
Text: personal thank you. And I want to thank my parliamentary secretary, Senator Simon

Speaker: NA
Text: Birmingham, who is in my view a future cabinet minister in waiting. His capabilities are

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinary.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Within industry, I want to pay particular thanks to Danny Price and David Green who are

Speaker: NA
Text: the two co-chairs of the Expert Reference Group. They have brought together an outstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: team under the Expert Reference Group, as well as having consulted widely. There are two

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Exigency economic management and modelling firm, Stuart Allinson and

Speaker: NA
Text: Adrian Palmer, who have been fundamental guides throughout the past four years. I could not

Speaker: NA
Text: have done this without them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Within the department, I want to acknowledge the secretary, Dr Gordon de Brouwer, who

Speaker: NA
Text: has engaged deeply in this process, and officers, Tas Sakellaris, James White, Kristin Tilley,

Speaker: NA
Text: Shayleen Thompson, Hilton Taylor and the rest of the Emissions Reduction Fund Taskforce

Speaker: NA
Text: within the department. I particularly want to acknowledge the absolutely indispensable advice

Speaker: NA
Text: and the countless hours of work from the senior officers: Maya Stuart-Fox; Trevor Power,

Speaker: NA
Text: who has been the head of the Emissions Reduction Fund Taskforce; and Dr Steven Kennedy,

Speaker: NA
Text: who is a deputy secretary within the department and who is really one of the shining lights of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Public Service.

Speaker: NA
Text: Within my office, I would like to thank my chief of staff, Wendy Black; senior adviser,

Speaker: NA
Text: Patrick Gibbons; adviser, Alex Caroly; the DLO who has helped work with the department on

Speaker: NA
Text: this, Nick Godden; and to make a special thanks to the adviser responsible for the Emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: Reduction Fund, Temay Rigzin, whose understanding of Treasury, of the Emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: Reduction Fund and of industry, and literally hundreds of hours of work, has been

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental to reaching this point.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ultimately, the government knows that the protection of the environment and pursuit of

Speaker: NA
Text: economic growth are not mutually exclusive objectives.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are two essential elements of a stronger Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why we do not agree with the proposition that the only way to protect the

Speaker: NA
Text: environment is by destroying Australia's competitiveness.

Speaker: NA
Text: And that is why we have moved to abolish the carbon tax as our first legislative act as an

Speaker: NA
Text: incoming government. It does not work. It is not fair. The Australian people rejected it.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a menu, therefore, of approaches available to reduce emissions in different

Speaker: NA
Text: economies and societies.

Speaker: NA
Text: For Australia, an approach that directly purchases emissions reductions through an

Speaker: NA
Text: Emissions Reduction Fund is a better way than an approach that raises prices for all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: By building on the successes of the Carbon Farming Initiative, this bill supports positive

Speaker: NA
Text: action by farmers, businesses and households.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill will use positive incentives to reduce emissions, unlock economic activity, boost

Speaker: NA
Text: energy efficiency and improve agricultural productivity.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill makes economic sense for Australia. It makes environmental sense for Australia. It

Speaker: NA
Text: can be supported, wherever one stands on climate change, because of the profound co-

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits to the environment, and it was endorsed expressly by the Australian people at the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time as they rejected expressly a carbon tax which had no mandate and does not work.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government therefore stands for practical actions that will achieve real and measureable

Speaker: NA
Text: results for the economy and the environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill will deliver these results through the Emissions Reduction Fund, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: wholeheartedly commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEES

Speaker: NA
Text: Human Rights Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Report

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr LAURIE FERGUSON (Werriwa) (10:07): On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Human Rights, I present the committee's seventh report of the 44th Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled Examination of legislation in accordance with the Human Rights (Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Scrutiny) Act 2011: Bills introduced 13 to 29 May 2014, Legislative Instruments received 8

Speaker: NA
Text: March to 30 May 2014-Report, June 2014.

Speaker: NA
Text: Report made a parliamentary paper in accordance with standing order 39(e).

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr LAURIE FERGUSON: by leave-The Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human

Speaker: NA
Text: Rights' seventh report of the 44th Parliament covers 42 bills introduced in the period 13 to 29

Speaker: NA
Text: May, seven of which have been deferred for further consideration, and 218 legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: instruments received during the period 8 March to 30 May. The report also includes the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's consideration of 15 responses to matters raised in previous committee reports

Speaker: NA
Text: with ministers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of the bills considered in this report, I note the following bills are scheduled for debate in

Speaker: NA
Text: the parliament this week:

Speaker: NA
Text:  Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2014; and

Speaker: NA
Text:  Fair Work Amendment Bill 2014.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report outlines the committee's assessment of the compatibility of these bills with

Speaker: NA
Text: human rights, and I encourage my fellow members to look to the committee's report to inform

Speaker: NA
Text: their deliberations on the merits of this proposed legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to draw members' attention to one bill in this report which is of particular

Speaker: NA
Text: interest and relevance to the committee's task of assessing legislation for compatibility with

Speaker: NA
Text: human rights.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 2014 consists of six schedules of

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to the Migration Act and the Australian Citizenship Act. Key changes include:

Speaker: NA
Text:  amending the existing limitations on applying for a further protection visa to include

Speaker: NA
Text: situations where the first visa application was made on behalf of a non-citizen. This would

Speaker: NA
Text: cover situations where the non-citizen did not know of, or did not understand, the nature of

Speaker: NA
Text: the application due to a mental impairment or because they were a minor;

Speaker: NA
Text:  extending debt recovery provisions for detention costs to all convicted people smugglers

Speaker: NA
Text: and illegal foreign fishers;

Speaker: NA
Text:  amending the role of authorised recipients for visa applicants, and the Migration Review

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal and Refugee Review Tribunal's obligation to give documents to authorised

Speaker: NA
Text: recipients;

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text:  providing access to, and use of, material and information obtained under a search warrant

Speaker: NA
Text: in migration and citizenship decisions; and

Speaker: NA
Text:  amending the procedural fairness provisions that apply to visa applicants.

Speaker: NA
Text: As noted in the report, the committee has raised concerns about each of these amendments.

Speaker: NA
Text: In most cases, the committee has sought more information from the minister, noting that the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement of compatibility for the bill did not provide an adequate assessment of how the

Speaker: NA
Text: limitation on rights in each case was reasonable, necessary and proportionate.

Speaker: NA
Text: In particular, the committee noted that extending the statutory bar on repeat protection visa

Speaker: NA
Text: applications to children and persons with a mental impairment engages a number of human

Speaker: NA
Text: rights. These include the best interests of the child and the right of persons with a mental

Speaker: NA
Text: impairment to legal capacity. The schedule also engages Australia's nonrefoulement

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations-the obligation not to return people to harm. In this regard, the committee notes

Speaker: NA
Text: that merits review of decisions to remove people from Australia is an important aspect of our

Speaker: NA
Text: nonrefoulement obligations. I encourage members to consult the full discussion of the bill in

Speaker: NA
Text: the report, which provides a more detailed account of the issues raised. Finally, in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: responses to matters previously raised by the committee, the report contains consideration of

Speaker: NA
Text: 15 such responses, and the committee's concluding remarks on these matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: With these comments, I commend the committee's seventh report of the 44th Parliament to

Speaker: NA
Text: the chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS

Speaker: NA
Text: Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Child Care Measures) Bill 2014

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed on the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: to which the following amendment was moved:

Speaker: NA
Text: That all the words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

Speaker: NA
Text: "the House declines to give the bill a second reading as:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1)t he Government has failed to provide sufficient information about the impact on families of the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to the Child Care Benefit;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) the Government has not completed an assessment of impacts on workforce participation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to the Child Care Benefit;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) the changes to the Child Care Benefit should not be legislated just weeks before the Productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission inquiry into Childcare and Early Childhood Learning provides its interim report; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) families have not had a chance to have their say on these changes; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) for these reasons, calls on the Government to remove the changes to the Child Care Benefit, set out

Speaker: NA
Text: in Item 2 of Schedule 1, from this bill, to allow separate and fully informed consideration by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament of the changes to the Child Care Rebate and the Child Care Benefit."

Speaker: Ms BUTLER
Text: Griffith) (10:11): Our population is changing. There are more older people

Speaker: NA
Text: than before. Baby boomers have started to retire, and people are living longer. It is all good

Speaker: NA
Text: news. One consequence of those changes is that Australia needs workers. Among others, we

Speaker: NA
Text: need people in their 20s, 30s, and 40s to have every opportunity to participate in our

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce. We need them to use their skills, to develop their skills, to be productive, to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes and to stay in the workforce so that their pay increases, so that their tax payments

Speaker: NA
Text: increase, so that they do not lose their skills, so that they learn, so that they stay connected, so

Speaker: NA
Text: that they can contribute.
