Speaker: NA
Text: One thing our country needs, so that people of parenting age can stay in the workforce, is

Speaker: NA
Text: child care. Child care allows parents to return to work. More than 978,000 families across

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia rely on child care on a daily basis. There are lots of good reasons why a parent

Speaker: NA
Text: might want to return to work-there is the obvious financial benefit of earning a wage, but

Speaker: NA
Text: there are other benefits too. One is that the longer you are away from the workforce, the more

Speaker: NA
Text: likely it is that your skills will become eroded or outdated. That can make it harder to get back

Speaker: NA
Text: into the workforce, and even once you are there it can mean delayed promotion, delayed

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for development and lower wages over a lifetime. You can miss opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: for promotion that you would have had, had you had a shorter absence from the workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another reason that people might want to return to work is wellbeing. For a lot of us, our

Speaker: NA
Text: identity is wrapped up in our work. If you have built a successful career, or developed skills,

Speaker: NA
Text: or you have been part of an organisation successfully for a long period of time, your identity

Speaker: NA
Text: can be largely wrapped up in what you do. It can be an opportunity for inclusion, an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity for social contact, an opportunity just to have a conversation that is not about

Speaker: NA
Text: nappies or pressing domestic concerns. It can affect your sense of self-worth. For those

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons it is important not just from a national perspective but also from an individual

Speaker: NA
Text: perspective that we remove barriers and impediments to returning to work for people who are

Speaker: NA
Text: parents.

Speaker: NA
Text: None of this is intended to denigrate or belittle the work of those who choose to remain out

Speaker: NA
Text: of the paid workforce to undertake important parenting responsibilities. Having been both a

Speaker: NA
Text: stay-at-home parent and a principal in a national law firm, I value both roles, and I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: in a lot of ways that stay-at-home parenting work can be tougher and more demanding than

Speaker: NA
Text: returning to a career in the paid workforce. For those who want to return to the paid

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce, our nation should do what it reasonably can to remove any barriers. One aspect of

Speaker: NA
Text: removing barriers is good regulation that allows people to have a job that they can return to,

Speaker: NA
Text: that prevents them from being sacked for taking parental leave, that helps working

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements to fit around life as a parent and that helps to fight discrimination against

Speaker: NA
Text: parents.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another aspect is not legislative; it is building a culture where absence from the workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: to have a child is seen as the norm for people of parenting age-in other words, a work

Speaker: NA
Text: culture where work and family fit together and are not in competition with each other, and

Speaker: NA
Text: where people are seen as individuals and parents, not just as workers. Obviously a further

Speaker: NA
Text: aspect is paid parental leave. It takes away some of the pressure of absence and helps reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantage, and it allows the person taking parental leave to keep in touch with the

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace throughout their absence.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, child care is a very important part of the puzzle. Without child care, returning to

Speaker: NA
Text: work can be just impossible. Australian parents and their kids need quality, accessible and

Speaker: NA
Text: affordable child care. Research shows the relationship between workforce participation for

Speaker: NA
Text: women particularly and the cost of child care. When the gross costs of child care go up by one

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent, women's workforce participation decreases by 0.7 per cent. These are obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning statistics given the imperatives that we have to make sure that our paid workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: base is as big as possible as our population changes and we face the challenges inherent in

Speaker: NA
Text: those changes. Child care is not just important for today's workforce; it is important for our

Speaker: NA
Text: nation's future. It is important to our ability to raise enough revenue to pay for the services

Speaker: NA
Text: that our people need. It is also important for our children's future. Early learning is so

Speaker: NA
Text: significant when it comes to making sure that our children will have the best prospects, the

Speaker: NA
Text: best opportunities and the best future possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason I made those opening remarks was to explain why I find this bill so

Speaker: NA
Text: disappointing and why I so strongly support the Labor amendment. It is because this bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: aimed at making child care less affordable for parents. The bill will decrease the real value to

Speaker: NA
Text: working families of the childcare rebate and the childcare benefit. It will do so by freezing

Speaker: NA
Text: indexation not just for the non means-tested child care rebate but also for the income

Speaker: NA
Text: thresholds of the means tested child care benefit. It is a cut of $336 million from childcare

Speaker: NA
Text: support that lowand middle-income families in Australia rely on.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is so ill-timed. It comes only weeks before the Productivity Commission inquiry that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government itself instigated is due to provide an interim report. The government should await

Speaker: NA
Text: the Productivity Commission's recommendations and views on child care before altering

Speaker: NA
Text: childcare policy. This is an alteration in policy in that it is aimed at making child care less

Speaker: NA
Text: affordable. Like many other Australians, I made a submission to the Productivity Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry into child care in good faith, expecting that the government of the day would await its

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations before making changes to child care. By reducing access to child care and

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing affordability the government is jumping the gun. It should be waiting for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Productivity Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: But more important than process issues are substantive issues. The measures in this bill are

Speaker: NA
Text: unprecedented. No government has frozen indexation on the childcare rebate without using

Speaker: NA
Text: the proceeds of the savings to help fund child care quality measures by returning the savings

Speaker: NA
Text: to early learning. No government at all has frozen the income thresholds on the childcare

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit. These unprecedented measures are greatly disappointing, but sadly this approach is

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent with the Liberal-Nationals' longstanding failure to support accessible, affordable

Speaker: NA
Text: child care.

Speaker: NA
Text: I remember very well in the late 1990s that one of the first measures of the newly elected

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government was to abolish operating subsidies for community childcare centres. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the same year, they reduced the childcare cash rebate from 30 per cent to 20 per cent for one-

Speaker: NA
Text: child families with incomes above $70,000 a year. The Howard government just did not get

Speaker: NA
Text: child care. Unfortunately, it is a pattern that is continuing.

Speaker: NA
Text: In contrast, Labor has an outstanding record on child care. Just last year then Minister Ellis

Speaker: NA
Text: recounted some of our achievements on child care in a speech to the Australian Childcare

Speaker: NA
Text: Alliance. She described some of Labor's achievements and said:

Speaker: NA
Text: In affordability alone we have seen a massive increase in investment, we have seen an increase in the

Speaker: NA
Text: child care rebate from 30 to 50 percent, we have seen the increase in the cap of the child care rebate

Speaker: NA
Text: from $4,354 a year up to $7,500 per year but importantly they aren't the only statistics that matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: The statistics that matter is the impact that this increase is having in Australian families. What we do

Speaker: NA
Text: know is that in 2004 when a family was spending on average 13 percent of their disposable income on

Speaker: NA
Text: their childcare fees, that by 2011 that figure stood at 7.5 percent.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: So we have seen a reduction in the proportion of disposable income spent on child care. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know that former Prime Minister Kevin Rudd, who was the member for Griffith before my

Speaker: NA
Text: election as the member for Griffith, was very proud of the move to increase the childcare

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance from 30 per cent to 50 per cent. He spoke to me about that change and about the

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of making child care available to working families.

Speaker: NA
Text: When you look at the history of the coalition's actions and Labor's actions on child care

Speaker: NA
Text: you see the difference. Labor has always believed in and supported workforce participation

Speaker: NA
Text: measures and early learning measures, whereas unfortunately the coalition has not. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: similar proposition when it comes to paid parental leave. I remember very well when Jenny

Speaker: NA
Text: Macklin was the Deputy Leader of the Australian Labor Party federally and the great pride

Speaker: NA
Text: that I felt as a young member of the Australian Labor Party that she was championing a paid

Speaker: NA
Text: parental leave scheme nationally. At the time, though, unfortunately the Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: was opposing paid parental leave. Instead, we saw the absolutely flawed policy of the baby

Speaker: NA
Text: bonus-a policy that was widely criticised as an example of poor public policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: We championed paid parental leave and, once Labor was elected to government, we

Speaker: NA
Text: commissioned a Productivity Commission inquiry and, quite rightly, waited for the outcome

Speaker: NA
Text: of that inquiry. At that point we implemented a paid parental leave scheme consistent,

Speaker: NA
Text: importantly, with the Productivity Commission inquiry recommendations. That was a

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum wage, fixed-amount paid parental leave scheme where everybody would get the

Speaker: NA
Text: same amount. It was a fair scheme, unlike the Abbott government's wholly unfair Paid

Speaker: NA
Text: Parental Leave Scheme where the more well off you are the more money you get from the

Speaker: NA
Text: government. It is frankly ridiculous and repressive.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that in this debate there has been a bit of discussion about the priorities in this

Speaker: NA
Text: government's spending when it comes to work and family policies. All I want to say about

Speaker: NA
Text: that is that it is very disappointing that we are seeing a lot of myths being perpetuated in the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. For example, last night we heard a member indicating that it was fair for paid parental

Speaker: NA
Text: leave paid by the taxpayer to be paid at full income replacement, notwithstanding the

Speaker: NA
Text: Productivity Commission's recommendation directly to the contrary, because annual leave

Speaker: NA
Text: and sick leave get paid at income replacement rates. That wholly misunderstands the nature of

Speaker: NA
Text: the paid parental leave payment that is going to be paid for by the taxpayer. It is flawed

Speaker: NA
Text: analogy because we all know that annual leave and sick leave are not paid for by the taxpayer;

Speaker: NA
Text: they are paid for by the employer.

Speaker: NA
Text: This partly demonstrates some of the problems with this paid parental leave scheme. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Abbott government wants the taxpayers to pay income replacement for well-off people and

Speaker: NA
Text: employers to stop paying those income replacements. In those situations where there has been

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprise bargaining and where productivity gains have been exchanged for improved

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions for working people and where employers are now paying income replacement paid

Speaker: NA
Text: parental leave, the government would like to relieve those employers of that obligation and to

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively subsidise those employers by transferring the obligation to make those payments

Speaker: NA
Text: from the employer to the taxpayer. Frankly, I think that is ridiculous and unfair.

Speaker: NA
Text: For that matter, all of the allegations made that everybody should have the same paid

Speaker: NA
Text: parental leave entitlements are really interesting, as they come from a government, a party and

Speaker: NA
Text: a tradition that champions individual bargaining, and I am sure they would not be suggesting

Speaker: NA
Text: that pay and condition improvements ought to come without corresponding increases in

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity and productivity gains. But I digress, Deputy Speaker Mitchell. We are talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about child care.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Abbott government's record on child care and work and family policy is just atrocious.

Speaker: NA
Text: They promised no cuts to education before the election, and what have we seen since the

Speaker: NA
Text: election-cutting funding for schools, cutting funding for universities, higher university fees

Speaker: NA
Text: for students, failure to guarantee future funding for preschool. And now early childhood

Speaker: NA
Text: education has been added to the long list of Abbott government broken promises. It is pure

Speaker: NA
Text: hypocrisy not least because the Prime Minister personally wrote to centres about the impact of

Speaker: NA
Text: capping the childcare rebate on families before the election, saying it would mean increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: out-of-pocket costs for families. Of course that is exactly what this bill is for; that is exactly

Speaker: NA
Text: what this bill does. We have already seen this government's announcements stripping almost a

Speaker: NA
Text: billion dollars from early education and care, $450 million cut from outside of school hours

Speaker: NA
Text: care, $157 million cut from family day care services and a range of other cuts. But we are

Speaker: NA
Text: now seeing this square, direct attack on the childcare rebate and the childcare benefit.

Speaker: NA
Text: The childcare benefit is means-tested and targeted. It is extraordinary that the government

Speaker: NA
Text: is going to make cuts to a payment for which eligibility starts to reduce when families earn

Speaker: NA
Text: just $41,000. We know from the Senate committee hearings that the government has done

Speaker: NA
Text: very little, if any, real analysis of who will be hurt by these changes and how much they will

Speaker: NA
Text: pay. Instead, this is a government that is trying to rush these childcare benefit changes

Speaker: NA
Text: through the parliament in a sneaky and underhanded way and these changes are going to have

Speaker: NA
Text: a negative impact on at least 500,000 lowand middle-income families. It is just not good

Speaker: NA
Text: enough.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a very disappointing set of changes, and that is why Labor believes that particularly for

Speaker: NA
Text: the childcare benefit there ought to be an opportunity to fully consider, consult and debate in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of those changes. That is why we have moved the amendment to split the bill. We

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that particularly for that relief targeted to lower and middle-income earners there

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to be an opportunity for further discussion and further consideration in respect of that

Speaker: NA
Text: change to the childcare benefit. Frankly, it is a ridiculous indictment of this government's

Speaker: NA
Text: policies that they are refusing to reconsider their ridiculous paid parental leave scheme where

Speaker: NA
Text: the more you earn the more you get, while at the same time making it harder for families to

Speaker: NA
Text: afford child care.

Speaker: Ms OWENS
Text: Parramatta) (10:26): I rise to speak on the Family Assistance Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Child Care Measures) Bill 2014. This bill seeks to do two things: to freeze the

Speaker: NA
Text: childcare rebate limit at $7½ thousand per child per annum for three years and to freeze

Speaker: NA
Text: income thresholds for the childcare benefit CCB for three years. In the second reading

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment proposed by the shadow minister, Kate Ellis, we have made it very clear that on

Speaker: NA
Text: this side of the House the opposition calls for the two elements of this bill to be separated so

Speaker: NA
Text: that they can be considered separately and there can be real community consultation with

Speaker: NA
Text: families and childcare providers on the effects of these changes separately.

Speaker: NA
Text: For Labor there is quite a difference between the two. The childcare rebate, firstly, was

Speaker: NA
Text: something that Labor also sought to freeze when we were in opposition. The then opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: of course fought against that and argued that it was poor decision and they went around the

Speaker: NA
Text: country saying that it was a poor decision. But at the time we were talking about freezing the

Speaker: NA
Text: childcare rebate in order to transfer that money into other areas of child care. The then

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition has now completely changed its mind and thinks that it is a very good idea not just

Speaker: NA
Text: to freeze the rebate but to take that money out of child care completely, in other words, reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: the amount of funding available to parents who seek to put their children into child care.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second element, though, the childcare benefit is something that we on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House have extraordinary concerns about. This benefit is very much about lowand middle-

Speaker: NA
Text: income families. In many ways the combination of the two, the rebate and the benefit,

Speaker: NA
Text: recognises that for lower income families the proportion of the disposable income they spend

Speaker: NA
Text: on child care is greater and this compensates lower income and middle-income families for

Speaker: NA
Text: that difference by providing an extra payment. I heard the minister this morning on radio

Speaker: NA
Text: pretending that the freezing of the benefit would not make a difference because parents would

Speaker: NA
Text: then pick it up in the childcare rebate. If you know anything about mathematics, of course you

Speaker: NA
Text: would realise that that is not true. The childcare benefit is a 100 per cent payment and the

Speaker: NA
Text: rebate is 50 per cent up to $7½ thousand, so the more you reduce the benefit the less a low-

Speaker: NA
Text: income family receives in assistance, and it can be a substantial amount over a 12-month

Speaker: NA
Text: period.

Speaker: NA
Text: In many ways, this is the government of extraordinary contradictions. We have an amazing

Speaker: NA
Text: one here where we see on one hand the gold plated paid parental leave scheme, which

Speaker: NA
Text: reimburses a parent at their full rate of pay up to $50,000, presumably intending to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: women to move in and out of the workforce. On the other hand, on the same page, they then

Speaker: NA
Text: make it more difficult for families to afford the child care they need on returning to work. So,

Speaker: NA
Text: on one hand they argue that they are trying to help women return to work and on the other

Speaker: NA
Text: hand they take the very thing that assists a family in raising children for the years after the

Speaker: NA
Text: birth of a child-again, an extraordinary contradiction.

Speaker: NA
Text: But we see it in so many other ways: the slowing down of the increase in the super

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution, which makes it more likely that a person will need the pension-and then they

Speaker: NA
Text: cut the pension. They cut all funding to urban rail projects, making it more necessary to drive,

Speaker: NA
Text: and then they raise the cost of petrol. They cut preventive health agencies, making it more

Speaker: NA
Text: likely that a person will need to see a doctor, and then they raise the cost of going to a doctor.

Speaker: NA
Text: They deregulate universities, presumably to allow more people in to universities, but make it

Speaker: NA
Text: less affordable in doing so. They increase the interest on HECS to six per cent so that the

Speaker: NA
Text: more you earn the less you pay. A person working in a lower-paid job with the same

Speaker: NA
Text: university degree will pay more for their university education than a person in a higher paid

Speaker: NA
Text: job. And of course there is this one, where they are providing extraordinary levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to high-income earners yet making it more difficult for women in the lowerand

Speaker: NA
Text: middle-income areas to actually return to work at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: You can see from our record in government the extent to which Labor understands the

Speaker: NA
Text: economic benefits of child care and preschool. We invested considerably in those areas,

Speaker: NA
Text: because we understand, unlike the current government, that prosperity is built not by the

Speaker: NA
Text: assets that we have in the ground but by the assets we have in our minds. We heard the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer mention the word '2050' recently in terms of the costs of pensions, but we never

Speaker: NA
Text: hear the government talk about 2050 in terms of prosperity and where this nation will be at

Speaker: NA
Text: that time. But those of us who do think about that know that in 2050 it will not be the coal in

Speaker: NA
Text: the ground that makes us prosperous; it will be what we have in our minds-our ability to

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: think, our ability to outperform intellectually and outperform in innovation the extraordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: powerhouses to our north.

Speaker: NA
Text: The assets in 2050 will not be 55-year-olds like me; they will be 35-year-olds. Given the

Speaker: NA
Text: speed of change, the assets in 2050 will be the minds of our 35-year-olds-who are being

Speaker: NA
Text: born this year, and it takes 35 years to make one. It takes 35 years to make a good 35-year-

Speaker: NA
Text: old. And, unlike many other assets, you cannot retrofit them. You cannot redo their first five

Speaker: NA
Text: years of life. When a baby's mind decides that it wants to learn about language, that is what it

Speaker: NA
Text: learns, and you either encourage it to do that or you do not. You cannot do it later at anywhere

Speaker: NA
Text: near the same speed and, if you try, it costs you more. It takes 35 years to build the good 35-

Speaker: NA
Text: year-old worker that we will need in 2050, and it starts this year with the birth of children. We

Speaker: NA
Text: knew that, and that is why when we were in government we invested incredibly in preschool

Speaker: NA
Text: and early childhood education and sought to raise the standards so that child care was not

Speaker: NA
Text: about child minding but was actually about building the lives and the assets of the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been a considerable amount of research done on this. It is incredibly

Speaker: NA
Text: impressive-not just the impact of child care on threeto five-year-olds or twoto five-year-

Speaker: NA
Text: olds but the impact of child care on zeroto two-year-olds. Goodstart.org.au has provided

Speaker: NA
Text: some incredibly well-researched data. It assessed all year in year 1 against seven development

Speaker: NA
Text: domains, and it found that children who did not attend preschool were 50 per cent more likely

Speaker: NA
Text: to be developmentally vulnerable than children who did and that children from the poorest 20

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of households were twice as likely to be developmentally vulnerable as those from

Speaker: NA
Text: the richest 20 per cent. In other words, as a government, you need to invest in the poorest 20

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of households to lift them. If you want to be a 'lifter'-to use the language of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government-you invest in the poorest 20 per cent of households, because they are the ones

Speaker: NA
Text: where the difference will be greater, where there is a 50 per cent greater chance of them being

Speaker: NA
Text: developmentally vulnerable than there is for a child who did not attend preschool. Children

Speaker: NA
Text: who were developmentally vulnerable were also three times as likely as other children to

Speaker: NA
Text: perform poorly in reading, numeracy and NAPLAN tests in year 3, year 5 and year 7, again

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrating that you cannot retrofit those first years of a child's life.

Speaker: NA
Text: Children who attended three years of early learning or more performed much better on

Speaker: NA
Text: four-year literacy and numeracy tests. These tests, in 2011, were done over 40 developed

Speaker: NA
Text: countries that participated in international tests in literacy and numeracy and science for grade

Speaker: NA
Text: 4 children. Children who had three years of early learning or more scored an average of 30 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 40 points higher in the tests than did children who had no early learning and around 20 points

Speaker: NA
Text: higher than those who attended only one year of early learning. So, again, these early years

Speaker: NA
Text: are incredibly important in setting up those foundations across those incredibly important

Speaker: NA
Text: disciplines of reading, maths and science. Children who were taught by a preschool teacher

Speaker: NA
Text: with a diploma or degree qualifications scored 20 or 30 points higher in year 3. So, again, that

Speaker: NA
Text: quality framework that Labor introduced was done for a reason. It was done to ensure that our

Speaker: NA
Text: children in those incredibly important years of age zero to five had absolutely the best start in

Speaker: NA
Text: life so that when they reach 35 years of age and they are competing against these

Speaker: NA
Text: powerhouses to the north they will be the employees that our businesses want and they will be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to build good lives for themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are incredible results. A 15-year study of 3,000 English schoolchildren found that

Speaker: NA
Text: access to high-quality preschool had a strong effect on later literacy and numeracy and that

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the effect of 18 months of preschool was stronger on literacy and numeracy at age 11 than

Speaker: NA
Text: were all the six years of primary school. In other words, you can make a greater difference

Speaker: NA
Text: with that 18 months of preschool than you can in six years of school-again, absolute

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence for why governments should be investing in these early years to an incredible extent

Speaker: NA
Text: and why a bill before this House that makes it more difficult for people from low-income

Speaker: NA
Text: families to keep their children in child care to an extent that benefits the child is incredibly

Speaker: NA
Text: poor decision making. It indicates an extraordinary lack of vision for the future and indicates

Speaker: NA
Text: a government that claims to be thinking about the future but actually is not in any way.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why Labor, when it was in government, did a number of really important things,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is really sad to see this government undoing those things as quickly as it can. Following

Speaker: NA
Text: its election in 2007 it increased the Child Care Rebate from 30 per cent to 50 per cent of out-

Speaker: NA
Text: of-pocket expenses and increased the cap from $4,300 to $7,500 per child, an incredibly

Speaker: NA
Text: important measure that meant that the number of children in child care at any one time grew

Speaker: NA
Text: to over one million, an increase of nearly 30 per cent since 2007.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also introduced federal funding for preschool, and as a result the number of children

Speaker: NA
Text: benefiting from 15 hours of preschool-that is the number of hours covered in the survey

Speaker: NA
Text: from the UK-increased from 12 per cent of children, in 2008, to over 56 per cent of children

Speaker: NA
Text: in 2008. We know that attending 15 hours of preschool leads to higher scores in year 3

Speaker: NA
Text: NAPLAN tests and year 4 maths, science and languages. In other words, that 15 hours of

Speaker: NA
Text: preschool is essential to building the assets this country needs.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are benefiting from historical advances in education that we inherited, largely due to

Speaker: NA
Text: our history. With the extraordinary efforts that our neighbours to the north are putting into

Speaker: NA
Text: education on 50-year plans, if we think we can continue the way we are and still be

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive in 2050, we are kidding ourselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let's look at what the government have done. They campaigned on making child care more

Speaker: NA
Text: affordable, yet they have done exactly the reverse. They stripped almost $1 billion from early

Speaker: NA
Text: education and care, $450 million for outside-school-hours care is gone, $157 million for

Speaker: NA
Text: family day-care centres is gone, support to help parents complete study and get back to work

Speaker: NA
Text: has been cut, programs to increase childcare places are completely gone, and Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: Child and Family Centres funding is gone. How extraordinary is that from a government that

Speaker: NA
Text: speaks the language but cuts the programs. Then there is $300 million in support for educator

Speaker: NA
Text: wages, which is completely gone. Now, they are out on the attack on the backbone of the

Speaker: NA
Text: childcare system, which is the Child Care Rebate and the Child Care Benefit. I stress again

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Child Care Benefit is the one that assists lowand middle-income families to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: their children in child care to the extent necessary for that child to benefit from that outcome.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have also cut funding to the Partnership Agreement on Early Childhood, which funded

Speaker: NA
Text: preschool attendance of up to 15 hours per week, which again is something that will have an

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinary impact on the future of our children.

Speaker: NA
Text: I heard the minister this morning on radio saying that you can move from the benefit to the

Speaker: NA
Text: rebate. A basic understanding of maths would indicate that that is not the case. I would hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that in future our children who attend preschool for more than 15 hours a week would be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to see that, because it is actually quite basic mathematics. She also said that the government

Speaker: NA
Text: had no choice. That is an extraordinary thing. I did a quick calculation this morning on paid

Speaker: NA
Text: parental leave and the Child Care Rebate, given that the Child Care Benefit, even in its most

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: expensive year of the forward estimates, would save the government $76.9 million this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: But I would say that it will cost Australians far more than that in the future through

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity cost. But $76.9 million is about 1.5 per cent of what they would spend in a year

Speaker: NA
Text: on the paid parental leave scheme. So instead of paying 100 per cent of wages for women, up

Speaker: NA
Text: to $50,000, they could pay 98.5 per cent of wages and that would actually cover the

Speaker: NA
Text: difference. So they do have choices. They are making choices to put money into one area and

Speaker: NA
Text: not another, and this is a very bad place to start cutting.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Text: Charlton) (10:41): I rise very reluctantly to talk about the Family

Speaker: NA
Text: Assistance Legislation Amendment (Child Care Measures) Bill 2014. I am reluctant because

Speaker: NA
Text: we should not be having this debate. Both sides of the House rhetorically agree about the

Speaker: NA
Text: huge importance of investing in early childhood. The member for Parramatta put it very

Speaker: NA
Text: eloquently when she spoke about the fact that the greatest investment this nation can have is

Speaker: NA
Text: in its children, especially in early childhood investment and especially for children from low

Speaker: NA
Text: socioeconomic backgrounds.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should not be having this debate on a bill that cuts assistance for child care-that

Speaker: NA
Text: represents a $336 million cut to childcare assistance in this country, with over $200 million of

Speaker: NA
Text: that cut hitting some of the poorest people in our community. Freezing the Child Care Benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: will leave over 500,000 families worse off, and these are low-income families, not rich

Speaker: NA
Text: families. I heard Liberal speakers last night, particularly the member for Bowman

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledging that on their own figures this will represent a hit of around $200 a year for

Speaker: NA
Text: each child. In fact, I would argue that is being wildly optimistic. Early Childhood Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: has done modelling estimating that a family on $60,000 a year, well under the average wage,

Speaker: NA
Text: with one child in the childcare system will be $1,800 a year worse off by 2016-17. From a

Speaker: NA
Text: total family income of $60,000 they will be $1,800 worse off. This is a massive hit. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Parramatta said, this is a massive hit on families that we need to be supporting by

Speaker: NA
Text: investing in child care. Early-childhood investment is so important, and this bill moves us

Speaker: NA
Text: away from that investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, this bill is part of a wider attack on child care by this government. This

Speaker: NA
Text: government has already stripped over $1 billion out of child care funding. This includes $450

Speaker: NA
Text: million for outside-school-hours care, $78 million per annum cut from the Aboriginal Child

Speaker: NA
Text: and Family Centres, and $157 million cut from the community support program. Now we

Speaker: NA
Text: hear that preschool funding, through the National Partnerships Agreement, is well and truly

Speaker: NA
Text: under threat. All of these will have an impact on families trying to invest in child care for

Speaker: NA
Text: their kids. For example, the $157 million cut from the community support program represents

Speaker: NA
Text: a $35 per week hit on families. That is nearly $2,000 per annum. If you add the $2,000 hit

Speaker: NA
Text: from that funding cut to the $1,800 hit from this you have almost $4,000 in cuts to childcare

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance for families. That particular cut really represents an attack on family day care.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those on the other side champion the fact that they are pro family day care. They are the

Speaker: NA
Text: ones who constantly support that very important part of the sector, but when you match their

Speaker: NA
Text: actions with the rhetoric, we find them well and truly wanting.

Speaker: NA
Text: A person in my wife's mothers group recently set up a family day care centre. It was a huge

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge for her to go around babyproofing a house and to go through all the training and

Speaker: NA
Text: quality assessment. One of the reasons she was able to take on this huge endeavour was that

Speaker: NA
Text: she got administrative assistance so that she did not have to spend three-quarters of her week

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: doing paperwork. This $157 million cut represents a direct attack on her and everyone like her

Speaker: NA
Text: who is trying to run a family day care centre and provide greater flexibility for families.

Speaker: NA
Text: All of this represents yet another broken promise from those on the other side. Mr Abbott

Speaker: NA
Text: went to the election promising to make child care more affordable. He promised to do away

Speaker: NA
Text: with these indexation freezes-he attacked them ferociously before the election. What do we

Speaker: NA
Text: see now? We see a billion dollars in cuts, more indexation freezes and more direct attacks on

Speaker: NA
Text: families.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Hunter Valley, my region, is among the regions that are least able to afford these cuts.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a region with quite diverse income levels, but it includes some of the poorest suburbs in

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation-and there is a real lack of child care. On average, there is a two-year wait for

Speaker: NA
Text: child care in the Hunter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can talk about the childcare situation in the Hunter from a personal perspective. My wife

Speaker: NA
Text: and I are, I acknowledge, in a very privileged position. But when my wife fell pregnant with

Speaker: NA
Text: our child, we did the right thing. Once we hit the 12-week mark and we had the scan that said

Speaker: NA
Text: that everything was generally okay, we put our name down-'unknown Conroy' was what we

Speaker: NA
Text: put down-at myriad childcare centres. We put our own name down with 15 childcare centres

Speaker: NA
Text: in the region. A year later, not one of them delivered a place. I remember, on 20 December,

Speaker: NA
Text: the last working day of the year, ringing 20 other childcare centres in the vain hope someone

Speaker: NA
Text: had a spot in an infants room. Luckily, one of them came through. That was a great relief to

Speaker: NA
Text: me and to my wife, who was very keen to return to work.

Speaker: NA
Text: We were in a privileged position-my wife returning to work was an optional thing. We

Speaker: NA
Text: were not in a position where she absolutely had to return to work. I know families where, in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to pay the family bills, the mother had to get back to work straight after they reached the

Speaker: NA
Text: six-week mark. Luckily we got a place. We have to drive about 15 kilometres to drop our

Speaker: NA
Text: daughter off before we go to work-and we manage it. But we are in a lucky position. In my

Speaker: NA
Text: region, you have to fight hard to get a childcare spot-and the funding attack in this bill only

Speaker: NA
Text: makes it worse.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other parts of this attack are really pernicious. For example, the $78 million per annum cut

Speaker: NA
Text: to Indigenous child and family centres will have a direct impact on my region. My seat of

Speaker: NA
Text: Charlton has a large Indigenous population, particularly on the west side of Lake Macquarie.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been campaigning to maintain funding for the Nikinpa Aboriginal Child and Family

Speaker: NA
Text: Centre. This is a great Indigenous childcare centre. It is a brand-new centre set up under a

Speaker: NA
Text: national partnership agreement funded by Labor. The only way it survives is through that

Speaker: NA
Text: program's funding and the childcare benefit. Every single family that goes to that centre relies

Speaker: NA
Text: on the childcare benefit. Their budget is so tight that, if one of their kids drops out, they lose

Speaker: NA
Text: money. So they are really under the gun, but they are doing great work. They are opposite a

Speaker: NA
Text: primary school that has a lot of Indigenous students. Once the kids who go to the centre turn

Speaker: NA
Text: three, they get taken across the road to the primary school. They see school assemblies, they

Speaker: NA
Text: go through the library-they get introduced into the culture of schooling before they have to

Speaker: NA
Text: go there. All the research shows that, for Indigenous families, that is crucial to getting kids to

Speaker: NA
Text: go to school and to prosper in school. All this is under attack from a government that talks

Speaker: NA
Text: about child care but does not believe in it. They talk the talk but they never walk the walk.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: What is worse is that all of this comes out of a poor process. When the minister gets up in

Speaker: NA
Text: question time, she talks about the importance of the Productivity Commission report. She tells

Speaker: NA
Text: us how they are the government that had the guts to get the Productivity Commission to look

Speaker: NA
Text: into child care and how Labor in government never had the guts to do that. But what is the

Speaker: NA
Text: point of getting the Productivity Commission to look at child care if you have made all your

Speaker: NA
Text: major policy decisions before they even report? Their draft report is not due for another five

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks, but we have already seen $1 billion worth of cuts to the childcare sector in the

Speaker: NA
Text: meantime. That just shows the hypocrisy of those opposite. They talk about cost-benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: analysis and they talk about in-depth economic analysis, but when there is a cut to be made

Speaker: NA
Text: they jump in with both feet.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are using the budget yet again as an excuse for these heartless cuts. As speaker after

Speaker: NA
Text: speaker on this side has pointed out, the budget is built on sand. They have confected a false

Speaker: NA
Text: budget emergency as a basis for pursuing all these heartless cuts. The federal budget is in

Speaker: NA
Text: good shape. We have one of the lowest debt levels in the western world. Debt is projected to

Speaker: NA
Text: peak at less than 20 per cent of GDP-less than a third of the OECD average. Those on the

Speaker: NA
Text: other side have confected this scare campaign in an attempt to fundamentally reshape the

Speaker: NA
Text: nature of Australia-to make it a more dog-eat-dog society-and to attack those on low and

Speaker: NA
Text: middle incomes, those who are the most vulnerable.

Speaker: NA
Text: This childcare legislation and the cuts it embodies must be viewed in the broader context of

Speaker: NA
Text: the attack on families which this budget represents. The significant cuts in the budget to

Speaker: NA
Text: family tax benefit part A will mean that, for a family on $60,000 a year with two kids between

Speaker: NA
Text: eight and 15, there will be a cut in payments of $6,000. These are not Labor figures; these are

Speaker: NA
Text: figures from NATSEM-a modelling organisation of high repute. So highly esteemed are

Speaker: NA
Text: they that the Prime Minister used them before the last election and stated on the public record

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are the premier modellers of family income in this country. They have stated in their

Speaker: NA
Text: analysis of the budget that a family on $60,000 a year with two kids between eight and 15 will

Speaker: NA
Text: lose over $6,000. That represents more than 10 per cent of their family income. Just imagine

Speaker: NA
Text: it: you are a family with a combined income less than the average wage and this government

Speaker: NA
Text: is cutting your family income by $6,000, or 10 per cent. That is a huge blow to families. Then

Speaker: NA
Text: you combine that with the attacks on child care-the kids in that family may have out-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: school child care-which this government has cut by $450 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: This really is a government that does not care about families. They claim that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: family friendly, but when you look at their actions rather than their rhetoric, they are found

Speaker: NA
Text: wanting. This attack on families is even more hollow when you look at their ridiculous paid

Speaker: NA
Text: parental leave scheme, a scheme worth over $5 billion a year-which, as the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Parramatta pointed out, well exceeds the cuts they are subjecting the childcare sector to.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a paid parental leave scheme that is grossly inequitable. Figures derived from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Library show that 80 per cent of women of child-bearing age, in my seat of

Speaker: NA
Text: Charlton, earn less than $42,000. That includes welfare transfers from the government. So 80

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of women in Charlton will receive less than $20,000 under Mr Abbott's ridiculous

Speaker: NA
Text: paid parental leave scheme. Why is it fair for a family in Charlton to receive less than $20,000

Speaker: NA
Text: to have a baby while someone in North Sydney or Warringah receives $50,000? Why are the

Speaker: NA
Text: babies of Charlton worth $30,000 less than the babies of North Sydney? They are not, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: shows the gross inequity of this government and the skewed priorities.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: It also shows that they are happy to rely on the Productivity Commission for some things

Speaker: NA
Text: but not for others. The Productivity Commission made it very clear that a minimum-wage

Speaker: NA
Text: system rather than a replacement-wage system was the most effective way of undertaking

Speaker: NA
Text: paid parental leave. It is the best way of providing incentives for workforce participation by

Speaker: NA
Text: women, particularly women in lowand middle-income jobs. They are the ones we really

Speaker: NA
Text: need to give an incentive to, to return to work.

Speaker: NA
Text: We hear ridiculous rhetoric from the other side that it is a workplace entitlement. I

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge them to find another workplace entitlement paid by the government. It is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace entitlement, it is a welfare measure, and every Australian woman should be

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to the same amount of welfare for having a baby. This paid parental leave scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: does not deliver that; in fact, it goes in the opposite direction, where the richer you are the

Speaker: NA
Text: more you get.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need to contrast this with the government's attacks on the childcare sector. The Grattan

Speaker: NA
Text: Institute, another good economic organisation-they do not always agree with what Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: does but they are serious, economic policy advisers-have found that investment in child care

Speaker: NA
Text: is twice as effective as investment in the paid parental leave scheme. As the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Parramatta said before, it is not just the first six months of a child's life that you need to invest

Speaker: NA
Text: in. You need to invest in their entire life and you need to encourage workforce participation

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond the first six months. Investing in child care is worth twice as much, is twice as

Speaker: NA
Text: effective, as investment in the paid parental leave scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: That really is the nub of this debate: $5½ billion a year on a paid parental leave scheme that

Speaker: NA
Text: rewards millionaires over lowand middle-income Australians is patently unfair. It is also

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair if you look at the opportunity cost. The opportunity cost means that with the $5½

Speaker: NA
Text: billion you could be well and truly avoiding the cuts to child care. In fact, you could be

Speaker: NA
Text: doubling what is currently invested in the childcare sector, making our childcare centres

Speaker: NA
Text: palaces, making them great places for kids to get the best start in life. Instead, we see the

Speaker: NA
Text: other side pursuing a narrow ideological agenda, where they want to attack any assistance for

Speaker: NA
Text: lowand middle-income families-just as they want to attack pensioners and unemployed

Speaker: NA
Text: people.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a government that claims to have a small-government mentality and be ending the

Speaker: NA
Text: age of entitlement. They are ending the age of entitlement for lowand middle-income

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, they are ending the age of entitlement for pensioners, but they are not ending the

Speaker: NA
Text: age of entitlement for millionaires. That is the great tragedy of the Australia we find at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a debate we should not be having in this place. We all agree that investment in child

Speaker: NA
Text: care is great. We all agree that we want to give our kids the best start in life. I say to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal-National coalition: match your words with action. Invest in child care, invest in giving

Speaker: NA
Text: our kids the best start in life, because this bill is not that. This bill is an attack on families. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: an attack on lowand middle-income kids. It is an attack on giving our kids, Australian kids,

Speaker: NA
Text: the best start in life. That is why Labor's amendments should be agreed to.

Speaker: Dr CHALMERS
Text: Rankin) (10:56): I also support the member for Adelaide's amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I appreciate the opportunity to speak about the bill and follow the wise words of my colleague

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Charlton and my other colleagues the member for Griffith and the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Parramatta. I also thought the member for Lalor made a characteristically thoughtful

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution last night.

Speaker: NA
Text: I begin my own contribution by paying tribute to childcare workers. In my own electorate,

Speaker: NA
Text: like so many of the electorates in this place, we are very fortunate to have some tremendous

Speaker: NA
Text: childcare centres full of people whose contribution and commitment to raising the next

Speaker: NA
Text: generation of Australians is faultless. On Chatswood Road, you can go past one of the centres

Speaker: NA
Text: in the morning-even before the sun comes up, if you are on a walk or a run-and see the

Speaker: NA
Text: childcare workers out there sweeping the astroturf. They are making sure they are there early

Speaker: NA
Text: enough so that when the tradie utes pull up with the young boys and girls to be dropped off to

Speaker: NA
Text: the childcare centre there is someone waiting for them and someone to care for them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am very blessed. I have two wonderful sisters, and one of them is a childcare worker. She

Speaker: NA
Text: used to run one of the child care centres in my own electorate, at Algester. I know from

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking to her, over the years, the extraordinary commitment of these childcare workers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even though they are not paid a great deal of money, I know that they often dip their hands

Speaker: NA
Text: into their own pockets to pay for the crayons or the butchers paper. I know they often do

Speaker: NA
Text: special things for the kids' birthdays out of their own pockets. I pay tribute to the types of

Speaker: NA
Text: people that my sister Chelley works with, because I do know they are fantastic people. You

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot say enough about their commitment and contribution to helping raise that next

Speaker: NA
Text: generation of Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my own electorate, there are something like 11,100 families who rely on child care.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are 147 approved services and something like 9,760 families who rely on the childcare

Speaker: NA
Text: rebate, which is one of the things we are talking about today. These are good people who

Speaker: NA
Text: want to be good parents and good workers, all at the same time. They are people who are just

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to make ends meet and, quite often, that means having access to good-quality and

Speaker: NA
Text: affordable child care.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government had two very different themes before and after the election, when it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to these sorts of issues. Before the election, they talked about being a government of no

Speaker: NA
Text: surprises. They talked about no cuts to education. They talked about being consultative. They

Speaker: NA
Text: sent all kinds of reassuring letters to childcare centres, pretending they had no plans to cut

Speaker: NA
Text: people's assistance when it came to the childcare system. After the election, of course, a very

Speaker: NA
Text: different theme emerged.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should not mince words about the theme that emerged after the election. It really is an

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair agenda. It is a deliberate attack. It is an ambush on people who want to access that

Speaker: NA
Text: good-quality child care at affordable prices. They are people who are just trying to make ends

Speaker: NA
Text: meet. In lots of ways it was less of a budget and more of an ambush that we saw, in this place,

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered by the Treasurer in May.

Speaker: NA
Text: The more kind interpretation of all of this would be to blame it in some way on ignorance

Speaker: NA
Text: or something like that, but the reality is that the government are not ignorant of the impact of

Speaker: NA
Text: these changes. They did not even care to ask what the impact would be, particularly on low-

Speaker: NA
Text: and middle-income families. It is unforgivable, to my mind, to think that they did not even

Speaker: NA
Text: ask any of their experts, 'What would this mean for people who are doing it tough in our

Speaker: NA
Text: community, who are trying to be good parents and good workers?' You would think that

Speaker: NA
Text: would be the very least that they could do. The fact that they did not ask for that kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: advice really does speak to their lack of care about this issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: There are people behind every policy change that is made. Every number that is on the

Speaker: NA
Text: page of a budget document represents an impact on a human being and an impact on their

Speaker: NA
Text: community. It is crucial to understand just who this policy change proposed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: government hurts. It is not accidental; it is deliberate, it is intentional and it is by design. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: another example of the burden of this so-called budget emergency-which is a con-being

Speaker: NA
Text: unfairly borne by the people who can least afford it.

Speaker: NA
Text: We get a bit of a hint of their thinking on some of these matters when we consider that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister really does think that there are two kinds of women in the workforce. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know this because of his comment not that long ago which tried to differentiate women of

Speaker: NA
Text: calibre and, by implication, women who are not of calibre. This was a really Romney-like

Speaker: NA
Text: moment. You will remember Mitt Romney talking about binders full of women when he was

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to defend himself against some of the allegations made in his own presidential

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign. Mitt Romney and Tony Abbott really are Downton Abbey brothers in arms when it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to these sorts of issues. We know that the Prime Minister has a view that there are

Speaker: NA
Text: some deserving women and some undeserving women. We know this especially in the case of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Paid Parental Leave Scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thought that those who spoke on this legislation before me did an extraordinary job of

Speaker: NA
Text: pointing to the unfairness in the government's Paid Parental Leave Scheme. The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Griffith explained it well in referring to it as a really regressive measure. It is not fair, when

Speaker: NA
Text: you have limited funds coming into the government, when you have budget constraints, to

Speaker: NA
Text: think that their highest priority would be $21 billion so that they can give $50,000 a year to

Speaker: NA
Text: the wealthiest parents in our community just to have a baby. It is extraordinary that they

Speaker: NA
Text: would prioritise that over some of the assistance that we are talking about today. It just shows

Speaker: NA
Text: how warped those priorities are. It is not just Labor saying that and it is not just the union

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that-as important and as crucial as the union is in looking after childcare workers.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a whole range of stakeholders who are saying that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to mention again, as other speakers have, that the Australian Industry Group argued

Speaker: NA
Text: that the cuts would not be necessary if some of the expenditure allocated to the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: Paid Parental Leave Scheme was redirected. You would think that would be a no-brainer.

Speaker: NA
Text: When you look at the unfairness of the PPL and the extravagance of that scheme compared

Speaker: NA
Text: with the unfairness of some of the things being proposed here, you would think that would be

Speaker: NA
Text: a no-brainer. It was not just the AiG who opposed this bill. Early Childhood Australia, Family

Speaker: NA
Text: Day Care Australia, Early Learning Association Australia, Australian Childcare Alliance,

Speaker: NA
Text: Goodstart Early Learning and the National Welfare Rights Network have all lined up. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is a long queue of people who think that this legislation has been rushed and that it needs

Speaker: NA
Text: more consideration and that it is not right to attack people on low and middle incomes who

Speaker: NA
Text: are just trying to access affordable child care. These groups cannot understand-just like big

Speaker: NA
Text: swathes of the community cannot understand-why there is a need to rush. Why the rush,

Speaker: NA
Text: from a government that said 'no surprises'? I can shed some light on that.

Speaker: NA
Text: As other speakers have reminded us-the member for Charlton mentioned this in his

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution-the Productivity Commission will report on some of these issues firstly in July

Speaker: NA
Text: and then I think in October. You would think the government would wait for the outcomes of

Speaker: NA
Text: that review before they made these changes. There are two reasons why they have not. The

Speaker: NA
Text: first reason is very sneaky. They have given a commitment that the Productivity Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: will come up with proposals that relate to the same sized funding envelope as we began with.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have rushed in $1 billion worth of cuts so that the envelope is substantially smaller for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Productivity Commission to report on. That would not be well known out in the

Speaker: NA
Text: community, but that is a sneaky thing that they are doing. I think the second sneaky reason is

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciated in the community, judging by all the doors I knocked on on the weekend in

Speaker: NA
Text: Meadowbrook in my electorate, plus the forum we held in Browns Plains. When people talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about this budget they say, 'What is the government thinking?'

Speaker: Mr Hunt
Text: We are thinking of the $240 billion in deficits that accumulated while you were

Speaker: NA
Text: advising the Treasurer.

Speaker: Dr CHALMERS
Text: Some of them say-and I certainly believe this as well-that what the

Speaker: NA
Text: government are trying to do is place a big bet that all this nasty stuff they are doing to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians now will be forgotten in two years time. That is all it is. That is why they are

Speaker: NA
Text: rushing out these regressive changes before they even get the outcomes of their own review.

Speaker: Mr Hunt
Text: We are thinking that the kids will have to pay for it if we don't pay for it now.

Speaker: Dr CHALMERS
Text: I would have thought the Minister for the Environment, who is at the

Speaker: NA
Text: table, would be up for some empirical policy advice-obviously not, judging by the

Speaker: NA
Text: interventions being made as he makes his way through his big stack of folders.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rush to make these cuts is really a political strategy. It does sell Australian mums and

Speaker: NA
Text: dads short. It does attack their living standards. The government try and justify it by a budget

Speaker: NA
Text: emergency that does not exist, if you listen to credible people, like the International Monetary

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund. If the government had an economic strategy, we would not be debating these cuts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, these cuts are not the only cuts that they propose to the childcare system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Others have spoken about a series of cuts that add up to around $1 billion, whether it is the

Speaker: NA
Text: $450 million for outside school hours care, the $157 million for family day care services, the

Speaker: NA
Text: funding that has gone from Indigenous child and family centres or the $300 million in support

Speaker: NA
Text: for educator wages-the people I began my contribution by talking about, the great people

Speaker: NA
Text: who look after our kids in the community. Now, of course, we have this attack on the absolute

Speaker: NA
Text: backbone of the childcare system: the CCR and of the CCB. We know from the education

Speaker: NA
Text: department that the combination of measures that we are debating now will hurt half a million

Speaker: NA
Text: lowand middle-income families, who will receive less support as a result of this measure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Griffith paid tribute to former Prime Minister Rudd, and I pay tribute to

Speaker: NA
Text: him as well and to former Prime Minister Gillard and all the ministers who were in this

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio, including the member for Adelaide and others, who did such a tremendous job in

Speaker: NA
Text: this policy area.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Kate Ellis: Tell me more!

Speaker: Dr CHALMERS
Text: The member for Adelaide would like to know more about this, so I will

Speaker: NA
Text: tell her more. One of the first actions of the new Labor government in 2007, as she would

Speaker: NA
Text: know, was to increase the childcare rebate from 30 per cent to 50 per cent and to increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: CCR cap. We also gave families the option of claiming the CCR payment fortnightly, which

Speaker: NA
Text: made a big difference-and there are all kinds of stats that others have spoken about.

Speaker: NA
Text: Modelling showed that out-of-pocket costs for a family earning 75 grand a year reduced from

Speaker: NA
Text: 13 per cent of their disposable income in 2004 to 8.4 per cent in 2012. There are reams and

Speaker: NA
Text: reams of stats like this to show what an extraordinary success Labor's childcare policies were

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: in government. We are very proud of these achievements not just because of the impact that

Speaker: NA
Text: they had on the childcare system and that they had on people's disposable income and their

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity to make ends meet but also because they were a contribution to the type of economy

Speaker: NA
Text: that we want in this country. We want an economy where more people participate, where

Speaker: NA
Text: more people benefit, where the gains of economic growth are more broadly and fairly shared.

Speaker: NA
Text: We make it easier for people to be simultaneously good workers and good parents.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Adelaide has mentioned a compelling stat, and it is worth mentioning

Speaker: NA
Text: again. Research shows that the relationship between childcare affordability and women's

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce participation is strong. A one per cent increase in the gross childcare price results

Speaker: NA
Text: in a decrease to mothers' employment rate of 0.7 per cent. That is a substantial, concrete piece

Speaker: NA
Text: of evidence about the impact that these sorts of measures that are being proposed can have on

Speaker: NA
Text: participation in our economy. Lower income families have been proven to be the first to drop

Speaker: NA
Text: out of work as childcare costs increase. I have a lot of lower income families in my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am proud to represent them. One of the reasons I wanted to speak on this is that the changes

Speaker: NA
Text: that are being proposed would have a disproportionate impact on those people that I am so

Speaker: NA
Text: proud to represent. As the member for Charlton said, you cannot just talk the talk of

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce participation; you need to walk the walk if you are fair dinkum about workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: participation. It is on measures like this that the rubber really hits the road.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have workforce challenges associated with the ageing of the population and all kinds of

Speaker: NA
Text: things. Participation is one of those workforce challenges. The participation rate has been

Speaker: NA
Text: bouncing around-in the last ABS data, I think it dropped down a little bit. In the long term,

Speaker: NA
Text: we have big challenges associated with finding the right amount of workers to support a

Speaker: NA
Text: growing proportion of retirees in our economy. That is why this debate is so crucial. If we

Speaker: NA
Text: make dads and especially mums choose between being good workers or good parents, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: selling them short. We are selling short their contribution to a stronger economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor is proud of its record in government. This bill should be split, as the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide's amendment proposes, because we should consider the changes to the child care

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit separately. We will oppose the bill if it is not split. This bill is a backward step. Like

Speaker: NA
Text: so many other things in the budget, it is contrary to the guarantees the government gave

Speaker: NA
Text: families before the election. To all of those childcare workers and parents relying on the

Speaker: NA
Text: childcare system in my part of the world in Logan City and some of the surrounding Brisbane

Speaker: NA
Text: suburbs, I want you to know that this side of the House is standing up for people on lowand

Speaker: NA
Text: middle-incomes in the childcare system. We are standing up for childcare workers, like my

Speaker: NA
Text: sister Chelley. We will continue to do that and that is why I support the member for Adelaide,

Speaker: NA
Text: who moved this amendment, and all the good people on this side of the House who have

Speaker: NA
Text: spoken in favour of it

Speaker: Mr THISTLETHWAITE
Text: Kingsford Smith) (11:11): I am pleased to speak in support of

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendment moved by the member for Adelaide. In doing so, I speak on behalf of 6,850

Speaker: NA
Text: families in the electorate of Kingsford Smith who receive the childcare benefit and the

Speaker: NA
Text: childcare rebate-that much-needed support for affordable child care in our community. I ask

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives of the government: why are you cutting funding for childcare support for

Speaker: NA
Text: families by freezing these two very important payments? Why are you making it harder for

Speaker: NA
Text: families to make ends meet by making childcare more unaffordable? Why are you doing this,

Speaker: NA
Text: when at the same time you are giving large multinational mining companies in this country a

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: tax break? It says everything about the priorities of this government. Why are you not

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting families in a time when cost-of-living pressures are through the roof?

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister Abbott is not the person he said he would be. This government is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: government that it said it would be prior to the election. Before the election, they made it

Speaker: NA
Text: clear that there would be no cuts to education, no cuts to health, no cuts to pensions and no

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts to the ABC and SBS-but in these bills we clearly see a cut to education and a cut to

Speaker: NA
Text: support for early childhood education in our community. It is a clear and continuing broken

Speaker: NA
Text: election commitment. Before the election, the Prime Minister personally wrote to all childcare

Speaker: NA
Text: centres about the impact of a proposal to cap the childcare rebate. Before the election the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's view, put in writing to those childcare centres, was that capping and freezing

Speaker: NA
Text: the childcare rebate 'would increase out-of-pocket costs for families.' Yet, this is exactly what

Speaker: NA
Text: his government is doing. The hypocrisy of this government knows no bounds when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: to the cuts that they have undertaken to education and health and their changes to pensions.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my community, the cost of living is the No. 1 political issue. It is the No. 1 pressure

Speaker: NA
Text: facing families. Housing costs are astronomical-they have gone through the roof. What is

Speaker: NA
Text: the approach of this government? They apply layer upon layer of additional pressure:

Speaker: NA
Text: implementing GP co-payments so that families will now have to pay every time one of their

Speaker: NA
Text: kids get sick and has to visit the doctor; removing family tax benefits and making it more

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult, particularly for single-parent families, to make ends meet; cutting the schoolkids

Speaker: NA
Text: bonus, vital support to families to ensure that they can meet the costs of sending kids to

Speaker: NA
Text: school; and now, in these bills, they are freezing the childcare rebate and freezing the

Speaker: NA
Text: childcare benefit. There is layer upon layer of more costs and more difficulty for families

Speaker: NA
Text: through these reforms.

Speaker: NA
Text: For many families in my community the Child Care Rebate or the Child Care Benefit is the

Speaker: NA
Text: difference between having a child in child care and not having the child in child care.

Speaker: NA
Text: Subsequently, it is the difference between the ability of some families to have both parents in

Speaker: NA
Text: the workforce and only one parent in the workforce-and that is very important to cost-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: living pressures and the ability of families to participate actively in society. Freezing these

Speaker: NA
Text: childcare rebates and benefits will make it more difficult for families. That is illustrated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers of people who will reach or have reached the cap for the rebate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The greatest betrayal in this reform is the fact that the savings generated from the freezing

Speaker: NA
Text: of these benefits will not be re-invested in early-childhood development or in the childcare

Speaker: NA
Text: system. They are clear cuts to early-childhood education and clear cuts to benefits and

Speaker: NA
Text: payments to families to help them meet the costs of having kids in child care. That says

Speaker: NA
Text: everything about this government's priorities, particularly in the context of offering tax breaks

Speaker: NA
Text: to wealthy mining companies and to those who are on large superannuation balances and who

Speaker: NA
Text: earn large incomes from them. It comes on top of cuts to early-childhood education in other

Speaker: NA
Text: areas-$450 million has been cut from the out-of-school-hours care program. In my area a

Speaker: NA
Text: school like Randwick Primary School, which has 800 students, has a waiting list of 100

Speaker: NA
Text: students-100 families are trying to get their kids into out-of-school care. How happy are

Speaker: NA
Text: they going to be about the cuts that this government is making to out-of-school care? They are

Speaker: NA
Text: going to be extremely pleased that $450 million is being cut when that money could be used

Speaker: NA
Text: to expand the number of positions at places like Randwick Primary School. Such care is

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary in the context of having both parents work, as modern families do.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Some $157 million is also being cut from Family Day Care services. Indigenous Family

Speaker: NA
Text: Day Care centres are facing cuts. One is the Gujuga Family Day Care Service in La Perouse,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I recently visited and which provides a wonderful service to young students. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: teetering on the edge, because the support they have been receiving from all levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: government is threatened by the federal cuts; and, no doubt, that will have an impact on the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of places they can provide for Indigenous families.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government's approach to childcare workers is nothing short of disgraceful. Anyone

Speaker: NA
Text: who has kids in child care, as I do, would know just how hard and important the work of

Speaker: NA
Text: childcare workers is for early childhood development. They are not simply a child-minding

Speaker: NA
Text: service. Early childhood workers are educators, and numerous studies demonstrate the value

Speaker: NA
Text: of early-childhood development for the ongoing educational capacity of kids and for the

Speaker: NA
Text: developmental abilities of kids, particularly those with disabilities-the value of early

Speaker: NA
Text: intervention and early education for kids with disabilities is infinite. I see it in my children.

Speaker: NA
Text: My eldest daughter could read words before kindergarten, because of the support and the

Speaker: NA
Text: education she was given by the educators in her childcare service. It is a valuable service that,

Speaker: NA
Text: historically, has been undervalued by the community. Relatively speaking, childcare workers

Speaker: NA
Text: are being paid a pittance when compared to the value of the service they provide for kids and

Speaker: NA
Text: their development and, ultimately, the productivity of our education system and the economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The previous government's approach was to say that finally as a society we need to value

Speaker: NA
Text: the work and the role of early childhood educators. We need to highly value the role they play

Speaker: NA
Text: not only in looking after kids and educating them, but also in the emotional support they

Speaker: NA
Text: provide. That was evident in the approach taken by the previous Labor government, guided

Speaker: NA
Text: quite ably by the member for Adelaide, in boosting the wages of childcare workers to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: they are paid a fair and decent wage.

Speaker: NA
Text: The greatest betrayal, as I have said, is that the money saved through these cuts is not being

Speaker: NA
Text: re-invested into early-childhood development. That says everything about the approach of this

Speaker: NA
Text: government and this government's priorities, especially when it provides a tax break for large

Speaker: NA
Text: multinational mining companies and for those with large superannuation balances and when it

Speaker: NA
Text: persists with the $16 billion Paid Parental Leave scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: The impact of freezing the Child Care Benefits will be monumental for some families. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Child Care Benefit is a targeted payment-it is means tested and starts to reduce once a

Speaker: NA
Text: family's income reaches $41,000 and cuts out at $145,000 for single-child families. So it is

Speaker: NA
Text: targeted to low-income families to ensure that they have the support and the wherewithal to

Speaker: NA
Text: send kids to child care. In the Senate inquiry into this particular bill, the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Education admitted that 500,000 families will receive less support for early-childhood

Speaker: NA
Text: education from the changes and the freezing of the Child Care Benefit. This proposal is being

Speaker: NA
Text: rushed through the House and the parliament with very little community consultation. I note

Speaker: NA
Text: that a number of advocacy bodies and people who work day to day in this space are opposed

Speaker: NA
Text: to these changes. Many of those bodies were given only five days to comment on the context

Speaker: NA
Text: and the implications of this bill. Perhaps one of the greatest ironies of this reform is the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Productivity Commission inquiry into early childhood education and learning is still

Speaker: NA
Text: running. One would think that the government would await the outcomes and the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations of their own inquiry before jumping to conclusions and rushing through

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, without adequate consultation of the wider community and interested parties-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: but, no, they have adopted this reform. Again, this is another example of a government

Speaker: NA
Text: without a plan and with policy being developed on the run-policy that is being rushed and

Speaker: NA
Text: that is ill-thought through, particularly on the implications for families.

Speaker: NA
Text: In terms of the childcare rebate, the impact will again affect a number of families in my

Speaker: NA
Text: community. The childcare rebate is a non means-tested payment that provides 50 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the out-of-pocket expenses up to $7,500 per child per year. In terms of the cost of freezing the

Speaker: NA
Text: cap, it has been revealed that 74,000 families will reach the cap in 2014-15 and that that will

Speaker: NA
Text: increase to 150,000 families in 2016-17. It says everything about the impact moving forward

Speaker: NA
Text: of freezing this benefit on those families for whom childcare will become unaffordable and

Speaker: NA
Text: more difficult as a result of this reform. In opposition, as I mentioned earlier, the current

Speaker: NA
Text: government, the Abbott government, opposed freezing the cap. Even when we were planning

Speaker: NA
Text: to invest that money back into the childcare system, they opposed this reform. But here we

Speaker: NA
Text: have them pushing ahead with this reform. It is a rushed reform. There has been inadequate

Speaker: NA
