Text: consultation, and this is symbolic of the government developing policy on the run.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, on behalf of those almost 7,000 families in my community who are feeling

Speaker: NA
Text: the pinch when it comes to the cost of living, who are struggling to make ends meet and to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that they keep their kids in child care, the childcare rebate and the childcare benefit can

Speaker: NA
Text: mean the difference between having their kid in child care and not having their kid in child

Speaker: NA
Text: care. The freezing of these payments and the rushed manner in which these reforms have been

Speaker: NA
Text: conducted, particularly in the context of the government's ongoing Productivity Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry, is something that the opposition does not support. This is why the minister has sought

Speaker: NA
Text: to split these bills. There has not been adequate consultation in order to get an appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: response from those in the community who are affected by these reforms and nor have the

Speaker: NA
Text: implications of these reforms been thoroughly thought through.

Speaker: Ms LEY
Text: Farrer-Assistant Minister for Education) (11:25): In summing up, I thank all

Speaker: NA
Text: the speakers on the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Child Care Measures) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2014 for their contributions to the debate. I want to reiterate that this government is

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to making child care more affordable, flexible and accessible for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: working families. I want to start by making something very clear to address so much of the

Speaker: NA
Text: misinformation from Labor members during this debate. Overall, this government is

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing, not cutting, childcare assistance to $28½ billion over the next four years to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: around a million families each year through the childcare benefit and the childcare rebate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposed amendments to the Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Child Care

Speaker: NA
Text: Measures) Bill will do two things: maintain the childcare benefit income thresholds for three

Speaker: NA
Text: years and continue to pause the childcare rebate limit at $7,500 per child per year for a further

Speaker: NA
Text: three years. Both of these measures will apply from 1 July 2014 for three years to 30 June

Speaker: NA
Text: 2017. It is fiscally responsible for this government to maintain, not cut-as the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide would have you believe-the current CCB income thresholds, along with the

Speaker: NA
Text: current CCR annual limit, pending the outcome of the Productivity Commission's inquiry into

Speaker: NA
Text: child care and early learning in October 2014. The terms of reference for this broad-ranging

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry include consideration of rebates and subsidies for child care. The draft report will give

Speaker: NA
Text: us the first insight into their proposed reforms and is due next month.

Speaker: NA
Text: The measures contained in this bill are, however, moderate and necessary. The Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: Education and Employment Legislation Committee noted:

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: … the committee is persuaded that these measures are limited, well targeted and for a finite period of

Speaker: NA
Text: time, and are a necessary part of the broader government agenda of repairing the budget and

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthening the economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government is making decisions that will prepare Australia for the long-term challenges

Speaker: NA
Text: and opportunities that confront us. The childcare benefit measure in this bill is a 2014-15

Speaker: NA
Text: budget measure and is one element of the government's broader measure to maintain

Speaker: NA
Text: eligibility thresholds for Australian government payments for three years. Maintaining the

Speaker: NA
Text: childcare benefit income thresholds will provide an estimated saving of $230 million over the

Speaker: NA
Text: forward estimates. Childcare benefit eligibility requirements will remain unchanged. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a cut. The government will continue to index-that is, increase the childcare benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: standard hourly rate, increase the minimum hourly amount and the multiple child loadings by

Speaker: NA
Text: the consumer price index on 1 July each year. It is important to note that the out-of-pocket

Speaker: NA
Text: costs incurred by most families because of the childcare benefit measure will be reduced by

Speaker: NA
Text: the childcare rebate, which is not income tested and which covers up to 50 per cent of out-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: pocket childcare costs, up to $7,500 per child per year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The childcare rebate indexation pause at $7,500 was first implemented by Labor in 2011.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor announced an extension of the measure as part of their 2013-14 budget and then took

Speaker: NA
Text: the $105 million in savings from the budget bottom line but never legislated for it. When this

Speaker: NA
Text: government sought to legislate the measure, Labor combined with the Greens in the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier this year to block the legislation that would have given effect to their own measure. So

Speaker: NA
Text: I welcome their apparent change of mind. It is very good to see that the opposition is no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer opposed to their own measure. The CCB measure will not impact families with

Speaker: NA
Text: incomes below $41,902, which is the lower income threshold for childcare benefit. These

Speaker: NA
Text: families will continue to receive the maximum rate of childcare benefit. Families with

Speaker: NA
Text: incomes above $41,902 will continue to receive CCB. The amount of CCB a family receives

Speaker: NA
Text: tapers to zero as their income increases to the relevant maximum income limit. The CCB

Speaker: NA
Text: measure in this bill ensures the payment is fair and sustainable in the longer term for families

Speaker: NA
Text: who need it most. And I want repeat this, because families need to be aware-despite the

Speaker: NA
Text: broad-brush accusations of the opposition-that the hourly and weekly rates of Child Care

Speaker: NA
Text: Benefit will continue to be indexed-that is, to increase. This means that, per hour, the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of Child Care Benefit that families receive will in fact continue to increase.

Speaker: NA
Text: A number of members opposite referred to the Productivity Commission's inquiry called by

Speaker: NA
Text: this government. We actually called for it in opposition, but it was never supported by Labor.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have talked it up today-and I am delighted that they have-but they never, ever

Speaker: NA
Text: supported its inception. As I have said, the measures in this bill do not in any way pre-empt

Speaker: NA
Text: the Productivity Commission inquiry into child care and early childhood learning, which is a

Speaker: NA
Text: holistic review into what is needed for the next generation, not just for the next few years. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are maintaining the current CCB income thresholds, along with the current CCR annual limit,

Speaker: NA
Text: pending the outcome of the Productivity Commission's inquiry, which will report finally in

Speaker: NA
Text: October of this year. As part of its broad-ranging review, the PC is looking into the rebates

Speaker: NA
Text: and subsidies available for each type of care. The inquiry's fourth term of reference

Speaker: NA
Text: specifically asks the commission to look into:

Speaker: NA
Text: Options for enhancing the choices available to Australian families as to how they receive child care

Speaker: NA
Text: support, so that this can occur in the manner most suitable to their individual family circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mechanisms to be considered include subsidies, rebates and tax deductions, to improve the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: accessibility, flexibility and affordability of child care for families facing diverse individual

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thousands of submissions and comments have been received, and a number of them have

Speaker: NA
Text: highlighted just how complex these payments are for families and service providers alike. So

Speaker: NA
Text: I really do look forward to the Productivity Commission's draft report next month. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: CCB and CCR measures in this bill are moderate and necessary measures for this time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, I would have preferred that we, coming into government, did not have to make

Speaker: NA
Text: these changes. Of course, I would have preferred that we did not inherit a budget disaster

Speaker: NA
Text: from Labor which needed urgent action to repair it. Of course, I would have preferred not to

Speaker: NA
Text: be standing here today to sum up a bill that brings in sensible, moderate measures to repair the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. These are choices that the Liberal and National parties, in government, have been

Speaker: NA
Text: forced to make-by the budget mess left to us by Labor.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that Australian families need flexibility. We know that our Productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission inquiry is going to deliver some real, valuable and terrific policy ideas for the

Speaker: NA
Text: next generation. I am delighted that the Productivity Commission will look at the options for

Speaker: NA
Text: the future, within the current funding envelope. I remind the House that the Productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission inquiry is a broad-ranging one, and that one of its terms of reference is to look at

Speaker: NA
Text: the current and future needs for child care in Australia, including the consideration of a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of factors such as the 'types of child care available including but not limited to: long

Speaker: NA
Text: day care, family day care, in-home care including nannies and au pairs, mobile care,

Speaker: NA
Text: occasional care, and outside-school-hours care'. I make that point because a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite have highlighted in their speeches the difficulties that they themselves have

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced in finding child care. They have highlighted the difficulties that their constituents

Speaker: NA
Text: face, and they have highlighted the frustrations of not finding the right child care, in the right

Speaker: NA
Text: place, at the right time, and for the right cost. We definitely want to reiterate our commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: to solving this problem. We came into government and inherited a childcare system that, if

Speaker: NA
Text: not completely broken, was certainly heading in that direction. The urgent action that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: taking in terms of repairing the budget is something that will set our economy on a good

Speaker: NA
Text: footing for the next generation. Our inquiry will look at innovative ideas for policies in child

Speaker: NA
Text: care.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do want to mention something else that a number of those opposite talked about, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts to the Jobs, Education and Training Child Care Fee Assistance-wrong. The program is

Speaker: NA
Text: currently uncapped as to how much parents can claim. Labor's inaction has seen the

Speaker: NA
Text: JETCCFA budget blow out by over $50 million in the past two years. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government is introducing two key changes commencing on 5 January next year: a maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: eight-dollar hourly cap for Jobs, Education and Training Child Care Fee Assistance, and a 36-

Speaker: NA
Text: hour weekly limit per child to payments to recipients who are undertaking study. The average

Speaker: NA
Text: childcare hours used by all families working or studying is around 24 hours a week, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: average hourly fee for all families is $7.65 per child-so most families will find no change to

Speaker: NA
Text: their current situation. For example, with the average childcare hours used by all families

Speaker: NA
Text: working or studying being around 24 hours a week, the 36-hour weekly limit will mean no

Speaker: NA
Text: change to most families' current situations. We are introducing these changes to better manage

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure and to ensure that recipients are accessing the program in the most cost-effective

Speaker: NA
Text: way. We want to ensure that JET fee assistance is available for as many income support

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: families as possible, to enable them to get the skills they need so that they can secure jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: now and into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Adelaide spoke of what she termed as 'cuts to family day care'-and I do

Speaker: NA
Text: need to mention this because she was, in fact, the minister during 2012, when an audit of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Community Support Program by the Australian National Audit Office found approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: 71 per cent of CSP funding was being allocated to family day care-which accounted for

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 10 per cent of all children in care. The ANAO recommended that the

Speaker: NA
Text: program's eligibility criteria be reviewed but, typically, Labor did nothing. So the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide knows that the program was unsustainable; she knew it in government, but did

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing to repair the situation when she had the chance. She squibbed her responsibilities and

Speaker: NA
Text: now sits on the other side and criticises this government for what we are doing to fix Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: mess.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor has no credibility on child care. The promises that they made never came to fruition.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, childcare fees skyrocketed by 53 per cent under Labor-that is, around $73 extra a

Speaker: NA
Text: week in fees for a family using the average hours of child care. In case members opposite say,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'oh yes, but that is before you factor in the subsidies to parents for the Child Care Rebate', let

Speaker: NA
Text: me make the point that out-of-pocket costs went up 40 per cent during that time. That in itself

Speaker: NA
Text: is a disastrous legacy to leave Australian families. The hypocrisy is breathtaking. I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: is a phrase we hear a lot in this House, but in fact, in this case, their hypocrisy is breathtaking.

Speaker: NA
Text: We will soon see that the Labor Party will oppose this bill-this bill that is designed to repair

Speaker: NA
Text: a budget disaster that they left us with. But in this bill is a measure that they in fact announced

Speaker: NA
Text: in their budget but from which they took $106 million in savings, and they assumed that cut

Speaker: NA
Text: would happen. They will sit here and oppose their own measure, which in itself is

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinary, because Labor members speaking on this bill have been hysterically wrong in

Speaker: NA
Text: so many instances. They say 'You are making cuts', 'You do not care', 'You are not interested',

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Children do not matter', and so on-there has not really been a rationale presented by

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite for why we would do these things.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the battle of ideas, there are often competing ideas. You might have different ideas about

Speaker: NA
Text: a range of philosophies and policies, but no Labor member has actually accused us of having

Speaker: NA
Text: a different idea. All they have accused us of is making cuts, and the reason is that they know

Speaker: NA
Text: the only rationale, the only reason, why we are doing these things is that we have no choice in

Speaker: NA
Text: the context of the budget that we have inherited. Labor just make up stories and scaremonger.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those listening to this debate may think that the amount of childcare benefit they receive for

Speaker: NA
Text: their children, the hourly amount, is going down, when in fact it is going up, because all we

Speaker: NA
Text: are doing is freezing thresholds. They might think that the amount of childcare rebate they can

Speaker: NA
Text: claim is going down, when in fact we are pausing the threshold. We are pausing these

Speaker: NA
Text: thresholds for three years to take the moderate, sensible action that we need to to restore the

Speaker: NA
Text: national accounts of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said, we have a plan, we have an agenda, we have ideas and we understand the

Speaker: NA
Text: landscape in which we exist and in which we work. We understand what parents need. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know that our Productivity Commission inquiry is going to look after those needs for the next

Speaker: NA
Text: generation. The accusation by a Labor Party that did not even support that inquiry of not

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting until that inquiry report is in, unfortunately a few months from now, fails to

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that this action is being taken in order to repair the budget and that means that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have a limited choice.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to commend this bill to the House, I want to reiterate that the childcare rebate

Speaker: NA
Text: measures in this bill are in fact Labor's own measures. They are Labor's own measures. They

Speaker: NA
Text: need to own up, they need to stand up and they need to say 'we will support this part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill.' If they oppose this whole bill, then they cannot be taken seriously as a responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition. If they oppose this whole bill, they are effectively opposing something they

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced themselves, and from which they took $106 million in savings to try, desperately,

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide that economic fig leaf of credibility that they had lurched to the last election with.

Speaker: NA
Text: How dishonest; how meaningless. It is absolutely appalling that Labor would not recognise

Speaker: NA
Text: that they in fact own half of the legislation that is being presented today. I commend the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Vasta): The original question was that this bill now be

Speaker: NA
Text: read a second time. To this the honourable member for Adelaide has moved as an amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: that all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: question is that the amendment be agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: The House divided. [11:44]

Speaker: NA
Text: Chesters, LM Clare, JD

Speaker: NA
Text: Claydon, SC Collins, JM

Speaker: NA
Text: Conroy, PM Danby, M

Speaker: NA
Text: Dreyfus, MA Elliot, MJ

Speaker: NA
Text: Ellis, KM Feeney, D

Speaker: NA
Text: Ferguson, LDT Fitzgibbon, JA

Speaker: NA
Text: Giles, AJ Gray, G

Speaker: NA
Text: Griffin, AP Hall, JG (teller)

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Jones, SP Leigh, AK

Speaker: NA
Text: Macklin, JL MACTiernan, AJGC

Speaker: NA
Text: Marles, RD Mitchell, RG

Speaker: NA
Text: Neumann, SK O'Connor, BPJ

Speaker: NA
Text: Owens, J Parke, M

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: Ms LEY
Text: Farrer-Assistant Minister for Education) (11:57): by leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Asset Recycling Fund Bill 2014

Speaker: NA
Text: Asset Recycling Fund (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2014

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Cognate debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed on the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: Grayndler) (11:58): The Asset Recycling Fund Bill 2014 is a part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Abbott government's ongoing attempt to con Australians about the level of its commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure investment. On a superficial level, it sounds like the government is doing

Speaker: NA
Text: something. Indeed, part this legislation creates a fund which the government proposes to fund

Speaker: NA
Text: new infrastructure proposals in the 2014-15 budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: But there is a real problem here. The budget includes no new money for infrastructure. The

Speaker: NA
Text: few new projects are being funded by cuts to existing road and rail projects. But more than

Speaker: NA
Text: anything else, this bill is about an attempt by the Commonwealth to flick pass responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: for nation-building to state governments. This will be done using the centrepiece of this

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, the $5 billion so-called Infrastructure Recycling Initiative. This fund will be

Speaker: NA
Text: available for two years. State governments willing to privatise public assets and spend the

Speaker: NA
Text: proceeds on infrastructure projects will be eligible to access the fund for a 15 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: premium on the price of the project. The creation of this fund mirrors the political story of the

Speaker: NA
Text: entire 2014-15 budget. It is a story about a Prime Minister who is cutting spending, because

Speaker: NA
Text: he is obsessed with small government. At the same time, he is attempting to paint himself as a

Speaker: NA
Text: high-rolling big spender on infrastructure. Because of the incompatibility of these positions,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister is desperate to pass responsibility for cuts onto other levels of government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last month's budget was something of a masterclass in the flick pass. For example, the $80

Speaker: NA
Text: billion in cuts to health and education spending are federal cuts, but the states will have to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver them. They will have to bear the political backlash out there in the community while

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister washes his hand and demands public acclaim for fiscal rectitude. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: same way, cash-strapped councils will have to wear the political pain of the Prime Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: billion dollars in cuts to financial assistance grants to councils.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation before us is of apiece with this buck-passing mentality. It seeks to impose

Speaker: NA
Text: greater responsibility for infrastructure on states while this coalition government seeks the

Speaker: NA
Text: credit. The funding sphere is a political minefield of privatisation of public assets. The extent

Speaker: NA
Text: to which this is a political issue is highlighted by the fact that it is not called a privatisation

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative; it is called recycling where states will be asked to take significant political risks for

Speaker: NA
Text: the privilege of accessing a 15 per cent bonus. This asset recycling initiative is a fancy-

Speaker: NA
Text: sounding name for privatisation of state assets and a reduction of Commonwealth spending on

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: I notice that the government claims that the $5.9 billion that will go into this proposed fund

Speaker: NA
Text: is new. That is blatantly untrue. The $5.9 billion was stolen from two existing infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: investment funds. The first, the Building Australia Fund, was established by Labor to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in transport, communications, energy and water infrastructure. The second, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Education Investment Fund, was also created by Labor and was designed to fund

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure investment in education and research.

Speaker: NA
Text: The abolition of the Education Investment Fund comes on top of its $5.8 billion of cuts to

Speaker: NA
Text: higher education and student support. The abolition raises serious questions about this

Speaker: NA
Text: government's commitment to the long-term sustainable funding of infrastructure for teaching

Speaker: NA
Text: and research at Australia' public universities. Without systematic and sustainable funding for

Speaker: NA
Text: research infrastructure, Australia will not be able to attract the best and brightest researchers

Speaker: NA
Text: in the world nor commit to significant long-term research and commercialisation projects

Speaker: NA
Text: done by our competitors.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Building Australia Fund and the Education Investment Fund delivered real, direct

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in productivity-driving infrastructure. Decisions about grants from these funds

Speaker: NA
Text: were subject to rigorous process. Projects funded from the Building Australia Fund had to be

Speaker: NA
Text: ticked off by the independent Infrastructure Australia to ensure that investments had genuine

Speaker: NA
Text: potential to add to national productivity. In the case of the Education Investment Fund, a

Speaker: NA
Text: specialist committee of independent experts exercised similar oversight and the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: government acted on the expert advice.

Speaker: NA
Text: The infrastructure recycling initiative is being presented today as a new means to leverage

Speaker: NA
Text: extra investment-that is, investment that would otherwise not occur-but it is a con. The

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: fund itself is being bankrolled by a raid on the two existing investment vehicles, not a single

Speaker: NA
Text: new dollar, as a result of this legislation that is before the parliament today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me put it another way: the government is dumping plans for actual direct investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: nation building and will use the money gained to pay the states to do its job. So, whether it is

Speaker: NA
Text: hard infrastructure in terms of transport infrastructure or investment in science and education

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions to boost our contribution to productivity, this government is abandoning both in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of direct investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me say again that the Commonwealth contribution to projects bankrolled by this fund

Speaker: NA
Text: will be the 15 per cent premium on the value of the infrastructure project but, under existing

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements, the Commonwealth consideration to infrastructure projects is either a fifty-fifty

Speaker: NA
Text: share with the states or in some cases an 80-20 split. So let's be honest: this fund is a cost-

Speaker: NA
Text: cutting measure at least as it relates to the Commonwealth budget. Most importantly, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: no checks and balances in this legislation to ensure that the projects funded by this asset

Speaker: NA
Text: recycling fund represent value for many. That is why the opposition today will be proposing

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments aimed at restoring the proper processes in decision making about infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fund is an emblem for this government's political cowardice and lack of vision both

Speaker: NA
Text: when it comes to actual investment and to probity standards. The term 'asset recycling' is a

Speaker: NA
Text: different way of saying privatisation: the sale of existing public assets that are owned by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people. I am neither for or against privatisation full stop, but it must be considered

Speaker: NA
Text: on a case-by-case basis. Sometimes it might be appropriate to sell a public asset but it is

Speaker: NA
Text: always vital to balance the short-term benefit of selling assets against the long-term downside

Speaker: NA
Text: of losing the revenue stream for that asset. Once the asset is sold as a one-off, the revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: stream is gone, so you can weaken the long-term fiscal position of government through a

Speaker: NA
Text: short term act. That is why privatisation is not always popular with voters. It involves real

Speaker: NA
Text: political risks. Taxpayers are sensitive about the idea of what some people call selling off the

Speaker: NA
Text: family silver. They know that in many cases a windfall gain is made at the cost of a long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue stream.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister understands the political risks involved in privatisation for state

Speaker: NA
Text: governments, so he knows that the sting of any voter backlash associated with this fund will

Speaker: NA
Text: be felt by the states, not the Commonwealth. It is a case of all care but no responsibility. I

Speaker: NA
Text: predict that future public complaints by state governments, particularly by coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: governments, about inadequate roads or public transport will be met by a standard prime

Speaker: NA
Text: ministerial response from the government, 'It's not my fault. It's the fault of the states.' I

Speaker: NA
Text: offered them access to the Asset Recycling Fund, which was already in place in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: money with the Building Australia Fund and the education infrastructure funding. This is just

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the mirage that was the government's so-called infrastructure initiatives in the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: in May, and you do not need to be Nostradamus to make this prediction.

Speaker: NA
Text: I watched for nearly a dozen wasted years as John Howard amassed a massive

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure deficit by behaving as though infrastructure was none of his business. When I

Speaker: NA
Text: was sworn in as infrastructure minister, Australia was ranked 20th in the OECD for

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in infrastructure as a proportion of GDP. When I left, we were first as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: the record investment that the federal Labor government put into nation building. Mr Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: was a determined federalist who provided no leadership on nation building. He found it easier

Speaker: NA
Text: to use surpluses, driven by the mining boom, to curry electoral favour with middle-class

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare than to actually invest in the future of this nation. After all, state premiers were

Speaker: NA
Text: always on hand to use as whipping boys if anyone complained about inadequate

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure. We have already seen it with this government's approach to public transport

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure where they have withdrawn every single dollar from every public transport

Speaker: NA
Text: project around the nation that was not already under construction.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition's preparedness to identify problems is exceeded only by their enthusiasm for

Speaker: NA
Text: passing them onto other levels of government. Rather than achieving actual progress, the

Speaker: NA
Text: government would rather retain power by dissolving lines of government responsibility and

Speaker: NA
Text: by playing the blame-game. While Labor builds the nation for the benefit of all, those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite oppose nation building and actually have legislation before the Senate to remove the

Speaker: NA
Text: term 'nation building' from any involvement in infrastructure. They believe that infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: is just about marginal electorates.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another problem with this new fund is its potential to distort the infrastructure market,

Speaker: NA
Text: because the window of opportunity for the privatisation of state assets is only two years and

Speaker: NA
Text: could encourage fire sales. It could give states an incentive to make poor decisions in their

Speaker: NA
Text: haste to get a piece of this action. This fund could lead to a crowding out of the infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: market for two years. Where you have more possibilities for investment than would otherwise

Speaker: NA
Text: be the case at the one time, you will get a lower price to taxpayers from the sale of those

Speaker: NA
Text: assets. Again, that is not a problem for the federal government, but it would be a problem for

Speaker: NA
Text: state governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question of how governments fund infrastructure is always critical. In office Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: worked with states to deliver funding for their proposals. We also created taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements designed to encourage private sector investment in infrastructure-

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements that this government has made no effort to utilise. Above all, we had faith that

Speaker: NA
Text: our creation of Infrastructure Australia to provide proper process for infrastructure decision

Speaker: NA
Text: making meant that our projects would add to national productivity. They were projects that

Speaker: NA
Text: yield productivity gains for themselves over time. They create jobs and they create economic

Speaker: NA
Text: activity that boosts government revenues. Some, like investments in urban rail, add to the

Speaker: NA
Text: amenity of cities and drive further productivity gains. They encourage people to leave their

Speaker: NA
Text: cars at home or move closer to their workplaces. That is why we funded all 15 projects that

Speaker: NA
Text: were identified as a priority by Infrastructure Australia. Whether it be projects like the Majura

Speaker: NA
Text: Parkway, or the Hunter Expressway, or whether it be rail projects like the regional rail link,

Speaker: NA
Text: we funded them on the basis of proper advice.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister, though, has put forward a budget in which none of the new projects

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been funded have been identified as priority projects by Infrastructure Australia. At

Speaker: NA
Text: the same time the Prime Minister believes that changes put forward to the Infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia legislation would undermine its independence, and we are seeking to move

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments in the Senate to fix up this flawed legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government's approach to infrastructure spending in the 2014-15 budget is wildly out

Speaker: NA
Text: of kilter with their rhetoric. If you judge the Prime Minister by his words, you might believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that he was committed to infrastructure investment. He has been out there with re-

Speaker: NA
Text: announcement after re-announcement claiming that projects that had been underway for years

Speaker: NA
Text: were somehow new. We heard the Deputy Prime Minister, yesterday, trying to claim the

Speaker: NA
Text: Moreton Bay Rail Link, which was first promised in the Queensland parliament in 1895. But

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: it took a federal Labor government in partnership with the Queensland state Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government and the local council to ensure that it occurred. In terms of that, the fact is they

Speaker: NA
Text: have announced projects which were funded in budgets by the previous Labor government,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the Inland Rail project. The study was done, the commitment was given in 2010 and

Speaker: NA
Text: funding of $300 million was in the 2011 budget for the Inland Rail line. They have announced

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly the same funding, exactly the same time frame, and they pretend that somehow it is

Speaker: NA
Text: something new.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new projects are being funded by cuts to existing road projects, like Melbourne's M80

Speaker: NA
Text: and Tasmania's Midland Highway, as well as by the cancellation of urban rail investment

Speaker: NA
Text: including the Melbourne Metro and Brisbane's Cross River Rail Project. The Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: scrapped these projects because he has an ideological aversion to public transport. He outlines

Speaker: NA
Text: that in his book Battlelines where he makes it clear that in his view there simply are not

Speaker: NA
Text: enough people who want to go from one destination to another to justify anything other than

Speaker: NA
Text: the use of a car. The fact is, we cannot deal with urban congestion in our cities unless we have

Speaker: NA
Text: both rail and road. That was recognised by Infrastructure Australia, which is why it

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended funding for both of those projects that were in place.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister also said before the election that they would have cost-benefit analysis

Speaker: NA
Text: of all projects of $100 million or more. That promise seems to have gone the same way as:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'No cuts to health or education or the ABC.' The fact is that in the budget that they put

Speaker: NA
Text: forward, where they say there was a budget emergency, they have advanced $1.5 billion for

Speaker: NA
Text: the East West project in Melbourne, this month, including $1 billion for stage 2 that is not due

Speaker: NA
Text: to commence this financial year or next financial year but the financial year after that, if they

Speaker: NA
Text: ever work out where it is actually going to go. It is an extraordinary advance payment to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian government, which is of course facing an election.

Speaker: NA
Text: Their rhetoric regarding infrastructure is designed to distract Australians from the real heart

Speaker: NA
Text: of the budget-the broken promises, the savage spending cuts and the unfairness. Here is this

Speaker: NA
Text: government's message to Australians: 'Never mind that you won't be able to see a doctor

Speaker: NA
Text: anymore. You'll be able to drive on a brand-new road that Labor funded three budgets ago.'

Speaker: NA
Text: They made a statement of claim that within 12 months there would be cranes in the sky for

Speaker: NA
Text: these projects that do not have planning, have not been through environmental assessment and

Speaker: NA
Text: do not have cost-benefit analysis.

Speaker: NA
Text: The problem for the government is that they spent so much time saying no to everything

Speaker: NA
Text: and being relentlessly negative that they did not craft alternative policies and did not craft an

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative vision for the nation, which is why, when they came to government, we saw the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget-for the first time since 2008-not include a single new dollar for the Bruce Highway

Speaker: NA
Text: or the Pacific Highway over the forward estimates. There is not a single new dollar for rail

Speaker: NA
Text: freight, yet the minister for infrastructure and his errand boy, the assistant minister, have been

Speaker: NA
Text: busy re-announcing projects on these two highways and other projects, pretending that they

Speaker: NA
Text: were not previously funded by the former, Labor government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has also ignored its own promises about the integrity of processes

Speaker: NA
Text: surrounding investment decisions. The government said before the election that it would work

Speaker: NA
Text: with Infrastructure Australia to ensure probity in selecting which infrastructure projects would

Speaker: NA
Text: attract Commonwealth support, and yet we know that with the Perth Freight Link project

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no plan, no design and no cost-benefit analysis at all. We know that because the WA

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: state government says that is the case. We believe that the Infrastructure Australia model got

Speaker: NA
Text: it right, but the government has introduced legislation, which it gagged in this place, to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: it to dictate IA's research agenda. The amendments would allow it to order IA to ignore

Speaker: NA
Text: certain classes of infrastructure, such as public transport. The amendments would allow it to

Speaker: NA
Text: gag Infrastructure Australia by preventing publication of its independent research. So, within

Speaker: NA
Text: months of its election, the government is creeping away from its commitments to probity. In a

Speaker: NA
Text: recent video, produced shamefully for political purposes to align with the D-Day

Speaker: NA
Text: commemorations, the Prime Minister threw away all pretence. He complained about 'analysis

Speaker: NA
Text: paralysis', which he said was preventing infrastructure projects from going ahead. What he

Speaker: NA
Text: was really saying was: 'Don't worry about proper analysis.' If the Prime Minister's word

Speaker: NA
Text: means nothing to him, he can take that up with the electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the meantime, we are stuck with this bill. While process is an inconvenience to be

Speaker: NA
Text: swatted away on that side of the House, the opposition will be moving amendments which

Speaker: NA
Text: will hold the government to its own claimed principles. The first would require that no project

Speaker: NA
Text: could be funded from this new fund unless it has been the subject of a full cost-benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: analysis ticked off by Infrastructure Australia and is in keeping with the government's own

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment that they would have proper analysis for any project in receipt of more than $100

Speaker: NA
Text: million.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second amendment relates directly to projects that are being funded by states via asset

Speaker: NA
Text: sales, thereby earning the 15 per cent premium. It would require the finance minister to table a

Speaker: NA
Text: disallowable instrument for each privatisation transaction as a precondition to eligibility for it

Speaker: NA
Text: to attract an incentive payment. It is aimed at empowering this parliament to hold the

Speaker: NA
Text: government to its own promises. Again, if the government is serious about funding genuine

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity-enhancing projects properly assessed by independent experts, it should have no

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty with this amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Several projects funded in the budget, including the Perth Freight Link, Melbourne's East

Speaker: NA
Text: West Link and Queensland's Toowoomba Second Range Crossing, are being funded even

Speaker: NA
Text: though Infrastructure Australia is yet to see full cost-benefit analysis. We are setting up a

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanism to make sure that the government's rhetoric is matched by the legislation. They

Speaker: NA
Text: need to be held to account so that we do not have absurdities like this $1½ billion advance

Speaker: NA
Text: payment to the Victorian government on behalf of taxpayers. What sort of budget slashes

Speaker: NA
Text: health through the Medicare co-payment, education by abandoning the Gonski reforms, and

Speaker: NA
Text: public transport projects on the basis of 'These measures need to be made because there's a so-

Speaker: NA
Text: called budget emergency,' but gives $1½ billion to sit in the Victorian government's bank

Speaker: NA
Text: account for no purpose other than making its budget look better prior to the election later this

Speaker: NA
Text: year? It stands in stark contrast to what the assistant minister said in a speech on 6 June. He

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: … we are driving the state governments very hard to give us timetables to ensure that we're meeting the

Speaker: NA
Text: expected time of delivery of these projects. That we're hitting milestones, that we're only making

Speaker: NA
Text: payments to states when they actually deliver the milestones, that they're not getting money in their

Speaker: NA
Text: bank account prior to milestones being delivered …

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only are there no milestones for the East West project; they do not know where the tunnel

Speaker: NA
Text: is going to emerge for stage 2. It is not even a line on a map, but they are giving them a billion

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars this year. That is why these amendments should be supported by the entire parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: They are respectful of proper process; they are also a requirement when public money funds

Speaker: NA
Text: projects that will drive productivity gains.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's approach in government was to engage in real nation-building. It was to establish

Speaker: NA
Text: proper processes with Infrastructure Australia. We also got on with investment: we doubled

Speaker: NA
Text: the roads budget; we increased the rail budget by more than 10 times; and we rebuilt a third of

Speaker: NA
Text: the national rail freight network, including cutting six hours from the trip from Melbourne to

Speaker: NA
Text: Brisbane and nine hours from the journey from the east to the west coast.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am very proud of the fact that we committed more money to urban public transport from

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007 until 2013 than all previous Commonwealth governments combined from Federation to

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007. We planned and funded the Moorebank Intermodal Terminal, delivering major

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity gains to Sydney and taking 3,300 trucks off the road every day-a project

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to generate about $10 billion in economic benefits through increased productivity,

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced freight costs, reduced traffic congestion and better environmental outcomes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The current government ran ads in the 2010 election campaign opposed to the Moorebank

Speaker: NA
Text: Intermodal Terminal. That is the opportunism we saw from those opposite. Compare that with

Speaker: NA
Text: the approach of the government-spurning the advice of Infrastructure Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: introducing legislation to undermine its independence, and failing to increase investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure spending, merely taking money away from projects that have been properly

Speaker: NA
Text: assessed and giving it to projects that are done on the back of an envelope. This bill avoids

Speaker: NA
Text: direct infrastructure investment while setting up the states and councils as the scapegoats of

Speaker: NA
Text: the future, when people begin to see the results of its underinvestment. Unless Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to this bill are accepted, the government will have successfully created a vehicle

Speaker: NA
Text: for pork-barrelling and doing favours for its friends in coalition state governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given the record of infrastructure underspending and pork-barrelling of the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition government, surely this nation can do better than simply winding back the clock. By

Speaker: NA
Text: creating this incentive fund-taking money that had already been allocated for proper nation-

Speaker: NA
Text: building investment, through the Building Australia Fund, and for proper investment in our

Speaker: NA
Text: future, through education and science research and innovation, through the education

Speaker: NA
Text: investment fund-what the government is seeking to do is reduce its own involvement in the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of infrastructure by paying the states and the private sector to do the heavy lifting.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is, of course, a role for private sector investment. That is why we created the

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure investment tax incentive, a scheme that would provide, through the

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure Australia process, an incentive in terms of changes to tax arrangements to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage investment by the private sector-not just in greenfield infrastructure but also in

Speaker: NA
Text: brownfield assets. We introduced that in last year's budget. It came into effect at the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: last year, but this government seems oblivious to it.

Speaker: NA
Text: We do not have a view on this side of the House that public sector is automatically bad and

Speaker: NA
Text: private sector is automatically good. That is the view of some of those opposite. They just

Speaker: NA
Text: want government to get out of the way in terms of government involvement in infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The consequences of that will be a reduction in investment and a scheme which will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: an incentive for state governments to privatise assets. Let me say this: if an asset is worthy of

Speaker: NA
Text: privatisation it needs to stand on its own merits. A top-up figure of 15 per cent over a period

Speaker: NA
Text: of just two years is a distortion of that process. If it is indeed in the longer-term interest of the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: state which owns that asset-through the people, at the end of the day-then we should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: distorting that process.

Speaker: NA
Text: This nation needs Commonwealth leadership on infrastructure. It does not need a

Speaker: NA
Text: government that ignores the advice of independent experts and consults the electoral map to

Speaker: NA
Text: inform its investment decisions. The last thing it needs is a return to the blame game that

Speaker: NA
Text: characterised the former government. Process is important, which is why we need to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that this legislation is amended to allow proper processes: proper assessments of projects plus

Speaker: NA
Text: accountability to this parliament by ensuring there is a disallowance instrument. I will be

Speaker: NA
Text: moving the amendments when it comes to consideration in detail and ask the House to

Speaker: NA
Text: support those amendments then. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr IRONS
Text: Swan) (12:28): I rise to speak on the Asset Recycling Fund Bill 2014 and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Asset Recycling Fund (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2014. We have just heard from the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Grayndler, the former minister for infrastructure, who has made some interesting

Speaker: NA
Text: comments in his introductory speech.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government has made an unprecedented commitment to infrastructure and the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation we are debating today forms a key part of that commitment. In just a few months

Speaker: NA
Text: since being elected, the government has shown its intent and strategic approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure across the country. With its decisions on massive visionary projects such as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Sydney airport infrastructure package and the Perth Freight Link, which impacts my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Swan, this is already in stark contrast to the previous minister's approach of

Speaker: NA
Text: untargeted and unfunded spending with no strategic plan or direction.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, I would suggest that nowhere in Australia is this government's commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure more apparent than in my electorate of Swan currently. But this bill takes the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's approach to a new level. It provides for future infrastructure through a recycling

Speaker: NA
Text: program involving federal financial incentives for the sale of mature assets by the state

Speaker: NA
Text: governments where the proceeds are directed into new infrastructure. This will potentially see

Speaker: NA
Text: a generation of new infrastructure projects across the country. It has the backing of the

Speaker: NA
Text: states-including, it seems, Labor controlled South Australia-as the premiers can see the

Speaker: NA
Text: advantages of the bill. Yesterday we saw proposals by the New South Wales government and,

Speaker: NA
Text: in May, Treasurer Nahan of Western Australia referred to a likely asset sale process in the

Speaker: NA
Text: state budget. So there is plenty of support from all sides, except, it seems, the other side.

Speaker: NA
Text: It seems from the former minister's speech that the Labor Party in this place is not fully

Speaker: NA
Text: behind this legislation and the previous speaker, the member for Grayndler, has indicated they

Speaker: NA
Text: will be moving some amendments. We will not be supporting those amendments, which

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to put a roadblock on this legislation. We know Labor's commitment to infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: is untargeted and chaotic. We know that the member for Perth, who is in the chamber at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment, is the chief opponent of the Perth Freight Link project which will link the Kewdale-

Speaker: NA
Text: Welshpool industrial area with the ports. We know that the member for Grayndler made

Speaker: NA
Text: Gateway WA conditional on mining tax revenue which did not exist. We know that the record

Speaker: NA
Text: of the previous government on delivering broadband infrastructure in WA was the worst in

Speaker: NA
Text: the country. We also know that there was no interest or intention of funding the Manning on-

Speaker: NA
Text: ramp in my electorate of Swan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's position on this legislation would make new projects more difficult and it would

Speaker: NA
Text: hold back new infrastructure projects in Australia. The previous speaker, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Grayndler, also talked about cost-cutting analysis and processes and cost-benefit analysis. It

Speaker: NA
Text: just amazes me when you look at what they did with the NBN and the process they went

Speaker: NA
Text: through there on the back of a drinks coaster. He said there might be a panic sale of assets.

Speaker: NA
Text: But when Labor came in and they wanted to start some of what they called their infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: spending and kick things along, they looked at any project that they said was shovel ready.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was no cost-benefit analysis. They just went straight into that. The pink batts is another

Speaker: NA
Text: prime situation, with the royal commission currently looking at that. So how they can sit there

Speaker: NA
Text: and talk about the processes of how things should be done after their previous record of six

Speaker: NA
Text: years just amazes me.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition have increased the infrastructure spending by 55 per cent over the period to

Speaker: NA
Text: 2018-19 compared to under Labor, whereas the previous speaker said we had not. Labor had

Speaker: NA
Text: no great record on public transport. The former minister did not realise that 50 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: public transport in Australia is by bus on roads. Seventy per cent of all domestic passenger

Speaker: NA
Text: movements within Australia-by car or bus-occur on roads, whereas he was slating the

Speaker: NA
Text: current Prime Minister as not being interested in any rail infrastructure. The shadow minister

Speaker: NA
Text: says asset recycling will discourage investment in public transport. But as today's minister

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out just the other day, the Commonwealth is doing a lot of heavy lifting in road

Speaker: NA
Text: funding, allowing states to bring forward other public transport projects. In fact, since the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition was elected, the states have committed $25 billion to major public transport projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill establishes an Asset Recycling Fund of $5.9 billion initially. The Asset Recycling

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund, as outlined in this year's budget, is being established to provide incentives to states and

Speaker: NA
Text: territories to invest in new infrastructure projects that boost economic growth. The $5.9

Speaker: NA
Text: billion is sourced from uncommitted money in the Building Australia Fund and the Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Investment Fund. I note the government is committed to adding to the ARF over time,

Speaker: NA
Text: including through the proceeds of the sale of Medibank Private and with proceeds from any

Speaker: NA
Text: further privatisation initiatives. The ARF will support the Asset Recycling Initiative, which

Speaker: NA
Text: encourages the sale of brownfield assets such as ports or electricity companies with proven

Speaker: NA
Text: earnings to private sector investors, freeing up more funds for infrastructure projects. To

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage funds to be spent on infrastructure projects, the Commonwealth government will

Speaker: NA
Text: provide payments of 15 per cent of the sale price of privatised assets to state and territory

Speaker: NA
Text: governments, on the condition that the proceeds of the sales are reinvested in productivity-

Speaker: NA
Text: enhancing assets. The sale of ports in New South Wales and Queensland Motorways

Speaker: NA
Text: highlights the interest of the private sector to invest in brownfield assets.

Speaker: NA
Text: The consequential amendments will apply to the COAG Reform Fund Act 2008, the Future

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund Act 2006, the Nation-building Funds Act 2008 and the DisabilityCare Australia Fund

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 2013. These amendments will allow for the fund to be managed by the Future Fund

Speaker: NA
Text: Board of Guardians, who have an exemplary record of managing investment portfolios for the

Speaker: NA
Text: government, and for the funds to be distributed through the COAG Reform Fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: Delivering modern infrastructure is a key part of the government's Economic Action

Speaker: NA
Text: Strategy to boost economic growth, increase productivity and create thousands of new jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Overall, the 2013-14 budget unveiled the biggest ever spend for infrastructure in our nation's

Speaker: NA
Text: history: $50 billion. Our plan will leverage greater co-contributions from the state

Speaker: NA
Text: governments as well as, for the first time in WA, co-contributions from the private sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: Encouraging investment from the private sector is the best way to ensure that taxpayers get

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the most infrastructure advancements that their money can provide. By changing the way that

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure projects are financed through partnering with state and territory governments

Speaker: NA
Text: and leveraging private sector investment, Australia is set to receive $126 billion worth of

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in productivity-enhancing infrastructure over the next 10 years. This new

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure will help relieve congestion which is believed to be costing our economy $15

Speaker: NA
Text: billion a year. It will create jobs and tackle pollution. Investing in infrastructure is an

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Initiatives such as the ARF are of particular importance in my state of Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia,where the transition of the mining boom from production phase to development

Speaker: NA
Text: stage creates unique challenges. A key aspect of the coalition's budget is to roll out an

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure plan that adequately deals with this change and that creates jobs for the

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of construction workers, as well as the many engineers, designers and professionals

Speaker: NA
Text: who play an important role in the delivery of major projects. It would be irresponsible not to

Speaker: NA
Text: aid the creation of jobs that ensure these highly skilled and experienced people remain in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, contributing to our economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: With this in mind, the Western Australian Treasurer, Mike Nahan, spoke of his

Speaker: NA
Text: government's plans for an 'orderly program of assets sales' in the 8 May state budget. He

Speaker: NA
Text: outlined the state government's plans to consider the sale of a number of brownfield assets

Speaker: NA
Text: including the Kwinana bulk terminal and the Utah Point facility at Port Hedland. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer went on to note:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's continuing ownership of the Perth Market Authority, the TAB and the Water

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation's assets, such as its wastewater treatment plants, will also be reviewed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Revenue derived from the sale of these assets will be directed to two areas: the reductions of

Speaker: NA
Text: the state's debt levels and to contribute to the cost of new infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth and WA state government have a track record of working together to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver much-needed infrastructure to the people of Western Australia. In the 2013-14 budget

Speaker: NA
Text: the government continued this tradition by making a record $4.7 billion commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: funding infrastructure in WA. As I said before, some of the best examples of this co-operation

Speaker: NA
Text: lay within my electorate of Swan. Projects such as the Perth Freight Link and Gateway WA,

Speaker: NA
Text: both funded by the state and Commonwealth governments, will allow growing cities like

Speaker: NA
Text: Perth to move into the future comfortable in the knowledge that they have the capacity to

Speaker: NA
Text: support a growing population and continued high exports on their roads.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unlike those opposite we have committed to funding these projects without a mining tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Labor Party somehow thought they were funding these projects from a tax that did not

Speaker: NA
Text: raise any money. I know the member for Perth is in the chamber, and she has stated before

Speaker: NA
Text: that she does not support the mining tax and recognises that it disproportionately affects the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of WA. It is a pity that her colleagues do not agree with her.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Perth Freight Link carries a price tag of $1.6 billion, of which the Commonwealth will

Speaker: NA
Text: fund $925 million, the state government will cover the remaining 20 per cent of government

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions and the private sector will fund the remaining amount-approximately $400

Speaker: NA
Text: million. Despite economic research which shows that for every $1 invested in the Perth

Speaker: NA
Text: Freight Link it will return $5 in economic benefits, this project would never have been funded

Speaker: NA
Text: by a Labor government. Even now, after years of research showing that this project will

Speaker: NA
Text: increase productivity, create jobs and improve the road network, it is still not supported by

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite. In fact I see the member for Perth in the chamber, and she recently called this

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal 'a scandalous squandering of taxpayers' funds.' I would like to remind the member

Speaker: NA
Text: that the debt and deficit levels in this country have reached a point where the government is

Speaker: NA
Text: now paying over $1 billion dollars per month in interest. The interest bill paid by the

Speaker: NA
Text: government between 2010-11 and 2013-14 on gross debt is over $46 billion dollars. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government could have funded almost the entirety of its infrastructure package with what is

Speaker: NA
Text: wasted on interest payments. That is, in my opinion, a real squandering of taxpayers' funds.

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite ongoing protest from those opposite I am pleased to note that it's not only the WA

Speaker: NA
Text: state government who recognise the opportunity that ARF grants give them to invest in long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term productivity-enhancing projects. Just today the New South Wales Treasurer, Andrew

Speaker: NA
Text: Constance, announced in the New South Wales budget that a long-term lease of 49 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the state's electricity network assets will assist with funding a comprehensive package of new

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure programs. This package includes $400 million for the Parramatta light rail, $5.2

Speaker: NA
Text: billion for the North West Rail Link and an extra $100 million for the Hunter Infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund, to name a few. The budget includes significant investment in road, rail and public

Speaker: NA
Text: transport, further disproving the claims from those opposite that the coalition's plans will

Speaker: NA
Text: discourage investment in rail or public transport.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition promised to build the roads of the 21st century, and it is legislation such as

Speaker: NA
Text: this which will see us do just that for the benefit of our economy and our nation. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: assistant minister pointed out on 6 June, our infrastructure plan is not a GFC-style pink batts

Speaker: NA
Text: program or a school halls program but a well planned program about building productive

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure. Increased funding and the encouragement of investment in infrastructure will

Speaker: NA
Text: provide benefits in both the short and long term by creating jobs, easing congestion and

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring prosperity for generations to come.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know I have spoken in this place about Infrastructure in my electorate before. One in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular is the Manning Road on-ramp and Canning Bridge vision, about which I had a

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting with the Minister for Transport, Dean Nalder, last week. We discussed that and

Speaker: NA
Text: talked about opportunities that might arise from this particular infrastructure fund for things

Speaker: NA
Text: like a Manning Road on-ramp, which I know the member for Perth was supportive of many

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago. I congratulate her for that interest she took in that particular area, because it now is

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming a safety issue for many people in that part of the electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: I see that the member for Perth is going to speak next. Maybe she might like to tell us some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the reasons she is so focused on delivering infrastructure nobody wants, particularly the

Speaker: NA
Text: South Perth train station. That was built into the forward estimates in her time. As someone

Speaker: NA
Text: who lives in South Perth and for many of the other residents there, it is something that is not

Speaker: NA
Text: required and something that is not wanted. Something like the Manning Road on-ramp is

Speaker: NA
Text: what most of the people in my electorate of Swan would look forward to. If the opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: arises, it would be great if we saw that come to fruition in the near future.

Speaker: NA
Text: We heard from the previous speaker as well how supportive they are of infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: funding. I remember quoting from an executive from Perth Airport who initially spoke to the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister for infrastructure in the previous government when he was looking for funding for, at

Speaker: NA
Text: first, the Gateway project. The response from the minister at that particular time was not

Speaker: NA
Text: supportive; it was saying, 'So you guys want another handout.' That type of attitude from

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite is the reason why they need to support this bill and get on with the job.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend this bill to the House.

Speaker: Ms MACTIERNAN
Text: Perth) (12:43): So many fallacies, so many fantasies and only 15

Speaker: NA
Text: minutes in which to address them all. I want to start by strongly supporting the contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: by the member for Grayndler. He gave, I think, a very cogent analysis-

Speaker: Mr Snowdon
Text: Erudite.

Speaker: Ms MACTIERNAN
Text: erudite and cogent analysis of how this legislation is in fact going to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage suboptimal decisions on dealing with assets. I will get onto the specific questions

Speaker: NA
Text: of the member for Swan in a few minutes, but I just want to make this general statement that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is very easy for politicians. They want to sound like they are being financially sound and

Speaker: NA
Text: financially prudent and they talk about privatising assets and using those assets to reinvest

Speaker: NA
Text: without any real detailed analysis of where, in fact, that is going to take us financially,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not that stacks up when we analyse this. The member for Swan is running away,

Speaker: NA
Text: because he knows I am just going to tell him about all his errors on Roe Highway stage 8.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Irons interjecting-

Speaker: Ms MACTIERNAN
Text: It is true. I take great pride in the fact that after decades of stalling on

Speaker: NA
Text: Roe Highway I was minister when we completed Roe Highway stage 4, Roe Highway stage

Speaker: NA
Text: 5, Roe Highway stage 6 and Roe Highway stage 7. But we were not prepared to commit to

Speaker: NA
Text: Roe Highway stage 8, because it simply did not make sense. It did not make sense when we

Speaker: NA
Text: saw the trajectory of the Fremantle Port development moving to the outer harbour and given

Speaker: NA
Text: our understanding that the basin of the port was going to be at its final stage some time

Speaker: NA
Text: between 2017 and 2020 and that a new container facility south of Roe Highway would need

Speaker: NA
Text: to be built. So, quite frankly, not only is developing Roe Highway Stage 8 a problematic

Speaker: NA
Text: process environmentally, but economically it does not make sense. It does not make sense to

Speaker: NA
Text: spend $850 million on five kilometres of road going to a port that is actually going to be

Speaker: NA
Text: moving south within a year after the opening of that road.

Speaker: NA
Text: Putting that to one side, I want to talk about this issue of asset reinvestment and how easy it

Speaker: NA
Text: is to adopt a mantra that makes it sound like you are being commercially sensible and

Speaker: NA
Text: commercially sound when in fact you are being the exact opposite. Now, there are cases

Speaker: NA
Text: where it does make sense to sell assets. Very often government will acquire assets and engage

Speaker: NA
Text: in development simply because the market is not strong enough. In the early stages of a

Speaker: NA
Text: development, government may need to invest in something that subsequently, when the

Speaker: NA
Text: population grows and matures, is a function that can be quite properly supported by the

Speaker: NA
Text: private sector. But making decisions in this area requires very, very detailed analysis. It

Speaker: NA
Text: depends on where the numbers fall and what the risks are in each individual case. First of all

Speaker: NA
Text: we have to look at the actual price received. When you sell something off, it is not money for

Speaker: NA
Text: jam. You are actually selling an asset. And quite often we see cash based reports in the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: that will show the sale of an asset as improving performance. We have all of this additional

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue that has come in because we have sold the asset, even though we may have sold that

Speaker: NA
Text: asset at a very poor price. Even when we are doing accounting on an accrual basis we might

Speaker: NA
Text: see a positive result where we get more than book value for an asset, even though that is in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact far less than its actual value. And hopefully I will have some time to tell the story of the

Speaker: NA
Text: great failed privatisation of the Perth freight network.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: We also have to look properly at the revenues lost and make a rational assessment as to

Speaker: NA
Text: whether it is cheaper to borrow than to lose the income stream concerned. Interestingly, the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Swan was going on about the level of debt and using the raw numbers of debt.

Speaker: NA
Text: That really has become a disingenuous obsession of the government. But we know that in

Speaker: NA
Text: making an intelligent assessment of where an economy is, where a government is, we look at

Speaker: NA
Text: net debt-to-revenue ratios. You do not just look at debt; you look at debt to revenue. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, if you are selling off your revenue-generating assets you might be reducing your net

Speaker: NA
Text: debt but you are also reducing your revenue. So you do need to make a careful calculation

Speaker: NA
Text: about whether or not the revenue you lose is actually going to be properly compensated for.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Western Australian government is now talking about selling the Utah Point Berth in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Port Hedland port. The rate of return on capital across the Port Hedland port is about 14.2 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. We do not have access to the more detailed information, but if we put the evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: together the rate of return on revenue in Utah Point would be much higher than that. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the facility that is really bringing home the bacon for the Port Hedland Port Authority. But

Speaker: NA
Text: even if you accept it at 14.2 per cent, compare that to the current state bond rates, which vary

Speaker: NA
Text: from about 3.75 per cent to eight per cent. We could actually borrow a lot less than the

Speaker: NA
Text: sacrifice of that income that we are getting from Utah Point. So, we are getting a much higher

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of return than we are paying in interest. If you are being sensible, if you are being really

Speaker: NA
Text: prudent, you will say to yourself, 'Does it really make sense for us to sell this?'

Speaker: NA
Text: For those reasons, we are deeply concerned that these privatisations be subject to a proper

Speaker: NA
Text: cost-benefit analysis so that for each one of those we do a detailed and proper analysis of just

Speaker: NA
Text: what that return will be and how it is going to impact on the net debt-to-revenue ratio rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than the financially simplistic and irresponsible approach of just focusing on the debt level.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are also particularly concerned that the 15 per cent bonus in itself-the supplement that is

Speaker: NA
Text: on offer by the federal government, and which does not enhance the amount of money

Speaker: NA
Text: available for infrastructure, because that could easily be given by way of a grant-has the

Speaker: NA
Text: potential to be a great distortion in itself. And it has the potential in part to become a subsidy

Speaker: NA
Text: to the private sector as state governments are prepared to discount the price in order to attract

Speaker: NA
Text: the supplement. We stress that the amendments we are putting up are very much designed to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that we have a much more economically rational discussion about the assets that are

Speaker: NA
Text: being proposed for sale, and whether or not that is in fact in the best interests of the taxpayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: But I think it is also important to understand that the potential risks of privatisation go well

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond the problem of ensuring that we get a good return on assets and that we do not

Speaker: NA
Text: unnecessarily sacrifice highly profitable revenue streams for a short-term boost in debt levels

Speaker: NA
Text: to enable brand-new projects to be announced. I want to talk about a couple of facilities, one

Speaker: NA
Text: of which is the Utah Bulk Loading Facility, which I referred to a bit earlier. This facility was

Speaker: NA
Text: built by the government in the Port Hedland port with the aim of providing a facility for the

Speaker: NA
Text: junior miners. For those who are less familiar with Port Hedland, it is a port that

Speaker: NA
Text: understandably has traditionally been dominated by BHP. Like many ports in WA, there has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a bit of an unfortunate history in terms of access by third parties to this infrastructure,

Speaker: NA
Text: even though the infrastructure might notionally be controlled by government. When FMG

Speaker: NA
Text: was attempting to become a player in the iron ore industry, BHP very much played hardball to

Speaker: NA
Text: keep FMG out. With the strategic intervention of the then government, FMG got its place in

Speaker: NA
Text: the sun, but, alas, FMG did much the same thing to the entrants attempting to come in behind

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: it. The development of a facility like the Utah bulk-loading facility was in part a way of

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with that.

Speaker: NA
Text: My concern is that this facility, even if it is sold for a good price and we get a good return

Speaker: NA
Text: on it, could fall into the hands of someone who was in fact ultimately a player and who had a

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic interest in keeping third parties out, and we have certainly seen this happen in the

Speaker: NA
Text: grain freight industry. Whilst that might be to the economic benefit of that company it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: going to be of economic benefit to the region, to Western Australia and to Australia. It is very

Speaker: NA
Text: important to understand this, particularly in relation to ports. The ports on the west coast,

Speaker: NA
Text: where we have very difficult marine conditions, are located where they are because they are

Speaker: NA
Text: the optimal places to site safe berthage. It is not like building a supermarket. If you want to

Speaker: NA
Text: compete you cannot just open one down the road. It is very difficult and complex to find a site

Speaker: NA
Text: where it is cost-effective to build such a facility. We really need to understand the long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: implications for regional development from these privatisations.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that the member for Swan talked about the state treasurer's proposal to sell Kwinana

Speaker: NA
Text: Bulk Terminal. This is pretty incredible given Mr Barnett's comment just before the last

Speaker: NA
Text: election that the one thing he would not be privatising is the Fremantle ports, and of course

Speaker: NA
Text: the Kwinana outer harbour is one of the Fremantle ports.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to talk briefly about a classic failed privatisation and how the need to be seen to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring down the debt levels, but clearly not looking holistically at the budget, can be a

Speaker: NA
Text: complete disaster. We had a situation in the late 1990s where another wheat farmer who had

Speaker: NA
Text: control of the transport portfolio spent a motza on roads leading everywhere. The budget was

Speaker: NA
Text: in great crisis and he came up with this great proposal to sell off the freight rail network. They

Speaker: NA
Text: said they would sell off the grain freight network and make heaps of money so that they could

Speaker: NA
Text: continue building more roads. We warned at the time that this would lead to cherry picking,

Speaker: NA
Text: with a great deal of focus by the private provider on the tier one lines, those lines on which

Speaker: NA
Text: there was a great deal of freight, whereas the smaller lines would basically be left to rot and

Speaker: NA
Text: not properly maintained, and ultimately the operator would walk away from those lines. We

Speaker: NA
