Text: were assured that that would never happen, but we did not believe it. Ultimately, everything

Speaker: NA
Text: we predicted has in fact happened. The amount of money we got for the sale of this asset did

Speaker: NA
Text: not even cover the book value. So there was in fact no actual net benefit at all asset-wise to

Speaker: NA
Text: the state. But we had a situation that has required subsequent governments, federal and state,

Speaker: NA
Text: to invest $360 million of taxpayers' money in an attempt to keep the freight network going

Speaker: NA
Text: and, in particular, to keep the tier three lines going. Much to the chagrin of the farmers we see

Speaker: NA
Text: that freight coming off the rail and onto the roads is creating mega road hazards and making

Speaker: NA
Text: many country towns and outer metropolitan roads very unsafe, requiring vast sums of money

Speaker: NA
Text: be spent. So it was a massive result of cost-shifting. It was a short-term political fix that over

Speaker: NA
Text: a decade later the people of Western Australia are still picking up the tab for. I urge the

Speaker: NA
Text: government to support these amendments. They are absolutely critical to getting a proper

Speaker: NA
Text: economic understanding of where we are going with privatisation.

Speaker: Mr TAYLOR
Text: Hume) (12:59): Being from a rural electorate and from a rural upbringing,

Speaker: NA
Text: off-road is a term I use often. Like many popular words, its meaning has been distorted over

Speaker: NA
Text: time. It is no longer just a descriptor for being away from the main road. Its new meaning is

Speaker: NA
Text: more along the lines of rough and rugged, pumped up with adrenaline, hooliganish and out of

Speaker: NA
Text: control. So off-road is a term I would like to use to describe the former Labor government. I

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: would comfortably use that term in that context. Not only did they go off-roading at the wheel

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian economy for six long years, they blew the tyres, cooked the radiator, stalled

Speaker: NA
Text: in top gear and ended up floating down the proverbial stream.

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite the glossy ads, we all know about the damage bill when you go off-road. The

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge before us is to get our economy back onto the straight and narrow. While the way

Speaker: NA
Text: forward is achievable, there is a major shift needed. The coalition budget before the House is

Speaker: NA
Text: a contribute-and-build budget. Today I want to talk about the build. The government is

Speaker: NA
Text: establishing an asset recycling fund to build the finances to support historically high

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure investment for Australia. Under this legislation, financial incentives will be

Speaker: NA
Text: provided to the states and territories to sell existing assets and reinvest the proceeds into

Speaker: NA
Text: productive economic infrastructure and into providing the additional investment dollars to

Speaker: NA
Text: fast-track nationally significant projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: At this time in our history, there is no question that infrastructure is absolutely critical. The

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure backlog in Australia has been variously estimated at somewhere between $455

Speaker: NA
Text: billion and $770 billion. These are numbers big enough, almost, to rival Labor's debt burden.

Speaker: NA
Text: A 2012 Infrastructure Australia report to COAG identified over $70 billion worth of priority

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure projects that we should be moving on immediately. They also identified that we

Speaker: NA
Text: are falling behind on maintaining our existing road and rail.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said in the House quite recently, there are two very good reasons why we need high-

Speaker: NA
Text: quality infrastructure and significant infrastructure investment. First, we are facing a dramatic

Speaker: NA
Text: slowdown in mining investment in this country. We are seeing mining investment, which had

Speaker: NA
Text: risen from something like $30 billion up to $120 billion, falling away dramatically because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the policies of the previous Labor government. We have frugal consumers and we have a high

Speaker: NA
Text: dollar. Without infrastructure investment, we will not, in coming years, see the sort of growth

Speaker: NA
Text: and prosperity we need. The second reason is that we face a productivity crisis. Productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: growth has slowed dramatically in recent years. We know that capital productivity is the heart

Speaker: NA
Text: of the problem. We are not making enough investments and we are not making investments in

Speaker: NA
Text: the right capital projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: So Australia faces a significant challenge over the coming years. Whilst our exports are

Speaker: NA
Text: growing strongly and are set to continue to grow strongly, we will need to lift our rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity growth if we are to continue to enjoy the types of increases in our standard of

Speaker: NA
Text: living that we have grown used to. In a speech in November 2013, the Deputy Governor of

Speaker: NA
Text: the RBA, Philip Lowe, emphasised the potential for infrastructure investment to address

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's declining productivity growth. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: … the Australian economy faces a substantial challenge. Over the next decade or so, if we are to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve anything like the type of growth in real per capita income that we have become used to, then a

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial increase in productivity growth will be required. We can no longer depend on a rising terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of trade and favourable demographics to make us richer. If this lift in productivity growth does not take

Speaker: NA
Text: place, then we will need to adjust to some combination of slower growth in real wages, slower growth

Speaker: NA
Text: in profits, smaller gains in asset prices and slower growth in government revenues and services – in

Speaker: NA
Text: short, slower growth in our average living standard. So the debate about productivity should not be seen

Speaker: NA
Text: as an esoteric one just for economists. Productivity growth matters and it matters a lot to our future

Speaker: NA
Text: living standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Lowe went on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: In the years ahead, it is unlikely that Australia's comparative advantage will lie in the production of

Speaker: NA
Text: standardised mass-produced manufactured goods for the global market. Instead, we have tremendous

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities in a range of more specialised high value-added goods and services, where it is the quality

Speaker: NA
Text: of our ideas and the quality of our execution that is the key. Whether or not we can seize these

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities depends critically on our human capital and our infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Later in his speech, he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The benefits of investment in transportation infrastructure are well known. Some of these are quite

Speaker: NA
Text: obvious, while others are more difficult to see, although no less important. Among the more obvious

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits is a reduction in travel times and costs for both people and goods. There can also be favourable

Speaker: NA
Text: social impacts through reducing travel stress and increasing the connectedness of communities. And

Speaker: NA
Text: there are environmental benefits as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, Labor did little to address these issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that good infrastructure investment needs to be depoliticised and we know it

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to focus on costs and benefits. That is something that the Labor government failed

Speaker: NA
Text: dismally to achieve. We have heard in this House that only 14 per cent of Labor's stimulus

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure was spent on productive infrastructure. We saw that, of the $80 billion of

Speaker: NA
Text: stimulus expenditure, none of it-not one dollar of it-went to Infrastructure Australia for

Speaker: NA
Text: approval. We need transparency, rigour and independence in our infrastructure investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Productivity Commission's 2014 report, Public infrastructure, stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: There are numerous examples of inferior project selection and inadequate assessment of the costs and

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits of public infrastructure projects … In particular, government decisions can become politicised

Speaker: NA
Text: and may be based on inadequate information and assessment of the costs and benefits of projects …

Speaker: NA
Text: Inferior investment decisions are not unique to governments … However, when the government makes

Speaker: NA
Text: mistakes regarding large public infrastructure projects, the consequences are felt more broadly by the

Speaker: NA
Text: community and taxpayers, often for long periods of time.

Speaker: NA
Text: In March last year, Fairfax business journalist Adele Ferguson authored an editorial in The

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney Morning Herald in which she discussed Infrastructure Australia. She said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: ALP government had created Infrastructure Australia to 'eliminate pork barrelling by creating

Speaker: NA
Text: a priority list of infrastructure projects based on a cost-benefit analysis and advising on major

Speaker: NA
Text: policy reforms'. However, we know that Infrastructure Australia was effectively marginalised

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Labor-Green government, as most famously evidenced by Labor's pre-election

Speaker: NA
Text: approval of the Parramatta to Epping Rail Link project-which did not feature on IA's list of

Speaker: NA
Text: priority tasks.

Speaker: NA
Text: In an article in The Australian in February this year, Deputy Prime Minister Warren Truss

Speaker: NA
Text: wrote:

Speaker: NA
Text: WHEN Anthony Albanese set up Infrastructure Australia in 2008 he made it his personal lapdog,

Speaker: NA
Text: largely answerable to him.

Speaker: NA
Text: IA was sidelined on any real decision-making, forced to play catch-up and chase its tail to justify

Speaker: NA
Text: projects Labor had already announced without consulting its expert advisory body.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's road and rail funding projects, its big-spending response to the global financial crisis, its

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure election promises, were all announced without being fully assessed by IA.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need look no further than the NBN for a clear example of poor infrastructure investment,

Speaker: NA
Text: with a significant impact on the government balance sheet. There was no cost-benefit analysis

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: and we saw extreme politicisation of investment in infrastructure. Indeed, we know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: decision was made on the back of a serviette.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the absence of an intervention from this government, state under-investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure is inevitable. As the Productivity Commission report I referred to earlier notes,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth has a comparatively wider and more efficient tax base, despite heavier

Speaker: NA
Text: levels of investment from the states and territories. This has already led to large transfers from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth to the lower levels of government, for the purpose of financing

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure. As an October 2013 report from Moody's demonstrates, state and territory debt

Speaker: NA
Text: levels have ballooned since 2008 and are projected to increase into the foreseeable future.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will further limit the funding that state governments can provide for infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is clear that the experts endorse our infrastructure focused budget. On budget night,

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure Partnerships Australia said:

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a very strong budget, because it makes difficult revenue and expenditure decisions, allowing

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra to fund an unprecedented $50 billion investment in economic infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chief Executive Brendan Lyon also commented that over the forward estimates the Abbott

Speaker: NA
Text: government's total infrastructure investment represents around a $9 billion increase compared

Speaker: NA
Text: to the last five years. He noted:

Speaker: NA
Text: The states will always have a central role in funding and providing public infrastructure, but with high

Speaker: NA
Text: levels of debt and substantial operating deficits, a higher and sustained level of national investment

Speaker: NA
Text: alongside the states is warranted.

Speaker: NA
Text: So it is clear what the experts say. It is clear that they are on our side.

Speaker: NA
Text: We recognise that there are still challenges ahead. Philip Lowe rightly points out that a key

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge is to ensure there are strong systems of governance in place so that money is spent

Speaker: NA
Text: wisely. That is why we restructured Infrastructure Australia. The second key challenge is the

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing funding of projects beyond the large expenditure we committed to in the budget. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: no use identifying infrastructure projects with large potential gains if a way cannot be found

Speaker: NA
Text: to finance them.

Speaker: NA
Text: The financing challenge arises not because of a lack of money available to invest in

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure. Many private-sector investors tell us-tell me-that there is plenty of money

Speaker: NA
Text: sitting on the sidelines waiting to be invested in infrastructure assets. The issue is more a

Speaker: NA
Text: reluctance of investors to take on the construction and patronage risks and/or the difficulties

Speaker: NA
Text: of charging for the use of infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Looking forward, we need to find a sustainable way in which to finance our infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: needs over the long term. Regardless of whether it is the private or public sector doing the

Speaker: NA
Text: financing, it is likely to be easier if we consider different options for pricing and funding

Speaker: NA
Text: transport infrastructure. User-pay models have emerged for all other utilities-water,

Speaker: NA
Text: electricity and telecommunications. We need to seriously consider broader user-pay models

Speaker: NA
Text: for all roads, with hypothecation of revenues not just for roads in general but also, perhaps,

Speaker: NA
Text: for the owner of the specific road. The technology is now available, and the benefits are clear.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only will this increase investment in high-growth and congested roads but also it will

Speaker: NA
Text: better regulate road use, encouraging commuters to find alternatives when there is significant

Speaker: NA
Text: congestion.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: In a report for Infrastructure Partnerships Australia, Deloitte has shown how this can work

Speaker: NA
Text: and, most importantly, how it will help regional areas, despite claims by some to the contrary.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a society, we have a lot riding on finding a way to pay for the infrastructure we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: boost our productivity and improve our living standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those of us who come from regional communities know that connectivity is king, and

Speaker: NA
Text: good connectivity comes from good communications infrastructure and good transport

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure. In my electorate of Hume we saw a complete failure of investment during

Speaker: NA
Text: those Labor years. The NBN failure is well known. It has been talked about at length in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House. We have also seen transport infrastructure-investment failure. The Hume Highway is

Speaker: NA
Text: now basically a conveyor belt of trucks in the evenings. We see the B-doubles going from

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne to Sydney and back, because rail has failed.

Speaker: NA
Text: For many years, since about 2007, in fact, we have seen the Labor government fail to

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficiently invest in rail infrastructure on that corridor. We as a government have said we

Speaker: NA
Text: want to address that. We want to address that with our $300 million investment in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne-Brisbane rail link and with further investment on the coastal corridor. That will

Speaker: NA
Text: take trucks off the road, it will support a better drive-a safer drive-and will mean fewer

Speaker: NA
Text: trucks on the Hume Highway. It will have the benefit of creating regional freight hubs

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the grain growers in the wheat belt of NSW, this will give many options they do not

Speaker: NA
Text: have today. They will be able to send their wheat to Newcastle, Port Kembla, Brisbane or

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne. The Barton Highway is also a failure of the previous Labor government. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: upping investment in the highway, including development of a staged duplication plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, our significant investments in black-spot and Roads to Recovery programs are

Speaker: NA
Text: important responses to a dire infrastructure backlog.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian public deserve better. We are no longer crammed into the back seat of some

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of juvenile joy ride like we were under the Labor government. The grown-ups are back

Speaker: NA
Text: at the wheel. We know that good infrastructure investment needs to be de-politicised, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: know it also needs to focus on costs and benefits. This is something the Labor government

Speaker: NA
Text: failed to do. Through an Asset Recycling Fund we will build the finances to support this

Speaker: NA
Text: government's record package of infrastructure investment. Five billion dollars has been

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to provide financial incentives over five years to the states and territories, to sell

Speaker: NA
Text: assets and reinvest those proceeds. This will leverage a significant increase in private sector

Speaker: NA
Text: investment and create massive new opportunities for investors. I fully commend this bill to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House.

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: Scullin) (13:14): In rising to make a contribution to debate on the Asset

Speaker: NA
Text: Recycling Fund Bill 2014 and the Asset Recycling Fund (Consequential Amendments) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2014, I will start by reflecting on two aspects of the contribution of the previous speaker, the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Hume. He referred to the position of the experts, in terms of this government's

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to infrastructure provisions, as being 'clear'. I agree with him in so far as that, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the conclusion he seeks to draw is simply not tenable. What the experts want out of a

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth government's approach to infrastructure provision is transparency and

Speaker: NA
Text: adherence to a strong evidence base which meets the productivity challenge of Australia. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is little in evidence under this government, as I and other Labor speakers have said on many

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions since the election when we have debated infrastructure in this chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I also note that the member for Hume did effectively set out, I believe, the scale of the

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure backlog we confront in Australia today and its relationship to the productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: crisis and challenge we must confront head-on if we are to preserve our standard of living.

Speaker: NA
Text: Insofar as he made those remarks in setting out the challenge, I am entirely in agreement with

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Hume. But, in agreeing with him in that regard, I see a very different path

Speaker: NA
Text: forward for the role of the Commonwealth with respect to infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have spoken regularly in this place about Commonwealth spending in infrastructure. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is partly because I represent an outer suburban electorate, an electorate that requires

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable investment in infrastructure across all asset classes. I am very pleased to say that

Speaker: NA
Text: under Labor it received its fair share. I have also spoken about Commonwealth spending in

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure because I believe the Commonwealth government has a vital role, a key role, in

Speaker: NA
Text: investing in the infrastructure of our cities-a role this government appears to be in denial

Speaker: NA
Text: about, even though it goes to the very heart of the productivity challenge that we face, as well

Speaker: NA
Text: as to pressing concerns about liveability, sustainability and of course equity.

Speaker: NA
Text: More generally, I am concerned to see Australia, through the Commonwealth, secure our

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure future in real rather than rhetorical terms, and delivering, not passing the buck

Speaker: NA
Text: to other tiers of government. In addressing these bills-I should make clear that I am also in

Speaker: NA
Text: support of both amendments foreshadowed by the member for Grayndler-I believe it is

Speaker: NA
Text: important to place them in their proper context: how our self-described infrastructure Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister is going about meeting this great productivity challenge Australia faces.

Speaker: NA
Text: I now turn to the provisions of the bills before us in turn. I note that the purpose of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Asset Recycling Fund Bill is to establish the Asset Recycling Fund as a dedicated investment

Speaker: NA
Text: vehicle with a focus on providing financial assistance and incentives to states and territories to

Speaker: NA
Text: create new productive infrastructure. The purpose of its companion bill is to make the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequential amendments required to other statutes to enable the effective operation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: fund. In short, these bills provide an incentive to privatise state or territory owned assets and

Speaker: NA
Text: to recycle the proceeds into new productive infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: While it has been said that this is the only recycling members of this government are

Speaker: NA
Text: inclined to support, I should point out that this clearly is not so. They are more than happy, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Grayndler has set out, to recycle and rebrand Labor infrastructure and

Speaker: NA
Text: investment as their own work. Of course, to talk of recycling in this context is another

Speaker: NA
Text: example of this government's recourse to Orwellian language. When we talk about recycling,

Speaker: NA
Text: we are of course talking about privatisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth contribution is to provide the state or territory with an additional 15

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of the reinvested sale proceeds of the cost of infrastructure projects. These bills are

Speaker: NA
Text: the vehicle for putting into effect the National Partnership Agreement on Asset Recycling,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was signed by all state and territory leaders in May this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the main bill the fund will receive an initial contribution of $5.9 billion at

Speaker: NA
Text: commencement, comprising uncommitted funds from the Building Australia Fund and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Education Investment Fund. Both these funds were formed by the former Labor government

Speaker: NA
Text: to fund land transport and education infrastructure projects respectively. So the money in this

Speaker: NA
Text: fund is of course Labor money. Under both of these Labor funds, projects to be funded by the

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio minister were subject to recommendations by an advisory board as to their merit,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: and crucially this requirement is not duplicated in the legislation before us now. This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: major omission and a major concern.

Speaker: NA
Text: Privatisation is, to me, far from a self-evident good, although I should point out that Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: is not opposed in all circumstances to the privatisation of certain public assets, and we will

Speaker: NA
Text: consider and have considered proposals on a case-by-case basis. We will support privatisation

Speaker: NA
Text: only where it is in the public interest to do so following proper independent scrutiny of this

Speaker: NA
Text: process. A case in point is Victorian Labor's proposed leasehold privatisation of the Port of

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne in order to fund vital transport infrastructure to replace one-third of Melbourne's

Speaker: NA
Text: level crossings with underpasses or overpasses to increase safety. I am personally very

Speaker: NA
Text: comfortable in supporting this decision. As alluded to earlier, clearly Labor governments of

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia and the ACT have signed the Asset Recycling Initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: As far as Commonwealth spending on infrastructure goes, in government Labor clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: leads the way, as of course it should. We saw this in the funding of nation-building

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure projects, including setting governance standards that allow decisions to be made

Speaker: NA
Text: in the national interest, not on the whims of the National Party or indeed narrow electoral

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns more broadly. Labor lifted infrastructure spending at the Commonwealth to record

Speaker: NA
Text: levels and, under the previous government, saw Australia rise from 20th in the OECD in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of spending on infrastructure as a proportion of GDP to first. We did so without

Speaker: NA
Text: privatisation funding this and without passing the buck to other levels of government. On a

Speaker: NA
Text: per capita basis, I note we were talking about an increase in funding from $132 per Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: This is not a debate about privatisation or spending on infrastructure. At issue here are

Speaker: NA
Text: questions of process, oversight and governance. All of these factors are essential in ensuring

Speaker: NA
Text: that the infrastructure that Australia needs gets built and that Australian taxpayers now and in

Speaker: NA
Text: the future get good value for money in contributing to a more productive economy and

Speaker: NA
Text: enhanced liveability.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's mechanism for achieving these goals was the creation of Infrastructure Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: the purpose of which has been to research and rank proposed infrastructure projects based on

Speaker: NA
Text: their potential to add to our economic productivity. This was the implementation of an

Speaker: NA
Text: election commitment, of course. The current governance arrangements are for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure Australia Council, the remit of which is set out in the Infrastructure Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: Act, to provide advice to the minister. Additionally, the Infrastructure Coordinator was

Speaker: NA
Text: established to assist the council in the performance of its functions. The previous minister

Speaker: NA
Text: made decisions based on advice of this independent panel. The point of this process was to

Speaker: NA
Text: depoliticise infrastructure spending and importantly also to decouple the infrastructure cycle

Speaker: NA
Text: from the all too short political cycle-the long term and the short term-and to establish a

Speaker: NA
Text: framework, an integrated policy approach for the provision of infrastructure in a strategic

Speaker: NA
Text: manner. This is what I believe nation building should look like. It is Labor's approach.

Speaker: NA
Text: One major piece of infrastructure that Labor committed to and budgeted for was the

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne Metro rail link. This was part of an overall investment in urban rail that

Speaker: NA
Text: represented more investment in urban rail infrastructure than that of all of Labor's federal

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessors combined since Federation-over $13½ billion. Stage 1 of this project was

Speaker: NA
Text: identified by Infrastructure Australia as ready to proceed. Infrastructure Australia describes

Speaker: NA
Text: the project as:

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: … a project that is expected to shape Melbourne's future transport network and land use patterns. The

Speaker: NA
Text: preferred option presented could achieve up to 30 per cent capacity increase in the urban passenger rail

Speaker: NA
Text: network however the project cost is approximately equal to the benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not just Infrastructure Australia and federal and state Labor who are in favour of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne Metro proceeding. Tourism & Transport Forum Chief Executive Ken Morrison

Speaker: NA
Text: has said that the Melbourne Metro project needed to be funded more swiftly, stating:

Speaker: NA
Text: We urge the government to look at ways to fund the project so it can commence as soon as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee for Melbourne Chief Executive Officer Kate Roffey has also backed Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: Metro and urged its urgent funding, saying:

Speaker: NA
Text: … we believe waiting until the end of the decade is too long.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is about ensuring that taxpayers get value for money and making sure the projects that

Speaker: NA
Text: are the most necessary go ahead. It would be a tragedy for Melbourne if the Melbourne Metro

Speaker: NA
Text: is replaced by a half-baked option, which appears likely to be the case should the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria not get the government they deserve at the end of this year and not get support from a

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth government that is prepared to invest in our cities and especially urban

Speaker: NA
Text: passenger rail.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Melbourne we are seeing what happens when this process is turned around, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: what can only be described as bizarre announcement by the Prime Minister of funding for the

Speaker: NA
Text: East West Link, or perhaps the east-east tollway, as it should be described. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has not seen, and as far as I am aware no Victorians have seen, a business case for

Speaker: NA
Text: this proposal. The decision to fund roads like the east-east tollway breaches another one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's so-called fundamental election promises-too many broken to count by now.

Speaker: NA
Text: This promise was to subject any infrastructure project worth more than $100 million to cost-

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit analysis. For this project, the Prime Minister will give the Victorian government

Speaker: NA
Text: advance payments of $1.5 billion by the end of this month, despite having produced no

Speaker: NA
Text: business case and despite the fact that $1 billion of this money is for stage 2, construction of

Speaker: NA
Text: which will not begin until 2015-16 and for which we do not even have a map. This breaches

Speaker: NA
Text: another commitment to refuse to hand out money for states unless milestones on planning and

Speaker: NA
Text: construction have been met. This is an absurdity that Labor's amendments would prevent.

Speaker: NA
Text: A secret report prepared by the construction firm Veitch Lister for the Linking Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: Authority in June 2003 obtained by The Age found that East West Link will trigger huge

Speaker: NA
Text: increases in traffic on key sections of Melbourne's road network with parts of Hoddle Street,

Speaker: NA
Text: already a disaster, amongst the worst hit. The modelling reveals hundreds of thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: motorists face more rather than less congestion as a direct result of this $6 billion to $8 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: project. Melbourne University planning expert Alan March was quoted as saying the money

Speaker: NA
Text: being spent on the road would be better invested in public transport, health or education. Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: March warned that international evidence suggested that such projects tended to add to traffic

Speaker: NA
Text: problems over the long term. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: All of the evidence all over the world suggests these sorts of projects are unlikely to fix things in the

Speaker: NA
Text: longer term … It is as if the government is determined to press ahead with a truck-based transport

Speaker: NA
Text: system at all costs irrespective of the impact on the rest of the city in the longer term.

Speaker: NA
Text: I could not agree more. Why cannot money from the fund established by these bills go

Speaker: NA
Text: towards urban rail? Perhaps this is yet another reason that oversight of infrastructure spending

Speaker: NA
Text: has been reduced and politicisation increased. I remember the Prime Minister wrote in his

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: book Battlelines of 'kings in their cars', and so presumably the rest of us are peasants on

Speaker: NA
Text: public transport to our Prime Minister. The then Leader of the Opposition and now Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister made some strange remarks before the election in asserting that 'the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: had no history of funding urban rail' and that 'it is important that we stick to our knitting-and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth is knitting when it comes to funding infrastructure such as roads.' This

Speaker: NA
Text: sums up this government's approach to this debate. It is just a triumph of the 'I reckon' school

Speaker: NA
Text: of public policy making, with the two coalition parties working hand in hand-the

Speaker: NA
Text: ideologically blinkered, who cannot abide public transport, and their friends in the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party, the party that brought us regional rorts. We saw that under Howard and we will see it

Speaker: NA
Text: again. The Australasian Railways Association Chief Executive Officer Brian Nye described

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Abbott as demonstrating that he 'simply doesn't understand public transport.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCCormack interjecting-

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: Clearly, the Prime Minister is not alone amongst members opposite. Mr Nye

Speaker: NA
Text: also said that this refusal to fund urban rail 'should send shivers down the spine of commuters

Speaker: NA
Text: everywhere'-as it does, in Scullin and I am sure right across Australia's cities and towns. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Nye pointed out that public transport use has almost doubled in Australian cities in the past

Speaker: NA
Text: decade and that more investment is needed to keep our cities from grinding to a standstill over

Speaker: NA
Text: the next 20 years. Grinding to a standstill-what would that mean for the productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge the member for Hume spoke so eloquently about only a few minutes ago? Mr Nye

Speaker: NA
Text: asked:

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly not everyone can afford an inner city car parking space, so how does Mr Abbott propose our

Speaker: NA
Text: growing population will get to work each day if he refuses to fund public transport?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCCormack interjecting-

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: That is a good question, and it is very disappointing that the parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: secretary has no interest in the circumstances of four out of five Australians and more than 84

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of our economic activity. This is a very good question. In particular, it is a good

Speaker: NA
Text: question for the constituents of Scullin, Lalor, Makin, Newcastle, Wills and Chisholm-

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly outer suburban constituents who have little option other than to drive, because

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs are increasingly located near the CBD at the moment, despite the tight financial

Speaker: NA
Text: constraints many of them live under. I note recent work has highlighted the cost-of-living

Speaker: NA
Text: impact. The cost-of-living impact of effectively requiring outer suburban residents to drive is

Speaker: NA
Text: something that the members opposite were very keen to talk about in opposition but they have

Speaker: NA
Text: little to say about it in government.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, it is vital that both amendments proposed by the opposition are supported.

Speaker: NA
Text: This would go some way to bridging the massive chasm between the rhetoric of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's position on infrastructure and the dismal reality that is condemning Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: cities and Australia's productivity more generally to a second-best future.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. BC Scott): It being almost 1:30pm, the debate is

Speaker: NA
Text: interrupted in accordance with standing order 43. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.

Speaker: NA
Text: STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS

Speaker: NA
Text: Netball Australia Grand Final

Speaker: Ms RYAN
Text: Lalor-Opposition Whip) (13:29): I stand here today proudly wearing my

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian navy blue and my Vixens' scarf. There is much excitement about a rugby league

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: match happening tonight, but the real state-on-state action will happen in Melbourne on

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunday. Melbourne Vixens, led by the great Bianca Chatfield, will face off against

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland Firebirds, led by Laura Geitz, in the ANZ Championship netball grand final. I

Speaker: NA
Text: wish both teams all the best in what will be a great display of Aussie netball. Members might

Speaker: NA
Text: like to note that the Australian clubs have dispensed with the clubs from across the ditch to

Speaker: NA
Text: create this Aussie final. I wish both teams all the best, but will be giving my considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: verbal support to the Vixens to bring home the trophy and the Victorian bragging rights. I

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot think of a better way for our Aussie captain Laura Geitz and vice captain Bianca

Speaker: NA
Text: Chatfield to prepare for the Commonwealth Games, where they will join forces to fend off

Speaker: NA
Text: those Kiwis. Go Vixens!

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. BC Scott): For the benefit of the House, Laura Geitz

Speaker: NA
Text: grew up in the electorate of Maranoa and went to school in Allora. You know who I am

Speaker: NA
Text: backing tonight.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bowel Cancer Awareness Month

Speaker: Mr ALEXANDER
Text: Bennelong) (13:30): I rise to inform the house about Bowel Cancer

Speaker: NA
Text: Awareness Month: when 'small actions create a big movement'. Bowel cancer is the second

Speaker: NA
Text: most common cancer in Australia-and our second biggest cancer killer, claiming the lives of

Speaker: NA
Text: 77 Australians every week. We have one of the highest rates of bowel cancer in the world,

Speaker: NA
Text: with around 15,000 people diagnosed every year. This disease does not discriminate on

Speaker: NA
Text: gender or age; however, early detection of bowel cancer does save lives, if detected early

Speaker: NA
Text: enough. Unfortunately the five-year survival rate in Australia is just 66 per cent compared to

Speaker: NA
Text: around 90 per cent for melanoma, breast and prostate cancers.

Speaker: NA
Text: To draw attention to bowel cancer, the iconic facade of Old Parliament House is this week

Speaker: NA
Text: being illuminated red and green, the colours of Bowel Cancer Australia's apple logo and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bowel Cancer Awareness Month ribbon. This disease is preventable, treatable and beatable,

Speaker: NA
Text: but people need to know about it. Today is Red Apple Day. I urge everyone in this place to

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase a Red Apple pin and munch on a red apple-full of fibre and great for your

Speaker: NA
Text: digestive system-and to spread the message of bowel cancer awareness.

Speaker: NA
Text: Levy on Fruit Growers

Speaker: Ms PARKE
Text: Fremantle) (13:32): I thank the Deputy Speaker on this red apple day. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: very appropriate, because last weekend I spoke to my father, who is a fruit grower in

Speaker: NA
Text: Donnybrook in south-west Western Australia, and I asked him what he thought of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal by Woolworths to charge primary producers a so-called voluntary levy to pay for

Speaker: NA
Text: Woolworths' Jamie Oliver advertising campaign. My father said this proposal is breathtaking

Speaker: NA
Text: and obscene. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been selling fruit and vegetables for 60 years into the metropolitan market, in Perth and have

Speaker: NA
Text: had to live with the fact that this is a supply and demand market, as are all the fresh produce markets in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: As with any perishable crop, withholding supply to market is not an option, so growers are in the

Speaker: NA
Text: position of being price-takers rather than price-makers. This is a fundamental imbalance between

Speaker: NA
Text: products and buyers. We commonly see mark-ups of wholesale to retail of 100 to 1,000 per cent. A

Speaker: NA
Text: farmer may receive 40c per kilo for their plums, which are then retailed for $4 per kilo, a 1,000 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: mark-up. This situation is deteriorating even further due to the distorting influence of Australia's two

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: supermarket chains. Because we have no anti-trust laws in Australia to prevent this type of market

Speaker: NA
Text: dominance, it will only get harder for primary producers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Supermarkets commonly sell fresh produce sourced from other countries and use this as a strategy to

Speaker: NA
Text: keep prices for local produce artificially low. Primary producers already pay levies for the promotion of

Speaker: NA
Text: fresh fruit and vegetables and to have this impost put on them again by a company is untenable, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: company is already effectively dictating the wholesale price that the grower receives.

Speaker: NA
Text: Flynn Electorate: Mt Larcom Show

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr O'DOWD (Flynn) (13:33): Mount Larcom is situated halfway between Rockhampton

Speaker: NA
Text: and Gladstone, and the Mount Larcom Show is on this Saturday and Sunday, 21 and 22 June.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a great regional show, and there are some 129 regional shows in Queensland, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: Mount Larcom one sticks out as one of the best. People come from all over the place,

Speaker: NA
Text: including Gladstone, Calliope, Rockhampton and, of course, Mount Larcom district.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a great agricultural show with much, much more to offer. There are horse events for all

Speaker: NA
Text: ages, including show jumping, a stud cattle program, poultry, show dogs. They also have ute

Speaker: NA
Text: masters, chainsaw events, trade displays, market stalls and lots more. Then there is the

Speaker: NA
Text: entertainment-sideshow alley for the kids and young adults alike. Fireworks are on at night

Speaker: NA
Text: time, and the bar runs late into the night. There is plenty of food, with barbecues and drinks

Speaker: NA
Text: available throughout the day. Don't miss it; if you are in the area, please attend, because it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: great show.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rankin Electorate: Teaching Symposium

Speaker: Dr CHALMERS
Text: Rankin) (13:34): I congratulate and commend Racquel O'Connor, the

Speaker: NA
Text: principal of Mabel Park State School, in my electorate for convening a symposium last week

Speaker: NA
Text: on attracting, retaining and developing teachers in Logan-a particular challenge for low SES

Speaker: NA
Text: areas. I was pleased to be able to participate in the opening sessions and delighted to see

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives of the council, state parliament, unions and universities and local principals

Speaker: NA
Text: there.

Speaker: NA
Text: In some schools in our community close to half the teachers are on short-term contracts-

Speaker: NA
Text: which means a scramble each term, lots of churn and a lack of continuity in the classrooms.

Speaker: NA
Text: The difficulty in attracting teachers arises out of a whole lot of issues, some of them around

Speaker: NA
Text: perceptions of our area which a lot of good local people are working hard to turn around.

Speaker: NA
Text: Compounding these issues, retention and development are compromised by a range of factors,

Speaker: NA
Text: including lack of flexibility, time and opportunities for capacity-building and support. These

Speaker: NA
Text: are huge issues for my community, because good teachers make a big difference to the lives

Speaker: NA
Text: of our young people. We heard one statistic that showed that teachers can account for around

Speaker: NA
Text: 30 per cent of the difference in student performance and a teacher in the top 10 per cent can

Speaker: NA
Text: do in six months what a teacher in the bottom 10 per cent takes a year to achieve.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to see the very best teachers in our local schools. Logan should be the first choice

Speaker: NA
Text: for teachers motivated by the chance to make a real difference. Right now not enough high-

Speaker: NA
Text: performing teachers and graduates are choosing Logan schools, and I will work tirelessly with

Speaker: NA
Text: Racquel and with all the others at her symposium to fix that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Eden-Monaro Electorate: Roads

Speaker: Dr HENDY
Text: Eden-Monaro) (13:36): My electorate of Eden-Monaro is receiving an early

Speaker: NA
Text: down payment on the government's increased roads expenditure. On 13 June, last Friday, the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Prime Minister visited Queanbeyan. Together with the New South Wales Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Premier Andrew Stoner, he announced a joint funding commitment of $50 million to build the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queanbeyan bypass. The Commonwealth and New South Wales governments have

Speaker: NA
Text: committed $25 million each to construct a 4.6-kilometre, two-lane carriageway linking the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of Ellerton Drive to the new Edwin Land Parkway intersection at Old Cooma Road. A

Speaker: NA
Text: bridge will also be built over the Queanbeyan River. The extension of Ellerton Drive will

Speaker: NA
Text: provide an alternative route for traffic wanting to bypass Queanbeyan's busy CBD and

Speaker: NA
Text: improve road safety. It is also a major economic development investment for the Queanbeyan

Speaker: NA
Text: district and has been the No. 1 infrastructure priority for the Queanbeyan City Council for a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of years.

Speaker: NA
Text: For those people worried that spending decreases in Canberra will adversely affect

Speaker: NA
Text: Queanbeyan and Eden-Monaro, can I say that this project will be a massive boost in

Speaker: NA
Text: investment and jobs. The coalition is definitely looking after Eden-Monaro. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth government will work closely with both the New South Wales government

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Queanbeyan City Council to deliver this vital piece of regional road infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: We expect that construction of the bypass will start as soon as mid-2015. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Refugee Council of Australia

Speaker: Mr ZAPPIA
Text: Makin) (13:36): I note that earlier today the Minister for Immigration and

Speaker: NA
Text: Border Protection hosted a refugee week function in Parliament House. I also note, that after

Speaker: NA
Text: having allocated ongoing core funding of $140,000 per year in this year's budget to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Refugee Council of Australia, the minister then, without explanation, cut the funding. The

Speaker: NA
Text: minister claims that he did not know the funding was in his own budget. This is another

Speaker: NA
Text: example of Abbott government ministers not understanding their own budgets.

Speaker: NA
Text: As Refugee Council of Australia CEO Paul Power said:

Speaker: NA
Text: This decision is petty and vindictive and is symbolic of the Minister's very poor relationship with the

Speaker: NA
Text: non-government sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Refugee Council of Australia was founded in 1981 by Major General Paul Cullen and

Speaker: NA
Text: today has a network of 185 organisations and hundreds of members. It is a reputable

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation that has existed for over 30 years. The support that these organisations provide

Speaker: NA
Text: refugees adds value to government funded programs and ultimately saves the taxpayers'

Speaker: NA
Text: funds. This is another example of a mean-spirited, penny-pinching decision of the Abbott

Speaker: NA
Text: government, where extreme right-wing ideology is driving policy instead of good

Speaker: NA
Text: government, fairness and common sense.

Speaker: NA
Text: Barker Electorate: Local Government

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: this week to welcome mayors from across the electorate of Barker to Canberra. These local

Speaker: NA
Text: government leaders are in Canberra this week for the Australian Local Government

Speaker: NA
Text: Association National General Assembly. They joined me for dinner on Monday night before

Speaker: NA
Text: attending a series of meetings across the week. This included, of course, time with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Assistant Minister for Infrastructure and Regional Development, the Hon. Jamie Briggs, to

Speaker: NA
Text: discuss the important topic of special local roads funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: The group of mayors visiting from Barker included Alan Arbon from Murray Bridge, Dave

Speaker: NA
Text: Burgess from Mid Murray Council, Evan Flint from Kingston in the south-east, Peter Hunt

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: from Berri Barmera, Neil Martinson from Renmark Paringa, Robert Sexton from Southern

Speaker: NA
Text: Mallee, Roger Strother from Coorong, Erika Vickery from Naracoorte Lucindale, and Richard

Speaker: NA
Text: Vickery from the Tatiara.

Speaker: NA
Text: I spent many years as an elected member in local government and continue to have a

Speaker: NA
Text: tremendous respect for the important work carried out by local councils, particularly in the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of vital services in regional areas throughout Barker. This week represents a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant opportunity for me to work with those local representatives to engage with the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government, and I have enjoyed that opportunity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Iraq

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr KELVIN THOMSON (Wills) (13:40): When they invaded Iraq and toppled Saddam

Speaker: NA
Text: Hussein, the leaders of the Coalition of the Willing, George W. Bush, Tony Blair, and John

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard said they were prepared to accept responsibility for their actions and accept the

Speaker: NA
Text: verdict of history. Ten years later that verdict is clear. Over a hundred thousand civilian men,

Speaker: NA
Text: women and children dead, thousands of soldiers dead, over $3 trillion spent-for what? The

Speaker: NA
Text: breaking of a country and the unleashing of tribal, ethnic and religious hatreds.

Speaker: NA
Text: We would be crazy to go back in there. Neither the Sunni nor Shia leadership in Iraq has

Speaker: NA
Text: any respect for our values of democracy, pluralism, rights for women, rights for minorities,

Speaker: NA
Text: separation of church and state. They still want to carry on a 1300-year-old fight over who was

Speaker: NA
Text: the rightful heir to the Prophet Muhammad! Neither of them promotes any form of respect, let

Speaker: NA
Text: alone affection, for Western nations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of offering gratuitous advice to President Obama about what he should do now,

Speaker: NA
Text: those US Republicans and those opposite who arrogantly invaded another country, without

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations authorisation, to destroy weapons of mass destruction that did not exist,

Speaker: NA
Text: should get down on their hands and knees and ask forgiveness for having got it so

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensively wrong and having created such a political and humanitarian catastrophe.

Speaker: NA
Text: Robertson Electorate: Queen's Birthday Honours List

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (13:42): I rise to acknowledge the achievements of three

Speaker: NA
Text: Central Coast residents who have been awarded an Order of Australia Medal in this year's

Speaker: NA
Text: Queen's Birthday Honours List. Philip Donnelly of Killcare was awarded the medal for his

Speaker: NA
Text: service to the Indigenous community through many sporting and charitable initiatives. Phil is

Speaker: NA
Text: also the president of the Bouddi Society, which organises events and publications related to

Speaker: NA
Text: the arts and to community, social and environmental issues. Last year, the society staged the

Speaker: NA
Text: Arts Festival 'Bouddi at Bells', held at Bells at Killcare, where around 600 people helped to

Speaker: NA
Text: raise $25,000 to support young artists in my community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Shirley Templeton of West Gosford was also awarded an Order of Australia Medal for her

Speaker: NA
Text: service to women and to the Gosford community. Ms Templeton has had extensive

Speaker: NA
Text: involvement in numerous community organisations, including the Country Women's

Speaker: NA
Text: Association of New South Wales, Girl Guides Australia and Meals on Wheels.

Speaker: NA
Text: And another outstanding Central Coast resident, Leonard Sargant, has been awarded an

Speaker: NA
Text: OAM for his ongoing long-term service to Gosford. Len is a local champion. He is the vice-

Speaker: NA
Text: president of the Gosford Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the treasurer of the Gosford

Speaker: NA
Text: RSL Sub-Branch, where he is also a director and life member. He was also a state councillor

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Central Coast Region at Clubs NSW from 2009 to 2013.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The Central Coast is privileged as a community to benefit from the contributions of Philip,

Speaker: NA
Text: Len and Shirley. They join the company of several other men and women of outstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: calibre, and I thank them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sport: Hockey

Speaker: Ms BURKE
Text: Chisholm) (13:43): I want to pay tribute to an Australian team who defeated

Speaker: NA
Text: the Netherlands in the Hockey World Cup. That is right, the Kookaburras took down the

Speaker: NA
Text: Netherlands. They demolished the Netherlands 6:1 in the Hockey World Cup last Sunday. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was an amazing effort and something I am sad that we have not played up enough; it has just

Speaker: NA
Text: not been a media event. But I want to congratulate the ABC, who did actually broadcast these

Speaker: NA
Text: matches for my hockey-mad family. This was a godsend. It was an amazing effort by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kookaburras: a 6-1 win, with Victorian Chris Ciriello getting a hat-trick off those amazing

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty corners and a great win for Ric Charlesworth, who has announced he will be retiring

Speaker: NA
Text: as coach after the Commonwealth Games-and a great effort by Jamie Dwyer in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: minutes, with Jamie now holding the record equally with Jay Stacey for appearing for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kookaburras 321 times; an amazing effort.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst the Hockeyroos did not do as well, they also made an amazing effort appearing in

Speaker: NA
Text: the finals, going down 2-1, also against the Netherlands, on their home turf-if you have ever

Speaker: NA
Text: watched the Netherlands cheer on a hockey team, you would be surprised at how passionate

Speaker: NA
Text: they are about this game, as are many people in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to end this statement with great concern about the fear of losing the three

Speaker: NA
Text: water based pitches we have in Victoria now: one at Monash University, in my seat, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to make way for housing, and the two at the State Netball Hockey Centre, which may

Speaker: NA
Text: go because of the East West Link. This would be a shame.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dobell Electorate: Valley View Public School

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs MCNAMARA (Dobell) (13:45): I wish to share with the House my recent visit to an

Speaker: NA
Text: outstanding school in my electorate, Valley View Public School in Wyoming. I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the relief principal, Mr Dave Stitt, for his invitation, and to congratulate Dave and his

Speaker: NA
Text: staff on the outstanding work that they are doing at the school. The school motto is

Speaker: NA
Text: 'innovation, opportunity and success', and this is a school which practises what it preaches. I

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed the school assembly and presented flags and certificates of appreciation to students

Speaker: NA
Text: who had participated in the community writing project. Mr Stitt proudly took me to visit the

Speaker: NA
Text: new Hardware Playzone that is a joint effort by the school, parents and carers of the multi-

Speaker: NA
Text: categorical class, Central Coast Bunnings Hardware stores, and other local small businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: who supplied labour and materials. This innovative playground is now providing a happy and

Speaker: NA
Text: safe area for children with ASD, and is shared between the multi-categorical class, the

Speaker: NA
Text: mainstream body and the Glenville Satellite class. It is proof of what can be achieved when

Speaker: NA
Text: the community works together. I especially wish to acknowledge the efforts of Miss Taimi

Speaker: NA
Text: Saxon from the multi-categorical class for her dedication to this project-and whose drive

Speaker: NA
Text: and enthusiasm made it all possible. It was great to join everyone who assisted in the building

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Hardware Playzone at the thank-you morning tea. My visit to the school was completed

Speaker: NA
Text: with a tour where I was able to observe the innovative learning techniques and aids that the

Speaker: NA
Text: school has adopted for their students as part of their curriculum. I look forward to a return

Speaker: NA
Text: visit in the near future.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Newcastle Electorate: Newcastle East Public School

Speaker: Ms CLAYDON
Text: Newcastle) (13:47): I rise to pay tribute to a school in my electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: which is visiting us here in Parliament House today: Newcastle East Public School. This

Speaker: NA
Text: school is Australia's oldest school, celebrating 198 years of continuous service to the children

Speaker: NA
Text: of inner-city Newcastle. Housed in heritage-listed Gothic buildings, the school fosters an

Speaker: NA
Text: awareness of its central role in the history of public education in Australia, and operates on

Speaker: NA
Text: the ethos: 'We are a country school in the heart of the city.' When the school opened its doors

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1816, Newcastle was home to just 400 people, with 17 convict children aged three to 13

Speaker: NA
Text: years the school's first students. The schoolteacher at the time, Henry Wrensford, was himself

Speaker: NA
Text: a convict on a conditional pardon.

Speaker: NA
Text: Newcastle East has come a long way over the years, and is now ably led by Principal John

Speaker: NA
Text: Beach and his team of dedicated educators, providing high-quality, universally-accessible

Speaker: NA
Text: education for all children. Earlier this year I was honoured to attend the launch of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Newcastle East Public School's bicentenary project, a series of celebratory events to be held

Speaker: NA
Text: over the next two years, culminating in 2016 when the school will reach the momentous

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion of 200 years of quality public education. Newcastle East Public School will be

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's first school to celebrate its bicentenary. Congratulations on your 198 years of

Speaker: NA
Text: education so far, and I can't wait to celebrate your bicentenary with you in 2016!

Speaker: NA
Text: Vinnies CEO Sleepout

Speaker: Ms ODWYER
Text: Higgins) (13:48): According to Homelessness Australia, over 100,000

Speaker: NA
Text: people are currently homeless in Australia. Most concerning to me is that thousands of those

Speaker: NA
Text: people are children. Homelessness is a scourge that both civil society and we as legislators

Speaker: NA
Text: have a responsibility and a duty to address. The best way government can reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: homelessness is by putting in place the right framework to educate our youth and to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: them with opportunities. It is also about putting in place a framework that will allow the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy to grow and prosper and, in turn, create jobs-and it is about putting the right

Speaker: NA
Text: framework in place to support those people in need. However, no matter how well we do at

Speaker: NA
Text: all of this, there will sometimes be those who find themselves in vulnerable positions through

Speaker: NA
Text: no fault of their own-it could be through family breakdown, domestic violence, or mental

Speaker: NA
Text: illness. That is why organisations such as St Vincent de Paul Society are so critical in our

Speaker: NA
Text: society. These volunteer, not-for-profit organisations help some of the most needy and most

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Thursday night, I will be participating in the Vinnies CEO Sleepout. This will be the

Speaker: NA
Text: third year that I have taken part. First held in 2008, it is a wonderful initiative which has

Speaker: NA
Text: raised more than $13 million for people who are suffering from homelessness and issues

Speaker: NA
Text: around poverty, providing education programs, recreation activities and extensive information

Speaker: NA
Text: and referral services. I urge those in this place to support this great cause by supporting those

Speaker: NA
Text: who are taking part in the Vinnies CEO Sleepout.

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Capitals Australia

Speaker: Ms MCGOWAN
Text: Indi) (13:50): It gives me great pleasure today to acknowledge the work

Speaker: NA
Text: of Regional Capitals Australia, and particularly the work of the Wodonga City Council in the

Speaker: NA
Text: formation of this wonderful national organisation. I am a proud champion. There are 50

Speaker: NA
Text: regional capitals of Australia-cities like Wagga Wagga, Albury-Wodonga, Mackay,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Geraldton, Launceston, Mt Gambier and Palmerston-with a total population of four million

Speaker: NA
Text: people and growing. In 2026-that is only 12 years from now-that population is estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: to be five million people. Regional capitals generate 15 per cent of GDP, at $219 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are the hubs that provide vital services to surrounding towns. I believe regional capitals

Speaker: NA
Text: hold the future for Australia's growth: they are tourist destinations, hubs supporting the

Speaker: NA
Text: agribusiness industry, and centres for energy resources, and our regional capitals have, on

Speaker: NA
Text: average, higher numbers already employed in the tertiary education sector than the rest of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: In closing, I would like to publicly acknowledge the work of two of my constituents in

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing this idea to the national stage: former Wodonga mayor, Mark Byatt, and Wodonga

Speaker: NA
Text: City Council CEO, Patience Harrington. While the idea might have begun in WA, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: Mark and Patience who pioneered a national organisation. It is early days for RCA, but I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that when the future history of the 21st century of Australia is written, regional cities will be

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised for their central role.

Speaker: NA
Text: School Chaplaincy

Speaker: Mr SIMPKINS
Text: Cowan) (13:51): I would like to speak about the National School

Speaker: NA
Text: Chaplaincy and Student Welfare Program. Leading up to the budget I received many emails

Speaker: NA
Text: about this from parents, particularly from Woodvale Primary School. After the funding for

Speaker: NA
Text: this program was announced in the budget, Pearsall Primary School also contacted me for

Speaker: NA
Text: support in trying to get a chaplain. The chaplains throughout the schools of Cowan are

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinarily positive. They make a very strong contribution, and their activities are

Speaker: NA
Text: completely legitimate and above board. A great example was a few years ago at Hudson Park

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary School, where the then chaplain, Shirley Pyrc, wrote one of the best school songs I

Speaker: NA
Text: have ever heard. They do make an excellent contribution.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that some people make allegations about chaplains, and make suggestions about

Speaker: NA
Text: evangelical activity, but I have never seen this nor have I had a complaint even alleging it in

Speaker: NA
Text: Cowan. Overwhelmingly, the support for the program is extremely strong, and I hope that the

Speaker: NA
Text: High Court decision will enable it to continue. In any case, I look forward to the government

Speaker: NA
Text: providing due support to allow the positive contribution of chaplains to continue within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cowan electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Jenkins, Mr Henry Alfred 'Harry', AO

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: Scullin) (13:53): I rise today to draw the attention of members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: to the awarding of the Order of Australia to the former member for Scullin, my predecessor,

Speaker: NA
Text: Harry Jenkins.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members: Hear, hear!

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: 'Hear, hear!' indeed. To say this award was appropriate is to say the very

Speaker: NA
Text: least. It represents, in my view-and I am sure in the estimation of many current and former

Speaker: NA
Text: members-due recognition of extraordinary service: service to the communities that make up

Speaker: NA
Text: the electorate of Scullin; service to the Shire of Whittlesea, in which he also served; service of

Speaker: NA
Text: course to this parliament; and indeed service to public life more generally. It has been said

Speaker: NA
Text: that Harry made a rare contribution to building public trust across his service in this place. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am so pleased to be able to congratulate Harry on this significant award in this place to which

Speaker: NA
Text: he gave so much, and I look forward to doing so personally.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: State of Origin

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: Mitchell) (13:54): I want to report to the House that this morning on a

Speaker: NA
Text: minus one degree, frosty Senate field, the New South Wales Parliamentary Blues defeated

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland two tries to nothing for the second year in a row. In a game no-one takes

Speaker: NA
Text: seriously, except perhaps the member for Fisher, Mal Brough, we were lucky to be joined by

Speaker: NA
Text: former NRL stars Nathan Hindmarsh-co-captain with myself for New South Wales-and

Speaker: NA
Text: Petro Civoneciva, co-captain of Queensland with member for New England Barnaby 'One

Speaker: NA
Text: Direction' Joyce. We were also joined by NRL CEO Dave Smith who, very fairly, played

Speaker: NA
Text: equally badly for both teams. We thank them all for joining us.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst I would like to say that sport was the winner, it probably wasn't. But I should praise

Speaker: NA
Text: a few strong performances. Member for Hume, 'Running Man' Angus Taylor, hit a tidy gap to

Speaker: NA
Text: streak away on the end of a beautiful ball held up perfectly and thrown by-who threw that

Speaker: NA
Text: ball? Was that me? Oh yes, it was me, but it would be hubris to point that out. He crashed

Speaker: NA
Text: through to score the try and win the game off the back of a great pass. Video referee Mark

Speaker: NA
Text: Simkin from the ABC confirms the pass left the hands backwards, and we all know video

Speaker: NA
Text: referees never get it wrong! It is also true what they say about the member for Charlton, Pat

Speaker: NA
Text: Conroy: he ain't pretty-he definitely ain't pretty-but he did look pretty good as he stepped

Speaker: NA
Text: around the member for Forde, Bert 'Beattie Slayer' van Manen, and crashed over in the 80th

Speaker: NA
Text: minute to seal the win in style. The omens are auspicious, the portents are awesome, as

Speaker: NA
Text: 100,000 true Blues fans tonight turn out at ANZ Stadium for the New South Wales side to

Speaker: NA
Text: break the drought and deliver not just this parliamentary trophy but the real trophy tonight to

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr THISTLETHWAITE
Text: Kingsford Smith) (13:55): I pay tribute to Patrick Byrne,

Speaker: NA
Text: former president of the Coogee Dolphins Rugby League Club, who passed away tragically on

Speaker: NA
Text: 23 May. Patrick Byrne was a remarkable Australian-community minded, fiercely loyal to

Speaker: NA
Text: his family and friends and, above all, heroic. In 2002, on a night out at the Sari Club in Bali,

Speaker: NA
Text: Patrick left his Coogee Dolphins rugby league teammates to buy cigarettes. What happened

Speaker: NA
Text: next changed his life forever. A bomb was detonated, killing 202 people, including 88

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians-20 of those from our community in Kingsford Smith. Wasting no time, Patrick

Speaker: NA
Text: courageously ran back into the inferno and carried several injured people to safety. Despite

Speaker: NA
Text: his brave efforts, for which he received a bravery award in 2008, six of Patrick's mates died

Speaker: NA
Text: that evening on their end-of-year football trip.

Speaker: NA
Text: When he returned he put aside his grief to assist family and friends, doing a fundraiser and

Speaker: NA
Text: earning an NRL community award. With Patrick as president of the club, Coogee won back-

Speaker: NA
Text: to-back A-grade premierships in 2007 and 2008. Speaking at Patrick's funeral in May this

Speaker: NA
Text: year, an older brother of one of the deceased, Paul Yeo, said of Patrick, 'He just saw too

Speaker: NA
Text: much.' Many said Patrick never got over the guilt of surviving that night. Although the bomb

Speaker: NA
Text: went off in 2002 and some of those involved in this insidious act of terrorism are now being

Speaker: NA
Text: released from jail, many in Australia continue to suffer and die. I pay tribute to Patrick, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: offer condolences to his family and friends. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Post

Speaker: Ms HENDERSON
Text: Corangamite) (13:57): Teesdale residents in the Corangamite

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate currently must collect their mail from the licensed post office at the general store.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many in the community are crying out for street and roadside mail delivery. The problem is

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia Post has a very undemocratic way of finding out what residents want. It

Speaker: NA
Text: distributes a survey by hand, and many of these go missing-so if a survey is not returned it is

Speaker: NA
Text: counted as a 'no' vote. This has skewed the result of the two previous mail polls held in

Speaker: NA
Text: Teesdale in Australia Post's favour. The Postal Industry Ombudsman has been very critical of

Speaker: NA
Text: this methodology.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week, as a strong local voice for Corangamite I hosted a community meeting in

Speaker: NA
Text: Teesdale. The good news is that Australia Post will hold another mail poll of all 720 homes in

Speaker: NA
Text: the town, commencing on 7 July. After I made representations to CEO Ahmed Fahour, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased that the poll has been delayed and that information will be placed on Australia Post's

Speaker: NA
Text: website so that residents can be better informed. Delivery of voting forms will also be

Speaker: NA
Text: improved-they will be cable tied to fences if someone is not home. However, Australia Post

Speaker: NA
Text: is sticking by its unfair method of surveying residents. This is wrong and unjust to country

Speaker: NA
Text: communities, and needs to change.

Speaker: NA
Text: Giles, Mr Daniel

Speaker: Ms CHESTERS
Text: Bendigo) (13:58): Today I rise to shine a light on Daniel Giles, a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of my community who is on the autism spectrum. Just recently, Daniel conducted a

Speaker: NA
Text: 24-hour walk with three other people in an effort to raise funds for Turn A Life Around, a

Speaker: NA
Text: program which uses the money from this fundraiser to purchase electronic equipment such as

Speaker: NA
Text: iPads to assist others with autism. Autism is a growing problem in our communities, and in

Speaker: NA
Text: none more than my own community of Bendigo. Because of the lack of resources that are

Speaker: NA
Text: being made available, because of the funding cuts we have seen to education, because schools

Speaker: NA
Text: just do not have the resources that would have been delivered under Gonski, the autism

Speaker: NA
Text: community in my electorate is getting on with the job of funding themselves. Through

Speaker: NA
Text: fundraisers like Turn A Life Around, through autism walks and through doing their own

Speaker: NA
Text: community work, they are raising the necessary funds to help their kids to purchase the

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment they need to get through school. Autism is an issue, and it is a growing issue in our

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: It being 2 pm, the member is interrupted. In accordance with standing

Speaker: NA
Text: order 43, the time for members' statements has concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Ms BIRD
Text: Cunningham) (14:00): My question is to the Prime Minister. Today, Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, is National TAFE Day, when we mark the opportunities and training that these

Speaker: NA
Text: important institutions provide for so many young Australians starting out in the workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why, then, is the Prime Minister determined to destroy opportunities for Australia's 400,000

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices by cutting almost $1 billion from the Tools for Your Trade program?

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: There will be silence on my right. The Prime Minister has the call.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah-Prime Minister) (14:00): Like the member who was asked the

Speaker: NA
Text: question, I value and appreciate the great work that our tradies do. I appreciate the need for

Speaker: NA
Text: proper training systems. The problem is that-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Moreton is not beginning well.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: for all their talk, members opposite were much better at spending money

Speaker: NA
Text: than they were at getting a result. Under the policies of members opposite, some 50 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of apprentices never completed their training. So what we want is a better training system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Macklin interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: There will be silence from the member for Jagajaga.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Members opposite actually cut $2.4 billion for skills training in the 2012

Speaker: NA
Text: MYEFO. Members opposite promised 2,650 trade training centres. They delivered fewer than

Speaker: NA
Text: 350 of those.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Owens interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Parramatta will desist.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: I want to assure the House that, under this government, money will be

Speaker: NA
Text: invested sensibly and good results will be achieved. We will spend some $5 billion on

Speaker: NA
Text: training over the forward estimates period. Very importantly, we will be giving trainees

Speaker: NA
Text: access to trade support loans because they deserve support on the same basis that university

Speaker: NA
Text: students have. We want a fair system, a good system, a flexible system and a productive

Speaker: NA
Text: system. That is what people will get under this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Ms LANDRY
Text: Capricornia) (14:02): My question is to the Prime Minister. Will the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister explain how addressing the debt and deficit mess inherited by this government will

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthen the economy and help families in Capricornia and the rest of the country?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah-Prime Minister) (14:03): I thank the member for Capricornia

Speaker: NA
Text: for her question. It is an excellent question. I can assure her that this government were elected

Speaker: NA
Text: to do a number of very important things. We were elected to scrap the carbon tax, because

Speaker: NA
Text: that will save households $550 a year. We were elected to stop the boats, because that will

Speaker: NA
Text: stop the deaths and also save some $2.5 billion over four years. We were elected to build the

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure of the 21st century, because, thanks to the neglect of state Labor governments,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's roads have been turned into the world's longest parking lot. We were elected above

Speaker: NA
Text: all else to clean up Labor's budget mess-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Dreyfus interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Isaacs will desist.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: which had given us the six biggest deficits in history, deficits stretching

Speaker: NA
Text: out as far as the eye can see and debts peaking at $670 billion. As a result of Labor's budget

Speaker: NA
Text: mess, the Commonwealth is currently borrowing $1 billion every single month. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: borrowing $1 billion every single month just to pay the interest on Labor's debt. That is dead

Speaker: NA
Text: money.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Think what we could do if we were not paying $1 billion every single month just to cover

Speaker: NA
Text: the interest on Labor's debt. Within a year we could fully fund the upgrade of the Bruce

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway. Within two months we could fully fund the Toowoomba range crossing. Within

Speaker: NA
Text: three months we could pay for the Western Sydney infrastructure package. Within six months

Speaker: NA
