Text: we could fund the duplication of the Pacific Highway. In over 12 months we could fund the

Speaker: NA
Text: East West Link in Melbourne. In one month we could fund the north-south road in Adelaide.

Speaker: NA
Text: In a month we could fund the Gateway Motorway upgrade in Brisbane. In just two weeks we

Speaker: NA
Text: could fund the Midland Highway project in Tasmania. In less than a week we could fund the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Games on the Gold Coast. In less than a month we could fund the Perth

Speaker: NA
Text: Gateway and in another month we could more than fund the Swan Valley bypass.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Albanese interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Grayndler will desist.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Albanese interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Grayndler is warned.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: I say to the member for Grayndler that the Labor Party were economic

Speaker: NA
Text: vandals in office and in opposition they are even worse. The Leader of the Opposition is

Speaker: NA
Text: groaning and moaning on the other side of the ministerial table. He is all complaint and no

Speaker: NA
Text: solution. Members opposite stand for bigger deficits, more debt and open borders.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: Maribyrnong-Leader of the Opposition) (14:06): My question is to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. The very last day before the last election the Prime Minister promised

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians no cuts to education, no cuts to health and no changes to pensions. Now that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister has cut $80 billion from schools and hospitals and has cut indexation to carers,

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans and pensioners, did the Prime Minister seriously expect the people of Australia to

Speaker: NA
Text: believe him when he said yesterday, 'This is an honest budget'?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah-Prime Minister) (14:06): This is the right budget for Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: because it tackles Labor's debt and deficit disaster. As for the figure that the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition bandies about, I challenge him to produce one of the Labor Party's budgets which

Speaker: NA
Text: has that figure in it. I challenge the Leader of the Opposition to come up with a single Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: budget with that figured in it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr Burke
Text: Madam Speaker, on a point of order on relevance, there is a request to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister for authentication. He has to look at his own budget documents for the cut.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor never made that cut.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: There is no point of order. The member will resume his seat. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has the call.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: There is no cut because there was no budget that contained it from

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Burke interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: the Leader of the Opposition is abusing the standing orders, and he

Speaker: NA
Text: knows it and will not do it again.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: There is no Labor budget that made the commitment that the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition refers to. This was a pie-in-the-sky, undeliverable promise from the Labor Party,

Speaker: NA
Text: that was never contained in any single budget. When it comes to schools, let me be very clear,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is an eight per cent increase this year, an eight per cent increase next year, an eight per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent increase the year after that, and a six per cent increase in the final year. When it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: public hospitals, there is a nine per cent increase this year, a nine per cent increase next year, a

Speaker: NA
Text: nine per cent increase the year after that, and a six per cent increase in the final year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: On the question of indexation, members opposite changed the indexation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the family tax benefit from male total average weekly earnings to CPI. Members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrated by their actions that the CPI is a fair indexation system. If it was fair for

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite to do it for the family tax benefit, it is fair for this government to do it to

Speaker: NA
Text: other benefits. If it was fair for Labor to do it, it is fair for the coalition to do it. This is a fair

Speaker: NA
Text: budget, an honest budget, and above all else, it is the right budget for Australia because it

Speaker: NA
Text: deals with Labor's debt and deficit disaster. We have our plan to deal with Labor's debt and

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit disaster. We have demonstrated how we are going to clean up Labor's mess. It is about

Speaker: NA
Text: time that Labor demonstrated how they will clean up the mess they created.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister during his answer-trying to hear the Prime Minister's response was almost

Speaker: NA
Text: impossible on this side of the House because of the wall of noise coming from the empty

Speaker: NA
Text: vessels on that side of the House. I would ask you to assist at least the electors of Australia to

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to hear the answers from the Prime Minister without the empty vessels opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: making so much noise.

Speaker: Mr Burke
Text: Madam Speaker, on behalf of the opposition, we have the same trouble with

Speaker: NA
Text: the cheering that goes on from their back bench.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member will resume his seat. There will be silence so that we can

Speaker: NA
Text: hear the member for Wright who has been given the call.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr BUCHHOLZ
Text: Wright-Government Whip) (14:10): I have an excellent question to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver to the Treasurer. Will the Treasurer explain to the House how repairing the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: mess that this government inherited will change the Australian economy for the better into the

Speaker: NA
Text: future?

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Text: North Sydney-The Treasurer) (14:11): I thank the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Wright for that question. He is an indefatigable advocate for good economic policy. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has been in the door on regular occasions and has been a strong advocate for government to

Speaker: NA
Text: live within its means. As the Prime Minister just said, this is a very fair budget and a very

Speaker: NA
Text: honest budget. I know that comes as a rude shock to the Labor Party given they delivered six

Speaker: NA
Text: budgets in a row from the member for Lilley, that were both unfair and dishonest. No budget

Speaker: NA
Text: could be more dishonest than the one delivered by the member for Lilley when he claimed

Speaker: NA
Text: that he was announcing on that night four budget surpluses in a row. We miss you, Swannie!

Speaker: NA
Text: Now of course he is writing a book-or actually, the Parliamentary Library is writing a book

Speaker: NA
Text: on his behalf-and we look forward to the wisdom that comes from that book.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The legacy of six years of Labor was $667 billion of debt, if no action is taken. Somehow

Speaker: NA
Text: they tend to believe that a number like that is pretty irrelevant-$667 billion with no

Speaker: NA
Text: surpluses on the horizon. The interest that the Australian people would pay on that $667

Speaker: NA
Text: billion would be $3 billion a month. Currently, we are paying $1 billion a month, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: legacy of Labor waste and expenditure lifted it to $3 billion a month, and 70 per cent of that

Speaker: NA
Text: goes to people living overseas because they are the people that have lent us the money.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been a lot of debate about whether it is a budget emergency or a budget crisis, so

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to go-

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Text: They are laughing! I am glad they are because I just want to cite someone

Speaker: NA
Text: very close to the Labor Party. That is why Swannie has got his head down-and you should

Speaker: NA
Text: all learn from him. The Reserve Bank of Australia board member John Edwards, principal

Speaker: NA
Text: adviser to Paul Keating and appointed by the Labor Party to the Reserve Bank, said yesterday:

Speaker: NA
Text: I've no doubt there is a budget crisis-

Speaker: NA
Text: Hello, someone in the Labor Party that understands economics knows that it is a budget crisis!

Speaker: NA
Text: He went on:

Speaker: NA
Text: We're accumulating debt as a higher share of GDP and of course in absolute terms, [it's] absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: astronomical compared to far more serious episodes in Australian history, including recoveries from

Speaker: NA
Text: serious recessions.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we do not do something about the debt and deficit legacy of Labor, we will face a crisis in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. In fact a Reserve Bank board member appointed by the Labor Party says that it

Speaker: NA
Text: exists now so to Labor I say: get out of the way and let us fix the budget!

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Ms PLIBERSEK
Text: Sydney-Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (14:14): My question is to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's last answer and his continued denials that

Speaker: NA
Text: he is cutting health and education. Yesterday the New South Wales treasurer said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's cuts to schools and hospitals are 'leaving the states $80 billion worse off'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why is the Prime Minister continuing to deceive Australians about his $80 billion cuts to

Speaker: NA
Text: schools and hospitals?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah-Prime Minister) (14:14): I am pleased that the Deputy Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition has asked me about the New South Wales budget, because the budget that

Speaker: NA
Text: the New South Wales Treasurer has brought down is a very good budget. It builds on the

Speaker: NA
Text: outstanding work of the former treasurer, now Premier Mike Baird, who is really doing very

Speaker: NA
Text: good work indeed. Commonwealth funding to New South Wales is increasing by $5.8 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: thanks to the budget that we brought down. Commonwealth spending to New South Wales is

Speaker: NA
Text: up by $5.8 billion thanks to the budget that this Commonwealth government brought down a

Speaker: NA
Text: few weeks ago, and that is $1.4 billion more than would have been the case under the policies

Speaker: NA
Text: of members opposite. Right around this country, thanks to the budget that we brought down,

Speaker: NA
Text: the states will be $9 billion better off over the next four years. This is a bonanza for the state

Speaker: NA
Text: governments under this government; it is an infrastructure bonanza. It is not just unsustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: recurrent spending, because this government is shifting spending out of short-term

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption and into long-term investment, because that is what we want to do. We want to

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: build a strong and prosperous economy so that over the long term our country will be safe and

Speaker: NA
Text: secure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again, for the benefit of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, in New South Wales, year

Speaker: NA
Text: on year, hospital funding grows by eight per cent, 10 per cent, 10 per cent and eight per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: In New South Wales, year on year, schools funding grows by seven per cent, eight per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: nine per cent and six per cent. This Commonwealth government is investing $15 billion in

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure in New South Wales. I am very proud of that, because there is a terrible

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure gap in New South Wales because of the neglect of members opposite. Because

Speaker: NA
Text: of the neglect of members opposite, roads in Sydney are some of the world's longest car

Speaker: NA
Text: parks. Well, that is going to change under this government. I am determined to be the

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure Prime Minister, and I am proud that with the help of this government Mike

Speaker: NA
Text: Baird will be the infrastructure Premier.

Speaker: NA
Text: World Heritage Areas

Speaker: Mr WILKIE
Text: Denison) (14:17): My question is to the Prime Minister. The UN will

Speaker: NA
Text: shortly decide Australia's request to delist 74,000 hectares of Tasmanian World Heritage

Speaker: NA
Text: forests. Regardless of the government's position, will you respect the World Heritage

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee's final decision and not attempt any unprecedented unilateral withdrawal from the

Speaker: NA
Text: World Heritage framework? And before taking any final action, will you at least give me time

Speaker: NA
Text: to bring a petition to the parliament next week in support of maintaining the listing?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah-Prime Minister) (14:18): I thank the member for Denison for

Speaker: NA
Text: his question. Of course he has a perfect right to bring petitions to this parliament on any

Speaker: NA
Text: subject at any time, and I respect the member's commitment to the environment. But I do say,

Speaker: NA
Text: in response to the member for Denison, that I too am a conservationist and I regard myself as

Speaker: NA
Text: as much of a conservationist as any member of this parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: There will be silence on my left. The member for Moreton is warned.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: The challenge that all of us in this parliament face in respect of the great

Speaker: NA
Text: state of Tasmania is to try to ensure that the great state of Tasmania is an economy as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: a national park. We need to ensure that the great state of Tasmania is a strong economy as a

Speaker: NA
Text: well as a beautiful national park. We need to ensure that the great state of Tasmania is a good

Speaker: NA
Text: place to work as well as-

Speaker: Mr Wilkie
Text: Madam Speaker, a point of order on relevance: the essence of the question is

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: There is no point of order.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: I understand and appreciate and share the commitment of the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Denison to Tasmania's forests. They are great renewable resources as well as pristine and

Speaker: NA
Text: beautiful places, and I want the people of Tasmania to be able to work in forests as well as to

Speaker: NA
Text: walk in forests. I want people to be able to make a living from forests as well as to appreciate

Speaker: NA
Text: their natural beauty. This is a question of getting the balance right, and the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Denison can trust this government to do just that.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr Wilkie
Text: Madam speaker, a further point of order: the question asked for really a yes or

Speaker: NA
Text: no-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: No, there is no point of order.

Speaker: NA
Text: Carbon Pricing

Speaker: Mr GOODENOUGH
Text: Moore) (14:20): My question is to the Treasurer. Will the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer inform the House of the consequences of a failure to repeal the carbon tax? How

Speaker: NA
Text: will the carbon tax continue to damage the economy if it is not repealed?

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Text: North Sydney-The Treasurer) (14:20): I thank the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Moore for his question. I note that he is a very worthy successor to his hugely impressive

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessor. Coming from Western Australia, he knows how important it is to repeal the

Speaker: NA
Text: carbon tax. I regret to inform the House that as a result of Labor's refusal to terminate the

Speaker: NA
Text: carbon tax the carbon tax will go up on 1 July this year from $24.15 a tonne to $25.40 a

Speaker: NA
Text: tonne-a five per cent increase in the carbon tax. If the Labor Party let us keep our election

Speaker: NA
Text: promise to get rid of the carbon tax, and if Labor were not blocking the repeal of the carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: tax, then we could get rid of the carbon tax immediately and prevent it going up on 1 July

Speaker: NA
Text: next year. They have already had a chance to support our repeal of the carbon tax laws. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are going to give them another chance next week to repeal that carbon tax laws before the

Speaker: NA
Text: carbon tax goes up again, on 1 July.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know the Leader of the Opposition has been running around to a few business groups

Speaker: NA
Text: in the last 24 hours. He spoke to the CEO's of some foreign entities and to the Business

Speaker: NA
Text: Council of Australia. What he has is one message for business and another message for the

Speaker: NA
Text: public. The message to businesses is along the lines, 'Don't worry, that carbon tax is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: go.' But to the public he says, 'Hang on, we are fighting to keep the carbon tax, because we

Speaker: NA
Text: want to see your electricity prices rise.' And rise they will.

Speaker: NA
Text: Getting rid of the carbon tax on average relieves each household of $550 in costs. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: almost one year ago that Kevin Rudd-remember him?-stated before the election, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Herbert, in Townsville:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Labor government has decided to terminate the carbon tax to help cost-of-living pressures for

Speaker: NA
Text: families and to reduce the costs for small business.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was Kevin, under the palm trees, up there with the member for MCMahon right by his

Speaker: NA
Text: side-I hope he has not forgotten that. The member for MCMahon was there saying that

Speaker: NA
Text: terminating the carbon tax was part of our positive economic plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: But that was 12 months ago-like, they don't keep their promises.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Shorten interjecting-

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Text: When it comes to being loyal and honest, you are not at the top of the

Speaker: NA
Text: queue, Bill. One of the best examples of that is your backflip on the carbon tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Text: MCMahon) (14:23): My question is to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister to his continued denials that he is cutting health and education funding. I also refer to

Speaker: NA
Text: Standard and Poor's statement on yesterday's New South Wales budget:

Speaker: NA
Text: The state government faced cuts to health and education funding from the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: government.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Why is the Prime Minister continuing to deceive the Australian people about his $80 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: of cuts?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah-Prime Minister) (14:24): For the benefit of the person who

Speaker: NA
Text: asked the question, let me repeat that every year school and hospital funding goes up under

Speaker: NA
Text: this government, and every year school and hospital money for the state governments goes up.

Speaker: NA
Text: The shadow Treasurer really should quote more completely if he is going to be taken

Speaker: NA
Text: seriously. If he wants to quote one, let me quote another. The Deutsche Bank Research Report

Speaker: NA
Text: 2014-15, released yesterday, stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: We note that Commonwealth grants to New South Wales have actually increased over the forward

Speaker: NA
Text: projection period, relevant to the 2013-14 budget update.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government is not only delivering more money to schools and hospitals but it is also

Speaker: NA
Text: tackling Labor's debt and deficit disaster. That is why it is not only an honest budget, not only

Speaker: NA
Text: a truthful budget, but it is the budget Australia needs for these times.

Speaker: NA
Text: Asylum Seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs GRIGGS (Solomon) (14:25): My question is to the Minister for Immigration and

Speaker: NA
Text: Border Protection. Will the minister inform the House of the measures taken in the budget to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide education services to the children of illegal maritime arrivals on Christmas Island and

Speaker: NA
Text: what challenges these measures will address? How are the government's policies fixing the

Speaker: NA
Text: mess the government inherited on our borders?

Speaker: Mr MORRISON
Text: Cook-Minister for Immigration and Border Protection) (14:26): I

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the member for Solomon for her question. She will be pleased to know, as I know all

Speaker: NA
Text: members on this side of the House are, that given that we have now had almost six months of

Speaker: NA
Text: no successful people smuggling ventures to Australia, it is saving the budget $2.5 billion. In

Speaker: NA
Text: addition to that, it is ensuring that we have freed up 20,000 places in our special humanitarian

Speaker: NA
Text: program over this year out to the end of the forward estimates. Further to that, it has freed up

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 1,000 places for women at risk, which we noted earlier today at the opening of

Speaker: NA
Text: Refugee Week.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we found when we came to government was not that arrangement. We found

Speaker: NA
Text: something very different. By stopping the boats, we are able not only to get the budget under

Speaker: NA
Text: control and get the refugee and humanitarian program back under control and ensure it has

Speaker: NA
Text: integrity, but we are able to deal with the problems in the detention network and with the

Speaker: NA
Text: issues with offshore processing that were left to us by the previous government. Labor did

Speaker: NA
Text: leave us a mess. They left us a mess because $1.2 billion was the shortfall in funding for

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively implementing offshore processing. They announced it but they did not fund it.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are great on announcements-they announce surpluses that are never delivered and they

Speaker: NA
Text: announce offshore processing policies that were never funded.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to that there was inadequate infrastructure for children-for families. After their

Speaker: NA
Text: involvement in those offshore centres they had processed no-one at all. Not one. More than

Speaker: NA
Text: 100 people have received decisions and recommendations now under the arrangements put in

Speaker: NA
Text: place in Papua New Guinea and Nauru-and there were no resettlement arrangements, none

Speaker: NA
Text: at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am asked quite specifically by the member for Solomon about the issues on Christmas

Speaker: NA
Text: Island. I can tell you that at the last election the previous government had provided education

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: to just 24 children on Christmas Island. There is a slight problem with that in that there were

Speaker: NA
Text: 140 primary-age children on Christmas Island at the time, and there were 425 children on

Speaker: NA
Text: Christmas Island at the time. That was addressed in this budget. There is $2.6 million to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that not just 24 children but every child held in detention on Christmas Island will go

Speaker: NA
Text: to school every single day. That is just one of the examples of cleaning up the mess. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: job is getting easier, because the number of children in detention is declining. The number of

Speaker: NA
Text: children right across our own networks and offshore is now fewer than 1,000. It has fallen by

Speaker: NA
Text: a third since the election. It has fallen by almost 50 per cent in mainland centres across

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. You know how you get children out of detention? You stop the boats. That is how

Speaker: NA
Text: you do it. That is what this government is doing. That is why children are coming out of

Speaker: NA
Text: detention and that is why this government has been successful and you lot failed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Text: Maribyrnong-Leader of the Opposition) (14:29): My question is to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. I refer to this fact sheet circulated by the member for Perth to her

Speaker: NA
Text: constituents.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: We do not use props.

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: I am just referring to it. It says, 'The government is delivering on its

Speaker: NA
Text: election commitment to support veterans by improving-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: indexed.' Given that the Prime Minister is actually cutting the indexation of veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions, why are members of his government using taxpayers' money to peddle his lies?

Text: The Leader of the Opposition will rephrase the last part of his question.

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: Given that the Prime Minister is actually cutting indexation of veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions, why are members of his government using taxpayers' money to peddle the fairytales

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Prime Minister?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: I am not sure that was much of an improvement.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah-Prime Minister) (14:31): I can understand why the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition is a bit obsessed with the member for Perth-because she is the member who

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to scrap the mining tax! The newsletter put out by the Minister for Foreign Affairs is

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely accurate. It is entirely accurate because we are improving indexation for the DFRDB

Speaker: NA
Text: and the DFRB pensions-as we promised. We are delivering precisely on our promise. But

Speaker: NA
Text: when it comes to dodgy newsletters, what about the Leader of the Opposition's?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: We are not having a competition in props. There will be none.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: His newsletter-I must say that he looks a bit younger in the photograph

Speaker: NA
Text: in that newsletter; the pressure is getting to him-from 2012 promised, in big print on the

Speaker: NA
Text: front page, 'a budget surplus for a strong economy'. When? Throughout this mendacious

Speaker: NA
Text: document-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Macklin: On a point of order, Madam Speaker: page 203 of your budget papers shows

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts to veterans' pensions.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: There is no point of order.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: When it comes to newsletters, the Leader of the Opposition is an

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely serial deceiver of his electorate and a serial deceiver of the Australian people. If

Speaker: NA
Text: you cannot trust the Leader of the Opposition even to get a question right, why would you

Speaker: NA
Text: ever trust him with the future of this country?

Speaker: NA
Text: International Aid Program

Speaker: NA
Text: WYATT ROY (Longman) (14:33): To help members opposite, my question is to the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Curtin, the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Will the minister advise the House of the

Speaker: NA
Text: steps the government is taking to ensure Australia's aid program is responsible, sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: and affordable?

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms JULIE BISHOP (Curtin-Minister for Foreign Affairs) (14:33): I thank the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Longman for his question and I can inform the House that this afternoon, at the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Press Club, I launched the Australian government's new aid policy and our new strategic

Speaker: NA
Text: direction for the $5 billion-a-year aid program that makes Australia one of the top 10 donors

Speaker: NA
Text: in the OECD. I really want to thank the Deputy of Leader of the Opposition for her full

Speaker: NA
Text: endorsement of our aid program. Her media release referred to 'the Abbott government's fresh

Speaker: NA
Text: new approach on overseas aid'. Thank you very much; I appreciate that.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we are doing is focusing on our region-90 per cent of our aid budget will be

Speaker: NA
Text: focused on the Indian Ocean-Asia Pacific. We are going to develop innovative ways to

Speaker: NA
Text: engage the private sector to promote economic development, to reduce poverty and to lift

Speaker: NA
Text: standards of living in our region. We will put in place performance benchmarks and mutual

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations with partner countries and we will work for better results. We are going to focus

Speaker: NA
Text: our aid investment on health and education, building capacity in workforces, infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: and, importantly, empowering women and girls. It is a fresh new approach. There will be no

Speaker: NA
Text: more raiding of the aid budget to cover Labor's blow-out in onshore-that is right, 'onshore'-

Speaker: NA
Text: processing costs. Seven hundred and forty million dollars was ripped out of the aid budget to

Speaker: NA
Text: cover their blow-outs in the immigration budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: You would have thought that, having left an interest bill of $1 billion a month on their

Speaker: NA
Text: borrowings, Labor would have developed some sort of responsible approach. But I could not

Speaker: NA
Text: believe it when yesterday the member for Kingsford Smith recommitted Labor to increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: the aid budget by $16 billion. Where is the money coming from? More debt! But you should

Speaker: NA
Text: not expect too much from the member for Kingsford Smith. Back when he was in

Speaker: NA
Text: government, he was telling us that he was eminently qualified to be the Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary-this is serious-for Pacific Island Affairs because he regularly swims at Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: beaches! There it is. He is an expert on the Pacific because he goes swimming on Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: beaches! What next? You are a Pacific expert because you can see Fiji from your electorate?

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian government will deliver a responsible, affordable, sustainable aid budget-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I thank the Deputy Leader of the Opposition for her endorsement of our new policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Higher Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (14:40): My question is to the Minister for Education. Will the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister inform the House how the government's higher-education reforms, announced in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget, will help more students gain a higher-education qualification on the New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: Central Coast and in other regional areas?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Robertson for her question. Yesterday I was very fortunate to meet with the

Speaker: NA
Text: mayors of Wyong and Gosford, from the New South Wales Central Coast, who are both very

Speaker: NA
Text: ably represented by the member for Dobell and the member for Robertson. They were very

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to hear how the government's higher-education reforms will be of such enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit to a regional area like the Central Coast of NSW.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will be of benefit in three particular ways. They were very pleased to hear that because

Speaker: NA
Text: we are extending taxpayer subsidies, per student, to non-university higher-education providers

Speaker: NA
Text: that will be a financial shot in the arm to the four TAFEs that exist on the Central Coast of

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales; and on National TAFE Day it is good to be able to explain to TAFEs that

Speaker: NA
Text: they will get a large financial support out of the government, because of that first aspect of

Speaker: NA
Text: our reforms.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, of course, we are removing the cap on diplomas and associate degrees so that

Speaker: NA
Text: universities-like the University of Newcastle-which offer a high preponderance of such

Speaker: NA
Text: associate degrees and diplomas, especially on the Central Coast, will be able to expand their

Speaker: NA
Text: offerings to students in an area that will service, eventually, 400,000 people on the NSW

Speaker: NA
Text: Central Coast. That will be a widening of opportunity to more students, particularly for those

Speaker: NA
Text: of low-socioeconomic-status backgrounds, who typically use those kinds of courses to go into

Speaker: NA
Text: undergraduate degrees and find a pathway to university.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, if the University of Newcastle does not take up the opportunity of both the lifting

Speaker: NA
Text: of the cap and the expansion of the Commonwealth Grant Scheme's non-university higher

Speaker: NA
Text: education providers, then the competition that we have created in the market will allow new

Speaker: NA
Text: entrants into the Central Coast of New South Wales to compete with the University of

Speaker: NA
Text: Newcastle, so forcing the University of Newcastle to, in fact, offer those courses-if they

Speaker: NA
Text: want to keep their market-or the new providers, using the new freedoms of a deregulated

Speaker: NA
Text: system, will be able to give low-SES young people on the New South Wales Central Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to get a higher-education qualification and improve their chances of

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing their income over a lifetime.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is very good news for regional Australia, in the higher-education reforms, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: mayors were very pleased to see it. These two measures alone are costing $820 million. So

Speaker: NA
Text: our priorities are to put $820 million into higher education. Labor's priority is to spend $1

Speaker: NA
Text: billion a month-being sent to debtors overseas-to pay the interest alone on the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: government's debt that was left to us by Labor. Labor's priority is a billion dollars a month in

Speaker: NA
Text: interest repayments; ours is $820 million to expand opportunity.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: on the member for Hume.

Text: government's plan for infrastructure development in New South Wales-in particular, the

Speaker: NA
Text: plan to duplicate the Pacific Highway, which runs through my electorate of Lyne?

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Text: Wide Bay-Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure and

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Development) (14:48): I thank the honourable member for Lyne for his question,

Speaker: NA
Text: because New South Wales receives almost $15 billion under the coalition's $50 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure investment plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Champion interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Wakefield is warned.

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Text: What a difference that is going to make to the road system in New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales, both in Sydney and in provincial centres, and of course there is $5.6 billion for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific Highway. Finally, the dream of duplicating the Pacific Highway all the way from

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney to Brisbane will be achieved.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Albanese interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Grayndler has been warned. One more utterance and he

Speaker: NA
Text: will leave.

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Text: There is $5.6 billion on the table over six years to complete that task. Before

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of this year the $115 million upgrade of the Kundabung to Kempsey sections and the

Speaker: NA
Text: $683 million for the Oxley Highway to Kundabung section will be underway. They will be

Speaker: NA
Text: major projects that will employ many people on the way but will also make a real difference

Speaker: NA
Text: to the movement of traffic along the Pacific Highway. There is another 115 kilometres

Speaker: NA
Text: between Woolgoolga and Ballina still to be commenced, but the design work is advancing on

Speaker: NA
Text: that project. All of this has been possible because the coalition has restored the traditional 80-

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 funding mix for the Pacific Highway, unlike Labor, who were demanding that the state pay

Speaker: NA
Text: 50 per cent of the cost-money that they did not have. Under Labor this project would have

Speaker: NA
Text: taken a decade to complete, or even more, because the state would not have been able to

Speaker: NA
Text: find-

Speaker: Mr Albanese
Text: Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. In order to be relevant the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: must indicate a single new dollar for a single new project.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: There is no point of order. The member will resume his seat. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Prime Minister has the call.

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Text: Five point six billion dollars-that is not $1; that is $5.6 billion! That is

Speaker: NA
Text: money that will deliver the job. It will deliver the construction of this important piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: highway-something that would never have happened if Labor had been returned to

Speaker: NA
Text: government. This is indeed an extraordinary project. It will cut at least 90 minutes off the

Speaker: NA
Text: travel time for heavy transport-even more for lighter vehicles. What it will also do is reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: the road toll on this road-the number of deaths on the Pacific Highway. The work already

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: completed has basically halved the number of deaths on the highway. This is an important

Speaker: NA
Text: project and one that the coalition will complete.

Speaker: NA
Text: DISTINGUISHED VISITORS

Speaker: NA
Text: The SPEAKER (14:51): I would like to advise the chamber that we have with us today a

Speaker: NA
Text: delegation from the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan, led by Mr Ikram Sayed, a member of

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament. We are delighted to welcome you here and we wish you every success with the

Speaker: NA
Text: future ahead for your democracy building. Welcome.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members: Hear, hear!

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: Drought

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Text: Hunter) (14:51): My question is to the Prime Minister.

Speaker: Mr Joyce
Text: Oh!

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Text: I'm after the organ grinder.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: I think the member will withdraw.

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Text: I withdraw, Madam Speaker. Prime Minister, in February you and

Speaker: NA
Text: your agriculture minister announced, with much fanfare, that additional drought assistance for

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers was imminent. Why then, more than three months on, have you and your minister

Speaker: NA
Text: broken that promise to farming communities by failing to deliver not one cent of drought

Speaker: NA
Text: concessional loans to a farming family?

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: New England-Minister for Agriculture and Deputy Leader of The

Speaker: NA
Text: Nationals) (14:52): It is an absolute honour to get a question from my shadow. Might I say it

Speaker: NA
Text: is going to be an absolute honour to answer it as well. We have already in our first tranche

Speaker: NA
Text: realigned $420 million of the Farm Finance Concessional Loans Scheme, which they were

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to get signed off by all of the states. On top of that, we put in $10 million for water

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure. We followed that up with a second drought package of $320 million, of which

Speaker: NA
Text: $280 million has been signed off by the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the finance

Speaker: NA
Text: minister. QRAA is already able to lend that out, and they are lending it out through the

Speaker: NA
Text: tranches that have been made available to them within the $420 million. We have also made

Speaker: NA
Text: money available for wild dog control, and we have made money available for water

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure-

Speaker: Mr Fitzgibbon
Text: Madam Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Wild dogs are a problem, but

Speaker: NA
Text: how could they be remotely relevant to drought funding? Not one farming family has received

Speaker: NA
Text: a cent. He has-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Minister for Agriculture will return to the question.

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: Back on 4 March, we got through the transitional farm family payment, and

Speaker: NA
Text: over 1,300 people have applied for and received assistance. So there is quite a few dollars in

Speaker: NA
Text: that, you clown. We are getting these payments out because we are the side that can get the

Speaker: NA
Text: work done. You are the side that talk about it; we are the side that do it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Vocational Education and Training

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Hinkler. As a former TAFE student, apprentice and tradesperson, and on this National TAFE

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Day, I ask the Minister for Industry how the government's trade support loans and plans for

Speaker: NA
Text: skills and training will provide opportunities for future students?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE (Groom-Minister for Industry) (14:54): I thank the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Hinkler for his question. It is great to see someone who has not only graduated from

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFE in his electorate but also gone out and had a real job, unlike many on the other side

Speaker: NA
Text: who have basically just been trade union officials. The member for Hinkler has actually done

Speaker: NA
Text: a trade, gone out there and got his hands dirty and he is now doing an absolutely fine job

Speaker: NA
Text: representing the people of Hinkler. The member said in his maiden speech:

Speaker: NA
Text: … without the opportunity to learn, you lose your ability to succeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Husic interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Chifley will desist.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE: That is a fine line from someone who knows how important it

Speaker: NA
Text: is to learn, to get your trade and to get out there and not only secure an income but also be

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the earning economy. We on this side of the House want to make sure that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: putting out from training institutions people that are job ready, able to contribute and have the

Speaker: NA
Text: training and the skills that industry needs. As of 1 July, we will be starting our trade support

Speaker: NA
Text: loans which will assist apprentices through the time they are in training.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Rishworth interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Kingston will desist.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE: This scheme is worth $1.9 billion over the forward estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: and will assist apprentices. Fourth year apprentices will be able to get up to $20,000. As we

Speaker: NA
Text: know, these loans are interest free. They will be indexed on 1 June each year and are interest

Speaker: NA
Text: free. These loans will see a 20 per cent discount to apprentices and certain skilled trainees

Speaker: NA
Text: once they graduate. That is what this scheme is all about. It is about assisting people on the

Speaker: NA
Text: way through their training so that they can meet their daily and weekly needs and giving them

Speaker: NA
Text: a bonus and an incentive when they have finished. We want to see these trainees and

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices not only be supported but also have access to the best training institutions

Speaker: NA
Text: available. So we support the TAFE system. We support all the RTOs, as long as they provide

Speaker: NA
Text: a competitive and quality skills training system. We want to make sure that anyone, but young

Speaker: NA
Text: people particularly, embarking on a trade, like the member for Hinkler did, has the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to get the best possible qualifications. This government will support them every

Speaker: NA
Text: inch of the way with a trade support loan. We will be able to put more into this area once we

Speaker: NA
Text: get over the $1 billion a month we have to pay in interest because of the debt the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: government left us.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pensions and Benefits

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: Maribyrnong-Leader of the Opposition) (14:58): My question is to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. Before the election, the Prime Minister promised Australians: no change to

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions. But the Prime Minister has since cut the indexation of pensions and will force

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians to work until 70 years of age-the oldest retirement age in the world. Why did the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister yesterday make the bizarre claim that there are no broken promises in his

Speaker: NA
Text: rotten budget?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Prime Minister will take no notice of the penultimate word.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah-Prime Minister) (14:58): There are no changes to pensions in

Speaker: NA
Text: this term of parliament. It is as simple as that. There are no changes to pensions in this term of

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament. If the Australian people do not like what this government has proposed, they can

Speaker: NA
Text: take the appropriate action at the ballot box at the next election. I will tell you what this

Speaker: NA
Text: government is doing and why this is a budget that is honest and necessary for our country at

Speaker: NA
Text: this time. This government is outlining a clear plan to fix Labor's debt and deficit disaster.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: We have demonstrated exactly what we propose to do to deal with the

Speaker: NA
Text: mess that Labor created. Now it is up to Labor to demonstrate what it will do to fix up the

Speaker: NA
Text: mess that it created. If Labor thinks that there is something fundamentally wrong about

Speaker: NA
Text: applying to pensions the indexation rate that they applied to the Family Tax Benefit-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Jagajaga will desist.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: If Labor thinks that there is something fundamentally wrong with that,

Speaker: NA
Text: then they should tell us what they are going to do. They should tell us what they are going to

Speaker: NA
Text: do to fix up the Labor debt and deficit disaster, because, Madam Speaker, it is absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: crystal clear, as things stand, that members opposite think there was no problem-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Sydney will desist.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: with debt and deficit and there was no problem with broken promises-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Lingiari will also desist.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: They are living in a fantasy world, that is what they are doing. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer pointed out earlier today in question time, even John Edwards-a long-term Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: staffer, a long-term friend of the Labor Party and a decent human being, it has to be said, but

Speaker: NA
Text: someone whom Labor appointed to the Reserve Bank Board-has come out and said,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Honestly, there is a budget crisis.' John Edwards is right: there is a budget crisis. We accept

Speaker: NA
Text: that; we have put out our plan to deal with it; and it is high time that members opposite woke

Speaker: NA
Text: up to reality and told us exactly what their plan is.

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare

Speaker: Mr VARVARIS
Text: Barton) (15:01): My question is to the Minister for Health. What is the

Speaker: NA
Text: government doing to ensure the sustainability and universality of Medicare? Is the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of any alternative policy being proposed?

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: Dickson-Minister for Health and Minister for Sport) (15:01): I thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for his question. People have seen right through question time today, and really since

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget, that Labor is full of complaint but not solution. We have put forward a solution in

Speaker: NA
Text: this budget to make sure that Medicare is sustainable. Over the course of the last 10 years, the

Speaker: NA
Text: money that we spend each year on Medicare has gone from $8 billion to $20 billion. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: an ageing population. By 2050 7½ thousand Australians a week will be diagnosed with

Speaker: NA
Text: dementia or Alzheimer's, and I want to make sure-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Plibersek interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Sydney will desist.

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: that our health system is designed-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Plibersek interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Sydney has been warned.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: so that we can take care of those people. I want to make sure that we can

Speaker: NA
Text: listen to the independent advice that was provided to Prime Minister Rudd and Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Gillard, when both those prime ministers commissioned independent reports into the health

Speaker: NA
Text: system. In both of those reports, Christine Bennett and Simon Keenan came back to Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: and said that the current health system is not sustainable. Bob Hawke knew it was not

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainable back in 1991, when he introduced the co-payment and we know that for 50 years

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor has supported a co-payment in the medicine scheme to make it sustainable for our

Speaker: NA
Text: population.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Moreton will remove himself under 94 (a).

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Moreton then left the chamber.

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: We are absolutely determined in this budget to introduce a modest co-

Speaker: NA
Text: payment of $7.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: And those on my right will desist.

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: If people cannot afford the $7, doctors still have the discretion to bulk-bill

Speaker: NA
Text: patients. Patients are bulk-billed by doctors by discretion and from 1 July next year doctors

Speaker: NA
Text: will have the same discretion to bulk-bill patients. Of the $7, $5 goes into a $20 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: medical research fund so that we can help meet all of those health needs into the coming

Speaker: NA
Text: decades; and the remaining $2 goes back to the doctors. A total of $468 million will help

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors to continue to bulk-bill and it will be in addition to the money that they receive under

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare now. It is an incredibly important measure to make Medicare sustainable.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor has not uttered one word about how they intend to listen to the advice that Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Rudd received to make Medicare sustainable. They are talking about $16 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: more for foreign aid; they are talking about putting more money into the union movement;

Speaker: NA
Text: they are talking about putting more money into education, health and everything else. But

Speaker: NA
Text: they will not tell Australians how they will pay for it. I noticed overnight in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom, in the Times, a call for patients to pay $10 to see a GP. I think it is a very important

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion. In that discussion they are saying they want to introduce a co-payment because

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a £30 billion gap in the UK's NHS over the course of the next 10 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: We want to make our system sustainable, and we need to hear from the Labor Party how

Speaker: NA
Text: they will support, not oppose, that measure. They need to get out of the way.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: Jagajaga) (15:04): My question is to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister aware that at Senate estimates the Secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: confirmed a saving of $65.1 million in the forward estimates as a result of cutting the pension

Speaker: NA
Text: of some 280,000 veterans, partners of veterans and war widows? How can the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to claim that he is not cutting pensions?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah-Prime Minister) (15:05): Because pensions go up every year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pensions go up every year-every March and every September pensions go up. Pensions will

Speaker: NA
Text: go up every single year. It is true that, come September 2017, if this government is re-elected,

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be a change in the rate of indexation. That is true, but pensions will continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase every single year. They will increase every March; they will increase every

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: September; they will increase every single year. I say again to the rather noisy member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Jagajaga-the member for Jagajaga who is so honest and truthful that she promised in her

Speaker: NA
Text: 2012 budget update that 'we are back in surplus'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: When are we back in surplus? Not 2012!

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Macklin: On a point of order, Madam Speaker. It is on relevance: for this budget and

Speaker: NA
Text: this Prime Minister's cuts to pensions.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: There is no point of order.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Lingiari is warned.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: There is no year ever when pensions go down. Every year pensions go up.

Speaker: NA
Text: They go up in March every year. They go up in September every year. They go up twice

Speaker: NA
Text: every year. The only difference is that from September 2017 they will be indexed by the same

Speaker: NA
Text: rate that the member for Jagajaga herself, as minister for family services, thought was fair and

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable for the family tax benefit. If it is fair and reasonable for the family tax benefit, if it

Speaker: NA
Text: is just and moral for the family tax benefit, it is moral for other benefits as well. Not only was

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Jagajaga being utterly untruthful in her budget update; she is being utterly

Speaker: NA
Text: untruthful now. She should be better than that-she really should be.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Post

Speaker: Mr TAYLOR
Text: Hume) (15:07): My question is to the Minister for Communications. I

Speaker: NA
Text: remind the minister that post offices provide key services to communities in my electorate and

Speaker: NA
Text: in other rural and regional areas. How is the government helping Australia Post to ensure the

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainability of rural and regional licensed post offices?

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Minister for Communications) (15:08): I thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for his question and note his very keen interest in this issue. Yesterday,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Post launched a rural sustainability package to support its licensed post offices. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is the latest in a series of initiatives that will contribute an additional $40 million a year to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure the sustainability of the licensed post office retail network, and that is on top of $320

Speaker: NA
Text: million paid annually to these licensees. For the first time, an additional 432 licensed post

Speaker: NA
Text: offices, almost all of whom are in rural and regional Australia, will be provided with access to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Post's electronic point of sale system, and it means they will now be able to deliver

Speaker: NA
Text: and get paid for additional services such as electronic payments and banking services.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are 2,550 licensed post offices, of which about two-thirds are in rural and regional

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. They have been doing it tough because the economics of the post office has been

Speaker: NA
Text: worsening. I want to acknowledge the great work that is being done, sometimes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: discomfort of Australia Post and, indeed, to the minister of the Senate Environment and

Speaker: NA
Text: Communications Committee, chaired by Senator John Williams and vigorously encouraged

Speaker: NA
Text: by Senator Boswell, who is, of course, retiring at the end of this month. The challenges facing

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Post are very significant. It is a very high-fixed-cost business. The letters business is

Speaker: NA
Text: a very high-fixed-cost business and every year letter volumes are declining. Every time there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a dollar less spent on letters, it is in excess of an 80c hit to the bottom line of the post office.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a result, about a billion fewer letters have been sent over the past five years. In the past

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: two years, Australia Post has recorded a combined loss of more than $400 million in its

Speaker: NA
Text: regulated letters business. That trend is going to accelerate. It is expected that letter volumes

Speaker: NA
Text: will decline by about eight per cent each year into the future. Australia Post now forecasts a

Speaker: NA
Text: loss of more than $300 million in its letters business next year. The consequence of that is

Speaker: NA
Text: that, while it has a profitable retail business and a profitable parcels business, by next

Speaker: NA
Text: financial year it is expecting to record a total company loss because of the losses on letters

Speaker: NA
Text: overwhelming the profits on parcels. There is a widely-held view that the parcels business is

Speaker: NA
Text: growing so fast that it will overtake the losses in letters. That is simply not right. So there are

Speaker: NA
Text: big existential challenges for Australia Post. We are taking them on. We are looking at

Speaker: NA
Text: reform. We are looking at all the options. We are working hard with the management to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that it continues to deliver a relevant and sustainable service to all Australians.

Speaker: Mr Abbott
Text: I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Text: North Sydney-The Treasurer) (15:11): Madam Speaker, I seek the

Speaker: NA
Text: indulgence of the chair to add to an answer.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The minister may proceed.

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Text: I was asked a little bit earlier about the words of John Edwards, a Reserve

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank board member. I quoted the Australian Financial Review from yesterday, in which he

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: I've no doubt there is a budget crisis. We're accumulating debt as a higher share of GDP and of

Speaker: NA
Text: course in absolute terms, [it's] absolutely astronomical compared to far more serious episodes in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian history, including recoveries from serious recessions …

Speaker: NA
Text: I should have added this comment referred to him from the article:

Speaker: NA
Text: He says even during the Great Depression we didn't see deficits as a share of GDP of the size we're

Speaker: NA
Text: now experiencing.

Speaker: NA
Text: I table this report because the member for Lilley is in denial. He has never been one for the

Speaker: NA
Text: facts. I table it for his edification.

Speaker: NA
Text: longstanding arrangements.' In response to a question: 'So there are no new projects. Is that

Speaker: NA
Text: correct?' Mr Mrdak responded, 'The program is continuing as it has been.'

Speaker: NA
Text: 2 MRS PRENTICE: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) expresses concern at the detention in Egypt of Australian citizen Peter Greste;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) notes that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Mr Greste is detained and currently on trial solely for conducting his role as a journalist and for

Speaker: NA
Text: peacefully expressing his opinion on events in Egypt; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) the imprisonment of Peter Greste is contrary to the right to freedom of speech and expression;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) recognises that the Prime Minister, Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Attorney-General have all

Speaker: NA
Text: been in contact with their Egyptian counterparts seeking Peter Greste's release; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) notes that the Australian Government:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) is offering all possible consular assistance to Peter Greste and his family;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) has been working with Egyptian authorities at all appropriate opportunities; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) is making direct and high-level representation to a number of other governments as part of a

Speaker: NA
Text: multi-pronged strategy to raise our ongoing concerns about the case.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 16 June 2014.)

Speaker: NA
Text: Time allotted-50 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speech time limits-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Prentice-10 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Next Member speaking-10 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Members-5 minutes each.

Speaker: NA
Text: [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 2 x 10 + 6 x 5 mins]

Speaker: NA
Text: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3 MS PARKE: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) shipbuilding is an industry that delivers the highest-value and most complex manufacturing

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes produced in Australia, and therefore represents expertise and capacity that must be

Speaker: NA
Text: maintained for its very significant national economic and security benefits;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) as an example of the multiplier effects of shipbuilding projects in respect of the quality and range

Speaker: NA
Text: of manufacturing it both requires and enables, at the commencement of the Collins-class submarine

Speaker: NA
Text: project there were only 35 Australian companies certified to Defence quality standards, whereas by

Speaker: NA
Text: 1998 there were more than 1,500;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) there are currently more than 7,000 people employed in shipbuilding across Australia, including

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 4,000 people employed in naval shipbuilding alone;

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) the Government has identified the need for more than 80 ships over the next 30 years for service

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Royal Australian Navy, and as part of border protection, Antarctic operations and scientific

Speaker: NA
Text: research, among other roles; and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) if Australian shipbuilding is not supported through a properly planned and managed program of

Speaker: NA
Text: project and maintenance work, it is likely that shipyards will close, thousands of jobs will be lost, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the critical expertise and capacity that have been developed will be irreparably squandered; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) calls on the Government to:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) provide certainty to the Australian shipbuilding industry and to thousands of Australian workers

Speaker: NA
Text: by settling a short, medium and long term program of government shipbuilding projects to ensure a

Speaker: NA
Text: balanced work flow and smooth delivery of key naval assets; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) bring forward relevant shipbuilding projects, including the Pacific patrol boat and replacement

Speaker: NA
Text: Anzac frigate projects, in a timely manner to ensure that shipyards, companies, and workers are not put

Speaker: NA
Text: at risk.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 16 June 2014.)

Speaker: NA
Text: Time allotted-remaining private Members' business time prior to 12 noon.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speech time limits-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Parke-5 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Members-5 minutes. each.

Speaker: NA
Text: [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 8 x 5 mins]

Speaker: NA
Text: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

Text: 1 MR NEUMANN: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) the National Congress of Australia's First Peoples (Congress) is the national representative body

Speaker: NA
Text: of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Congress:

Speaker: NA
Text: (i) was established with a view to creating a new relationship with governments to reset the

Speaker: NA
Text: relationship based on partnership and genuine engagement with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander

Speaker: NA
Text: peoples; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) is owned and controlled by its membership and independent of government;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) recognises:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) the important role of Congress as a leader and advocate for recognising the status and rights of

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders as First Nations Peoples in Australia; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) that the existence of an effective national body is essential to the Government's ability to fulfil its

Speaker: NA
Text: Closing the Gap targets;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) acknowledges that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Congress received Deductible Gift Recipient status in July 2013, allowing it to begin to pursue

Speaker: NA
Text: income opportunities with corporate Australia and the wider community;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) the previous government committed:

Speaker: NA
Text: (i) $29.2 million over four years to establish Congress; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) $15 million over three years in the 2013 budget to support Congress to continue to develop

Speaker: NA
Text: income opportunities to sustain the organisation; and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) ongoing Commonwealth funding beyond 2013 is essential to support the continued sustainability

Speaker: NA
Text: of an independent national voice for First Nation Peoples;

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) notes with concern that the Government plans to cut the $15 million funding and abandon the

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to the sustainability of Congress as the national representative body for Aboriginal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Torres Strait Islander Peoples; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) calls on the Government to commit to the sustainability of a strong Congress by honouring the $15

Speaker: NA
Text: million funding commitment.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 13 February 2014.)

Speaker: NA
Text: Time allotted-20 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Neumann-5 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Members-5 minutes each.

Speaker: NA
Text: [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 4 x 5 mins]

Speaker: NA
Text: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

Text: 2 MR SIMPKINS: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes the mutually beneficial and strengthening cooperation between Australia and Japan with

Speaker: NA
Text: particular emphasis on our:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) strong trade relationship;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) significant strategic partnership; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) developing defence equipment and technology relationship;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) acknowledges the:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Australian Government's success in concluding the Japan Australia Economic Partnership

Speaker: NA
Text: Agreement;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) scope to further enhance our relationship in areas such as investment and education;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) Australian Government's plans to combat sovereign risk for foreign investment in Australia by

Speaker: NA
Text: repealing both the carbon and mining taxes;

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) importance of elevating the bilateral security and defence relationship to a new level, based on

Speaker: NA
Text: our shared strategic interests in regional and international peace, stability and prosperity; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) importance of the forthcoming visit to Australia of Prime Minister, His Excellency Mr Shinzo

Speaker: NA
Text: Abe, in further building our strategic partnership with Japan into a new special relationship; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) commends the Australian Government for enhancing the relationship between Australia and Japan,

Speaker: NA
Text: which will be mutually beneficial for the economies and people of Australia and Japan.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 16 June 2014.)

Text: 3 Ms O'Dwyer: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House notes:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) that the spirit of ANZAC is one of special significance to all Australians as it showcases the

Speaker: NA
Text: attributes of courage, mateship and sacrifice which were demonstrated at the Gallipoli landing;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) that the ANZACs helped define us as a people and as a nation, they were ordinary Australians who

Speaker: NA
Text: performed extraordinary deeds and were drawn from the smallest towns and biggest cities;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) that the Government is enabling Australians to honour the service and sacrifice that epitomises the

Speaker: NA
Text: ANZAC spirit by increasing the funding allocated to each federal electorate across Australia to

Speaker: NA
Text: $125,000 via the ANZAC Centenary Local Grants Program; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) the Government's commitment to community-based commemoration, as promised at the last

Speaker: NA
Text: election.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4 Dr Leigh: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) recognises that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) since 1975, earnings at the 90th percentile have risen three times faster than earnings at the 10th

Speaker: NA
Text: percentile; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) since 1980, the top 1 per cent income share has doubled, and the top 0.1 per cent income share

Speaker: NA
Text: has tripled; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) overall, inequality in Australia is now higher than it has been in three-quarters of a century;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) notes that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) analysis by NATSEM (which the Prime Minister once described as 'the most reputable and

Speaker: NA
Text: authoritative modelling organisation in Australia') shows that the 2014-15 budget will redistribute

Speaker: NA
Text: income from lower-income households to higher-income households;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) by 2017-18, NATSEM analysis suggests that the budget will cause:

Speaker: NA
Text: (i) across all households, a 2.2 per cent drop in disposable incomes in the bottom quintile, and an

Speaker: NA
Text: 0.2 per cent rise in disposable incomes in the top quintile;

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) among couples with children, a 6.6 per cent drop in disposable incomes of households in the

Speaker: NA
Text: poorest quintile; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (iii) among single parents, a 10.8 per cent drop in disposable incomes of households in the poorest

Speaker: NA
Text: quintile; and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) calls upon the Government to rethink a budget that not only breaks promises and produces higher

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit figures than in the Pre-election Economic and Fiscal Outlook 2014, but also fails the 'fair go test'

Speaker: NA
Text: by hurting low and middle income families.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 2 June 2014.)

Speaker: NA
Text: Time allotted-20 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr LEIGH -5 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Members-5 minutes each.

Speaker: NA
Text: [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 4 x 5 mins]

Speaker: NA
Text: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

Text: 6 Ms Hall: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) June is Lipoedema Awareness Month, and that Lipoedema is a painful disorder of fat metabolism

Speaker: NA
Text: and distribution that causes deposition of fat in 5 to 15 per cent of the population (mainly women) in the

Speaker: NA
Text: legs and arms; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Lipoedema is:

Speaker: NA
Text: (i) an underdiagnosed disorder for which sufferers receive poor medical diagnosis and no

Speaker: NA
Text: counselling support-Lipoedema is a poorly supported illness; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) one of the most underfunded chronic conditions in Australia with limited research as to its

Speaker: NA
Text: cause and the treatment required for patients;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) calls for:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) a public awareness campaign to be launched and for Medicare Locals to be involved in the

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) support to be given to people living with Lipoedema to ensure appropriate ancillary services are

Speaker: NA
Text: available; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) notes the need for research and population data on Lipoedema.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 16 June 2014.)

Speaker: NA
Text: DOCUMENTS

Speaker: NA
Text: Presentation

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, documents are tabled in accordance with the list circulated to honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier today. Full details of the documents will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.

Speaker: NA
Text: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment

Speaker: NA
Text: The SPEAKER (15:14): I have received a letter from the honourable member for Gorton

Speaker: NA
Text: proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion, namely:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's failure to have a plan for Australian jobs while attacking job seekers and cutting

Speaker: NA
Text: training opportunities for young people.

Speaker: NA
Text: I call upon those honourable members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places.

Speaker: NA
Text: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR (Gorton) (15:15): Thank you very much, Madam Speaker.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a matter of public importance, and for that reason the opposition wants to have a true

Speaker: NA
Text: debate on the future of jobs in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: With the benefit of hindsight it is easy to conclude that this government has no interest in

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting for Australian jobs but, back when the Prime Minister was the opposition leader, it

Speaker: NA
Text: was not so easy. That was a time when the then Leader of the Opposition visited hundreds of

Speaker: NA
Text: workplaces, using workers as props-as a backdrop to his doorstops-he had his hard hat on,

Speaker: NA
Text: and he had his high-vis vest and safety glasses, and he claimed he would defend their jobs if

Speaker: NA
Text: he was ever to be elected prime minister. Well, this proved to be all talk and no action: within

Speaker: NA
Text: months of the election, this government stood back and watched the collapse of the car

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. Worse, in this place, we had a treasurer goad Holden to leave this country-and that

Speaker: NA
Text: is what Holden promptly decided to do. Toyota soon followed. With these two decisions, we

Speaker: NA
Text: will now see thousands of workers-thousands of high-skill jobs-disappear. With the

Speaker: NA
Text: departure of those iconic companies, tens of thousands of jobs are at grave risk in the

Speaker: NA
Text: automotive parts industry and beyond. Where is the Prime Minister now, given the amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: time he was willing to spend as opposition leader in workplaces around this country? He is

Speaker: NA
Text: not visiting blue-collar workers in these companies, assuring them that he will fight for their

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs. He is not visiting Holden and Toyota to assure those workers-those soon-to-be-

Speaker: NA
Text: retrenched workers-that he will find them new jobs. No, the Prime Minister has gone

Speaker: NA
Text: missing in action when it comes to providing opportunities for employment for those workers

Speaker: NA
Text: and other workers in the labour market. The fact is that the Prime Minister has no idea what it

Speaker: NA
Text: will do to those workers and their families when the car industry effectively dies. What

Speaker: NA
Text: arrogance and ignorance was on display by the Prime Minister when he talked about

Speaker: NA
Text: liberating these workers from secure employment-what more shameless approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: industry policy can there be than for a Prime Minister to suggest that the best way forward for

Speaker: NA
Text: these workers is to lose secure employment and be placed in an unemployed position or, at

Speaker: NA
Text: best, to find precarious employment in the labour market?

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not just the car industry; the dysfunction of this government was revealed when it

Speaker: NA
Text: bungled the handling of the future of our national aviation carrier, Qantas. When Qantas

Speaker: NA
Text: announced 5,000 effective full-time jobs would be cut, the government was all over the place.

Speaker: NA
Text: When anxious Qantas workers looked to the government to fight to save their jobs, the

Speaker: NA
Text: government could only find time to fight amongst themselves. For months we saw

Speaker: NA
Text: speculation, leaking, and backgrounding-against each other-about what should happen.

Speaker: NA
Text: When Qantas tried to work with the government, it was rebuffed by the Prime Minister. One

Speaker: NA
Text: day the Treasurer would outline what Qantas needed to do to secure a debt guarantee-you

Speaker: NA
Text: could read about it on the front page of The Financial Review-and the next day the

Speaker: NA
Text: government would walk away and say it was not possible. What was the result of this

Speaker: NA
Text: dysfunction, this ineptitude, and this callous disregard for workers? The consequence was

Speaker: NA
Text: that, under this government, thousands of Qantas jobs will go overseas-that is, pilots, cabin

Speaker: NA
Text: crew, flight attendants, engineers, maintenance workers and, quite possibly, the chair of the

Speaker: NA
Text: company, the majority of directors, and even the head office of this iconic Australian flagship

Speaker: NA
Text: company will go overseas. This government might think that is fine, but Labor knows-as

Speaker: NA
Text: most Australians know-that once skilled jobs go offshore, they do not come back. Once you

Speaker: NA
Text: lose skills in your labour market, it is very difficult to replace them. That is why we will fight

Speaker: NA
Text: to keep Qantas Australian and to keep jobs in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaking of Qantas and job cuts, there was some devastating news today with the

Speaker: NA
Text: announcement that QantasLink flights into Nhulunbuy in the Northern Territory will cease

Speaker: NA
Text: from August. This is a direct result of the closure of the alumina refinery at Gove. Where is

Speaker: NA
