Text: the government now? Where is the government's plan to assist Nhulunbuy and north-east

Speaker: NA
Text: Arnhem Land, a community facing a loss of 1,200 jobs? This will destroy that community. It

Speaker: NA
Text: happened months ago-and the Prime Minister, who promised to be there in his first week as

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, has not turned up for nine months! We will see devastation in that community

Speaker: NA
Text: as a result, and there has been no response from the government and no response from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. This self-proclaimed Indigenous Prime Minister has turned his back on his

Speaker: NA
Text: promise to return to north-east Arnhem-like he has with so many other promises.

Speaker: NA
Text: What of other companies announcing more than 100 job losses? Simplot, Electrolux,

Speaker: NA
Text: Caterpillar, BP, Rio Tinto, Kellogg's, BHP, Arrow Energy, Forge Group, Alcoa, Asciano,

Speaker: NA
Text: Sensis, Optus, and many, many more. No wonder the government's own department forecast

Speaker: NA
Text: that there would be 160,000 fewer jobs than the Prime Minister promised before the election.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: But it is not just this government's indifference to jobs and ineptitude; it is not that they do not

Speaker: NA
Text: have an industry minister-they have an industry minister, but they have no industry policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: This industry minister has not won one debate within the cabinet. The cruelty and the callous

Speaker: NA
Text: disregard for workers to be found in industry policy, or in the lack thereof, is writ large in the

Speaker: NA
Text: papers of the budget. It can be seen vividly in the cuts to apprenticeships and traineeships that

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Cunningham will refer to in this debate. What is it about this government that

Speaker: NA
Text: it thinks it can say to the young job seekers of this country 'you need to earn or learn' while it

Speaker: NA
Text: is cutting $1 billion out of apprenticeships and traineeships? What does the government think

Speaker: NA
Text: young people can do when unemployment amongst young people hits more than 13 per cent?

Speaker: NA
Text: How can they find a job to earn when the economy is in that state?

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor does support the principle of earning or learning, but you have to have jobs with

Speaker: NA
Text: which to earn and you have to have training places in which to learn. Without that investment

Speaker: NA
Text: and without those job opportunities, it is an absolute disgrace that this government thinks it is

Speaker: NA
Text: okay to cut income for job seekers under the age of 30 for six months. To think that young

Speaker: NA
Text: people will be able to survive for six months without any support whatsoever is ridiculous. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is not only economically ridiculous and absurd; it is socially reprehensible. What we have

Speaker: NA
Text: here is an obligation that has been placed on young people in this country to either earn or

Speaker: NA
Text: learn, and yet the opportunities will not exist in many parts of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week I was in Devonport and Launceston, and in Devonport in northern Tasmania

Speaker: NA
Text: youth unemployment is north of 20 per cent. What does the government expect those young

Speaker: NA
Text: people to do? What we have here is a government that is willing to punish young job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: for not finding jobs, and the way they will punish them is to rip away the only support they

Speaker: NA
Text: get from the government while they are looking for work. It just does not make any sense. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is harsh, it is mean and tricky, and it is going to ensure that we see greater social disharmony.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are going to see antisocial behaviour, we are going to see an increase in crime, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: going to see an increase in self-harm and we are going to see young people despairing in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country because they have no support whatsoever.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the most ludicrous part of the government's proposition? I found out last week that

Speaker: NA
Text: even though the government is choosing not to provide any support for these job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: under the age of 30 for the first six months, they are going to oblige them to look for 40 jobs a

Speaker: NA
Text: month. There was a time when the principle of mutual obligation did apply-it started under

Speaker: NA
Text: Working Nation under the Keating government and was embraced by the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government-and you were provided with a modest level of income while at the same time

Speaker: NA
Text: you were required to look for work. That was continued by subsequent governments. This

Speaker: NA
Text: government is the first in living memory to tear up the compact between government and job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers. They are tearing up the principle of mutual obligation and are expecting young

Speaker: NA
Text: people under the age of 30 to fend for themselves in a labour market where few opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: exist in some regions of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government does not get it. The Prime Minister does not get it. They have a lot to

Speaker: NA
Text: answer for, and they should be looking after young people. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr HARTSUYKER
Text: Cowper-Deputy Leader of the House and Assistant Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment) (15:25): I certainly welcome the opportunity to speak on this matter of public

Speaker: NA
Text: importance concerning jobs and training. What we have heard is 10 minutes of rhetoric from

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Gorton and failed immigration minister, the guy who won the silver Logie for

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: boat arrivals-not the gold Logie; the member for MCMahon won the gold Logie on failed

Speaker: NA
Text: border protection-and who certainly has no reputation at all with regard to job creation. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: us think about Labor's record in relation to unemployment. On their watch youth

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment queues increased by 55,000, on their watch the rate of youth unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: increased by almost three per cent and on their watch the number of unemployed increased by

Speaker: NA
Text: 200,000. He seems to have suddenly found a solution to the problems of the Australian car

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, and their solution is endless rhetoric. Let us remind the good member of the past,

Speaker: NA
Text: because he seems to have forgotten that Mitsubishi left Australia on their watch. He was not

Speaker: NA
Text: able to stop Mitsubishi from leaving. He claims he has all of the answers today, yet

Speaker: NA
Text: Mitsubishi left. He is looking left, he is looking right, but Mitsubishi left on his watch. Former

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister Gillard announced funding for Ford-it was going to save Ford, it was going

Speaker: NA
Text: to create jobs, and what happened? Ford announced it was leaving. Far from being the

Speaker: NA
Text: champion of people in the workforce, the member opposite is nothing but a failure.

Speaker: NA
Text: We on this side of the House believe that nothing creates opportunities faster, and nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: creates more jobs, than a strong economy. The budget that was handed down in this House

Speaker: NA
Text: just weeks ago sets the stage for building jobs into the future. It was a budget that invests for

Speaker: NA
Text: our future rather than what the opposition did when in government, and that was to spend for

Speaker: NA
Text: today. Ours is a budget that invests in infrastructure; it is a budget that provides incentives

Speaker: NA
Text: and programs to assist people into work. Members opposite face some real challenges as we

Speaker: NA
Text: approach 30 June. They could assist with the repeal of the carbon tax-a $7.6 billion hit on

Speaker: NA
Text: the economy. If the members opposite were serious about having concerns for unemployed

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, if the members opposite were serious about creating jobs for young Australians,

Speaker: NA
Text: they would immediately assist the government in the repeal of the carbon tax. What are you

Speaker: NA
Text: doing? You are sitting there and doing nothing. You are sitting on your hands, when the

Speaker: NA
Text: repeal of the carbon tax will create jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then there is the mining tax. Those opposite are standing in the way of the repeal of the

Speaker: NA
Text: mining tax. Why don't you support the repeal of the mining tax? Why don't you come over

Speaker: NA
Text: this side and vote for it? We believe the best way to create jobs is through a strong economy. I

Speaker: NA
Text: noticed that you mentioned the great state of Tasmania in your contribution.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. BC Scott): Order! The minister might refer his

Speaker: NA
Text: comments through me, not at me. The use of the word 'you' is a common mistake on both

Speaker: NA
Text: sides of the chamber.

Speaker: Mr HARTSUYKER
Text: The good member mentioned the great state of Tasmania and

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment there. There are some great industries in Tasmania, and the dairy industry is in

Speaker: NA
Text: a state of growth. In north-western Tasmania, an area of high unemployment, we see an

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing demand for labour, and what do the members opposite do? They insist on imposing

Speaker: NA
Text: a carbon tax-a carbon tax that increases the cost at the farm gate by around $10,000 a farm;

Speaker: NA
Text: a carbon tax that adds massively to the cost of milk processing. The competitors to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmanian dairy industry are not carrying those taxes. They are not carrying a carbon tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: the world's largest carbon tax. If those opposite were serious about the job prospects for

Speaker: NA
Text: young Tasmanians, they would come over here and vote with us on the repeal of the carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: The good old member for Franklin has left the chamber. She was not interested enough to

Speaker: NA
Text: stay around. She is the last remaining Labor member for Tasmania. It was not that long ago

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that the member for Franklin would have been joined by four other members. Labor used to

Speaker: NA
Text: hold five seats in Tasmania, but not any more. There is only one left. She is the last Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: member standing. With a reputation like theirs on job creation, it is no wonder. It is because

Speaker: NA
Text: of the job-destroying Labor-Greens alliance.

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe that the best way to grow jobs is through a strong economy. We also have a

Speaker: NA
Text: suite of programs to assist in the creation of jobs and to assist job seekers. We have a job

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment bonus that will provide a $2,500 payment to encourage young people to get and

Speaker: NA
Text: keep a job, to get into work and stay off welfare for 12 months. If they stay off welfare for a

Speaker: NA
Text: further 12 months and stay in work-that is two years in total-there is an additional $4,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a $6,500 incentive to encourage young people to get into work.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have relocation assistance of up to $6,000 to encourage people to move to a regional

Speaker: NA
Text: area and $3,000 to move to a metropolitan area. If those job seekers who need assistance to

Speaker: NA
Text: move have dependents, there is a further $3,000 available. We have the restart program,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is going to encourage employers to put on older workers to enjoy the benefits bringing

Speaker: NA
Text: workers with a lifetime of experience into the workforce can bring. It is a $10,000 incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: for employers to employ people over the age of 50. It is a very important program.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have the Tasmanian jobs plan. It is an incentive payment for employers in Tasmania to

Speaker: NA
Text: put on an extra Tasmanian. I would hope that they would take up that program because, as we

Speaker: NA
Text: know, Tasmania is the state with the highest unemployment in the country. It is a state that

Speaker: NA
Text: could benefit greatly, as I said, from the growth in the dairy industry. But what do the

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite do? They insist on retaining the job-destroying carbon tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have a range of measures in the budget in relation to skills and training, including the

Speaker: NA
Text: $476 million Industry Skills Fund to deliver close to 200,000 targeted training programs over

Speaker: NA
Text: four years. We have trade support loans to encourage young apprentices to get their training.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have expanded opportunities with expanded scholarships for young people from

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantaged backgrounds. We have expanded funding to students studying diplomas,

Speaker: NA
Text: advanced diplomas and associate degrees. These are great programs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Also, more recently, I announced the rollout of phase 1 of our revamped Work for the Dole

Speaker: NA
Text: program. It is a program which has the potential to give young people some of the important

Speaker: NA
Text: basic skills that they need to assist them to get by in the workplace. Many employers have

Speaker: NA
Text: been telling me that young job seekers are presenting at the gates of their businesses without

Speaker: NA
Text: the necessary basic skills to get by in the workplace-simple skills such as turning up on

Speaker: NA
Text: time, having the right attitude and getting on with their workmates. These are skills that we

Speaker: NA
Text: who have been in the workforce for many years take for granted but unfortunately are sadly

Speaker: NA
Text: lacking for many job seekers.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have engaged in expanding Work for the Dole, giving young people in 18 selected

Speaker: NA
Text: locations who have been unemployed for 12 months or more the opportunity to participate in

Speaker: NA
Text: a Work for the Dole program, gain those new skills and have something to take to a future

Speaker: NA
Text: employer. They can have a reference as to what they have done, what they have achieved and

Speaker: NA
Text: what they have contributed to their community. As I get around the country, there is

Speaker: NA
Text: widespread acceptance of our revamped Work for the Dole program. Local councils

Speaker: NA
Text: understand the importance of Work for the Dole. Participants understand the importance of

Speaker: NA
Text: Work for the Dole. So many young people are saying to me, 'Give me a chance to participate.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Give me a chance to show you what I can do.' I am certain that there will be many young

Speaker: NA
Text: people who will benefit greatly from our enhanced Work for the Dole program.

Speaker: NA
Text: We on this side of the House understand quite clearly that nothing creates jobs faster and

Speaker: NA
Text: more effectively than a strong economy. That is why we introduced the budget recently into

Speaker: NA
Text: this House. It is a budget that sets Australia up for the future. When they see the members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite voting again against the repeal of the carbon tax and the repeal of the mining tax, it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be clear to the young people and job seekers of Australia that they are not about getting

Speaker: NA
Text: the settings right. They are not about assisting in the creation of jobs. They are only about

Speaker: NA
Text: standing in the way. We are a government focused on creating opportunities and giving young

Speaker: NA
Text: people assistance into work. They are an opposition that could not manage the budget when

Speaker: NA
Text: they were in government and do not understand the facts of what we need in this country to

Speaker: NA
Text: create jobs. They are simply intent on standing in the way.

Speaker: Ms BIRD
Text: Cunningham) (15:35): What a valiant effort at wrapping a whole lot of rubbish

Speaker: NA
Text: in a ribbon! Honestly-let's bell the cat here-you cannot drag millions and millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars out of a particular area, such as skills, and then say, 'Because we have given what is

Speaker: NA
Text: left a new name we have new initiatives.' That is what the government is attempting to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reality is that $2 billion for programs in the skills area has been cut. The bit that is left-

Speaker: NA
Text: the member, for example, talked about the Industry Skills Fund-at half the size of the

Speaker: NA
Text: original programs that were knocked off to create it is rebadged and renamed and we are told,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Isn't it wonderful? We have a new program.' It is not wonderful. It is not wonderful because

Speaker: NA
Text: what the government has actually done is cut $2 billion out of skills programs and $1 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: out of support for apprentices. It should be held responsible for it. Young apprentices and

Speaker: NA
Text: their families will be holding the government responsible for it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wanted to take the opportunity to back my colleague's matter of public importance today

Speaker: NA
Text: because, as we indicated in the parliament-and I acknowledge that the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledged this-today is National TAFE Day. The point I want to make in this debate

Speaker: NA
Text: about the importance of creating opportunities for both jobs and the training that will go

Speaker: NA
Text: towards achieving those jobs for not just young people but the whole Australian population is

Speaker: NA
Text: that many people may find themselves in life circumstances where they need to retrain. They

Speaker: NA
Text: might have been out of the workforce, for example, raising a family for a significant amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of time and they need to re-enter the workforce. They might be existing workers in a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular industry sector that has been the topic of much debate-and my colleague raised

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the issues there-where workers need to reskill for future job opportunities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Investing in the people of this nation is a significant task, yet this government sees it

Speaker: NA
Text: simply as a cost. That is how they view it. It is a cost and as much as you can cut out of it, you

Speaker: NA
Text: cut out of it, until it is down to the bone and then you blame the people who fall through the

Speaker: NA
Text: cracks and are not able to get the training and education they need to get into the jobs they

Speaker: NA
Text: need for their own situation. You doubly punish them then by making them wait for six-

Speaker: NA
Text: months before they get income support. That is the reality of what you have done in this

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. That is the reality that will face communities across this nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The previous member talked about the importance of providing pathways. I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: take him to the really disgraceful cut in the apprenticeship sector, that they have made in this

Speaker: NA
Text: budget, which is to abolish the Apprenticeships Access Program. For example, I visited one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the centres in Parramatta run by the Motor Traders Association where they are working

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: with the most disadvantaged young people in that area to give them exactly what the member

Speaker: NA
Text: was talking about-the basic skills in a pre-apprenticeship level course to equip them to get

Speaker: NA
Text: an apprenticeship. Why is that cut, if the government is as committed as it says it is to

Speaker: NA
Text: providing young people with pathways?

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Rowland interjecting-

Speaker: Ms BIRD
Text: Yes. The apprenticeships mentoring program provided mature age people as

Speaker: NA
Text: supports for apprentices to assist them to ensure that they can get through to completion-

Speaker: NA
Text: another great program well supported by industries wanting to give young people a chance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Abolished, completely gone. So if the government is as serious as they claim to be, they have

Speaker: NA
Text: gone to the very wrong programs in terms of the cuts that they have made and, as a result,

Speaker: NA
Text: they are leaving young people, their families and their communities in a much more difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not surprising, because we have had for quite a few years now conservative state

Speaker: NA
Text: governments who have carried out exactly the same sort of agenda with our tremendous

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFE system. TAFE has provided trades and a second-chance education for people across

Speaker: NA
Text: this country for a number of generations now. It is a trusted brand and it should be a trusted

Speaker: NA
Text: brand, because its priority and its focus have been on providing the skills and opportunities,

Speaker: NA
Text: the re-entry qualifications that people need to engage in further education and work. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: national asset. It is actually a national strategic advantage that we have had such a fantastic

Speaker: NA
Text: public education provider in the VET sector. On this day, as on every other day of the year,

Speaker: NA
Text: we should all be committed to challenging those state governments who have been cutting the

Speaker: NA
Text: heart out of TAFEs and calling them on it, saying to them, 'Reinstate TAFE. Recommit to

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting it and ensure that it has a long and prosperous future in this country.'

Speaker: Mr TAYLOR
Text: Hume) (15:40): It is a great pleasure for me to speak on this all-important

Speaker: NA
Text: topic of unemployment particularly youth unemployment. It is an issue in my electorate, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: know in many other rural areas. I will also talk about the related issue of skill shortages,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is a serious issue particularly in the eastern part of my electorate down the Hume

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given the topic of the MPI and given the enormous amount of money that the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: claims to have spent on jobs and skill creation and skill development and the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: programs that they claim to have put into place, we might have expected that the track record

Speaker: NA
Text: of outcomes would be superb. So I spent a little bit of time looking at their actual track record

Speaker: NA
Text: between the time they got into government in 2007 and the time they left government in 2013

Speaker: NA
Text: to see how they had gone.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thought I would start with youth employment. Take note that between 2004 and 2008

Speaker: NA
Text: there was 13 per cent growth in youth employment. Between May 2008 and May 2014, with

Speaker: NA
Text: the exception of a small uptick at the end-which we will ignore for now and which I will

Speaker: NA
Text: come back to in a moment-we saw an eight per cent reduction in youth employment across

Speaker: NA
Text: the economy. There was an eight per cent reduction across the time that Labor was in

Speaker: NA
Text: government. Shame!

Speaker: NA
Text: At the same time we can look at youth participation rates in the workforce. It was running

Speaker: NA
Text: along merrily between 2004 and 2008, rising from about 70 per cent participation up to 71 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent participation-nice work by the past Howard government. But from early 2008 through

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: to the end of 2013, there was a reduction from 71 per cent to 66 per cent in youth

Speaker: NA
Text: participation-five per cent reduction in participation rates across the time of the last Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government. Now they might say, 'That's all right. We were putting them all into training.' But

Speaker: NA
Text: what we also find is that the youth unemployment rate went from nine per cent in January

Speaker: NA
Text: 2008 to 12.4 per cent by the end of 2013. What a shameful record of youth employment and

Speaker: NA
Text: youth unemployment we saw from that last Labor government.

Speaker: NA
Text: And when we dig little deeper, we find some hotspots. In western and north-western

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania they managed to achieve a 21 per cent unemployment rate from the Labor-Greens

Speaker: NA
Text: alliance, destroying jobs in Tasmania. In Cairns, it was 20.5 per cent, in North Adelaide it was

Speaker: NA
Text: 19.7 per cent, and in south-eastern Tasmania it was 19.6 per cent. Well done, Labor-Greens

Speaker: NA
Text: alliance!

Speaker: NA
Text: They crow about the extraordinary work they did on training. Let us have a look at

Speaker: NA
Text: apprenticeships. Between 2007 and 2013 apprenticeship commencements fell by 37 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: No wonder we have got skills shortages in my electorate! By contrast, between 2001 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007 under the Howard government, we saw a 33 per cent increase in the numbers of

Speaker: NA
Text: apprenticeships-all that money, all those programs, and what did you achieve? Absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing. What a disastrous performance we have seen.

Speaker: NA
Text: So how are we going? We have only had a short while but let us have a look at the facts. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the last four months the Australian economy has created 100,000 jobs. We hear from the other

Speaker: NA
Text: side lots of talk about a job loss here, a job loss there, but in total we have created 100,000

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs. If you calculate that for the next five years, it works out at about 1.5 million jobs against

Speaker: NA
Text: our target of one million that we said before the election. So this is the track record we are

Speaker: NA
Text: already seeing from the coalition government. It is time for you to face the facts and the truth:

Speaker: NA
Text: your performance was absolutely abysmal and it is time for change.

Speaker: NA
Text: Earlier speakers have spoken about the extraordinary range of programs we are putting in

Speaker: NA
Text: place which are targeted and cost efficient and, I am sure, will deliver the jobs and

Speaker: NA
Text: employment that the young people in my electorate want to see. We are a coalition for jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are a coalition for employment and we are the party of opportunity for young people in

Speaker: NA
Text: stark contrast to those opposite.

Speaker: Mr CHAMPION
Text: Wakefield) (15:45): This is a government that has got all the emotional

Speaker: NA
Text: characteristics of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde. Before the election we had the Prime Minister, then

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition leader, wandering around the country in fluoro. I remember him chucking ice

Speaker: NA
Text: around. I remember him gutting fish. I remember him visiting Ford in Geelong-all designed

Speaker: NA
Text: around jobs to give people reassurance.

Speaker: NA
Text: What have they done in government? They have instituted policies that are cruel and

Speaker: NA
Text: calculated to divide the Australian community and the economy. They are calculated to

Speaker: NA
Text: entrench disadvantage and accelerate that disadvantage. Perhaps most concerning is that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are utterly, utterly cavalier about jobs. To that extent you need look no further than my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate and the treatment that Holden got where we saw the Treasurer of this country

Speaker: NA
Text: chasing Holden out of the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will give this to him: he endeavoured to repeat his record in the Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: where they offered assistance to the car industry to make sure they stayed here, to make sure

Speaker: NA
Text: they employed here, to make sure they exported here. He had all of that rhetoric when he

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: came down and visited Holden but he lost the cabinet battle and then we had a Treasurer who

Speaker: NA
Text: chased Holden out of the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: From that, we are seeing a domino effect through car manufacturing to Toyota and the

Speaker: NA
Text: components sector, and what happens? Fifty thousand jobs. Not a job lost here or there;

Speaker: NA
Text: 50,000 jobs-more than 10,000 in South Australia-lost in areas that can least afford it.

Speaker: NA
Text: After that performance you would think that they would be a bit reticent but, oh no, in this

Speaker: NA
Text: budget they cut a billion dollars out of the auto industry thus putting more pressure on the

Speaker: NA
Text: components industry. Anyone who knows the components industry knows that we are very,

Speaker: NA
Text: very close to seeing an early exodus of the car industry, because of the pressure this

Speaker: NA
Text: government has put on it.

Speaker: NA
Text: What have they got as a panacea to address this employment issue? They have put in place

Speaker: NA
Text: a $155 million growth fund, which they bragged about, but when I asked the industry minister

Speaker: NA
Text: specific questions in consideration in detail just today, what kind of response did I get? Just a

Speaker: NA
Text: diatribe about the Labor Party. No specifics, no thought-out proposals, no projects, no skills

Speaker: NA
Text: based programs for redundant workers-none of that-just diatribe, just rhetoric.

Speaker: NA
Text: We see that here. We see them wrapping this rubbish up in a ribbon as the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Wollongong said-$2 billion worth of cuts in skills and apprenticeships, a billion dollars out

Speaker: NA
Text: of Tools For Your Trade, and what do we hear? 'Everything's good. Everything's fine. It'll all

Speaker: NA
Text: be right.' The government employ this unbelievable Orwellian language. They think that if

Speaker: NA
Text: they say it long enough and hard enough, they can defy reality.

Speaker: NA
Text: What did we see in the budget? We saw a budget that smashed economic confidence,

Speaker: NA
Text: consumer confidence. You do not need to look too far. ABC on 21 May 2014, Michael

Speaker: NA
Text: Jander, their business editor-this was the headline: 'Consumer sentiments slump after federal

Speaker: NA
Text: budget announcement'. It drops 6.8 per cent to 92.9-that is solidly below the 100-point level

Speaker: NA
Text: where optimists equal pessimists; 60 per cent of families thought they would be worse off;

Speaker: NA
Text: and just 3.1 percent of people thought they would be better off. That is what they are doing

Speaker: NA
Text: for the retail industry. We have seen what they did for the manufacturing industry and then

Speaker: NA
Text: they are going to slam the retail industry-another big employer of the young.

Speaker: NA
Text: To top it all off, we see what they are doing to young people: cutting them off the dole after

Speaker: NA
Text: six months and then expecting them to look for 40 jobs a months during that time when they

Speaker: NA
Text: are not receiving any income. We know what the outcome of that will be: further breaches,

Speaker: NA
Text: further time without income. That will leave many young people homeless, without income

Speaker: NA
Text: and without the capacity to get a job. So we have got this assault on jobs, assault on fairness,

Speaker: NA
Text: and this entrenchment of disadvantage and policies that are deliberately set out to make things

Speaker: NA
Text: worse. If those opposite think that they can get away with this anti-Labor rhetoric and

Speaker: NA
Text: nonsense they put out in this House, they have got another thing coming. These are very, very

Speaker: NA
Text: harsh measures that are designed to hurt Australia. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr VAN MANEN (Forde) (15:50): As usual, we have listened to five minutes of

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution from the other side that is of no relevance to this debate and does nothing for the

Speaker: NA
Text: future direction of this country. Before I delve into the government's positive plans to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity for young people, I think it is relevant to revisit and spend some time looking at

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's past record on employment. It is very illustrative of what we have seen over the past

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: six years and the past nine months with the Labor government still completely devoid of ideas

Speaker: NA
Text: and any future direction and sense of what it needs to do for the future of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nearly 200,000 additional people were unemployed over the past six years, and we can

Speaker: NA
Text: compare that to the Howard government's efforts prior to 2007 where there was a decrease of

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly 270,000 people in unemployment. When it comes to planning for Australian jobs, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: clear that this government has the policies and plans that will provide successful outcomes for

Speaker: NA
Text: addressing unemployment. As previous speakers already mentioned, in the last nine months,

Speaker: NA
Text: we have seen the creation of over 100,000 new jobs in our economy. Under Labor-and their

Speaker: NA
Text: last couple of speakers were carrying on about various businesses-since 2008, an average of

Speaker: NA
Text: 67 Australian manufacturing jobs were lost every single day. Manufacturing jobs were lost,

Speaker: NA
Text: roughly, every 19 minutes while Labor was in government. In May 2011 the former

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer, Mr Swan, promised to create 500,000 new jobs in the following two years. Well,

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor succeeded in missing that target, like it did everything else, by well over 200,000 jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: In total Labor's legacy was about 700,000 unemployed Australians, which is the highest

Speaker: NA
Text: number in 15 years. Suffice to say, with a record like that, it is ironic that the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: even brings up this topic for debate today. As I said at the outset, they have no plans to do

Speaker: NA
Text: anything for the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: More importantly, in relation to the topic we are discussing today, we should spend a little

Speaker: NA
Text: time to focus on those who are currently unemployed, particularly in the youth sector. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: national youth unemployment is currently around 13 per cent. In Logan it is higher at 15 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent and on the Gold Coast it is 17 per cent. We, as a government, want to help prevent young

Speaker: NA
Text: people falling into the welfare trap. That is exactly the essence of what we are seeking to do

Speaker: NA
Text: with our positive plans for the future. To address youth unemployment our plan is for young

Speaker: NA
Text: people with work capacity to be either earning or learning. The government are introducing a

Speaker: NA
Text: range of assistance measures to help with training and education costs. We are not giving

Speaker: NA
Text: young people the option to jump into welfare when they leave school. We want to encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: young people to have fulfilled lives, because we believe that the best kind of welfare is a job.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is not only because you will earn more than you would on the dole, but it is because it

Speaker: NA
Text: gives young people the necessary skills to succeed in the workplace and to have rewarding

Speaker: NA
Text: careers.

Speaker: NA
Text: If young people cannot find a job straight out of school, we will have a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative pathways to find work which includes the $20,000 Trade Support Loans for those

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaking apprenticeships. In discussions I have had with one of our wonderful education

Speaker: NA
Text: providers, the Australian Industry Trade College,-and we are working with them to open a

Speaker: NA
Text: campus in Beenleigh-I have learnt that they take students in grades 11 and 12 and tailor a

Speaker: NA
Text: school curriculum to line up with the requirements of employers. Ninety-five per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: students that have gone through that particular school have graduated with their QCE, but, far

Speaker: NA
Text: more importantly, with a job and with an apprenticeship. This funding will help those students

Speaker: NA
Text: pay for their course fees at this particular school.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are options out there. I think it is instructive to note that the Australian Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade College came out of a Howard government program. Nothing those opposite have done

Speaker: NA
Text: for the last six years has assisted this. It is only this government that will provide a future for

Speaker: NA
Text: the young unemployed in our community. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Text: Charlton) (15:55): It is a great MPI to talk on and it is a very important

Speaker: NA
Text: one, although I disagree slightly with one sentence in the MPI. I think the government does

Speaker: NA
Text: have a plan for jobs. Unfortunately, it is to destroy them. The member for Wakefield alluded

Speaker: NA
Text: to this earlier. If you look at the auto industry, before the election the industry said, 'If you cut

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to our industry, we have to leave.' What did this government say? 'We know better.

Speaker: NA
Text: We're going to cut $500 million.' Then what happened? Holden leaves and takes Toyota with

Speaker: NA
Text: them. That is 50,000 direct jobs gone and another 200,000 indirect jobs under threat daily,

Speaker: NA
Text: because this government had a plan and that plan was to destroy jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you look at what they are doing in naval shipbuilding, they are kissing goodbye to 5,000

Speaker: NA
Text: high-skilled, nation-building, defence shipbuilding jobs that are vital to our national security.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you look at SPC, one of the government's own MPs questioned the honesty of the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and the Treasurer-quite rightly. As we saw before the election there was not a

Speaker: NA
Text: worker in a high visibility vest that the PM could not get near fast enough. He loved them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the election I have not seen him at a factory, and I have not seen him have the courage

Speaker: NA
Text: to go to a factory. He has not been to Alcoa, he has not been to Holden, and he has not been to

Speaker: NA
Text: Toyota. He has not had the guts to visit any of them and say why his $500 million cut is

Speaker: NA
Text: ending their industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us look at what the government have done since the election. They have cut the $1

Speaker: NA
Text: billion Aussie jobs plan that would have really helped to diversify the economy. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister claims that he wants to be the infrastructure Prime Minister. Well, how about

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting the Australian Jobs Act which said that with every large project in this country you

Speaker: NA
Text: had to give Aussie companies and their workers a go first? It is now gone. If you look at the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's $2 billion of cuts to skills and training, that is gone. There are huge attacks on

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFE and huge attacks on Tools For Your Trade which are all gone. The response from the

Speaker: NA
Text: government member is typical of what their attitude is-when in doubt blame the jobseeker;

Speaker: NA
Text: when in doubt make it harder to get training, make it harder to get Newstart and blame them;

Speaker: NA
Text: when in doubt blame the workers. It is a classic response.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have heard a few statistics quoted from the other side and I have a few as well. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, since this government came to power the unemployment queue is longer by 23,000

Speaker: NA
Text: people. That equates to 100 people a day being added to the unemployment queue. The

Speaker: NA
Text: previous speaker said that, under Labor, unemployment was the highest in over 15 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Well, you have already broken that. There are 23,000 additional people on the unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: queue. Even more worrying, there are nearly 17 million less hours of work per month in the

Speaker: NA
Text: market sector. So, those who are lucky enough to have a job are working less. That is a huge

Speaker: NA
Text: impact. Youth unemployment in the eight months the government have been in power in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of statistical collection has gone from 12.7 per cent to 13.1 per cent, which is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: significant increase in such a short amount of time.

Speaker: NA
Text: One area I want to touch was the government's great shield. People may remember that

Speaker: NA
Text: before the election they hid behind their little pamphlet 'Our plan-real solutions for all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians'. Whenever Mr Abbott got a hard question he just said, 'Don't worry, I've got my

Speaker: NA
Text: pamphlet that provides all the answers.' There was also the six-point plan that some of their

Speaker: NA
Text: candidates in Western Sydney had a bit of trouble with. If I go to the employment section of

Speaker: NA
Text: the pamphlet, what is the one graph that they choose to highlight? What is the one graph that

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrates how worried they are about unemployment? It is the long-term unemployed

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: where they have a graph that shows the unemployment queue. What has happened since they

Speaker: NA
Text: have come to power? Since they have come to power long-term unemployment in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: has gone up by 20 per cent in eight short months, that is 30,000 more long-term unemployed

Speaker: NA
Text: people than before they were elected. It is so much that I have had to draw an extra symbol on

Speaker: NA
Text: the graph. It is so out of scale with the graph that they took to the Australian people. This

Speaker: NA
Text: shows that the government are all talk and no action.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an incredibly important topic. We are talking about the future of Australians. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are talking about the future of young people and trying to give them a chance to have gainful

Speaker: NA
Text: employment, where they can raise a family and contribute to Australian society. All we get

Speaker: NA
Text: from the other side is glib slogans, empty three-word slogans. Their actions are cutting $1

Speaker: NA
Text: billion from the Australian jobs plan, cutting $2 billion from skills and training, cutting other

Speaker: NA
Text: forms of support, attacking child care and ripping away any support for Australian job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers. All we get from them is blaming the job seekers-blaming the young people trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: find work in the member for Wakefield's electorate, the member for Gellibrand's electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: and my electorate of Charlton. When in doubt, they blame young people and they blame job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers. It just demonstrates that they are not fit to govern this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs PRENTICE (Ryan) (16:00): When I read today's MPI, I had to seriously question

Speaker: NA
Text: what document those opposite were actually reading. They seem to have picked up the ALP

Speaker: NA
Text: propaganda scare folder. It is quite obvious that they have not even read the coalition policy

Speaker: NA
Text: documents or, indeed, the budget papers, or are they away in their own parallel universe yet

Speaker: NA
Text: again? The alternate Labor universe is where they pretend that the carbon tax actually reduces

Speaker: NA
Text: greenhouse gas emissions and does not drive up the cost of living. The alternate Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: universe is where the cost of doing business as a result of the carbon tax and the 20,000 new

Speaker: NA
Text: pieces of regulation under Labor does not increase and, in fact, it means that small businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: are forced to cut staff, costing Australian jobs and contributing to the rising unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: level. The alternate Labor universe is where changing the rules for employment services-

Speaker: NA
Text: thereby removing the financial incentive to find the unemployed a part-time job, even if they

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted one-does not in fact leave thousands of Australians jobless and the hospitality

Speaker: NA
Text: industry crying out for part-time casual staff. The alternate Labor universe is where those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite remain blind to these facts: an average of 67 Australian manufacturing jobs were lost

Speaker: NA
Text: each day under Labor since 2008-that is one manufacturing job every 19 minutes on their

Speaker: NA
Text: watch; and in 2011 the member for Lilley promised, until he was blue in the face, to create

Speaker: NA
Text: 500,000 new jobs over the following two years, when in fact, two years later, Labor missed

Speaker: NA
Text: that target by more than 200,000 jobs. The alternate Labor universe saw unemployment rise to

Speaker: NA
Text: its highest level in 15 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: How in this alternate Labor universe does cutting the Australian Defence Force Gap Year,

Speaker: NA
Text: the ADF's most successful recruiting program, improve training opportunities for young

Speaker: NA
Text: people? How does repealing the Green Corps program, which provided valuable vocational

Speaker: NA
Text: education opportunities, help job seekers and training opportunities for young people? How

Speaker: NA
Text: does abolishing the Australian Building and Construction Commission help job seekers,

Speaker: NA
Text: where malicious strike action with ulterior motives drives up the cost of doing business? The

Speaker: NA
Text: industry has been in decline over recent years due to Labor's policies pandering to the unions.

Speaker: NA
Text: How does suffocating a once-strong industry create employment opportunities and skills

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: training for Australians? The answer is simple: it does not. The alternate Labor universe is

Speaker: NA
Text: some mythical, topsy-turvy world where they live far, far away from reality.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Cunningham demonstrated that Labor is still living in this alternate

Speaker: NA
Text: universe when she talked about the government's decision to cease apprenticeship access. If

Speaker: NA
Text: she wants to talk about job outcomes, the access program was delivering a meagre 26 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: job outcome under her watch despite spending more than $100 million on this program every

Speaker: NA
Text: year. We are about target outcome focused programs. Thankfully, on this side of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: we do not live in a state of chronic psychosis and blissful ignorance. No-on this side we are

Speaker: NA
Text: well and truly aware of the cold, hard facts about the state of unemployment and education

Speaker: NA
Text: left behind by the previous, Labor government. That is why we are determined to repeal the

Speaker: NA
Text: carbon tax and reduce the burden of red and green tape on individuals, businesses and

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations. That is why the coalition is deregulating universities, which will see

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for 80,000 additional places in sub-bachelor degrees such a diplomas, advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: diplomas and associate degrees. Commonwealth funding has been expanded to support people

Speaker: NA
Text: studying these courses. The coalition government has expanded Commonwealth funding for

Speaker: NA
Text: bachelor degrees to all registered higher education institutions, not just universities.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have introduced the largest ever Commonwealth Scholarships Program, creating more

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for students with low socioeconomic backgrounds from regional areas to enter

Speaker: NA
Text: tertiary study. Apprentices will now be eligible for Trade Support Loans, helping with the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of their training and the purchasing of the tools for their trade. Streamlining of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry Skills Fund and a commitment of $476 million will see 200,000 targeted training

Speaker: NA
Text: places over four years in areas of need. The coalition is boosting the number of older workers

Speaker: NA
Text: participating in the workforce through the Restart initiative. Businesses will receive up to

Speaker: NA
Text: $10,000 for employing workers older than 50.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are just some of the initiatives the coalition government is taking to improve

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for job seekers and training opportunities for young Australians. We have a

Speaker: NA
Text: proud history on this side of the House of improving the job market, allowing businesses to

Speaker: NA
Text: do what they do best, boosting employment and seeing the next generation trained and

Speaker: NA
Text: educated to strive in an increasingly competitive market. It is time that Labor stopped their

Speaker: NA
Text: delusions of false accomplishment and let the coalition government get on with the job.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite-not from within the chamber but in my office. I would like to commend the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Ryan for one thing, and that is the maroon scarf around her neck. However, I

Speaker: NA
Text: condemn her and the people that she is sitting with for the heavy burden they have sadly put

Speaker: NA
Text: around the necks of young Australians. We were led to believe before the election that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, the member for Warringah, would fight for Australian jobs. He has a record

Speaker: NA
Text: of being a fighter, a boxer, but, sadly, we have seen so many jobs go offshore-jobs that will

Speaker: NA
Text: never come back-particularly in manufacturing, when he said that Australia would always

Speaker: NA
Text: have a manufacturing sector. He has neglected it on his watch.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, my opponent, the member for Warringah's candidate, promised an LNP

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment that there would be a jobs forum in the electorate of Moreton within 100 days of

Speaker: NA
Text: gaining office. Nearly 300 days in and there is still no jobs forum, despite me writing to two

Speaker: NA
Text: ministers about it and asking them to keep their word. On the south side of Brisbane, most of

Speaker: NA
Text: the electorate of Moreton has a youth unemployment rate nudging 15 per cent. Sadly, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: also seeing cuts in the TAFE sector in Queensland. John-Paul Langbroek is committed to

Speaker: NA
Text: closing one in three TAFEs-it is a horrible fact to acknowledge on National TAFE Day, but

Speaker: NA
Text: that is the reality facing Queenslanders. As we have heard from other speakers from other

Speaker: NA
Text: states around this nation, they have all been impacted-and they will be impacted further by

Speaker: NA
Text: the short-sighted decision to cut $2 billion from schools and training programs.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have a government that is happy to commit to that Queensland government policy of

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 years ago of 'earning or learning', yet they are ripping money away from programs that

Speaker: NA
Text: actually provide support to young people in apprenticeships and to help them get into

Speaker: NA
Text: employment and education. We should be responding to the issue of youth unemployment by

Speaker: NA
Text: investing in young people, not cutting them off when they most need help.

Speaker: NA
Text: On National TAFE Day I acknowledge that, over the last 40 years, TAFE has emerged as

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the top vocational education systems in the world, as the traditional master and

Speaker: NA
Text: apprenticeship scheme has changed and evolved to reflect the modern world. So why does

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland state government policy not recognise TAFEs achievements-its contribution to

Speaker: NA
Text: our society and the incredible skills of the teachers who work there? Instead they have

Speaker: NA
Text: decided to savagely cut investment in TAFEs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last year the Newman Queensland government announced details of reforms which will

Speaker: NA
Text: make all public funding contestable. It will remove all assets from TAFE Queensland,

Speaker: NA
Text: introduce HECS student loans to make students pay even more for training, and restrict access

Speaker: NA
Text: to places at TAFE for many students. In fact, the recent Queensland budget announced that

Speaker: NA
Text: campuses will be opened up for use by for-profit providers and 38 TAFE colleges look likely

Speaker: NA
Text: to close.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need more skilled workers. We have employers calling out to people from around the

Speaker: NA
Text: world to come over on 457 visas because they cannot find enough skilled workers in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland and other parts of Australia. We need more plumbers, more electricians, more

Speaker: NA
Text: carpenters and more fitters and turners. The Labor government helped 21,000 Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: access an apprenticeship through the Kickstart initiative. Thanks to Labor, senior high school

Speaker: NA
Text: students across Australia have better access to trade training centres. However, we have also

Speaker: NA
Text: seen TAFE fees soaring in many places. It has disastrous consequences when these fees go

Speaker: NA
Text: up, particularly for poorer families-and especially when someone is the first person in their

Speaker: NA
Text: family to go on to higher learning.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Queensland we have seen a crazy situation where some fees have now increased tenfold,

Speaker: NA
Text: or 1,000 per cent, which is way beyond the reach of ordinary working people. For example, a

Speaker: NA
Text: Diploma of Sustainability course in Cairns went up from $439 in 2013 to more than $6,000

Speaker: NA
Text: this year. This information is from Curtis Pitt, the state member for Mulgrave. Her son's

Speaker: NA
Text: ambition is to work in film and television and the fee for that course rose from $3,000 in one

Speaker: NA
Text: year to more than $20,000. Those fees make such courses out of the reach of ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, particularly poorer Australians. Despite the empty words of those opposite, we

Speaker: NA
Text: are not seeing an improvement in long-term unemployment or in opportunities for young

Speaker: NA
Text: people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs SUDMALIS (Gilmore) (16:10): This government stands for employment solutions to

Speaker: NA
Text: work, not for employment dissolution to welfare. Gilmore's unemployment rate was the fifth

Speaker: NA
Text: highest in Australia, at 9.3 per cent, when Labor left government last year. Those opposite cry

Speaker: NA
Text: crocodile tears over budgetary reallocations. The redirection of taxpayer dollars is an obvious

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the failed program measures of the last Labor government, when an extra 200,000

Speaker: NA
Text: people were looking for work. Those opposite should be ashamed. Our current unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: is the legacy of six years of Labor government that promoted handouts, bonuses and carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: tax compensation without any sense of a return from the recipients, with no proper audit and

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly with no measure of delivery outcomes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those opposite have absolutely no idea. To condemn a young unemployed person to a life

Speaker: NA
Text: of welfare dependence is the very pathway to a lack of self-esteem, progressing to social

Speaker: NA
Text: isolation, depression and possibly antisocial behaviour. The plan to encourage re-engagement

Speaker: NA
Text: through volunteering is a proven method of revitalising people and growing their self-

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government is getting on with the job of repairing the cracks that the Australian Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: party left in our economy. We are getting on with the job of restoring business confidence,

Speaker: NA
Text: creating one million new jobs and getting the budget into black. It is those on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House who truly care about employment and Australia's future prosperity, rather than welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: horizons as far as the eye can see.

Speaker: NA
Text: Gilmore is one of just 18 trial sites for the government's revamped and revitalised Work for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Dole scheme. During the next few months, over 800 local job seekers will have the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to learn new skills, get work ready and contribute back to the community that has

Speaker: NA
Text: helped them get on their feet. With over 6,000 unemployed in my electorate, I am focused on

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing new opportunities and better skills to our people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government's 20,000 Trade Support Loans will help restore the prestige of an

Speaker: NA
Text: apprenticeship and help our local youth in Gilmore get through the tough years that a trade

Speaker: NA
Text: apprenticeship brings. These loans will allow apprentices to buy tools or a vehicle, or to

Speaker: NA
Text: simply keep their head above water. Our scheme offers incentives for apprentices to complete

Speaker: NA
Text: their training with a $4,000 discount on their loan when they complete their apprenticeship.

Speaker: NA
Text: This actually supports TAFE education-which, by the way, is predominantly funded by the

Speaker: NA
Text: state government.

Speaker: NA
Text: After all, why should a plumber, an electrician, a builder, a baker or any other kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: tradesperson be treated any differently to a university graduate? Without a builder to construct

Speaker: NA
Text: our homes, our offices and our city infrastructure, we would not have universities in the first

Speaker: NA
Text: place. In many towns across Australia, especially in rural and regional Australia, the highest

Speaker: NA
Text: income earners you will find are the builders, the miners, the plumbers and the bakers-as it

Speaker: NA
Text: should be. It is time to restore the prestige of an apprenticeship and that is just one thing this

Speaker: NA
Text: government is doing to get Australia, and our unemployment rate, back on track. Labor's so-

Speaker: NA
Text: called support for manufacturing and workers has to be questioned when associated jobs were

Speaker: NA
Text: lost at a rate of 67 a day. That equals one job lost every 19 minutes; what a disgrace.

Speaker: NA
Text: Industries like the Shoalhaven Paper Mill or the Port Kembla steelworks used to employ tens

Speaker: NA
Text: of thousands of people between them under the last coalition government. Since Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: election in 2007, we are now lucky to see that total more than 1,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are also investing in older Australians with our $10,000 Restart grant for businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: who employ workers over 50. This is a strong incentive to employ some of our wisest and

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest assets in the Australian workforce. The electorate of Gilmore has one of the highest

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers of these wise residents in the entire country. We have over 20,000 age pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: who make up a strong, experienced and mature workforce and we are proud of that fact. This

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative will be part of our efforts to reduce our chronic local unemployment, as well as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Green Army project, which is an amazing initiative. This government is in the business of

Speaker: NA
Text: creating a strong economy and keeping jobs for Australians. I am in the business of fixing

Speaker: NA
Text: Gilmore's unemployment rate.

Speaker: NA
Text: There have been many occasions in the last 12 months where I have spoken in passionate

Speaker: NA
Text: terms about the devastating effect of the Labor Party's carbon tax on regional employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those opposite have no concept that for a small, local, family owned business the huge

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in electricity cost causes them to think twice about employing young people for part-

Speaker: NA
Text: time employment. They simply cannot afford it. It was easier to just do it themselves so they

Speaker: NA
Text: could stay ahead financially, and so employment for young people chronically dropped. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: in business for almost 20 years. I know full well how important work experience and work

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence is for a new employee. Having employed more than about 150 people in a period

Speaker: NA
Text: of 20 years, I know exactly what skills they need. We do not do young people any favours by

Speaker: NA
Text: not encouraging them to start volunteering or to get their initial work experience. Ultimately,

Speaker: NA
Text: the efforts of these initiatives and the efforts of this government will lead to a much greater

Speaker: NA
Text: potential for growing paid employment for every unemployed person.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. BC Scott): Order! The discussion is now concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEES

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure and Communications Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Membership

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. BC Scott) (16:15): The Speaker has received advice

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Chief Opposition Whip nominating Ms MACTiernan to be a supplementary member

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Standing Committee on Infrastructure and Communications for the purposes of the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's inquiry into infrastructure planning and procurement.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Minister for Communications) (16:16): by leave-I

Speaker: NA
Text: move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That Ms MACTiernan be appointed a supplementary member of the Standing Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure and Communications for the purpose of the committee's inquiry into infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: planning and procurement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS

Speaker: NA
Text: Asset Recycling Fund Bill 2014

Speaker: NA
Text: Asset Recycling Fund (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2014

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Cognate debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed on the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr VARVARIS
Text: Barton) (16:17): I am very pleased to be speaking on the Asset

Speaker: NA
Text: Recycling Fund Bill 2014 and the Asset Recycling Fund (Consequential Amendments) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2014 today. This initiative is a bold and necessary component of Australia's infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: future. The bills propose that the government can sell public assets, such as Medibank, with

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the resulting proceeds going towards much needed infrastructure investment projects. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Asset Recycling Fund is scheduled for commencement on 1 July this year. The coalition is

Speaker: NA
Text: proud to be the government that is actively responding to our infrastructure crisis. The last six

Speaker: NA
Text: years have seen infrastructure growth all over Australia stagnate under procrastination and

Speaker: NA
Text: delay. The coalition, under our two infrastructure leaders, the Prime Minister and the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Infrastructure and Regional Development, is making an historic investment in the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: this year to get on with building Australia's infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: For too long, our infrastructure needs have not kept up with population growth. This has

Speaker: NA
Text: detrimental effects for Australia as a competitive international player, for economic certainty

Speaker: NA
Text: and for the lives of fellow Australians. Congestion on roads bearing the heavy burden of

Speaker: NA
Text: traffic is costing our economy $15 billion a year, and weak productivity growth from a range

Speaker: NA
Text: of factors is threatening the stability of our future living standards. Infrastructure development

Speaker: NA
Text: and implementation is top priority for this government. Years of procrastination and delay

Speaker: NA
Text: threaten current and future economic prosperity. The undeniable truth is that we must act

Speaker: NA
Text: now. We have to break the complacency that was paralysing our infrastructure growth and

Speaker: NA
Text: resolve the infrastructure backlog. The coalition is getting on with the job, as per our election

Speaker: NA
Text: promise, of building the roads of the 21st century by committing to existing projects. We will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be wasting further time and funds on consultation and analysis while not actually rolling

Speaker: NA
Text: anything out.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think what Macquarie Group Executive Director, Jim Miller, said previously really homes

Speaker: NA
Text: in on this point:

Speaker: NA
Text: We have this inertia where everyone is pointing to each other. The Commonwealth is pointing to the

Speaker: NA
Text: States; the States are pointing to the Commonwealth. Meanwhile we haven't achieved anything.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the differentiating factor between members on this side of the chamber and those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite. Instead of leaving such important decisions solely to other parties to figure out how

Speaker: NA
Text: to get the project going, the coalition's budget figures constitute a historic infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: investment and prove that we have listened to stakeholders and gotten stuck into the job of

Speaker: NA
Text: building the roads and transport of the 21st century within just eight months of being in

Speaker: NA
Text: government. The critics might say the coalition is merely committing to existing projects by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor government. But, ultimately, there is a big difference between commitment and

Speaker: NA
Text: action. The coalition is about action and getting the job done.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note from the recent Infrastructure Australia report that urgent reforms are needed to

Speaker: NA
Text: address our growing population in all areas of Australia. Sir Rod Eddington, Chairman of

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure Australia, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Focusing on the right reforms will help us to use existing infrastructure more efficiently … and involve

Speaker: NA
Text: private players more in the ownership and management of traditionally publicly owned assets by

Speaker: NA
Text: recycling capital to fund new infrastructure … These reforms, however challenging, will leave

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians better off-with more capable Governments, better planned infrastructure that meets their

Speaker: NA
Text: needs, and more sustainable, affordable transport options.

Speaker: NA
Text: The good news for Sir Rod and for Australians across the nation is that a core element of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's Economic Action Strategy is the commitment of an additional $11.6 billion in

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget for the Infrastructure Growth Package. I also wish to refer to the draft report of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Productivity Commission produced in March of this year which notes:

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Efficient public infrastructure plays a key role in a competitive and productive economy and the

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing funding and financing of infrastructure development in Australia is therefore of critical

Speaker: NA
Text: importance.

Speaker: NA
Text: I proudly support the $5 billion contained in the budget to establish the Asset Recycling

Speaker: NA
Text: Initiative, which will provide incentive payments to states and territories that sell assets so

Speaker: NA
Text: that proceeds can be reinvested to fund essential infrastructure right around Australia. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: a win-win scenario. This record level of investment in infrastructure by a Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: government reflects our resolve to get things done, because that is what we were elected to

Speaker: NA
Text: do. Delaying infrastructure is harmful to the national interest and will ultimately impede long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term economic prosperity.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my electorate of Barton, residents are already benefiting from the actions of an effective

Speaker: NA
Text: government. Through smart investing and modes of financing, stage 2 of WestConnex is set

Speaker: NA
Text: to begin early next year, with the Commonwealth and state governments working together.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an $11 billion project that will greatly benefit the constituents and motorists in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate. The project received a $1.5 billion commitment from the coalition to the state of

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales and a further $2 billion as a concessional loan to accelerate the delivery of

Speaker: NA
Text: stage 2 by up to 18 months. This innovative reform of finance is the type of creative financial

Speaker: NA
Text: solution we have needed for a long time, and it has taken a coalition government to deliver it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The WestConnex is one of the largest transport infrastructure projects in Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: project will deliver 33 kilometres of new and upgraded motorways linking Western and

Speaker: NA
Text: South-western Sydney with the city, Sydney Airport and port precincts. It will remove traffic

Speaker: NA
Text: in that motorists can bypass busy CBD streets and go underground. An estimated 3,000 trucks

Speaker: NA
Text: use these existing roads daily and this development will mean their travel times will be

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced and the traffic burden placed on local roads will ease.

Speaker: NA
Text: Beyond addressing motorist needs, the WestConnex will deliver more than $20 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars in economic benefits to New South Wales with a further 10,000 jobs created during

Speaker: NA
Text: the construction period. This is an outstanding testimonial to what an efficient infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: government can achieve. Projects like these can continue to operate right around the nation

Speaker: NA
Text: with the onset of the Asset Recycling Fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: Initiatives like these are essential to reducing infrastructure construction costs and address

Speaker: NA
Text: any barriers to private sector financing. The last six years of the Rudd-Gillard-Rudd

Speaker: NA
Text: government have seen our infrastructure stagnate with high congestion on local roads. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Productivity Commission's draft report on public infrastructure highlighted poor project

Speaker: NA
Text: selection and poor planning as some of the major constraints on Australians receiving the

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure they need, and that is very disappointing. If we are to prosper and create

Speaker: NA
Text: economic certainty for all Australians now and into the future, we must get on with delivering

Speaker: NA
Text: the roads, ports and means of transport for all Australians immediately.

Speaker: NA
Text: The budget constraints now and into the future mean we are facing infrastructure deficits

Speaker: NA
Text: exacerbated further by the previous five record deficits under the Labor government. Further,

Speaker: NA
Text: we have layers of bureaucracy that stifle infrastructure growth and development-for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, nearly 600 different local, state and territory governments along with

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth government and infrastructure departments. This is creating inefficient and

Speaker: NA
Text: slow development from ideas to reality, meaning our projects take a long time to get off the

Speaker: NA
Text: ground and therefore become unattractive to potential investors.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition is committed to working constructively with state counterparts to address

Speaker: NA
Text: needs and move projects forward in a timely fashion. The Asset Recycling Fund will tap into

Speaker: NA
Text: potential private investor funding to alleviate the burden on traditional government revenue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members of the opposition are against user-pay models, but infrastructure can only be funded

Speaker: NA
Text: through either increases in tax, increases in borrowings or user charges. Because of the large

Speaker: NA
Text: debt and deficit we are in and the tax revenue languishing from changes to demographics,

Speaker: NA
Text: asset recycling is a viable and necessary option to address our chronic infrastructure shortage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unless a government is innovative and prepared to confront the challenges that lie ahead,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia will continue to face a chronic undersupply of infrastructure. Everyone has to

Speaker: NA
Text: contribute to these investments because there simply is not a surplus of money.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition fully recognises this, and we are committed to tackling these challenges head

Speaker: NA
Text: on. Members of the opposition may counter by saying these are all the things they have done

Speaker: NA
Text: whilst they were governing. Unfortunately, their track record speaks otherwise. As mentioned

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier, the WestConnex project is not new, and Labor had the chance for years to do right by

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Barton and New South Wales. But it never kicked it off.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further west of the WestConnex, the Parramatta-Epping rail link was delayed by seven

Speaker: NA
Text: years until a coalition government came into power. Another infrastructure fiasco was the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Broadband Network, costing in the billions and still not having reached their

Speaker: NA
Text: targeted numbers well and truly after the initial rollout phase. Any government that spends the

Speaker: NA
Text: hard-earned dollars of taxpayers is accountable for the outcomes of their investment. These

Speaker: NA
Text: projects should ultimately enhance the lives of constituents and respond to their needs.

Speaker: NA
Text: To further highlight the enormity of support for this bill-which should illustrate the dire

Speaker: NA
Text: straits we were left in with regard to infrastructure-states and territories all signed the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Partnership Agreement on Asset Recycling at the Council of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Governments meeting on 2 May this year. This signed agreement with state and territory

Speaker: NA
Text: counterparts means that for every dollar of government investment it will harness a return of

Speaker: NA
Text: $8 for infrastructure revenue. The Asset Recycling Initiative will leverage close to $40 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: of new infrastructure investment from the states and territories.

Speaker: NA
Text: This unanimous support for the agreement demonstrates that state and federal levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: government can work together. Ultimately, the real outcomes of the coalition's record

Speaker: NA
Text: spending on infrastructure investment aside from roads, rail and urban transport is that people

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit by having more time back in their personal lives. We must not forget that initiatives

Speaker: NA
Text: like an asset recycling fund which goes on to fund important road projects and improve

Speaker: NA
Text: logistics has a very real benefit in terms of human value for all Australians. Less time spent

Speaker: NA
Text: on congested roads means more time at home and with family. Fewer heavy vehicles in the

Speaker: NA
Text: CBD means urban transport can get from A to B faster, carrying passengers who spend less

Speaker: NA
Text: time stuck in traffic and more time doing the things they enjoy. Weekends can be freed up for

Speaker: NA
Text: personal time as opposed to waiting in traffic.

Speaker: NA
Text: The big winners of the coalition's infrastructure spend and Asset Recycling Initiative are

Speaker: NA
Text: the people and families that make up our society. Giving time back to people and families

Speaker: NA
Text: who are already time poor is important, and this will be achieved with the coalition's growth

Speaker: NA
Text: package. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Ms CHESTERS
Text: Bendigo) (16:28): In rising to speak to this bill I want for a moment to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay credit to the government for their creative writing skills and the name of the Asset

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Recycling Fund Bill 2014. How do they come up with this stuff? Operation Sovereign

Speaker: NA
Text: Borders, Enhancement Removal Program for Regional Post Boxes, Asset Recycling-do they

Speaker: NA
Text: sit around? Is there a whiteboard? Is there a competition amongst the backbenchers? How do

Speaker: NA
Text: they come up with this stuff? At the end of the day, asset recycling is purely and simply

Speaker: NA
Text: privatisation. It is the sale of public assets so private enterprise can make a profit from them.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not anything new; it is straight out of the modern Liberal playbook.

Speaker: NA
Text: In short, this bill intends to provide an incentive for state governments to privatise their

Speaker: NA
Text: assets and then recycle the proceeds into new infrastructure projects. As I said, this is not

Speaker: NA
Text: new; this is what Liberals and Nationals do when they get elected. They sack public servants

Speaker: NA
Text: and sell off public assets as quick as they can. It is a throwback for many Victorians to the era

Speaker: NA
Text: of Jeff Kennett. In office, Jeff Kennett immediately instituted budget cutting measures and a

Speaker: NA
Text: privatisation program. In fact, Jeff sacked over 50,000 public servants. In his first three years

Speaker: NA
Text: of office, he closed 350 government schools, cut 7,000 teaching jobs and sacked thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: school cleaners on Christmas Eve. Kennett also sold off billions of dollars worth of Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: public assets. And he did this, he claimed, because of a budget emergency-again, language

Speaker: NA
Text: straight out of the Liberal Party handbook that we hear again today in this chamber. Kennett

Speaker: NA
Text: privatised state owned services, including electricity and gas utilities, the ambulance service

Speaker: NA
Text: and prisons as well as other services. The sale of gas and electricity raised $29 billion when it

Speaker: NA
Text: was sold to private enterprise.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst nobody disagrees that in the short term this money did go into the budget, the
