Speaker: NA
Text: longer-term economic cost to the people of Victoria still raises questions about whether this

Speaker: NA
Text: sale was worth it. Putting electricity generation and distribution into private hands neither

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced the price of electricity nor helped the broader public interest. Since privatisation,

Speaker: NA
Text: electricity prices to the consumer have gone up by 50 per cent-and to think that members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite are upset about the price on carbon. Where is the critique of the cost of privatisation?

Speaker: NA
Text: Who led the revolt against Kennett, and who is leading the revolt against this government, but

Speaker: NA
Text: people in regional communities? Regional communities were the first to vote Kennett out.

Speaker: NA
Text: They were the first to stand up and say that they did not support the sale of public assets. They

Speaker: NA
Text: did not believe that they would get good services in the bush if public assets are privatised.

Speaker: NA
Text: And I share their fears. That is why I support the amendments moved by Labor in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House and in the Senate that will require as a precondition for the spending of

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth funds on the asset recycling initiative (a) an Infrastructure Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: assessment of the new infrastructure that includes a published cost-benefit analysis and (b) the

Speaker: NA
Text: tabling of a disallowable instrument for each privatisation or reinvestment transaction. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: important for our communities that we ensure that there is strong oversight when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: the sale of our public assets. Regional Australians fear the fire sale of public assets, because

Speaker: NA
Text: where is their representation? Where are the Nationals on this? In opposition they are quite

Speaker: NA
Text: happy to say, 'We'll stand up for the bush', but the moment they get elected into government

Speaker: NA
Text: they crumble to the city based Liberals when it comes to public assets. They flounder and

Speaker: NA
Text: agree with silly terms such as 'asset recycling' and agree with the Liberals in their agenda to

Speaker: NA
Text: sell off assets. I call on the members who represent regional communities to stand up and to

Speaker: NA
Text: support Labor's amendments, because these amendments are the only ones that will truly

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that people in the country will be represented when it comes to their public assets. If

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the states seek to gain from the sale of public assets or the assets recycling program it should

Speaker: NA
Text: be subject to the measures as outlined in Labor's amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the state of Victoria there are not many assets left after Kennett's big privatisation bender

Speaker: NA
Text: of the early 90s. But there is one: there is still the Port of Melbourne. And on that particular

Speaker: NA
Text: one, only a week ago Jeff Kennett actually argued that the state government should proceed

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately to sale and that not selling it was 'politically dead'. Well, politically dead is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: good enough reason for the sale of a public asset and is another reminder of why it is so

Speaker: NA
Text: important that we have oversight when it comes to the sale of our public assets. Whilst the

Speaker: NA
Text: port remains one of the last significant public assets on the Victorian books, it is important to

Speaker: NA
Text: note that the Victorian government has made noises publicly about this program, and in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House we have not forgotten it. They are so concerned about this particular program that they

Speaker: NA
Text: have actually made a submission to the Productivity Commission. The Victorian government

Speaker: NA
Text: is so worried that Victoria could be disadvantaged under the plan because so many public

Speaker: NA
Text: assets were sold off in the 1990s that in their submission Victoria argued that the privatisation

Speaker: NA
Text: push of the Kennett years has left the state with less scope to benefit from this measure. They

Speaker: NA
Text: argue that any such incentive payments must also provide financial rewards for past efforts in

Speaker: NA
Text: selling off public assets. Is this state government for real? Once you have sold them off they

Speaker: NA
Text: are gone. What do they not understand about how the market works? Yet they are arguing that

Speaker: NA
Text: they should be rewarded for their past efforts.

Speaker: NA
Text: These comments are not surprising from a government that is becoming increasingly

Speaker: NA
Text: chaotic and increasingly dysfunctional. Just to touch very quickly on an example of how

Speaker: NA
Text: dysfunctional this government has become in my area of Bendigo, it appears that if you want

Speaker: NA
Text: to get funding right now from this government all you have to do is ring up the local paper-a

Speaker: NA
Text: very good paper, the Bendigo Advertiser-and if they run a front-page story about your

Speaker: NA
Text: particular issue then within days you will get a visit from the Premier and a visit from the

Speaker: NA
Text: education minister promising funding. That is exactly what we saw happen to the Kalianna

Speaker: NA
Text: Special School this week and exactly what we saw happen to the Annie North project. And

Speaker: NA
Text: good on them for speaking out about the lack of investment from the Liberal government in

Speaker: NA
Text: the state of Victoria. But it is a bad way to do policy if local schools and local organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be on the front page of their local paper to get funding. The secret is out now, and

Speaker: NA
Text: watch every front page of the Bendigo Advertiser and watch the state government throw

Speaker: NA
Text: money desperately trying to win the next state election. It is another reason that it is so

Speaker: NA
Text: important that these amendments are adopted. These decisions about infrastructure should be

Speaker: NA
Text: independently assessed and recommended by Infrastructure Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: We all know that the Liberals are obsessed with Melbourne metro based transport projects,

Speaker: NA
Text: leaving electorates like my electorate out in the cold when it comes to decent infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: funding. We have our own fair share of projects-regional infrastructure projects, roads

Speaker: NA
Text: projects and rail projects that we also need funding for. Yet the Libs and the Nats in the state

Speaker: NA
Text: of Victoria continue to champion a dud tunnel, the east-west tunnel, with little precious

Speaker: NA
Text: funding left available for vital regional infrastructure and rail projects. This one project

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrates why it is so important that Infrastructure Australia should be involved in the

Speaker: NA
Text: approval of any major projects. This is one project that we have heard of today in this House

Speaker: NA
Text: and that we have seen reported in the media that lacks the transparency around the decision

Speaker: NA
Text: making that is required for major infrastructure projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of allocating the $8 billion in funds to our regional highways, arterial roads and

Speaker: NA
Text: local roads that are falling apart and riddled with dangerous cracks and potholes, the money

Speaker: NA
Text: has been allocated to what has been described as a dud tunnel. The tunnel does not solve the

Speaker: NA
Text: congestion problems of Melbourne. There are very few people in Melbourne who need to go

Speaker: NA
Text: from east to west. People in the east and the west need to go to the city.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no design yet, or even a mark on the map, showing where this tunnel will pop out.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why? Because we have a state election, and who wants to be the sitting MP who has to go

Speaker: NA
Text: around door knocking saying, 'My government has decided to knock down your house so that

Speaker: NA
Text: the tunnel can pop out in your backyard.' This is the problem with policy decisions that are

Speaker: NA
Text: made on a whim, and it is another reminder about why we have established Infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and why these decisions should be independently assessed by Infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: After the last election the Prime Minister was reported in The Age as saying that he did not

Speaker: NA
Text: even need to see the business case for the East West Link. The journalist went on to report in

Speaker: NA
Text: The Age that over $1.5 billion in funds would go to this tunnel without the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: even seeing the full business case. How is that a good way to do good governance and ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that taxpayers are getting value for money?

Speaker: NA
Text: The government is making this advance payment to the state of Victoria to help fast-track

Speaker: NA
Text: the project and make their budget look good before the next state election. Is that how

Speaker: NA
Text: desperate the Liberals have become to prop up a dysfunctional and chaotic state government.

Speaker: NA
Text: If there were one example that demonstrated that there is a need for greater transparency, it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be the East West Link project of Melbourne. There are so many major regional

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure projects that need urgent attention, and not just to help families get from A to B

Speaker: NA
Text: but also to help our products get from the north of the state to the ports. The Mildura freight

Speaker: NA
Text: rail project is one that comes to mind. Other projects are the Calder Highway upgrade to the

Speaker: NA
Text: north, completing the Calder Freeway upgrade to freeway standard the whole way from

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne to Bendigo, and the Bendigo Airport upgrade. These are just a few of the many

Speaker: NA
Text: projects that could benefit from regional infrastructure funding. Instead, the Liberal obsession

Speaker: NA
Text: with Melbourne means that these projects are delayed.

Speaker: NA
Text: But where are the Nationals? Standing on these roads and at the airport during the election

Speaker: NA
Text: period, Mr Truss was happy to visit Bendigo Airport during the election period, but since the

Speaker: NA
Text: election he has not been back. He did not even have the time to meet with the council, who he

Speaker: NA
Text: met during the election period, when they were here a few weeks ago. These vital projects are

Speaker: NA
Text: standing still because the government has its priorities wrong when it comes to infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: funding. These problems are being ignored in favour of Melbourne projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: Good road and rail links are critical to supporting regional communities. If our farmers are

Speaker: NA
Text: to get their product to market they need a decent regional infrastructure system. Right now

Speaker: NA
Text: this government is not prioritising it in the regional parts of Victoria. The only major transport

Speaker: NA
Text: project that Central Victoria will benefit from in the next few years is the Regional Rail Link,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was funded and started by former federal and state Labor governments. Yet I note that

Speaker: NA
Text: in a few months Denis Napthine and Warren Truss will probably be there cutting the ribbon to

Speaker: NA
Text: say, 'Job well done.' Well, it is not a job well done for the Liberals and Nationals, because

Speaker: NA
Text: they were not the ones who allocated funding to it. They were the ones who simply sat back

Speaker: NA
Text: and watched money that Labor allocated in government to see the building of this project.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: They have an opportunity right now to start planning for the next regional rail project, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Mildura freight rail upgrade. But we have not yet seen this government prioritise that project.

Speaker: NA
Text: Without the amendments moved by Labor, asset recycling is a bad deal for states. Given

Speaker: NA
Text: that the federal government already provides at least half the funds for many projects, where

Speaker: NA
Text: does the 15 per cent incentive sit when it comes to the 50 per cent allocation. There is a

Speaker: NA
Text: problem with the maths when it comes to this particular bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: I urge the members of the House to support Labor's amendments, because only through

Speaker: NA
Text: these amendments will we actually get genuine transparency and ensure that, if there are sales

Speaker: NA
Text: of private assets, the funding goes towards projects that really will make a difference to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and, in particular, regional Australia.

Speaker: Mr SUKKAR
Text: Deakin) (16:43): I was really pleased to follow the member for Bendigo in

Speaker: NA
Text: her contribution to this debate, because the member for Bendigo spoke at some length about

Speaker: NA
Text: her opposition to the state coalition government's policy in respect of the sale of the Port of

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne Corporation. There were a couple of minutes there where the member for Bendigo

Speaker: NA
Text: spoke stridently against that proposed sale. I suppose the problem for the member for Bendigo

Speaker: NA
Text: is that she should probably speak to the state Labor opposition leader, Daniel Andrews, who,

Speaker: NA
Text: in November 2013, committed the Labor Party, if elected, to sell the Port of Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation. So there we have it. The member for Bendigo has repudiated sensible state

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor party policy, where they were brought kicking and screaming to accept that the sale of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Port of Melbourne Corporation would be very positive. So, Member for Bendigo, I think

Speaker: NA
Text: you have a little bit of explaining to do when we head back to Victoria. I also suspect that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: another case of saying one thing in Canberra and another thing when we all head home to our

Speaker: NA
Text: electorates.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before I start my contribution on the Asset Recycling Fund Bill 2014, I want to assure the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bendigo that nobody in Victoria-certainly nobody in the outer east of

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne where the seat of Deakin lies-refers to the East West Link as 'the dud tunnel'.

Speaker: NA
Text: She might be concerned about the inner-city Greens and the internal Labor Party fights that

Speaker: NA
Text: will happen with respect to-

Speaker: Mr Fitzgibbon
Text: On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: you cannot preface your

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks by saying, 'Before I get to the bill I want to say this,' and claim you are being relevant

Speaker: NA
Text: to the bill. The member, by his own admission, is not being relevant to the bill.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Craig Kelly): There is little bit of latitude.

Speaker: Mr SUKKAR
Text: I commend the member for Hunter for trying to save the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bendigo, but nothing will save her from the woeful contribution she just made.

Speaker: NA
Text: People in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne, in my seat of Deakin, greatly appreciate the

Speaker: NA
Text: Asset Recycling Fund Bill which we are here to debate today. Let us remember that this is an

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement that the federal government was able to strike with every single state government,

Speaker: NA
Text: including state governments of the other political persuasion. So I find it very surprising that

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendments being sought here are not being repudiated by those opposite. This bill, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Asset Recycling Fund, is a key component of ensuring that we meet our commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: give Australia the infrastructure of the 21st century-something we spoke about ad nauseam

Speaker: NA
Text: during the election campaign and something we have spoken about ad nauseam since forming

Speaker: NA
Text: government.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: What sets us apart from the Labor Party is that we do not send out endless media releases

Speaker: NA
Text: or make endless announcements. I do not follow New South Wales politics that closely, but-

Speaker: NA
Text: gee whiz-I can recall that many infrastructure projects being announced three, four or five

Speaker: NA
Text: times. Even in my own state the Labor Party does it. There is no shame. They will announce

Speaker: NA
Text: the same infrastructure project time and time again-without any credible way to fund it. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Asset Recycling Fund will ensure that we have the means to deliver on our promises.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fund is designed to provide incentives and support for our state and territory

Speaker: NA
Text: governments to sell their existing assets and invest the freed-up capital into new productive

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure-infrastructure that will provide the foundations for a more productive

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. I could not believe the member for Bendigo-she was almost rewriting Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: history when bemoaning privatisations. I think we need to sit her down with former Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers Hawke and Keating. Perhaps she can educate them on the mistakes they made when

Speaker: NA
Text: implementing their very important privatisation agenda. It shows you just how far the once

Speaker: NA
Text: great Labor Party has retreated from what it was.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Asset Recycling Fund will start with an initial commitment of $5.9 billion. This

Speaker: NA
Text: money comes from uncommitted amounts in the Building Australia Fund and the Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Investment Fund and will be managed by the Future Fund Board of Guardians. The Asset

Speaker: NA
Text: Recycling Fund builds on earlier coalition government measures to create future funds-

Speaker: NA
Text: thanks, as we know, to former Treasurer Costello-to benefit current and future generations

Speaker: NA
Text: by providing long-term investments in our future economic development, not just spending

Speaker: NA
Text: money with the next election in mind. These are not short-term measures. They are for the

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term benefit of the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the 2014-15 budget, the coalition government, unlike Labor, invested a fair dinkum $50

Speaker: NA
Text: billion into key infrastructure projects. I have been very gladdened to read that that $50 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: investment will support more than $125 billion of construction activity once you take into

Speaker: NA
Text: account private sector and other sources of funding. In other words, a $50 billion commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: by this government, which is unprecedented, unlocks an additional $75 billion of private

Speaker: NA
Text: investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the last few years, much has been made by members opposite about the need for

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in infrastructure projects. Every question time, it seems, the former infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: minister interjects in some sort of desperate attempt to salvage some kind of legacy-but I

Speaker: NA
Text: can tell him that that legacy has been shot out of the water, so he should just give up. We on

Speaker: NA
Text: this side of the House will deliver on our promise of modern infrastructure. It is a key part of

Speaker: NA
Text: our Economic Action Strategy to boost jobs along with investment. Again, it was something

Speaker: NA
Text: we spoke about ad nauseam before the last election.

Speaker: NA
Text: Building the roads of the 21st century is a crucial step and I am very proud that prior to the

Speaker: NA
Text: election, through advocacy from Victorian federal members-or federal candidates, as I

Speaker: NA
Text: was-we were able to secure a $1½ billion commitment in relation to the East West Link.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an unprecedented investment in crucial infrastructure for Victoria. Again, the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Bendigo referred to it as 'the dud tunnel'. She should probably speak to the former Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: state government and former Labor Premiers John Brumby and Steve Bracks, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: East West Link, the most crucial infrastructure project in Victoria, was first identified by the

Speaker: NA
Text: former state Labor government through their Eddington review in 2008. The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bendigo has effectively repudiated Daniel Andrews, the current opposition leader; the last

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: two state Labor premiers of Victoria; and two great prime ministers-Bob Hawke and Paul

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating. I think that shows you exactly what has happened to the Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to the $1½ billion that was committed pre-election, we recognised, in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: unlock Melbourne's west and to provide a second river crossing in Victoria, that stage 2 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: East West Link needed to be accelerated too. Clearly stage 1, with our $1½ billion

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment, will kick it off and get it started this year. But the additional $1½ billion for

Speaker: NA
Text: stage 2 is recognition that, in order to have an entirely integrated road system in Victoria, that

Speaker: NA
Text: second river crossing-in addition to stage 1 of the East West Link-is going to be absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary. So there we go. We have $3 billion committed by this government to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: the East West Link, stages 1 and 2, starts immediately.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another huge advantage for the Victorian economy-not just once the road is completed,

Speaker: NA
Text: because we know there will be massive benefits for businesses and commuters-is that during

Speaker: NA
Text: the construction phase of stages 1 and 2 of the East West Link over 6,000 construction jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: will be created. That is why responsible union leaders in Victoria have been desperately

Speaker: NA
Text: making pleas to the state Labor Party to get behind the East West Link. I suspect that secretly

Speaker: NA
Text: they wish it happens. They want the hard decision taken away from them. I can promise the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party that, yes, we will make the hard decision. In fact, it is not that hard; it is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: positive announcement for Victoria. There will be 6,000 new jobs during the construction

Speaker: NA
Text: phase of the project.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the big problem with the East West Link? The problem is, for residents of Deakin,

Speaker: NA
Text: Aston and Menzies and people who live in the eastern suburbs, the Eastern Freeway

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively ends at an inner-city street at Clifton Hill. This project will ensure that Deakin

Speaker: NA
Text: residents commuting to the airport, across town for work in the West, or even into the inner

Speaker: NA
Text: north or the CBD, will no longer have to sit on the Eastern Freeway for hours on end. A stark

Speaker: NA
Text: example of that is that every Sunday afternoon, when I am making my way to the airport

Speaker: NA
Text: during a sitting week, I sit on Alexandra Parade at the end of the Eastern Freeway for the

Speaker: NA
Text: better part of half an hour. This is on a Sunday afternoon. So I absolutely appreciate it when

Speaker: NA
Text: my constituents complain to me about the time they spend on the Eastern Freeway.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a huge fillip for the Victorian economy, it is a huge fillip for jobs growth and,

Speaker: NA
Text: importantly for the residents of Deakin, the East West Link will ensure that the eastern

Speaker: NA
Text: suburbs are no longer forgotten and that the eastern suburbs have the infrastructure they

Speaker: NA
Text: need-not only for small businesses but also for everyday mums and dads. Quite frankly, the

Speaker: NA
Text: time you spend on the freeway often determines whether you get home to bathe your children,

Speaker: NA
Text: give them a kiss or read them a book before they go to bed. It is real life for these people. If

Speaker: NA
Text: we are able to save mums and dads-and all family members-time commuting, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity benefits but there are also deeply-felt personal benefits for everybody.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Asset Recycling Fund is the culmination of an historic agreement between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth government and the states, including Labor states. Clearly, there is bipartisan

Speaker: NA
Text: support for it, if you put aside the endless opposition we get from members of the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party. It makes sense. Recycling assets and ensuring that those funds from

Speaker: NA
Text: privatisations are contributed to productivity-enhancing infrastructure should not be anything

Speaker: NA
Text: new. There should not be anything particularly novel to members opposite, except that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: very positive. If it is novel to those opposite, then they should read the legislation and

Speaker: NA
Text: consider it, because it makes complete sense.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: If asset recycling means that rather than having endless media releases, endless photo

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities which the Labor Party was so good at for six years, we start delivering

Speaker: NA
Text: projects-we have men and women on the ground with projects actually happening-it will

Speaker: NA
Text: be a huge fillip for the broader national economy, not just for the Victorian economy, and will

Speaker: NA
Text: have long-term benefits on the economy through more efficient freight movement and

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity of our citizens.

Speaker: NA
Text: I congratulate the Victorian state government for working hand in glove with us, in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of our investment in the East West Link, because it has indicated to the Victorian people that

Speaker: NA
Text: when you have state and federal governments who do not endlessly squabble, things can be

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered. Ultimately, my residents in Deakin want to see action. They want to see things

Speaker: NA
Text: happening. They do not want to see blame shifting from one level of government to another.

Speaker: NA
Text: The $3 billion we are committing to the East West Link-and countless other infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: projects around the country-will be a huge shot in the arm for the Victorian and national

Speaker: NA
Text: economies. I therefore commend the relevant minister for this historic Asset Recycling Fund

Speaker: NA
Text: and congratulate him for being able to negotiate this with each of the states.

Speaker: Mr CHAMPION
Text: Wakefield) (16:58): I was somewhat shocked to hear the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Deakin say the word-not using the words 'asset recycling'. It slipped out; he could not help

Speaker: NA
Text: it; he could not keep it contained. The word 'privatisation' slipped into Hansard. He wandered

Speaker: NA
Text: off the focus-group tested 'asset recycling', the Orwellian attempt by the Liberal Party's

Speaker: NA
Text: spinmeisters. They thought privatisation sounded bad: 'We'll call it asset recycling.' So we get

Speaker: NA
Text: this Orwellian bill. It does not have one dollar extra in infrastructure. All it does is link what

Speaker: NA
Text: was already in the budget in infrastructure spending-under Labor-to a privatisation

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, Labor is not against the selective privatisation of some assets. Indeed, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke-Keating years there were some privatisations-Qantas and the federal airports come

Speaker: NA
Text: to mind. We have always taken a selective view, a public interest view, a public good view, of

Speaker: NA
Text: this issue. The problem with those opposite is that they always approach privatisation as a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of ideology.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's two proposed amendments to this bill are, firstly, to allow Infrastructure Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: assessment of new infrastructure as productivity-enhancing projects, and that includes a

Speaker: NA
Text: published cost-benefit analysis; and, secondly, the tabling of a disallowable instrument for

Speaker: NA
Text: each privatisation and reinvestment transaction. That is for very good reason, because there

Speaker: NA
Text: are sensible privatisations and then there are what the Liberal Party do, which are ideological

Speaker: NA
Text: privatisations.

Speaker: NA
Text: We see an inability of the language in this bill-and indeed in the language used by this

Speaker: NA
Text: government-to just be honest and talk straight with the Australian people. It is one of their

Speaker: NA
Text: government's problems in terms of the co-payment. We saw the member for Hume getting in

Speaker: NA
Text: a bit of strife today. It is one of the Prime Minister's problems. It is the reason he now has to

Speaker: NA
Text: write to pensioners across the country, presumably to right some wrongs, to fix up some

Speaker: NA
Text: communication issues. This bill is about the encouragement of states to privatise their assets

Speaker: NA
Text: willy-nilly. There is a 15 per cent reward. There is a smaller contribution than states normally

Speaker: NA
Text: put into infrastructure, which is normally either 50 per cent or 80 per cent. The government is

Speaker: NA
Text: putting in a small reward so that some state governments go on a privatisation frenzy-not in

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the public interest, not selectively looking at assets in the public interest, but simply selling

Speaker: NA
Text: things off willy-nilly.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know what Liberal state governments do when they get any sort of encouragement in

Speaker: NA
Text: this area. I can tell you what happened in South Australia. In the nineties we saw the Olsen

Speaker: NA
Text: government sell many assets that the state had, willy-nilly. They sold the state TAB for $50

Speaker: NA
Text: million. That sounds like a good outcome, except that it earned $50 million a year. They sold

Speaker: NA
Text: it to the Queensland TAB. Apparently there is some risk involved in gambling revenue, so

Speaker: NA
Text: they got that one off their books. That privatisation continues to plague the racing industry in

Speaker: NA
Text: my state to this day. To this day it is regretted. It was a foolish privatisation. It was a

Speaker: NA
Text: privatisation which was in no way in the interests of the taxpayers of the state of South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. When the ideological test is applied, we get some pretty bad outcomes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Olsen government also leased our electricity assets. This was not just unpopular; it

Speaker: NA
Text: also did not live up to the expectations. An article by Tory Shepherd in The Advertiser on 21

Speaker: NA
Text: February this year carried the headline, 'ETSA sale cost South Australia $2b as prices soar,

Speaker: NA
Text: says damning report on privatisation'. That report was by Professor Quiggin, who is quoted as

Speaker: NA
Text: saying, 'South Australia is really Exhibit A in privatisation leading to higher prices.'

Speaker: NA
Text: I would just warn those opposite that it is all very well to be a cheer squad for these sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: privatisations, but I can assure them that often the rhetoric catches up with you when reality

Speaker: NA
Text: hits. There are other reports, such as one by Dr Phillip Toner from the University of Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: in 2012, in which he noted, 'South Australia, which has a fully privatised electricity industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: has the highest prices of all states.' He also noted, 'New South Wales electricity prices

Speaker: NA
Text: increased largely due to a massive increase in capital expenditure from the mid-2000s.'

Speaker: NA
Text: It is an interesting point about New South Wales power prices. We know that power prices

Speaker: NA
Text: are a big issue for the public-a very big issue indeed. I would not blame any person across

Speaker: NA
Text: the country for being worried about electricity prices. But most of this is about privatisation

Speaker: NA
Text: or, in the case of state owned assets, in the preparation for their eventual privatisation. In John

Speaker: NA
Text: Quiggin's report Privatisation of Queensland electricity assets: A preliminary evaluation, he

Speaker: NA
Text: notes:

Speaker: NA
Text: In South Australia, privatisation was advocated in the 1990s on the basis that it was necessary for

Speaker: NA
Text: participation in the National Electricity Market. Far from reducing prices, the result was to raise them to

Speaker: NA
Text: the highest levels in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: This was due in part to massively increased distribution charges. As the SA Essential Services Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: Lew Owens noted in an interview with ABC Stateline (2003):

Speaker: NA
Text: The simple explanation for that is in addition to the wholesale energy price you have to add the

Speaker: NA
Text: network charges for the poles and wire businesses.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are dearer in SA because the assets were revalued back in 1996 prior to privatisation and

Speaker: NA
Text: locked in by legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a very important observation by Lew Owens, who was the Energy Regulator in South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. In the run-up to the privatisation of electricity assets, state governments typically

Speaker: NA
Text: fatten the pig before market today. They do that by gold-plating the infrastructure and by

Speaker: NA
Text: raising the prices that consumers pay. That is how South Australia ended up not just with the

Speaker: NA
Text: highest prices in Australia but, as was reported on 21 March 2012 in The Advertiser, 'South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's power prices set to become the highest in the world says Energy Users Association

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia'.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Jensen interjecting-

Speaker: Mr CHAMPION
Text: We hear the member opposite interjecting. They had a pretty fair go in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of those power prices at the time. They were out there every day beating up on the

Speaker: NA
Text: straw man that was the carbon price, but of course the main culprit in those price rises was

Speaker: NA
Text: network charges; it was the cost of poles and wires being passed on to consumers. That is a

Speaker: NA
Text: direct result of the privatisation of what was a natural monopoly-the poles and wires. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: noted in a more recent report of February 2014, and in another one by Dr John Quiggin,

Speaker: NA
Text: Electricity privatisation in Australia: A record of failure. He notes on page 12:

Speaker: NA
Text: In some cases, governments have sought to increase the sale price of assets by raising costs to

Speaker: NA
Text: consumers in the lead up to privatisation, or by allowing price increases after privatisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: You cannot blame the entities that buy these assets for trying to gouge what are natural

Speaker: NA
Text: monopolies. Those opposite come into this chamber and talk about asset recycling; what they

Speaker: NA
Text: really mean is privatisation. They put in place a bill that has not one extra dollar for

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure and yet they claim the infrastructure is a result of the privatisation. Then they

Speaker: NA
Text: make all sorts of claims about how these things will benefit taxpayers and consumers, who are

Speaker: NA
Text: one and the same. I can tell you that we have heard these tales before in the South Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: context. We have seen dramatic and detrimental effects on taxpayers and consumers. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: why you cannot be too much of a cheer squad for privatisation; why you cannot be too much

Speaker: NA
Text: of an ideological advocate for privatisation. You have to apply rational thinking to it rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than just charging down a particular path. You have to be selective, when you are dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: with state governments, about what you will reward and what you will not reward. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: reason for Labor's amendments.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an infrastructure con in so many ways. We hear the Prime Minister and others

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about him being the 'Infrastructure Prime Minister'. If you look at my electorate, that

Speaker: NA
Text: is almost certainly not the case. The electrification of the Gawler to Adelaide rail line is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: important project for moving into town commuters who live in the outer suburbs of Adelaide

Speaker: NA
Text: or in the town of Gawler, which is a large regional centre, and many people come in from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Barossa Valley and further up the track, such as wheat belt towns like Mallala and Kapunda,

Speaker: NA
Text: where I grew up. The rail project would be efficient and sensible. It would help people, would

Speaker: NA
Text: take cars off the road rather than putting cars on the road and would give people a far better

Speaker: NA
Text: commute. I lived in Gawler some years ago, and I drove to town every day. I can tell you it is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a pleasant commute; you spend a lot of time in the car. It is much more pleasant to go

Speaker: NA
Text: along on a train where you can read, relax and have a bit of time out and not focus on the

Speaker: NA
Text: traffic. That project was cancelled by the Abbott government. They do not want anything to

Speaker: NA
Text: do with public transport no matter how much sense it makes. That is a blow not just to my

Speaker: NA
Text: state but to jobs in my state and to the northern suburbs of Adelaide, which has been the

Speaker: NA
Text: victim of so many of this government's decisions, especially in terms of the automotive

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. We see the impacts of the Treasurer chasing Holden out of the country-something

Speaker: NA
Text: I talked to the House about once before. Now we see the impact of them cancelling important

Speaker: NA
Text: economic infrastructure for the state of South Australia-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr CHAMPION
Text: The member for Barker visited the Barossa Valley recently he cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: work out that the very people who live there use the trains in Gawler. He comes in here and

Speaker: NA
Text: he yells and barks and bleats, but his government-the government he is a part of-has

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: cancelled this important project. I am reliably informed he has told his Liberal Party

Speaker: NA
Text: preselectors that he is going to be a minister within two terms. That is what he has claimed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the good preselectors of Barker. I hope that he fulfils that-perhaps he can knock off the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mayo and put this project back on track. He will be a hero to South Australia but,

Speaker: NA
Text: if he cannot, I hope his preselectors come after him. I cannot imagine a more joyous thing to

Speaker: NA
Text: do.

Speaker: NA
Text: To conclude, this bill is in so many ways a complete con. It does not put an extra dollar

Speaker: NA
Text: into infrastructure. It does not put one single extra bit of tar or roadway down that would not

Speaker: NA
Text: have otherwise been put down. It takes the word 'privatisation' and then substitutes it with

Speaker: NA
Text: 'asset recycling', an Orwellian term that is designed by a Liberal Party focus group. This bill

Speaker: NA
Text: hides the fact that in so many areas this government has turned the clock back, particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: public infrastructure and particularly in my electorate and in South Australia. Like so many

Speaker: NA
Text: things that this government does, it is a complete and utter sham. Only Labor's amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: can make this bill any better.

Speaker: Dr JENSEN
Text: Tangney) (17:13): The difference between Labor and Liberal philosophies

Speaker: NA
Text: is the difference between good enough and never enough. The Asset Recycling Fund Bill will

Speaker: NA
Text: turn lazy assets into hardworking assets, increasing returns and securing our children's quality

Speaker: NA
Text: of life well into the future. The country is in a mess because the Labor government battered

Speaker: NA
Text: her with a mining tax, a carbon tax, pink batts, school halls, the NBN and so on. Today, this

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible coalition government has to think smarter about how we all do business. Interest

Speaker: NA
Text: payments on Labor's debt are $1 billion per month-or $2,000 annually for a family of four. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is time to stop beating up on the country and time to start getting excited about her prospects.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Asset Recycling Fund is an exciting first step in paying down the debt and clearing off

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor deficit legacy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth will provide states and territories with incentive payments of 15 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the sale price of privatised assets with the returns to be re-invested into new priority

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure projects. The Commonwealth funding program is capped at $5 billion. The

Speaker: NA
Text: positive interest on the fund alone will make a significant contribution to paying off the

Speaker: NA
Text: monthly national credit card bill. However, more importantly, the asset recycling bill provides

Speaker: NA
Text: proof that this government is living up to its word to give hope, reward and opportunity to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people and to deliver the roads of the 21st century. It is exciting to think that inert

Speaker: NA
Text: capital of underperforming assets will become liquid and available to the marketplace. This

Speaker: NA
Text: freed-up capital will inspire the genius of the market to deliver real solutions of those

Speaker: NA
Text: desperately short of 21st century infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let's not fool ourselves about what this bill is and what it does. This bill is liberal because

Speaker: NA
Text: it believes in incentive-it gives states incentives to take a long, hard look at everything they

Speaker: NA
Text: own. Every person on the street knows that a good return is dictated by risk and reward. The

Speaker: NA
Text: most stinging point is that there are those in Labor ranks capable of questioning the central

Speaker: NA
Text: premise of what we are debating today-namely, if our state and federal asset is chugging

Speaker: NA
Text: along, producing a nominal net return of two per cent-is that good enough?

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me speak here of the specific good from this legislation for my electorate of Tangney

Speaker: NA
Text: and for Western Australia. The Perth Freight Link is made possible through this bill. This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive plan to get heavy-goods vehicles from the port to the airport. The Perth

Speaker: NA
Text: Airport and surrounding areas serve as a major passenger and freight network hub for the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Perth metropolitan area. The need for this project has been driven by the expected doubling of

Speaker: NA
Text: passenger air travel and the road freight task over the next decade, coupled with proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: consolidation of the Perth airport terminals. Figures I have suggest 11 per cent annual growth

Speaker: NA
Text: for 2013 in use of runway 21, the southern runway of Perth Airport. Further traffic will be

Speaker: NA
Text: generated by industrial developments in the southern part of the airport and in the surrounding

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of Kewdale and Forrestfield and from commuter traffic in the eastern and south-eastern

Speaker: NA
Text: suburbs of Perth. The Perth Freight Link will stop the nonsense of stopping at 33 sets of

Speaker: NA
Text: lights, as is the current situation. The importance of Perth Airport cannot be overstated in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australian context: think of the FIFO worker, the online shopper and the high-value-

Speaker: NA
Text: add exporter.

Speaker: NA
Text: One aspect of this project that interests me greatly is the envisaged public-private dynamic.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the first time the Commonwealth and Western Australian governments will be seeking

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for private sector co-contribution towards a major road project. The Perth

Speaker: NA
Text: Freight Link has an estimated cost of $1.6 billion, with $925 million contributed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth. Private sector co-investment will ensure maximum value is achieved from

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayer dollars with minimal impact on the federal budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: With industry and government investment, Perth Freight Link is expected to establish the

Speaker: NA
Text: Roe Highway as the preferred east-west freight link in Perth. To support and sustain a

Speaker: NA
Text: growing population and economy, developing freight links that clear congestion and ease

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure on existing roads will provide significant productivity uplifts for Perth. Increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: the productivity of our workforce is the only way to secure our current standard of living, and

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure our global competitiveness.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perth Airport is growing. For example, based on figures of total departures between 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: and last year, Perth Airport has grown by 61 per cent. Western Australia demands and

Speaker: NA
Text: deserves a clear and well-thought-out plan not just for this decade but for many decades to

Speaker: NA
Text: come. It is expected that Perth Freight Link will be opened by 2021.

Speaker: NA
Text: WA government estimates indicate that the Roe Highway extension will deliver benefits of

Speaker: NA
Text: $5.20 for every dollar invested; and the Stock Road and High Street improvements will

Speaker: NA
Text: provide $1.70 in benefits for every dollar invested. This game-changing project would never

Speaker: NA
Text: have been delivered under the previous Labor government, which remains opposed to this

Speaker: NA
Text: vital freight link.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the good news for WA does not stop at the Perth Freight Link. The coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: government is also delivering the Perth Airport Gateway, the Swan Valley bypass, the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Highway upgrade, North West Highway upgrades, as well as Tonkin Highway

Speaker: NA
Text: upgrades.

Speaker: NA
Text: In sum, this bill introduces incentive and asks the states: 'Why are you holding this asset?'

Speaker: NA
Text: and 'Is it really necessary?' The aim of this bill is that we turn that lazy two per cent into a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong six per cent return. This will enable us to pay down the Labor debt and stop paying the

Speaker: NA
Text: $1 billion-a-month interest payments on that debt. Not only this, but in turn, it will provide a

Speaker: NA
Text: springboard of capital from which new companies, ideas and ventures can be attained. This

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition government believes in free enterprise, believes in ideas and believes in people. So

Speaker: NA
Text: the liquidation of lazy assets will be transferred to a pool, a fund as set up by this bill, and

Speaker: NA
Text: moneys can be added and attached by interested parties and individuals.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Initial funding will come from the uncommitted funds in the Building Australia Fund, $2.4

Speaker: NA
Text: billion, and the Education Investment Fund, $3.5 billion, that were established in 2009.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further contributions will come from the sale of Medibank Private and other potential

Speaker: NA
Text: privatisations. Through the hard work, dedication and vision of the Prime Minister, Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: and Finance Minister, this pool of moneys, joined as it surely will be by other moneys, will be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to provide people across Australia with the roads of the 21st century. That is the plan. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was a key part of a document called 'Our Plan-Real Solutions for all Australians'. We

Speaker: NA
Text: launched our plan in 2013 and now in government we are executing that plan-keeping our

Speaker: NA
Text: promises to the Australian people, as we said we would. This is what good governments do,

Speaker: NA
Text: and Labor will never understand that We said we would stop the boats, and we have. We said

Speaker: NA
Text: we would reduce red tape, and we have. We said we would fix the budget disaster, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: are. This bill will not fix everything overnight, but what an important first step it is. It is, in

Speaker: NA
Text: essence, a pure marker of enabling legislation. It is creating incentive and cutting waste-that

Speaker: NA
Text: is what this bill is about; that is what the Liberals are all about.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor would never dream of putting something like this before the House. It is akin to

Speaker: NA
Text: cutting off their right arm, and that is the arm from which they eat the union's cake. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: no-one in this place who can honestly say that a commercial enterprise can stay fit by eating

Speaker: NA
Text: cake. State assets have always been less competitive, more regulated, less effective and less

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient than their private sector counterparts or comparisons. In brief, as we have seen time

Speaker: NA
Text: and time again in this place, the Labor Party are incapable of taking the hard decisions. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party are congenitally incapable of putting Australia's interest ahead of their own party

Speaker: NA
Text: political interest. Shame, Labor, shame.

Speaker: NA
Text: We face a significant challenge. The previous government delivered five budget deficits,

Speaker: NA
Text: totalling $195 billion. Their last budget was another $123 billion worth of projected deficits.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have implemented some structural savings in this budget, which will start low and slow

Speaker: NA
Text: and which will build over time. What we are looking to do in this bill is to sell assets which,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether in public hands or in private hands, will continue to provide services to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community and which we believe the private sector would provide more efficiently and more

Speaker: NA
Text: cost effectively. We will reinvest the proceeds from the sale of those assets. We will recycle,

Speaker: NA
Text: if you will, by investing them in new productivity enhancing infrastructure. So we have got

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure, existing assets, which we can sell and which will continue to provide benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Australian economy and to the Australian community. We think the private sector

Speaker: NA
Text: would be able to do it better and we would be able to invest the proceeds from those sales in

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthening our economy into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the final analysis, it is about smarter choices and hard decisions. 'Smarter choices' means

Speaker: NA
Text: being cognisant of the extremely benign global monetary environment and the cheap money

Speaker: NA
Text: policies being enacted across many OECD countries. Smarter choices means knowing when

Speaker: NA
Text: to 'hold'em' and when to 'fold'em'. When talk of tapering is on the table, it might be time to

Speaker: NA
Text: make hay. Sell at the top of the market: this could be as good a price as we will get. Lazy

Speaker: NA
Text: logic says that you should keep depreciating the dirty old rust bucket until it falls over,

Speaker: NA
Text: because it still throws a two per cent return. It might cost a tonne in between but it still throws

Speaker: NA
Text: off two per cent. Labor's lazy logic says that we should keep these unproductive, uneconomic

Speaker: NA
Text: assets because we own them now, and we always should own them, because we always did.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is absolutely perverse. It is a lazy logic born of a fundamental distrust of the free market.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a lazy logic born of a fundamental distrust of the Australian people. As a wonderful

Speaker: NA
Text: warrior woman once said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The only problem with socialism is that you eventually run out of other people's money.

Speaker: NA
Text: As this bill, the Asset Recycling Fund Bill 2014, will support the Asset Recycling Initiative,

Speaker: NA
Text: provides incentive payments to states and territories for the sale of assets if the proceeds are

Speaker: NA
Text: reinvested in productivity enhancing infrastructure, it is critical that we hurry up and pass this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill. This fund will expedite strategic and nationally significant infrastructure. To quote that

Speaker: NA
Text: famous Irish Liberal , and Leader of the Irish Home Rule Party, Charles Stewart Parnell:

Speaker: NA
Text: No one can say to his nation, 'Thus far shalt thou go and no further'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Similarly, I challenge any Labor member here today to look their constituents in the eye and

Speaker: NA
Text: say that they purposefully opposed this bill, that they purposefully opposed progress and the

Speaker: NA
Text: building of new roads in their electorates. This great nation will march on. It must.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Liberal plan is ready and we are acting on our mandate. Our solid and terrific mandate

Speaker: NA
Text: is to see our Real Solutions plan enacted and to return hope, reward, and opportunity to all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians and to build a safe, secure Australia. We will succeed. We will succeed because

Speaker: NA
Text: history always sides with those with better ideas, and ultimately those with the right solutions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those right solutions for fixing Australia's deficit and disaster are the Liberal's Economic

Speaker: NA
Text: Action Strategy-a strategy we outlined in the Real Solutions documents all those months

Speaker: NA
Text: ago. Real results do not have to be really hard. All it takes is for Labor to give up their lazy

Speaker: NA
Text: logic and back our plan to get Australia back on track. We have done it before, and we will do

Speaker: NA
Text: it again.

Speaker: Mr THISTLETHWAITE
Text: Kingsford Smith) (17:28): The Asset Recycling Fund Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2014 and related bill are very bad bills. Once again they are a great example of 'Howardian'

Speaker: NA
Text: language. This is the language of the Howard government, which used to give titles to bills

Speaker: NA
Text: which meant the complete opposite. I am reminded of the More Jobs, Better Pay Bill, which

Speaker: NA
Text: was, of course, a title given to a bill that actually cut unemployment benefits. I am also

Speaker: NA
Text: reminded of Work Choices. Wasn't that a wonderful use of Howardian language for the

Speaker: NA
Text: naming of a bill-Work Choices, whereby the most vulnerable in our society were given no

Speaker: NA
Text: choice? They were forced into taking contracts and conditions that cut their award wage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Here we have it again in the Asset Recycling Fund Bill 2014. When I saw this title, I

Speaker: NA
Text: thought: 'Gee, that's an interesting title for a bill. I wonder what this bill is about.' I read the

Speaker: NA
Text: explanatory memorandum and then I saw it-privatisation

Speaker: NA
Text: This is exactly what this bill is about: privatisation. I thought to myself, 'why can't they just

Speaker: NA
Text: say that this bill is about selling government assets-selling assets owned by the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia?' But no-because this government are all about deceit. They are first-class-tick-

Speaker: NA
Text: when it comes to deceit of the Australian people. It was Tony Abbott, now Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: who said before the election, 'no cuts to education, no cuts to health, no changes to pensions

Speaker: NA
Text: and no cuts to the ABC and SBS'-yet that is exactly what has been done in the current

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. What is worse is that the Prime Minister says that these are not broken election

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments, and that there is no deceit at all of the Australian people. Well, the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people would be horrified to know that the Commonwealth is encouraging the states to sell

Speaker: NA
Text: assets that are owned by the taxpayers of Australia, and offering a financial incentive for them

Speaker: NA
Text: to do so-a 15 per cent payment on the sale value, which has been described by Chris Aulich,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: a professor of public administration, as a 'bribe'. There is an expert in public administration

Speaker: NA
Text: and in the sale of public assets describing what this government is doing as a bribe-and that

Speaker: NA
Text: says it all, about this government's approach to infrastructure development in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: These assets-electricity, gas, water, transport, health, and education assets-are not

Speaker: NA
Text: owned by the Abbott government; they are owned by the people of Australia. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: government assets that deliver government services. They return dividends to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: public, which allow them to invest in schools, in roads, and in education. In my state of New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales over the last couple of years, the energy assets have been returning $1 billion in

Speaker: NA
Text: revenues to the people of New South Wales-and that money has been used to upgrade

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitals, to build new schools and to upgrade schools. To think that these assets that are

Speaker: NA
Text: owned by the Australian people are going to be sold-importantly, without any due diligence

Speaker: NA
Text: and without consideration of what is in the national interest; just so that a government can

Speaker: NA
Text: secure a 15 per cent payment, or a bribe, as described by Chris Aulich, on the asset-is

Speaker: NA
Text: somewhat horrific. It is akin to someone selling the family home to get a 15 per cent windfall,

Speaker: NA
Text: and then renting for the rest of their life and, over time, paying more for an asset that they

Speaker: NA
Text: once owned. It does not make any sense. Governments should not be paying other

Speaker: NA
Text: governments to sell assets that are owned by the Australian public.

Speaker: NA
Text: These two bills, the Asset Recycling Fund Bill 2014 and the Asset Recycling Fund

Speaker: NA
Text: (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2014 represent the complete failure of this government to

Speaker: NA
Text: develop any plan to invest in infrastructure for the nation's future. Labor believes that the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government should take a leading role in working with states and territories to fund

Speaker: NA
Text: nation-building infrastructure projects, including setting government standards to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions to be made in the national interest, not according to a political cycle. Labor will be

Speaker: NA
Text: moving amendments in the House which would ensure that the Building Australia Fund

Speaker: NA
Text: requires that the minister may not recommend a proposal for Commonwealth funding unless

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister has considered advice from Infrastructure Australia as to the merit of the project

Speaker: NA
Text: and, particularly, as to its contribution to enhancing our nation's productivity. That is the basis

Speaker: NA
Text: on which Australia should be making investments in assets on the back of the sale of other

Speaker: NA
Text: assets.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further, we will move an amendment requiring the finance minister to table a disallowable

Speaker: NA
Text: instrument, for each privatisation or re-investment transaction that the government deems

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible for the incentive payment, as a precondition to the payment of Commonwealth funds.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is to ensure that there is some due diligence to this process. We cannot allow a blank

Speaker: NA
Text: cheque for this government to do deals with states, and to allow those states to completely sell

Speaker: NA
Text: off assets without any sort of due diligence being done-with the carrot being provided of a

Speaker: NA
Text: 15 per cent windfall on the asset sale price. It is almost immoral-to think that a government

Speaker: NA
Text: would make such an encouragement, in a piece of legislation such as this, to sell off assets

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been owned by the Australian people for centuries and have returned dividends that

Speaker: NA
Text: fund additional government services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given that the federal government often provides at least half of the funds for many

Speaker: NA
Text: projects, the replacement of direct support of that nature with a 15-per-cent incentive that

Speaker: NA
Text: allows the federal government to withdraw from the historically large commitments that were

Speaker: NA
Text: made by Labor is a backward step. It is a sneaky and underhanded withdrawal from proper

Speaker: NA
Text: scrutiny of investment and planning for infrastructure in this country. This is an initiative that

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: should sit on top of-it must sit in addition to-the high level of federal commitment under

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor to funding nation-building projects in road, rail and other nationally significant

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure. The federal government's refusal to fund nation-building urban passenger rail

Speaker: NA
Text: projects remains a major failure. These should be funded even-handedly, following

Speaker: NA
Text: independent advice from a transparent decision-making body. Failure to do so distorts state

Speaker: NA
Text: decision making and leads to suboptimal productivity outcomes. The Abbott government is

Speaker: NA
Text: on very shaky ground when it comes to investment in infrastructure. An article in The Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Morning Herald on 12 June reports that:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Abbott government has been accused of pork-barrelling after analysis of the budget's infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: spending revealed Coalition electorates are favoured for new money by a ratio of three to one.

Speaker: NA
Text: A Fairfax Media analysis of the Abbott government's 2014 budget has calculated that, of the new

Speaker: NA
Text: projects announced and funded, just under three-quarters were in Coalition electorates.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it does not end there. The Herald goes on to report that, in comparison, the majority of

Speaker: NA
Text: projects which lost federal funding in the 2013 election-because of course we know the

Speaker: NA
Text: government reduced the amount of expenditure on infrastructure-were in non-Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: electorates, such as the Metro Melbourne Rail Link in Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: This politicisation of infrastructure is sad and petty. It is also harmful to our nation's

Speaker: NA
Text: development and, importantly, it is harmful to productivity-building infrastructure in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. Labor is happy to stand on its record with respect to investment in infrastructure; in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, we are quite proud of what we achieved as a government in the six years that we were

Speaker: NA
Text: investing in infrastructure. Our record, and the facts, speak for themselves. When Labor came

Speaker: NA
Text: to government, Australia as a nation was 20th in the world-20th in the OECD in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: spending on infrastructure as a proportion of GDP. By the time we left government, Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: was No. 1 in terms of the amount of money spent on infrastructure as a proportion of GDP-a

Speaker: NA
Text: great indication of Labor's investment in infrastructure. We lifted the funding from $132 per

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian to $225 per Australian. We created Infrastructure Australia to research and to rank

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed infrastructure projects based on their potential to add to economic productivity; and

Speaker: NA
Text: we delivered a national port strategy and a national freight strategy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us have a look at what the coalition has done since they have come to government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Almost all of its package is re-announcements of Labor-funded projects. I had to laugh in

Speaker: NA
Text: question time yesterday when the Minister for Infrastructure and Deputy Prime Minister was

Speaker: NA
Text: up here talking about so-called new projects that had been invested in by this government. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, he cited the Port Botany rail freight project, which happens to be in my electorate, and

Speaker: NA
Text: which I happen to know is almost completed. It is almost finished-it is being built as we

Speaker: NA
Text: speak, but the Deputy Prime Minister claims this as a new infrastructure project being

Speaker: NA
Text: invested in by this government. That is a great symbol of the approach of this government

Speaker: NA
Text: when it comes to infrastructure and the claims they are making, and of the deceit they are

Speaker: NA
Text: perpetrating on the Australian people.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government also refuses to invest money in public transport, dumping Brisbane's

Speaker: NA
Text: Cross River Rail project, the Perth public transport package and the Melbourne Metro, and is

Speaker: NA
Text: in the process of gutting Infrastructure Australia by giving the minister the power to exclude

Speaker: NA
Text: classes of infrastructure from its consideration and to prohibit the publication of research.

Speaker: NA
Text: This point was confirmed by Infrastructure Australia representatives just two weeks ago in a

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Infrastructure and Communications hearing into public infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia. In that hearing they confirmed that the minister is now able to direct

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure Australia not to look at a particular proposal-which may be in the nation's best

Speaker: NA
Text: interests, which may improve productivity and which may be a passenger rail program-just

Speaker: NA
Text: because the minister feels that way. That is not the way to develop infrastructure and to

Speaker: NA
Text: develop the productivity of our economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor doubled the roads budget to $46.5 billion, and upgraded 7,500 kilometres worth of

Speaker: NA
Text: roads. We lifted local government roads grants by 20 per cent. The coalition has committed to

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne's east-west rail link and Sydney's WestConnex project without a cost-benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: analysis. Here they are saying 'Infrastructure Australia plays a valuable role, it should be

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in assessing the value of infrastructure projects; it should apply cost-benefit analysis

Speaker: NA
Text: principles'. Certainly when I was a member of the Senate the finance minister used to make

Speaker: NA
Text: quite a deal of the importance of a cost-benefit analysis before any government project is

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken-and here they are in defiance of their own election promises and in defiance of

Speaker: NA
Text: their own rhetoric when it comes to assessing infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have shamelessly re-announced Labor projects such as the Gateway North in

Speaker: NA
Text: Brisbane and the Bruce and Pacific highway upgrades. If you drive up the Pacific Highway

Speaker: NA
Text: these days, you will find the Bulahdelah bypass has just been completed. You will go through

Speaker: NA
Text: the Kempsey bypass, you will see the Ballina bypass which has just been completed, and you

Speaker: NA
Text: will see the Woolgoolga bypass being constructed. These are all projects that Labor funded

Speaker: NA
Text: and put in place, and that Labor is building. I used to laugh, because I used to be the duty

Speaker: NA
Text: senator for that particular area, and I would go up there to open various stages of the Kempsey

Speaker: NA
Text: bypass, and Andrew Stoner, the deputy leader of the government in New South Wales, was

Speaker: NA
Text: always there claiming that this was a New South Wales government-invested project and

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to steal the media associated with the project. That must be something that runs in

Speaker: NA
Text: conservatives' blood in this country, because that is exactly what has occurred again. The

Speaker: NA
Text: disease has spread to Canberra, because that is exactly what is occurring with infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: and this government-they are stealing the credit for projects that were put in place and that

Speaker: NA
Text: were built by Labor governments and trying to claim them as their own.

Speaker: NA
Text: In rail, Labor committed to more investment in urban rail infrastructure than all of its

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessor governments combined since Federation-$13.6 billion invested in rail projects

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Labor government, which says it all about our commitment, particularly to passenger

Speaker: NA
Text: rail projects; and $3.4 billion in the rail freight network over six years. We also rebuilt more

Speaker: NA
Text: than one-third of the network-4,000 kilometres of track. So these are bad bills. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: dressed up as asset recycling bills when in fact they are justifying privatisation of assets that

Speaker: NA
Text: are owned by the Australian people. It is a deceit perpetrated on the Australian people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: name of privatisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr EWEN JONES (Herbert) (17:43): I rise with great pride to speak about the Asset

Speaker: NA
Text: Recycling Fund Bill and the Asset Recycling Fund Consequential Amendments Bill. We went

Speaker: NA
Text: to the election in 2013, and 7 September saw us elected as the government for Australia. We

Speaker: NA
Text: took four main promises to that election. No. 1 was to axe the carbon tax. That should be the

Speaker: NA
Text: easiest thing in the world to do, because we had bipartisan support-Kevin Rudd lined it up

Speaker: NA
Text: and shot it dead. It was gone. He had laid it down and put it to death. That would be the easy

Speaker: NA
Text: part. So we came in here and we passed the bill. Funnily enough, we asked the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Hughes, who was in the last parliament, if he was ever under any misconceptions about our

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: position on the carbon tax-we had always said it was going to go. But Labor, of course, had

Speaker: NA
Text: a few views on that sort of thing. When we came in here, Labor said they were going to

Speaker: NA
Text: terminate the carbon tax. But when the Minister for the Environment, Greg Hunt, stood up

Speaker: NA
Text: and presented the repeal bill, Labor voted against it-and they are still voting against it. So,

Speaker: NA
Text: whilst it has been passed in here, it is sitting over in the other place. But I will give that one a

Speaker: NA
Text: tick.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our second big one was to stop the boats. It has been six months without a boat. With a

Speaker: NA
Text: little bit of steel in the spine of the minister involved, he stood up and meant what he said. He

Speaker: NA
Text: went to the party room and he sold us on what we were supposed to do-and we have stopped

Speaker: NA
Text: the boats. We are actually shutting down detention centres in this country at the moment, so

Speaker: NA
Text: we can give that one a big tick.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third one was to build the roads of the 21st century, and that one is on its way. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: think there is anything surer than Warren Truss with the bit between his teeth. Jamie Briggs,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Assistant Minister for Infrastructure and Regional Development, has been all over the

Speaker: NA
Text: country telling us what we are going to do, how we are going to do it and the amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: money we will be spending. I was on the record in 2010 admitting and conceding that Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: spent more on infrastructure, including roads, than the Howard government did. I was on the

Speaker: NA
Text: record saying that. We will spend more than the Labor government did, just as the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government spent more than the Hawke-Keating government. The Hawke-Keating

Speaker: NA
Text: government spent more than the Fraser government. The Fraser government did not spend

Speaker: NA
Text: more than the Whitlam government, though-no-one spent more than the Whitlam

Speaker: NA
Text: government!

Speaker: NA
Text: The fourth promise was to fix the budget. That is on its way. That is what the budget is all

Speaker: NA
Text: about. Our first budget is responsible. Everyone's shoulder is to the wheel. We have a national

Speaker: NA
Text: narrative for where we as a country want to go. We want to go back to the days when we

Speaker: NA
Text: lived within our means. I have always said that no business returns to profit by shutting its

Speaker: NA
Text: doors. Similarly, no federal government budget returns to surplus by shutting down the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. It is a delicate balancing act that we have to have.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was still a real growth in spending in this budget of 2.7 per cent. Those opposite will

Speaker: NA
Text: stick to their mantra of spending growth in real terms needing to be two per cent. They had to

Speaker: NA
Text: cut another 0.7 per cent further just to get to where they wanted to be. They said for the last

Speaker: NA
Text: six years that spending would be cut to two per cent growth in real terms. They never actually

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved it. Of course, they also said that they would bring the budget to surplus a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: times. I am an auctioneer and I can count pretty high and pretty fast but-by jingo!-there is

Speaker: NA
Text: a bit of work to be done to try to keep up with the number of times they did that.

Speaker: NA
Text: How do we keep the economy moving? How do we keep the economy going? How do we

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure that we do not stall the economy? An example is in Townsville, where we have

Speaker: NA
Text: state support for the ring road. The coalition government have brought forward the second

Speaker: NA
Text: part of that project. We want it done in one fell swoop because the local contractors want to

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure that the work is being done. That sort of tenacity and forward-looking and forward-

Speaker: NA
Text: thinking management by your minister and assistant minister on infrastructure spending is

Speaker: NA
Text: something that should be held in high regard. Instead, it is met with derision from the other

Speaker: NA
Text: side.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The Queensland government faces probably the biggest task in this country after nearly 20

Speaker: NA
Text: years of Labor rule. It has a massive debt and deficit issue, far greater in real terms than the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian government. If you talk to Queensland Treasurer Tim Nicholls, he understands the

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge. The capacity of state governments over generations to earn and increase their own

Speaker: NA
Text: income has been wound back. Tim Nicholls, the state Treasurer, will tell you straight away

Speaker: NA
Text: that he does not like stamp duty and payroll tax but, if you take those away, he will not collect

Speaker: NA
Text: any money to bring into the state coffers. It must be very tempting for state governments,

Speaker: NA
Text: though, because they are faced with debt and deficit problems, to sell assets and simply retire

Speaker: NA
Text: debt. That would be a very tempting thing to do-to simply retire debt and try to get rid of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor memory as quickly as possible. This is what these bills address. It is about the benefit.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is about having an asset and what comes of that asset. Yes, we should be retiring debt. But,

Speaker: NA
Text: no, we do not want to stall the economy. There should be a pay-off and there should be

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit for it.

Speaker: NA
Text: When Treasurer Joe Hockey was in Townsville he was asked what he needed to see. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was asked what, if he were to be the nation's Treasurer, he wanted to see. He said, 'I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: see cranes in the sky. I want to see dozers pushing dirt. I want to see work being done,

Speaker: NA
Text: because we have to build stuff. We have to make sure that we are being productive and

Speaker: NA
Text: producing infrastructure.' It is not just infrastructure. Anyone can build school halls. It needs

Speaker: NA
Text: to be infrastructure that provides greater access for trade and commerce. That is what we

Speaker: NA
Text: need. That is where we want to be focused.

Speaker: NA
Text: When Andrew Robb was in Townsville he said not only do we have to be spending more

Speaker: NA
Text: money on infrastructure but we have to think about how we fund it. Every country in the

Speaker: NA
Text: world has an infrastructure deficit. So we have to try to figure out how best to address it.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no way in the world that a government can just come straight out and spend the

Speaker: NA
Text: money. Maybe those opposite could! But no government with any sort of responsibility could

Speaker: NA
Text: just come out and spend the money to get our infrastructure up to date. So how do we

Speaker: NA
Text: maximise the best terms? How do we do the most we can for our dollar? It is by engaging in

Speaker: NA
Text: the private sector and engaging foreign capital. That is how we have to do it. The Asset

Speaker: NA
Text: Recycling Fund Bill is part of our response to that. These are the positive measures that we as

Speaker: NA
Text: a country and government will take to make it more alluring and profitable for state

Speaker: NA
Text: governments of the day who hold these assets to reinvest in their states and in their local

Speaker: NA
Text: communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are some technical aspects of this bill I would like to walk through. The Asset

Speaker: NA
Text: Recycling Initiative taps into private sector investor interest in established brownfield

Speaker: NA
Text: assets-those are established assets, such as ports or electricity companies, with proven

Speaker: NA
