Text: earnings-in order to fund new infrastructure projects. You will find that companies such as

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation firms do not want to invest in greenfield sites because they would be risking

Speaker: NA
Text: the superannuation of our workers forever. Where something has a genuine business case, that

Speaker: NA
Text: is what superannuation firms will invest in. They will not invest in greenfield sites.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian government is establishing the Asset Recycling Fund as a dedicated

Speaker: NA
Text: investment vehicle for providing financial assistance and incentives to states and territories to

Speaker: NA
Text: create new infrastructure that boosts economic growth. We are boosting economic growth in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland. In Townsville, say, if the state government was to sell the Townsville port and

Speaker: NA
Text: part of that money went into investing in new infrastructure, that could lead to new

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: commerce, which would lead to more people moving to Townsville, leading to people buying

Speaker: NA
Text: cars and building and buying houses, and there would be stamp duty and registration-the

Speaker: NA
Text: money churn that goes through the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Asset Recycling Fund will be established from 1 July this year. This will allow

Speaker: NA
Text: funding to flow to infrastructure priorities and promote productivity and generate economic

Speaker: NA
Text: growth. The infrastructure growth package will build Australia's infrastructure for the 21st

Speaker: NA
Text: century. In the budget the Abbott government delivered a record $50 billion for infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: investment commencing with an initial $5.7 billion and the government is committed to

Speaker: NA
Text: adding to the fund over time.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you speak to the trade minister when he travels overseas, he says that he hosts

Speaker: NA
Text: roundtables and at those roundtables they have serious investors and all sorts of infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions. What they want to know is whether Australia will change the rules. We had lots

Speaker: NA
Text: of investment here in the mining boom and then suddenly we brought in the mining super

Speaker: NA
Text: profits tax which turned into the mining rent tax-it's the vessel with the pestle, not the

Speaker: NA
Text: chalice from the palace! It was just a bit of a hodgepodge of bills and that sort of thing which

Speaker: NA
Text: led capital investment to flee overseas. Andrew Robb, the Minister for Trade, has been told

Speaker: NA
Text: that if we are serious we will provide the ground rules and those are the rules under which we

Speaker: NA
Text: want to invest. What he is trying to say to those people overseas is that we are serious. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, the foreign minister, the defence minister and the trade minister were all

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas last week with key clients, key countries around our region and around the world,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they were saying that we are open for business. We are speaking with a coherent

Speaker: NA
Text: message.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Asset Recycling Fund will support the Asset Recycling Initiative which will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: incentives for states and territories to sell existing assets and invest in new infrastructure that

Speaker: NA
Text: supports a more productive economy. That is the key here. This sends the message that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is open for business all the way through. This historic agreement with the states has

Speaker: NA
Text: the potential to raise close to $40 billion of new infrastructure funding around the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what we have to be doing here.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fund's purpose will be to have an explicit purpose consistent with government's

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in productivity enhancing infrastructure, so it will not just be about building

Speaker: NA
Text: marine parks or shutting down fishing industries or anything like that. You will not be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: use it for that. The establishment of the investment fund will allow capital amounts to be

Speaker: NA
Text: invested by the Future Fund Board of Guardians to earn interest that will also be available to

Speaker: NA
Text: fund investment in infrastructure. This funding comes from uncommitted money in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Building Australia and Education Investment Fund-$2.4 billion from the Building Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund and $3.5 billion from the Education Investment Fund. The Asset Recycling Fund also

Speaker: NA
Text: allows for the new fund to be credited with proceeds from the sale of Medibank Private and

Speaker: NA
Text: with the proceeds of any further privatisation initiatives.

Speaker: NA
Text: The key here is to look at who is looking after us. We have a bit of a history when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: to putting money away. We have got the Future Fund which was looked after by Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Costello at the time. He put the money there to start off with. That has gone pretty well with

Speaker: NA
Text: money in the bank to make sure that public servants have their superannuation paid for and

Speaker: NA
Text: guaranteed, and that is a pretty serious investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Payments to states and territories will be made through the COAG Reform Fund. Once

Speaker: NA
Text: again, there are lots of checks and balances all the way through there. The project funding for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Asset Recycling Fund to cover payments to states and territories through COAG Reform

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund will require the approval of the finance minister following recommendations made by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer or the Minister for Infrastructure. So the Asset Recycling Fund will have Future

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund Board of Guardians. The Treasurer and the infrastructure minister will have the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for ensuring that funds that pass through the COAG Reform Fund special

Speaker: NA
Text: account and the infrastructure portfolio special account are expended in a manner consistent

Speaker: NA
Text: with the purposes of the fund as set out in the legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have a track record when it comes to these things. In places like Townsville we need

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure spending. We need to make sure that it is funded. We need to be able to fund it

Speaker: NA
Text: as well as we possibly can and get as big a bang for our buck as we possibly can. When it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to Townsville, we are delivering on infrastructure at our university. We are delivering

Speaker: NA
Text: $42 million for the Australian Institute of Tropical Health and Medicine. We have got the ring

Speaker: NA
Text: road going through-another $160 million-and there is the investment brought forward of

Speaker: NA
Text: $120 million for the Joint Logistics Hub at Townsville under construction as we speak. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is the Vantassel Street bypass. It was approved in 2010. It was supposed to start but we had a

Speaker: NA
Text: flood in 2011 so the federal government pulled funding for flood relief in Townsville and put

Speaker: NA
Text: it into flood relief in Brisbane. That is what Labor's infrastructure minister did. That is what

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's infrastructure minister thought of North Queensland when it came to infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: there.

Speaker: NA
Text: All in all I am very happy with what is happening here. I think that we have to be smart

Speaker: NA
Text: with what we are doing and I think that with the leadership we have shown here and the

Speaker: NA
Text: management that we will put in place, this is a great move for Australia. I thank the House.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Text: Charlton) (17:58): I am pleased to make a contribution on the Asset

Speaker: NA
Text: Recycling Fund Bill. In beginning I would be remiss not to comment on the contribution from

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Herbert who lectured this side about stable ground rules and predictability-

Speaker: NA
Text: this from the party of regional rorts; this from the party that changed infrastructure legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: to take away from an independent expert body, Infrastructure Australia, the ability to grant tax

Speaker: NA
Text: concessions for designated infrastructure investments and grant those powers to the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister who presided over the regional rorts affair. The hypocrisy and the chutzpah of

Speaker: NA
Text: The Nationals on regional rorts and infrastructure investment is beyond belief. But I will give

Speaker: NA
Text: it to the member for Herbert: he said all that he said with a straight face, and I respect his

Speaker: NA
Text: ability to do that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am pleased to make a contribution on these bills, and the purpose of these bills-let's

Speaker: NA
Text: make no bones about it-is to encourage state and territory governments to privatise assets

Speaker: NA
Text: and recycle the proceeds into new infrastructure. Labor is moving two sensible amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: to the bills. The first requires that the minister may not recommend a proposal for

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth funding unless they have considered advice from Infrastructure Australia as

Speaker: NA
Text: to the merit of the project, especially its contribution to productivity. The second requires that

Speaker: NA
Text: the finance minister table a disallowable instrument for each privatisation or reinvestment

Speaker: NA
Text: transaction that the government deems eligible for the incentive payment as a precondition for

Speaker: NA
Text: the paying of Commonwealth funds. In relation to the substantive nature of these bills, Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: believes that the federal government does need to provide leadership in collaboration with our

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: states in funding nation-building infrastructure projects. Government standards are important

Speaker: NA
Text: in this process in ensuring that decisions on investment are made in the broad national interest

Speaker: NA
Text: and not in the interests of political parties. The work of Infrastructure Australia is critical in

Speaker: NA
Text: this regard, and I will elaborate on this further in my contribution.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor recognises that asset recycling can be beneficial in certain circumstances and not in

Speaker: NA
Text: others. It is the obligation of the individual state and territory governments to make these

Speaker: NA
Text: determinations in consultation with their communities. The federal government of course

Speaker: NA
Text: already makes a very substantial contribution to many infrastructure projects, and Labor is of

Speaker: NA
Text: the view that it is a retrograde step to replace the substantial direct contribution with a simple

Speaker: NA
Text: 15 per cent incentive. If you are going to have a 15 per cent incentive, that cannot be an

Speaker: NA
Text: excuse for the federal government to retreat from infrastructure funding in other ways. Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: believes that this new asset recycling approach must be in addition to the very substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: levels of federal government funding in nation-building projects. Anything less will have a

Speaker: NA
Text: dire consequence for economic growth and prosperity in this nation. It is also worth noting the

Speaker: NA
Text: record investment in infrastructure that occurred under Labor-and this was delivered without

Speaker: NA
Text: state governments privatising their public assets to pay for it.

Speaker: NA
Text: All sides of the House agree on the fundamental importance of infrastructure investment to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian economy. It is of vital importance that governments invest in roads, rail, ports

Speaker: NA
Text: and airports. The World Economic Forum's Global Agenda Council on Infrastructure makes

Speaker: NA
Text: the very important point that the cost of building infrastructure is vast but the cost of failing to

Speaker: NA
Text: make these investments is incalculable. The OECD correctly identifies that upgrading

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure drives competitiveness, boosts trade and promotes economic growth. So,

Speaker: NA
Text: investing and building new infrastructure as well as improving existing infrastructure is

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamentally important to growing our economy and improving productivity. And of course

Speaker: NA
Text: the completed and upgraded infrastructure assets deliver enormous benefits for the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: and our society as a whole. The OECD has also noted that new ways of infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: financing are needed. And, as I have said previously, asset recycling can be an appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: vehicle to fund new assets and infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor has proposed amendments that enhance this purpose. These are having Infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia assess the new infrastructure as 'productivity enhancing' and the requirement to

Speaker: NA
Text: table a disallowable instrument for each privatisation or reinvestment transaction. These

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that this asset-recycling vehicle is appropriate and is in the national interest. And it is

Speaker: NA
Text: important that we include Infrastructure Australia in this process, because, since its creation in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2008, Infrastructure Australia has made a very important contribution to the way the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government makes decisions on infrastructure investment. In the year Infrastructure Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: was created, its chair, Sir Rod Eddington, said of the new body:

Speaker: NA
Text: It introduces a bold new approach to identifying, planning, funding and implementing infrastructure of

Speaker: NA
Text: national significance across Australia. It also introduces rigorous and robust economic analysis of

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure investments prior to government decision-making.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is disappointing therefore that the current government is seeking to undermine its

Speaker: NA
Text: effectiveness and operation. It is clear that the Deputy Prime Minister wants a return to the

Speaker: NA
Text: days of infrastructure investment decisions being made on the basis of coalition electoral

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage and not the broader national interest. If the federal government is to pursue this

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: asset recycling model, it is essential that Infrastructure Australia remain involved in the

Speaker: NA
Text: process. The amendments we are proposing ensure that it does.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendment, which will ensure that, before approval, Infrastructure Australia provides

Speaker: NA
Text: an assessment that the new infrastructure is 'productivity enhancing, including publishing a

Speaker: NA
Text: cost-benefit analysis, greatly strengthens the bills. In speaking on the asset recycling bills, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant to highlight Labor's approach to infrastructure investment and what we have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: from the coalition since they have come to government. Those of us on this side of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: are rightly proud of our record of achievement in infrastructure investment. Because of this

Speaker: NA
Text: record investment, Australia has gone from being ranked 20th out of 25 in the OECD to being

Speaker: NA
Text: ranked second in terms of spending on infrastructure as a proportion of gross domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: product. This is a great achievement. It is an achievement that the last Labor government and

Speaker: NA
Text: the then Minister for Infrastructure should be rightly proud of. And it is a very important

Speaker: NA
Text: statistic: because of Labor's investment, Australia is ranked second among the nations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: developed world in terms of infrastructure investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: And let's looks at what the results of that investment have been. The roads budget doubled

Speaker: NA
Text: to $46.5 billion; local government road grants were lifted by 20 per cent; $13.6 billion was

Speaker: NA
Text: invested in urban rail infrastructure, more than all Labor's predecessors combined; and $3.4

Speaker: NA
Text: billion was invested in the rail freight network. As well as these investments, the fundamental

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of infrastructure to Labor can be seen in the fact that we appointed the first-ever

Speaker: NA
Text: dedicated Minister for Infrastructure and created Infrastructure Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now, let's compare Labor's record with what the Abbott government has done in just nine

Speaker: NA
Text: months. They are re-announcing projects that have been funded by Labor; they are refusing to

Speaker: NA
Text: invest money in public transport; they have cut almost $1 billion out of financial assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: grants to local councils for roads; and they have cut $52 million to reserve a corridor for high-

Speaker: NA
Text: speed rail on the east coast and shut down the high-speed rail advisory group. What a pathetic

Speaker: NA
Text: start from a man who wants to be known as the infrastructure Prime Minister. And it is no

Speaker: NA
Text: surprise, because those on the other side have form on this issue. This is the coalition that

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered the regional rorts affair. We cannot forget the cheese factory that was funded and

Speaker: NA
Text: closed down, the rail line that burnt down, the half-million-dollar grant to Coonawarra Gold

Speaker: NA
Text: for a project that was never built, and my personal favourite: the pet food factory that never

Speaker: NA
Text: opened. Think of all those pets that are going without food now because of the regional rorts

Speaker: NA
Text: affair! And that is the track record of those on the other side. They have not met a barrel of

Speaker: NA
Text: pork that they have not wanted to get their hands into.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is important in the context of infrastructure in my region of the Hunter. On speaking

Speaker: NA
Text: on this issue, we need to be very conscious of the needs of the Hunter Valley, which is a high-

Speaker: NA
Text: growth region and provides a very strong economic contribution to our economy. The Hunter

Speaker: NA
Text: benefited greatly from the previous Labor government's historic infrastructure commitments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Hunter Expressway is the biggest infrastructure project ever undertaken in the region.

Speaker: NA
Text: The $1.7 billion expressway, funded by Labor, has recently been opened. Its benefits are

Speaker: NA
Text: significant. It cuts travel times between Newcastle and the Hunter Valley by up to 25 minutes

Speaker: NA
Text: and provides an easier and more direct route to the Port of Newcastle for heavy vehicles.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition's neglect of the Hunter is apparent in the recent budget. In the budget lock-up,

Speaker: NA
Text: when local Hunter journalists enquired about infrastructure funding in the budget for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunter, Treasury officials referred them to the Hunter Expressway project. These officials

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: were apparently not aware that the Hunter Expressway was funded by the Labor government

Speaker: NA
Text: in the 2009-10 budget, and had been open and operating for several months. This

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrates the complete lack of commitment to Hunter infrastructure from those on the

Speaker: NA
Text: other side. When they were questioned about it, the only project they could point to was a

Speaker: NA
Text: $1.7 billion project funded and built by Labor.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is not the only important piece of infrastructure in my region that we should be

Speaker: NA
Text: discussing. The Glendale Transport Interchange is the most important infrastructure need, not

Speaker: NA
Text: only in my electorate of Charlton, but for the whole of the Hunter Region. Close to $40

Speaker: NA
Text: million has been invested in this project from all levels of government. I am proud that

Speaker: NA
Text: although the infrastructure concerned is primarily the responsibility of the New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: government, the previous federal Labor government has invested $12.5 million towards the

Speaker: NA
Text: project. This funding is being used to complete major road works in preparation for the

Speaker: NA
Text: construction of the Pennant Street Bridge and rail overpass. This is a very large project that

Speaker: NA
Text: will take a considerable amount of time and resources to complete.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second stage of the interchange will require further significant funding. Unfortunately

Speaker: NA
Text: it appears that no additional funding was allocated to this project in the recent New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales budget. The New South Wales Liberal government has already committed some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proceeds of the privatisation of the Port of Newcastle to light rail infrastructure in the inner

Speaker: NA
Text: city of Newcastle. However, the residents of western Newcastle and western Lake Macquarie,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I represent, are equally entitled to an allocation of funding from the privatisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given Glendale is the most important infrastructure project for the Hunter, it would be

Speaker: NA
Text: inexcusable for the state government not to direct further funding to complete the interchange.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Port of Newcastle was sold for $1.7 billion, in excess of double what the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: government thought they would get for it, yet they are recycling less than $350 million of that

Speaker: NA
Text: to the region. It is only fair that the Glendale Transport Interchange, the most important piece

Speaker: NA
Text: of infrastructure in the region, is built with the proceeds from the port, a port built on

Speaker: NA
Text: transport of goods that have come from the western suburbs of Newcastle, from West Lake

Speaker: NA
Text: Macquarie and from up the Hunter Valley. Residents there will directly benefit from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Glendale Transport Interchange. If this is an example of asset recycling under the coalition I

Speaker: NA
Text: am very worried about what they will do in future, because it demonstrates again that they

Speaker: NA
Text: have only contempt for the Hunter and only pay lip-service to the region.

Speaker: NA
Text: The high-speed rail is another example of this contempt. High-speed rail is a fair way off in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of being economical, but Labor did the right thing in government. The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Grayndler allocated $52 million to feasibility studies and put together a working group to look

Speaker: NA
Text: at preserving a corridor. These are all important projects which mean that when high-speed

Speaker: NA
Text: rail becomes economical on the east coast we will be ready to move. This will be a

Speaker: NA
Text: revolutionary project for the east coast and my region in particular. If it were feasible to

Speaker: NA
Text: commute daily to Sydney in less than two-and-a-half-hour to three-hour each way, that can

Speaker: NA
Text: only be good for my region. It would grow the economic base and the population and really

Speaker: NA
Text: secure the future of Australia's sixth largest city.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the coalition have thrown all of that away by abandoning this effort. They should be in

Speaker: NA
Text: a position where they understand that advance planning is incredibly important. The Badgerys

Speaker: NA
Text: Creek announcement this year, welcomed by people on my side, could proceed only because

Speaker: NA
Text: in the 1980s the visionary Hawke Labor government preserved the land, did the planning and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: set aside the zoning of the land so that the project could go ahead when the time was right.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those on the other side take no lessons from history, unfortunately.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another area where they show contempt for my region is the Resources for Regions

Speaker: NA
Text: program run by the New South Wales Liberal government. It is another example of asset

Speaker: NA
Text: recycling, which is what we are debating in this bill. The Resources for Regions program

Speaker: NA
Text: aims to support regional and rural communities affected by mining by addressing

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure constraints. Local government areas that are identified as being mining affected

Speaker: NA
Text: communities are eligible to apply for funding from the program. The New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: government recently added the local government areas of Cessnock, Maitland and Newcastle

Speaker: NA
Text: to the list of councils eligible for funding. Late in the process they are only adding Cessnock,

Speaker: NA
Text: Maitland and Newcastle to this program for mining affected areas. I cannot think of any local

Speaker: NA
Text: government areas that are more the heart blood of mining than these areas, except for one,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is the Lake Macquarie City Council LGA, which is yet to be added to this list. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: proud of the fact that there are six operating coalmines in Charlton. I would, however, ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales government to explain how a council that has six operational mines within

Speaker: NA
Text: its boundaries is not a mining affected community. Perhaps the Hunter Liberal MPs can

Speaker: NA
Text: explain this to my constituents. It is outrageous that Lake Macquarie Council is not eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: for this program, and it again demonstrates that the Liberal Party only pays lip-service to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunter Region.

Speaker: NA
Text: To conclude, Labor is of the view that in certain circumstances asset recycling can have

Speaker: NA
Text: merit, but of course state and territory governments have to determine this with their

Speaker: NA
Text: communities. The amendments moved by my colleague the member for Grayndler improve

Speaker: NA
Text: and strengthen the bills. The involvement of Infrastructure Australia in assessing productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: enhancements is important and vital to avoid the regional rorts we saw under the last coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: government. Having a disallowable instrument means that this parliament has the final say on

Speaker: NA
Text: how Commonwealth funding is allocated. God forbid those on the other side who want to

Speaker: NA
Text: support the privatisation of a hospital.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can assure my constituents that whatever the fate of these bills, and whatever the future

Speaker: NA
Text: intentions of the New South Wales government are, I will continue to lobby for improved

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure in Charlton, most particularly the Glendale Transport Interchange, the most

Speaker: NA
Text: important infrastructure priority in all the Hunter region.

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend the amendments to the House.

Speaker: Mr COLEMAN
Text: Banks) (18:13): I am very thrilled to speak on the Asset Recycling Fund

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 2014, a very good piece of legislation. I will start by responding to some of the remarks

Speaker: NA
Text: of the member for Charlton. He is always a colourful contributor in this place. The problem

Speaker: NA
Text: with the previous government's approach in this area, as in so many others, was to announce a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole lot of projects and do absolutely nothing about funding them. We have seen this right

Speaker: NA
Text: across the board, but nowhere more so than in infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The list of projects is a list of infamy. In Western Australia, there was the Great Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway and the North West Coastal Highway-neither were funded by Labor. In South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, there was the APY Lands road network-not funded under Labor. In Queensland,

Speaker: NA
Text: there was the Cape York regional package-not funded. In New South Wales, there were a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of projects: Bolivia Hill, Mount Ousley, the Tourle Street Bridge duplication and,

Speaker: NA
Text: close to the member for Charlton, the Scone level crossing-all unfunded projects. One of the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: first things this government had to do in this infrastructure space was fund these projects. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: all well and good to put out a press release, to stand at the relevant intersection, shake hands

Speaker: NA
Text: with someone and say, 'This is going to happen,' but unless you actually fund the project, it

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot happen. The alternative to funding it is to just borrow more money and increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: debt level of this nation. That of course is something we would not countenance. So there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: very clear contrast.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill we are discussing today is a very good piece of legislation. In a very practical way

Speaker: NA
Text: it encourages the states to recycle their assets and to invest in new productive infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fund has some $5.9 billion in it-a very substantial amount indeed. The fund will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: additional funding of 15 per cent when a state seeks to invest in an infrastructure project after

Speaker: NA
Text: recycling an asset. The combination of that 15 per cent incentive with a fund of about $6

Speaker: NA
Text: billion means that, if the fund is fully utilised, there will be $40 billion of additional

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure investment. This is important because these are big, expensive projects and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: not always easy to find the funds to make them happen. A 15 per cent incentive will be very

Speaker: NA
Text: effective in pushing projects across that line of viability, projects that otherwise might not

Speaker: NA
Text: have happened.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rather than creating a whole new bureaucracy, setting up a new department or setting up

Speaker: NA
Text: lengthy negotiations with the states, the Asset Recycling Fund provides a very simple signal

Speaker: NA
Text: to the states: if you are willing to invest in important capital expenditure, we will stand there

Speaker: NA
Text: right beside you and provide a 15 per cent incentive. That will be critical because, as I said,

Speaker: NA
Text: many projects are just short of that line; 15 per cent will tip many of them just over it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure is important economically because it is the economic gift that keeps on

Speaker: NA
Text: giving. Once you put in place a critical piece of infrastructure-whether it is a road, a port or

Speaker: NA
Text: any other similar facility-once you make that difficult decision to invest, in many cases,

Speaker: NA
Text: many billions of dollars, that piece of infrastructure is then there for the long run. If it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: road, say, it delivers for you on day one, it delivers for you a year down the track, it delivers

Speaker: NA
Text: for you a decade down the track and it delivers for you many decades down the track.

Speaker: NA
Text: Think about some of the iconic infrastructure in our nation's history. Think about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney Harbour Bridge, for example. What an extraordinary piece of infrastructure that is. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the 80-plus years since its construction, it has generated incalculable economic benefits for

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Sydney and for the nation more generally. Then there is the Snowy Mountains

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme, another well-known example. Closer to the present day, there is the M4 highway in

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney. Imperfect though it is-and we are going to fix that with the WestConnex-it has

Speaker: NA
Text: undoubtedly had an enormous impact in opening up Western Sydney to economic growth. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen many business precincts pop up along the M4. That would not have happened had

Speaker: NA
Text: the road not been there. With those business precincts-with the warehouses and the

Speaker: NA
Text: factories-come the jobs. Ultimately, why do we care about economic growth? We care about

Speaker: NA
Text: economic growth because economic growth means jobs, and infrastructure means economic

Speaker: NA
Text: growth. That is why it is so important.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no question that infrastructure is important. I suspect even those opposite would

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge that basic point. But those opposite have shown an inability to take the really

Speaker: NA
Text: tough decisions in this space. There has been no harder or more important decision in

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure than the decision to build an airport in Western Sydney. Western Sydney has

Speaker: NA
Text: been crying out for an airport for decades. The original identification of the Badgerys Creek

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: site occurred back in 1969. I was born in 1974, so for my entire life there has been a proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: to build an airport at Badgerys Creek. We all know that there are complexities associated with

Speaker: NA
Text: building a new airport. As a consequence of those complexities, the project did not get

Speaker: NA
Text: approved. It did not go forward. It took the Prime Minister, with his vision of infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: for the nation and for Western Sydney, to bite the bullet and make that hard decision.

Speaker: NA
Text: Frankly, I think the vast majority of people in Sydney know we had to do it and know it

Speaker: NA
Text: was the right decision. There is a strong level of community support-and so there should be.

Speaker: NA
Text: Badgerys Creek is going to be a huge economic boon for Western Sydney. There will be

Speaker: NA
Text: 4,000 jobs in construction. That is great, but of course construction only goes on for so long.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is arguably more important is the ongoing economic benefit-the ongoing infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements, the productivity improvement, the fact that you will be able to get freight into

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Sydney more quickly and at lower cost. What does that mean? More freight comes in

Speaker: NA
Text: and so you get more economic activity in Western Sydney, with more material moving

Speaker: NA
Text: through those warehouses. When more material moves through those warehouses-because it

Speaker: NA
Text: can move around so efficiently-what happens? More jobs. That is why it matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: The best forecast is for an extra $60 billion in GDP by 2060. That is an important figure,

Speaker: NA
Text: but these figures can sometimes be a bit abstract. What does it really mean? It means a huge

Speaker: NA
Text: number of new jobs for Western Sydney. It also means that for Kingsford Smith Airport-a

Speaker: NA
Text: loyal servant of the nation for many decades-there is a reality about what it can and cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: do. It can only grow so far. The approval of a second airport means that we all recognise that

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingsford Smith has a logical capacity. That capacity will be reached fairly soon and

Speaker: NA
Text: Badgery's Creek will help to fill the void.

Speaker: NA
Text: Badgery's Creek is accompanied by the Western Sydney roads package. This is a critical

Speaker: NA
Text: development. Bringelly Road, Northern Road and Elizabeth Drive are all roads that have not

Speaker: NA
Text: kept pace with the growth of Western Sydney. My colleagues the member for Macarthur and

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Lindsay, whose electorates are directly involved in this, have been articulate

Speaker: NA
Text: advocates for the need of an upgrade of that infrastructure. A $3 billion project will be great

Speaker: NA
Text: for the area.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is also great to see the cooperation of the state government. The Commonwealth is

Speaker: NA
Text: providing some 80 per cent of funding for the Western Sydney road project, and the state is

Speaker: NA
Text: providing 20 per cent. This is a good common-sense example of governments rolling up their

Speaker: NA
Text: sleeves and getting things done. That is what the people of Western Sydney and Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: generally want to see.

Speaker: NA
Text: Closer to my electorate, the government has made a very important infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment in stage 2 of the WestConnex. Most critically for my electorate, this means the

Speaker: NA
Text: duplication of the M5 East. The M5 East can be incredibly frustrating to drive on. It is only

Speaker: NA
Text: two lanes. This will make four. It is the main arterial road from the south-western part of

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney into the city-from the Beverly Hills interchange, which is in my electorate; the

Speaker: NA
Text: duplication going towards the city. Best estimate from the department is that it will save 25

Speaker: NA
Text: minutes for people travelling to the city in peak hour. That is an enormous benefit from a

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity perspective and from a family-life perspective, because it means people get home

Speaker: NA
Text: quicker at the end of the day. That can only be a good thing. So there is great cooperation

Speaker: NA
Text: with the state government.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a $1½ billion direct injection from the Commonwealth and a concessional loan of

Speaker: NA
Text: $2 billion, which has really helped. As we discussed before, with these projects, it is often

Speaker: NA
Text: about tipping them over the edge and making them happen, and that $2 billion concessional

Speaker: NA
Text: loan has got WestConnex and the M5 duplication over the line-so much so that the

Speaker: NA
Text: development will start next year and the project will be completed within five years. These

Speaker: NA
Text: are lengthy projects, and that is a very good time frame.

Speaker: NA
Text: WestConnex will be a tremendous benefit and is consistent with the government's overall

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to getting the economy moving again. We see a similar situation in environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: approvals, where the Minister for Environment has stepped forward and provided approvals

Speaker: NA
Text: for some $400 billion of projects that were sitting idle under the previous government in a

Speaker: NA
Text: maze of indecision, red tape and bureaucratic malaise. The Minister for the Environment last

Speaker: NA
Text: year, prior to Christmas-one of the first things he did on taking office-stepped in and said,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'These are critical and massive job-creating projects, and we are going to enable them to

Speaker: NA
Text: happen.' At the end of the day, that is the critical role of government: enabling things to occur

Speaker: NA
Text: in the economy. The government has great limitations on what it can do regarding direct

Speaker: NA
Text: intervention in the economy, and so much of that is best left to the private sector. What we

Speaker: NA
Text: can do-and what we are doing, through this infrastructure package-is enable private-sector

Speaker: NA
Text: investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are not used to that in my state of New South Wales, because in 16 years we had a state

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government. We had more announcements about infrastructure than the births, deaths

Speaker: NA
Text: and marriages page. There were all sorts of things that were going to happen. I have to say,

Speaker: NA
Text: we did as a populace, the people of New South Wales, become a little cynical. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Parramatta-Epping rail link was announced with much fanfare; we literally lost count of the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of times. There were so many hard hats, so many fluro vests, so many announcements

Speaker: NA
Text: and so much happening. At the end of the day, people will judge governments on their

Speaker: NA
Text: results-as they should-and the infrastructure results in New South Wales, in that sorry

Speaker: NA
Text: period between 1995 and 2011, were just appalling. That is why it is so great to see the

Speaker: NA
Text: emphasis on infrastructure, from the New South Wales government working hand in hand

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Commonwealth, in this asset-recycling area.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the fundamental commitments of the government prior to the election was to build

Speaker: NA
Text: the roads of the 21st century. We know that we need that. We know that for too long difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure projects have been put in the too-hard basket. This government, through a

Speaker: NA
Text: combination of direct investment, incentives for states to invest and getting rid of arbitrary

Speaker: NA
Text: and excessively regulated approval processes so as to allow the private sector invest, is going

Speaker: NA
Text: to build the roads of the 21st century. WestConnex is a critical one for my electorate and this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill will assist in that tremendous government initiative.

Speaker: Mr NEUMANN
Text: Blair) (18:28): I am speaking in relation to the two bills before the

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber: the Asset Recycling Fund Bill 2014 and the Asset Recycling Fund (Consequential

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendments) Bill 2014, which would create the Asset Recycling Fund, the ARF. This would

Speaker: NA
Text: provide financial assistance and incentives to the states and territories to invest in

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure. It is the result of a national partnership agreement reached by the first ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: of the states and territories on 2 May this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill proposes that the Commonwealth provide states and territories, which privatise

Speaker: NA
Text: their assets and recycle the proceeds into new productive infrastructure, an additional 15 per

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the reinvested sale proceeds to the cost of new infrastructure. It must be remembered

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is no new money here. It does not contain any new funding at all. In fact, it puts

Speaker: NA
Text: aside a bucket of money-$2.4 billion of uncommitted funds from the Building Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund and $3.5 billion of uncommitted funds from the Education Investment Fund. In listening

Speaker: NA
Text: to speaker after speaker from the coalition, you would think that billions and billions of

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars in new money was being rolled out in this fund, but it is just a recycling of federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government funds which we created when we were in government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government said they intend to make further contributions to the Asset Recycling Fund

Speaker: NA
Text: from the privatisation of Medibank Private and other privatisations, unnamed. We created the

Speaker: NA
Text: Building Australia Fund, the BAF, and the Education Investment Fund, the EIF, to fund land

Speaker: NA
Text: transport and education infrastructure respectively, and those funds were doing precisely that.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposed ARF has similar governance provisions to those of the BAF and the EIF, as

Speaker: NA
Text: managed by the Future Fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: We do not believe these bills in their current form adequately maintain the governance

Speaker: NA
Text: standards that we introduced for the BAF and the EIF. The shadow minister, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Grayndler, has circulated proposed amendments that relate to governance standards, with

Speaker: NA
Text: proper cost-benefit analysis published by Infrastructure Australia and a disallowable

Speaker: NA
Text: instrument requirement for the Treasurer so that greater parliamentary oversight is a

Speaker: NA
Text: precondition of payment of Commonwealth government funds.

Speaker: NA
Text: Concerns about this legislation were raised in the Senate Finance and Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Administration Committee inquiry by the Australian Technology Network of universities:

Speaker: NA
Text: Curtin University, University of South Australia, RMIT University, the University of

Speaker: NA
Text: Technology Sydney and Queensland University of Technology. They teach about a quarter of

Speaker: NA
Text: a million students in higher education campuses around the country. They looked at this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation and expressed some concern about it and about the winding up of the BAF and the

Speaker: NA
Text: EIF, especially as 59 per cent of the initial funding for the ARF comes from the Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Investment Fund, which those universities have benefited from in the past. We know that

Speaker: NA
Text: higher education is going to be more expensive under this government. The ATN asked: if the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of the ARF closely aligns to the purpose of the Building Australia Fund, without

Speaker: NA
Text: proper public transport spending, what protection will there be for future higher education

Speaker: NA
Text: research and education related infrastructure spend? There was no response from the

Speaker: NA
Text: government to that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I recall a coalition policy at the last election-a so-called five-pillar economy-about

Speaker: NA
Text: research in higher education and world-class education. What they are doing here is taking

Speaker: NA
Text: away money from those areas. But that is to be expected from a government that does not

Speaker: NA
Text: even have a science minister. And anything to do with climate change or research or

Speaker: NA
Text: innovation or creativity seems to get abolished. If it is a body, organisation or group that is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing some public service, some social and economic good, and it has any of those terms in it,

Speaker: NA
Text: it was abolished in MYEFO or indeed in the budget. These bills are silent in relation to future

Speaker: NA
Text: research and education related infrastructure spending. It is typical.

Speaker: NA
Text: We heard those opposite criticise us about infrastructure. We have a proud record with

Speaker: NA
Text: respect to infrastructure. I can recall many occasions in the last six years, in the time I have

Speaker: NA
Text: been in this place, where coalition members voted again and again against infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: spends, whether it was the necessary funds for recovery after the floods in South-East

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland and the cyclones in North Queensland or the nation-building response we had to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake as a result of the global financial crisis-which those opposite think is a myth, a bit

Speaker: NA
Text: like the Loch Ness monster. We had to spend that money to keep 250,000 people in jobs and

Speaker: NA
Text: to keep the economy going and avoid recession. Again and again we put forward bills in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place in relation to an infrastructure spend to keep jobs in place, to help rural and regional

Speaker: NA
Text: areas and urban areas with rail, transport, infrastructure for councils and regional and local

Speaker: NA
Text: community infrastructure funding. We proposed the nation-building economic stimulus, with

Speaker: NA
Text: the BER. In the last six years in this place, those opposite, who were critical of us in

Speaker: NA
Text: government, voted against all those things.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we came into power in November 2007 we massively increased the infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: spend. We were ranked 20th and by the time we left office we were ranked No. 1. In dollar

Speaker: NA
Text: spends we lifted infrastructure from $132 to $225 per Australian. For Queensland it was even

Speaker: NA
Text: better. We reversed the blockages on productivity and infrastructure the coalition government

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to address-ports, road, rail. They did not fund an urban rail project north of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tweed; there was nothing in Queensland. When we were in government we spent more

Speaker: NA
Text: money on urban transport than was spent by every government in the history of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth of Australia. We saw it as a priority to get people to commute to their places

Speaker: NA
Text: of work by public transport rather than by car. It is good for the economy and it is good for

Speaker: NA
Text: the environment. We doubled road funding to $46.5 billion. We upgraded 7,500 kilometres of

Speaker: NA
Text: local roads. We increased grants to local governments through Roads to Recovery by 20 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. In my area, Ipswich City Council got $6.5 million in Roads to Recovery grants-more

Speaker: NA
Text: than they had ever seen before.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was not just that. As I said, we committed $13.6 billion to urban rail infrastructure. We

Speaker: NA
Text: saw that as a priority. We invested heavily in the national rail freight network-some $3.4

Speaker: NA
Text: billion over six years. We rebuilt more than a third of the whole network. We are talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about more than 4,000 kilometres of track. We invested $64 billion in infrastructure and we

Speaker: NA
Text: committed tens of billions of dollars to further nation-building if we were re-elected. We also

Speaker: NA
Text: faced the terrible disasters that I referred to not just in Queensland but in Victoria and other

Speaker: NA
Text: states, including the fires and floods in Western Australia. We addressed those issues. We

Speaker: NA
Text: ended the utterly shameless pork-barrelling that those opposite undertook. The ANAO report

Speaker: NA
Text: on regional rorts was quite damning of the Howard government.

Speaker: NA
Text: We started investing in regional and rural communities. We set up Infrastructure Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: to get rid of inefficiency and increase efficiency in the economy, and we put a priority on jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: and productivity. The Abbott government have ignored my electorate since they have been in

Speaker: NA
Text: power. The Abbott government never talk about the last section of the Ipswich Motorway,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Howard government refused to build it. The Ipswich Motorway was the most

Speaker: NA
Text: important road project west of Brisbane. We spent $3 billion to upgrade from Dinmore to

Speaker: NA
Text: Darra. Up to 100,000 vehicles a day can travel on that road at the most congested times. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are talking about 100,000 vehicles a day potential. What did we do? It was planned, designed,

Speaker: NA
Text: built and opened under a Labor government. It was not just about turning up for a photo

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity-it was done. You can drive on it any day of the week. It is important. The

Speaker: NA
Text: service roads took 25 per cent of the traffic off the Ipswich Motorway. When the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: voted against the Ipswich Motorway project west of Ipswich, the Blacksoil Interchange, we

Speaker: NA
Text: funded it. We partnered with the then state Labor government and that project, the Ipswich

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Motorway, created and sustained up to 10,000 jobs during the global financial crisis. There

Speaker: NA
Text: were 300 jobs created and sustained on the building the Blacksoil Interchange-$54 million

Speaker: NA
Text: there. To the credit of the LNP state government in Queensland, they have come to the party

Speaker: NA
Text: and that project will be opened later this year. That is critical for the 40,000 vehicles a day

Speaker: NA
Text: and the commuters in rural and regional areas not just in Ipswich and Brisbane but in

Speaker: NA
Text: Toowoomba, the Lockyer Valley and the Scenic Rim and Somerset regions. We, under a

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government, did what the coalition government refused to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: My concern is that this 15 per cent-it will not be 75 per cent; it will not be 50 per cent-

Speaker: NA
Text: will be the basis of Commonwealth government infrastructure contributions in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what I expect will happen. This government has abandoned whole areas. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister is very good at saying that he is the Prime Minister for this and that. For example, he

Speaker: NA
Text: is the Prime Minister for women, but he has very few women on the front bench over there;

Speaker: NA
Text: he is the Prime Minister for Indigenous affairs, but he will cut $534.4 million in

Speaker: NA
Text: programmatic funding for health, education, justice and other programs for Aboriginal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Torres Strait Islander people; and he is the infrastructure Prime Minister, but he cuts rail

Speaker: NA
Text: projects, like the Brisbane Cross River Rail project in Queensland and the rail link in Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government see that as a state responsibility. They keep rolling out projects such as the

Speaker: NA
Text: inland rail freight project, saying they are their projects. We were funding them. They are a

Speaker: NA
Text: continuation of what we were doing. There are no new dollars in this bill. It is a fake and a

Speaker: NA
Text: fraud. They are claiming projects that are being built but that the Labor government designed,

Speaker: NA
Text: budgeted for and funded.

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation is really about a right-wing privatisation binge typical of coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: governments. We see that in Queensland, my home state. We have seen the most despicable,

Speaker: NA
Text: disgraceful propaganda by the LNP and Campbell Newman on a $33 billion privatisation

Speaker: NA
Text: binge they are about to undertake. It did not do Anna Bligh and the Labor government much

Speaker: NA
Text: good when they tried to privatise assets in Queensland, so I do not think it will do Campbell

Speaker: NA
Text: Newman and the LNP government much good when they go to the polls by March next year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The consultation was not genuine at all. It was bogus; a predetermined consultation process.

Speaker: NA
Text: The majority of Queenslanders by the public response, even on the dummy website, the bogus

Speaker: NA
Text: website, opposed it. A recent poll found that 47 per cent of respondents would be less likely

Speaker: NA
Text: to vote for the Queensland LNP government if they continued their drive towards

Speaker: NA
Text: privatisation of state assets. They spent $6 million of Queensland taxpayers' money on an

Speaker: NA
Text: elaborate consultation program that was called Stronger Choices, and it was a flop. The

Speaker: NA
Text: people did not want it. They did not want to privatise assets, but the LNP decided to do it

Speaker: NA
Text: anyway. Organisationally, if the LNP in Queensland had any integrity, it would front up with

Speaker: NA
Text: a cheque for the taxpayers of Queensland from their own campaign coffers and put it back

Speaker: NA
Text: into consolidated revenue.

Speaker: NA
Text: This was an LNP propaganda campaign with a fancy website and incessant ads. When I

Speaker: NA
Text: was travelling around the country, I found the ads everywhere interstate. As a shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister, I was travelling in different states and would see the ads on TV channels. They were

Speaker: NA
Text: not even directed solely to Queensland. There were fliers in the mail. We even saw

Speaker: NA
Text: information kiosks in my electorate at the Riverlink Shopping Centre in North Ipswich which

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to a so-called $80 billion debt and annual interest costs-it was untrue. It was simply

Speaker: NA
Text: misleading and an overtly political campaign. It was completely misleading. The budget

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: papers in the Queensland government reveal that the gross debt under Campbell Newman has

Speaker: NA
Text: increased by $14.6 billion-or $833,000 per hour under the state LNP government.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my electorate, in Ipswich, unemployment has gone up from 5.3 per cent to 12.3 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: under Campbell Newman. So much for asset recycling. They privatised by stealth. They did

Speaker: NA
Text: not tell the people that they were going to undertake privatisation. There are organisations and

Speaker: NA
Text: bodies in Queensland that have been privatised repeatedly, but the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken these big campaigns to privatise the big stuff, such as the big energy companies.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is $33 billion on the table. The people do not want this legislation. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments that need to be considered, and the shadow minister will put them. This bill has

Speaker: NA
Text: real flaws. The whole privatisation commitment of this government is about an ideological

Speaker: NA
Text: right-wing, free-marketeer, buccaneering system. It will not be copped by the public in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. If the Queensland government thinks it can get away with that, wait until March

Speaker: NA
Text: next year and we will see how they go.

Speaker: Mr FLETCHER
Text: Bradfield-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Communications) (18:43): I am pleased to speak on the Asset Recycling Fund Bill 2014.

Speaker: NA
Text: This very important bill will establish the Asset Recycling Fund, which is a dedicated vehicle

Speaker: NA
Text: to facilitate investment in new infrastructure. It will operate by providing financial incentives

Speaker: NA
Text: to state and territory governments to sell existing assets and to reinvest the sale proceeds into

Speaker: NA
Text: additional infrastructure. I want to cover three points in the time available to me tonight.

Speaker: NA
Text: Firstly, Australia's infrastructure has significant deficiencies, and there is a backlog of projects

Speaker: NA
Text: which need to be commenced. Secondly, these deficiencies are of considerable public policy

Speaker: NA
Text: importance and, thirdly, this bill establishes a mechanism which will help to facilitate

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in new infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: If I turn firstly to the proposition that we have a significant deficiency in the state of our

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure in Australia it is no exaggeration to say that this is one of the common themes

Speaker: NA
Text: of public policy commentary in Australia today. We can look at numerous sources of data; for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, the World Economic Forum's 2010-11 Global Competitiveness Index ranks

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian infrastructure at 22nd out of 139 countries. However, as Infrastructure Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out, when you look at the measures that are more relevant to Australia, our ranking is

Speaker: NA
Text: in the 30s and 40s. Our total capital stock expressed as a proportion of our GDP is below the

Speaker: NA
Text: average of OECD countries, and the position has been getting worse with public investment

Speaker: NA
Text: in infrastructure as a proportion of our GDP declining in recent years. These figures confirm

Speaker: NA
Text: the anecdotal impressions that many of us would get as we go through the shiny new airports

Speaker: NA
Text: in many Asian countries. We are being eclipsed in Australia by the infrastructure spending of

Speaker: NA
Text: many developing countries, such as China and the Middle East. All of us, I am sure, have had

Speaker: NA
Text: the experience of travelling through a modern, large, well-planned airport in Asia-I can

Speaker: NA
Text: mention Hong Kong airport opened in 1998, Bangkok opened in 2006, Singapore's Changi or

Speaker: NA
Text: numerous airports in China.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is somewhat depressing to return to Australia and disembark at Kingsford Smith Airport

Speaker: NA
Text: with its rabbit warren of successively-added gates and the unedifying experience of being

Speaker: NA
Text: forced through the duty-free perfume and cigarettes before reaching the overcrowded

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration control area. The unflattering comparisons do not stop at airports, as anyone who

Speaker: NA
Text: has used either urban or long-distance railways in Japan or China or Singapore knows only

Speaker: NA
Text: too well. According to a 2010 report by the OECD,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia faces a shortfall in infrastructure which could worsen with the demand pressures exerted by

Speaker: NA
Text: the mining boom, population growth and environmental concerns.

Speaker: NA
Text: Similar conclusions were reached by Engineers Australia, an organisation which prepares a

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive annual scorecard of Australia's infrastructure position. Its 2010 report card

Speaker: NA
Text: ranks some critical sectors as 'poor' and the overall position in Australia as merely 'adequate'.

Speaker: NA
Text: A report a couple of years ago by Infrastructure Partnerships Australia cites estimates of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's 'infrastructure investment task' as ranging from $455 billion in a 2008 report by

Speaker: NA
Text: ABN Amro to $770 billion estimated by Citigroup. The recent Productivity Commission draft

Speaker: NA
Text: report into public infrastructure, issued earlier this year, cites a range of other estimates,

Speaker: NA
Text: including a $300 billion estimate by Infrastructure Australia in 2013. So it is clear that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: a range of bodies opining that Australia has a significant infrastructure shortfall. There

Speaker: NA
Text: appears to be a broad consensus that this shortfall has arisen over quite a number of years, due

Speaker: NA
Text: to continued underinvestment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me turn next to the proposition that this is a matter of considerable public policy

Speaker: NA
Text: importance and something that government and, indeed, the community ought to be very

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned about. The consequences of this under-investment are being felt in many areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: our economy and our society: the growth in exports from Australia is placing strain on our

Speaker: NA
Text: ports; there is congestion in our cities exacerbated by population growth and changing

Speaker: NA
Text: demographics; our electricity infrastructure is under pressure; and there is continuing

Speaker: NA
Text: investment needed to support key industries, including mining. There are a range of other

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons for the lack of investment in infrastructure and, therefore, the deficiencies in

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure are putting increasing pressure on our economic performance and on our social

Speaker: NA
Text: wellbeing.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a clear and direct link between infrastructure and our national productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: performance. One of the best historical examples to explain the connection between

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure and productivity is the investment made by the US government in the interstate

Speaker: NA
Text: freeway system in the 1950s. This was originally justified as a defence measure, but it had

Speaker: NA
Text: huge productivity benefits, because it reduced the delivery times for goods and expanded the

Speaker: NA
Text: geographic area within which any one company could cost effectively supply customers, and

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore increased the intensity of competition to the benefit of consumers and to the benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: of overall economic efficiency. There is quite a considerable economic literature on the

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity spin-offs from the US interstate freeway system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Rod Eddington in 2011, as the chair of Infrastructure Australia, noted that:

Speaker: NA
Text: Productivity has slowed as a direct result of infrastructure shortfalls-time lost in travel, delay at ports,

Speaker: NA
Text: lost production due to water restrictions.

Speaker: NA
Text: So the economic case for increased investment in infrastructure is a very strong one, but there

Speaker: NA
Text: is also a strong equity and quality of life case to be made. John Kenneth Galbraith, the well-

Speaker: NA
Text: known US economist-actually born in Canada, for the pointy heads-in the 1950s coined

Speaker: NA
Text: the term 'Private Affluence, Public Squalor' to convey the idea of a rich society which under-

Speaker: NA
Text: invests in its public infrastructure. His point was that this harms social cohesion and results in

Speaker: NA
Text: a society which fails to reach its full potential. If congested roads mean that you face a longer

Speaker: NA
Text: travel time to work, you are wasting time sitting in traffic, rather than being with your family

Speaker: NA
Text: or in pursuing other activities meaningful to you. That wasted time obviously has a substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: economic cost, particularly when multiplied by the millions of people in the same position,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: but it has a very real social cost as well. Therefore one of the most important things

Speaker: NA
Text: governments can do to improve the quality of life of the people they serve is to deliver good

Speaker: NA
Text: quality infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me turn therefore to the proposition that this bill lays out an effective mechanism to

Speaker: NA
Text: facilitate investment in new infrastructure. It is an effective mechanism which recognises that

Speaker: NA
Text: much of the day to day work of planning and, indeed, funding major infrastructure projects

Speaker: NA
Text: occurs at state government level but that there is an important role for the federal government

Speaker: NA
Text: in supporting the states in the work that they do. It is the mechanism contained in this bill to

Speaker: NA
Text: address that issue and to support and encourage the states which is a particularly noteworthy

Speaker: NA
Text: piece of public policy innovation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The measures in this bill and the scheme which will be established are, in my view, very

Speaker: NA
Text: much in the tradition of some of ideas argued by the well-known Yale University economist

Speaker: NA
Text: Robert Shiller, who a few years ago wrote a book called Finance and the Good Society. His

Speaker: NA
Text: argument, essentially, was that the reputation of finance as a sector has not been that good

Speaker: NA
Text: following the 2008 financial crisis; but that, in fact, on reflection, the role of the finance

Speaker: NA
Text: sector is of the first importance in delivering economic and social welfare. To quote from one

Speaker: NA
Text: particular book review which summarised the argument, the reviewer noted that Shiller:

Speaker: NA
Text: … makes a powerful case for recognizing that finance … is one of the most powerful tools we have

Speaker: NA
Text: for solving our common problems and increasing the general well-being.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the examples that Shiller gives is the importance of mortgages-the fact that through

Speaker: NA
Text: the invention of this financial instrument it becomes possible for most people to afford a

Speaker: NA
Text: home, even though very few of us are in a position to pay the full capital cost of a home when

Speaker: NA
Text: we first we want to buy. I would argue that, consistent with the notion that clever financial

Speaker: NA
Text: thinking can deliver important social benefits, the essence of this bill is to establish a fund

Speaker: NA
Text: which will be used to offer incentives to the states to recycle their assets. It recognises that the

Speaker: NA
Text: states-all of them-have significant assets on their balance sheets, many of which can be

Speaker: NA
Text: sold. At the same time, the states and, indeed, the nation face a very large task in funding all

Speaker: NA
Text: of the new infrastructure that is required. Therefore, if we can recycle the existing assets, if

Speaker: NA
Text: we can monetise those existing assets, and take the proceeds to fund the provision of new

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure assets there is a very significant social welfare benefit to follow as a

Speaker: NA
Text: consequence. The mechanism set out in this bill to achieve that public policy objective is to

Speaker: NA
Text: establish the Asset Recycling Fund, and this will be a dedicated investment vehicle with a

Speaker: NA
Text: focus on providing financial incentives to the states and territories to create new

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Asset Recycling Fund will be managed by the Future Fund Board of Guardians. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: important to note that this board of guardians has a proven track record in managing

Speaker: NA
Text: investment portfolios in the public interest. It has been responsible for the management of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Future Fund. In 2006, the balance in that fund stood at $64 billion and, as at 31 March this

Speaker: NA
Text: year, it stood at $97 billion. So it is a significant achievement in managing that particular

Speaker: NA
Text: fund, and that expertise is now to be deployed to manage the moneys that will make up the

Speaker: NA
Text: Asset Recycling Fund. The initial balance of this fund will be $5.9 billion and there will be

Speaker: NA
Text: further credits to come into the fund in the future. It will be used to help fund investment that

Speaker: NA
Text: expedites nationally significant infrastructure; it will also fund payments to local and territory

Speaker: NA
Text: governments under the Roads to Recovery program. This is a mechanism to unlock the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: balance sheets of the states to target investment in productive economic infrastructure. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent with and facilitates the delivery of the government's Infrastructure Growth Package

Speaker: NA
Text: announced in the 2014-15 budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Abbott government has come to power with strong commitments in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure, and this bill lays out a specific and effective public policy measure to give

Speaker: NA
Text: effect to the policy commitments that we have made. On this side of the House, we believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that delivering modern infrastructure is a crucial part of the government's Economic Action

Speaker: NA
Text: Strategy to boost economic growth and prosperity, increase productivity and create thousands

Speaker: NA
Text: of new jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Asset Recycling Fund will be seeded with $2.4 billion from the Building Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund and $3.5 billion from the Education Investment Fund. Over time, it is likely that there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be sources for additional funds to come into the Asset Recycling Fund-for example,

Speaker: NA
Text: should there be Commonwealth assets which are privatised. The consequence of the moneys

Speaker: NA
Text: being put into this fund is that they will then be available to be paid to state governments

Speaker: NA
Text: under incentive arrangements, which will in turn encourage the states to look for opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: to monetise existing assets and to take the proceeds from those assets and reinvest them in

Speaker: NA
Text: vitally needed infrastructure-infrastructure in road, in rail and in other areas. This can in turn

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver not only the economic efficiency and productivity benefits that I have spoken about

Speaker: NA
Text: and for which infrastructure is so important but also those vital social benefits, because people

Speaker: NA
Text: are required to spend less time in their car and so have more time left to spend with their

Speaker: NA
Text: family or doing other things of importance to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I conclude with the observation that the question of refreshing and renewing Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure is very much on the national public policy agenda. There is widespread

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement that our infrastructure is deficient and there is a backlog of projects which need to

Speaker: NA
Text: be commenced. The Abbott government is getting on with that work, and this bill establishes

Speaker: NA
Text: an additional public policy mechanism to underpin that work by establishing a significant

Speaker: NA
Text: fund which will allow moneys to flow to infrastructure priorities to improve productivity and

Speaker: NA
Text: generate economic growth. There are great economic and social benefits to be captured for

Speaker: NA
Text: our nation if we can find the best ways to fund and build the world-class infrastructure we

Speaker: NA
Text: need, and the mechanism set out in this bill is an important way of achieving that public

Speaker: NA
Text: policy objective.

Speaker: Ms RYAN
Text: Lalor-Opposition Whip) (18:58): I rise tonight to speak on the Asset

Speaker: NA
Text: Recycling Bill 2014 and related bill. Governments everywhere are exploring the possibilities

Speaker: NA
Text: that asset recycling may deliver. In a high-growth electorate such as mine and having met

Speaker: NA
Text: with the National Growth Areas Alliance this morning, I am acutely aware that the provision

Speaker: NA
Text: of infrastructure is vital.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the time of the previous Labor government, Lalor and many other growth corridor

Speaker: NA
Text: electorates did benefit from infrastructure investment. In Lalor, specifically, funding was

Speaker: NA
Text: provided through local councils for community centres, libraries and local road project There

Speaker: NA
Text: were also capital investments into TAFE and university. The rollout of the NBN commenced,

Speaker: NA
Text: and our local hospital received funds to expand facilities. All of these investments were much

Speaker: NA
Text: needed in our high-growth area. Locally, we benefited from major infrastructure investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The federal government contributed $3.2 billion for the regional rail link, set to increase rail

Speaker: NA
Text: access for both business and passengers-a project that will deliver economic benefits to

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria. This project, currently underway, is being delivered ahead of time and on budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those working on this project should be rightly proud of that achievement. And why is this

Speaker: NA
Text: project being delivered in this cost-effective and timely way? Because of Labor's initiatives

Speaker: NA
Text: during its term in government-that is why.

Speaker: NA
Text: When Labor came to power in 2007, it inherited an infrastructure mess; it was more than

Speaker: NA
Text: an infrastructure mess really-it was an infrastructure disaster. The current infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: minister was there during the Howard days, so he will not find it difficult to remember the

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Partnerships Programme rort scandals. We on this side well remember the millions

Speaker: NA
Text: of taxpayer dollars wasted on projects in regional areas-projects that had dubious merit. The

Speaker: NA
Text: word profligate has been thrown around this chamber much in recent days by those opposite;

Speaker: NA
Text: in error, I might say. But here we have a clear history. So what are some of the memories of

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition government's infrastructure disaster? Projects like the cheese factory in

Speaker: NA
Text: Wangaratta which was awarded $22,000 in government assistance-despite the fact that it

Speaker: NA
Text: had shut its doors. That one comes to mind, as does funding provided to an ethanol plant in

Speaker: NA
Text: Gunnedah: taxpayer funding was provided, but it actually produced no ethanol. The minister

Speaker: NA
Text: must also remember the $600,000 federal government grant given to struggling Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: company Beaudesert Rail-against the advice of corporate administrators, and in breach of

Speaker: NA
Text: the program's own criteria. These examples are not a ringing endorsement of the coalition's

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity to handle infrastructure. Back in 2005, the Business Council of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledged how cracked the Howard government's infrastructure funding system was, and

Speaker: NA
Text: called for a massive overhaul. As part of their Infrastructure Action Plan for Future

Speaker: NA
Text: Prosperity, the council reported:

Speaker: NA
Text: …that the current state of Australia's most fundamental infrastructure – supporting all elements of the

Speaker: NA
Text: transport network, energy and water supplies, and the basic facilities to support growing and spreading

Speaker: NA
Text: urban communities – is in urgent need of reform, repair and expansion.

Speaker: NA
Text: They went on:

Speaker: NA
Text: We are at the crossroads in terms of infrastructure development as a result of poor institutional

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements and policy choices. Changes are required to alleviate current capacity constraints, and

Speaker: NA
Text: provide additional capacity to support high growth in the years ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me repeat that, Deputy Speaker: 'as a result of poor institutional arrangements and policy

Speaker: NA
Text: choices'; 'changes are required'. This was after, or during, the years that the coalition were in

Speaker: NA
Text: charge of this country. And so, as is always the way, it was Labor who acted on the failures of

Speaker: NA
Text: that system. It was Labor who were determined to create an infrastructure funding system

Speaker: NA
Text: where government could make decisions based not on lobbying but on hard evidence about a

Speaker: NA
Text: project's worth; about a project's value to the community-and not on the basis of an electoral

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy. It was Labor who announced that, if elected to government, we would create a

Speaker: NA
Text: statutory body to create a balanced and strategic blueprint for future funding, and that is what

Speaker: NA
Text: we did with the Infrastructure Australia Act in 2008.

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure Australia was created to enact evidence based decision making; to deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: policy and regulatory matters; to drive reform on legal, tax, planning and infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: finance; to evaluate the business cases of projects and project financing options, including

Speaker: NA
Text: private-public partnerships; and to review the adequacy of Australia's infrastructure, identify

Speaker: NA
Text: the gaps, and prioritise the nation's projects. Its first task was to undertake a nationwide audit

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia's infrastructure, and then to form a priority list for the future. Only infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
