Text: projects which met a minimum rate of return-determined through rigorous cost-benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: analysis and review-were recommended. With Infrastructure Australia, Labor showed

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership by investing in nationally significant projects and by ensuring lasting reforms. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: us not forget that it was under a Labor government that infrastructure spending grew from

Speaker: NA
Text: $132 to $225 per Australian. It was under Labor that Australia rose to No. 2 in the OECD

Speaker: NA
Text: rankings by the scale of the investment made in fixed capital. And it was under Labor that the

Speaker: NA
Text: total annual investment in our nation's roads, railways, ports, energy generators, water supply

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities and telecommunication networks hit a record $58.5 billion in 2011-12, equivalent to

Speaker: NA
Text: 4 per cent of GDP. We on this side of the House invested, not to gain cheap political points

Speaker: NA
Text: but because, after years of inaction under the Howard government, it was what this country

Speaker: NA
Text: needed. Key to all of this was Infrastructure Australia, because their informed, evidence-

Speaker: NA
Text: based analysis and advice ensured that we were investing in the infrastructure that would

Speaker: NA
Text: drive national growth and productivity. But informed, evidence-based analysis is not what the

Speaker: NA
Text: current government is about.

Speaker: NA
Text: Along with some of my colleagues, I met this morning with representatives of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Growth Areas Alliance, an alliance of local councils that serve high-growth communities

Speaker: NA
Text: around Australia. This alliance, which understands infrastructure needs and which has put

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable time and effort into preparing reports for government, has received no feedback

Speaker: NA
Text: on its submissions. I repeat, this alliance has provided government with valuable information

Speaker: NA
Text: and it has received no feedback. What does this tell us about our current government? It tells

Speaker: NA
Text: us that the coalition government seems intent on making decisions that have no basis in well-

Speaker: NA
Text: developed planning, and that they are not intending to listen to groups from across this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. Take, for example, my home state of Victoria: in the recent federal budget, over $3

Speaker: NA
Text: billion was allocated for the second stage of the East West Link. One billion of this will flow

Speaker: NA
Text: into Victoria's coffers in just a couple of weeks. In a recent senate estimates hearing, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: revealed that this project has no business plan. You heard correctly-no business plan. The

Speaker: NA
Text: project has not been examined by Infrastructure Australia. It was also revealed that the

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated cost-benefit ratio was lower than the proposed upgrade for the Western Ring Road,

Speaker: NA
Text: a project that was not funded; indeed, a project to which some current funding is now being

Speaker: NA
Text: redirected. There are no detailed plans for the east-west project and no details about the land

Speaker: NA
Text: or houses that will need to be compulsorily acquired, and no information about the road's final

Speaker: NA
Text: alignment. There is no detail about where this tunnel will come up; no detail about when it

Speaker: NA
Text: will see the light of day. There are no details about whether the road will be tolled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The state government provides hollow words about the benefit to the people in the west of

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne, but those who live and work locally are having trouble making any kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: accurate analysis due to the lack of detail. This project is years away from being shovel-ready,

Speaker: NA
Text: but this federal government has seen fit to allocate $l billion to the Victorian government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Something about this does not feel right. The chat around town is that the federal government

Speaker: NA
Text: made these funds available due to its nonsensical rule about not funding rail infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The original Metro rail link, a project that was planned and researched over many years with a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong endorsement from Infrastructure Australia, has now been junked in favour of the

Speaker: NA
Text: current Metro light plan. Transport is a big issue in my electorate. In fact, Wyndham City

Speaker: NA
Text: Council is running a campaign to 'get Wyndham moving', because people in my electorate are

Speaker: NA
Text: commuting to work for two or more hours a day, whether it be by road or rail. To fund a

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: project that there is no detail for and to plainly ignore the Metro rail link project, which has

Speaker: NA
Text: been endorsed by experts, is a slap in the face for my community.

Speaker: NA
Text: So back to the asset recycling bill. Asset recycling can have merit in certain circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest that merit can be determined through careful and detailed planning and deep

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation with the community. This bill, however, does not seem to have those checks and

Speaker: NA
Text: balances at its core. This bill also has the potential to dilute the historically high level of

Speaker: NA
Text: federal commitment to infrastructure funding, a level achieved under Labor. At the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting between Joe Hockey and the state and territory Treasurers, it was reported that

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria left the meeting 'very disappointed'. The Victorian Treasurer, Michael O'Brien,

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out that this asset recycling plan has very little benefit for Victoria, as the state has

Speaker: NA
Text: very few assets left to sell. Victoria sold off many of its key assets during the Kennett years of

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1990s. Michael O'Brien indicated he was disappointed the state would receive no credit

Speaker: NA
Text: for the hard decisions of the past. Apparently, the federal Treasurer made it very clear he was

Speaker: NA
Text: not prepared to look backwards.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last year The Melbourne Review ran an article discussing the benefits of privatising the

Speaker: NA
Text: Port of Melbourne. It makes the case for asset recycling in a positive way, but it also provides

Speaker: NA
Text: this caveat:

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria's competitiveness and wealth are inextricably tied to the health of our infrastructure ... With

Speaker: NA
Text: considered investment in projects that are genuinely economically sound, the process of

Speaker: NA
Text: commercialising Victoria's public assets would enhance our state's growth immensely.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are three words that stand out in that statement: 'genuinely economically sound.' This

Speaker: NA
Text: government wants to be known for its infrastructure. Many a time we have heard the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister say that he will be the Prime Minister for infrastructure, as if saying it will make it

Speaker: NA
Text: happen. If that is so, and if this government wants to be remembered for successful

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure projects, then this government needs to heed advice such as that given out by

Speaker: NA
Text: The Melbourne Review last year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The asset recycling program appears to offer very little for Victoria. It appears that, as this

Speaker: NA
Text: government refuses to look backwards at the asset sales that have occurred in Victoria,

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria will miss out on infrastructure spending under this bill. I also have some very real

Speaker: NA
Text: doubts about the way this government is interacting with Infrastructure Australia, and whether

Speaker: NA
Text: they are taking into account the evidence-based information that they are being given in the

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions they are making. Nothing I have heard in this chamber gives me confidence that this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill will ensure good service and good infrastructure for Victoria, or good service or good

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure for growth corridors nationally. In particular, I have very little faith that this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: will deliver for my community in Lalor.

Speaker: Dr GILLESPIE
Text: Lyne) (19:12): I rise to talk about the Asset Recycling Fund Bill and the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequential amendments bill. The value of infrastructure and productivity to individuals,

Speaker: NA
Text: communities, cities, states and nations is the essence of this bill. Some people do not quite

Speaker: NA
Text: understand what asset recycling and unlocking the value of assets means, so I will explain that

Speaker: NA
Text: process. Infrastructure, whether it be road infrastructure, telecommunications, dams, ports,

Speaker: NA
Text: rail lines, hospitals, schools or utilities, delivers improvements in lifestyle, in amenity and in

Speaker: NA
Text: production. The better that infrastructure is, the better the productivity. In particular, transport

Speaker: NA
Text: links and telecommunication links need to be fast and efficient, because if they are not fast

Speaker: NA
Text: and efficient everything becomes more expensive. The old saying that 'time is money' really

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: does apply in this space. The longer it takes our producers to get products to market, the more

Speaker: NA
Text: costs increase, and our competition gets an advantage. The less competitive we are, the less

Speaker: NA
Text: income there is for our nation and citizens. Poor infrastructure that is not efficient means more

Speaker: NA
Text: expense, so our products become more expensive, which in turn means our competitors get an

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage. That is really important, because one in five jobs comes from trade internationally.

Speaker: NA
Text: Increasing our productivity means that people will end up paying less for goods and services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Poor productivity means goods and services become more expensive, so the cost of living

Speaker: NA
Text: goes up. Productivity gains bring the cost of living down. People are not connecting

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity gains with cost of living, but that is what we as a nation have to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second thing that this asset recycling addresses is unlocking value. Unlocking value

Speaker: NA
Text: means realising the value of one's asset. The states have many assets that hold value for them,

Speaker: NA
Text: but that value is not realised in a financial sense. In the early years of our Federation, and

Speaker: NA
Text: subsequently, the world economy and the Australian economy were quite different to what

Speaker: NA
Text: they are now. Many initiatives that we had-such as establishing major utilities and energy

Speaker: NA
Text: systems, transport bodies such as Qantas, banks such as the Commonwealth Bank and the

Speaker: NA
Text: state banks and things such as the old GPO, which became Telecom Australia-were

Speaker: NA
Text: bankrolled and run by governments. But both state and federal governments have vacated that

Speaker: NA
Text: space to a degree already. Most of these exits have been spectacular successes. You only have

Speaker: NA
Text: to look at what has happened to the Commonwealth Bank since it was sold off by the nation

Speaker: NA
Text: to see that. You only need to look at how Telstra has grown over the years since it was sold

Speaker: NA
Text: off to see that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Initially, the scope, extent and capital required government involvement, but now we have

Speaker: NA
Text: a different world. We have huge amounts of capital available in this country both in private

Speaker: NA
Text: banks and in super funds that private enterprise could marshal. If the value of these assets

Speaker: NA
Text: were realised enormous amounts of infrastructure could result. Private enterprise now has the

Speaker: NA
Text: capability and the finances to run energy systems. It has demonstrated that time and time

Speaker: NA
Text: again. Previous governments have used the realisation of things such as Telstra and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank to pay off huge national debts. You only have to look at the debt that

Speaker: NA
Text: was left behind by the Keating government to see that. The asset sales-Qantas, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank and Telstra-delivered most of the reduction in debt. Look at what

Speaker: NA
Text: happened with the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. Private enterprise used that

Speaker: NA
Text: intellectual capital and expanded it around the world. We now have a world leader in that as

Speaker: NA
Text: well.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is why our Asset Recycling Fund has been created. It has been created to facilitate

Speaker: NA
Text: financial incentives for the states and territories to sell or lease their existing assets so that

Speaker: NA
Text: they can realise a financial windfall and reinvest that in their own new infrastructure. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Asset Recycling Fund will be created by rolling the funds from the Education Investment

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund, the proceeds of the Building Australia Fund and the proceeds from the sale of other

Speaker: NA
Text: assets, such as Medibank Private, into this fund. The fund will be administered by the

Speaker: NA
Text: managers of the current Future Fund. We should have a lot of confidence because when that

Speaker: NA
Text: was created it was at about $60 billion and now it is worth over $94 billion. So they do a good

Speaker: NA
Text: job at it. National partnership agreements, both in asset recycling and infrastructure, will

Speaker: NA
Text: guide this through the COAG process.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: How does this initiative work? What is its value to the states? The value is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth passes to the states from this fund an extra 15 per cent on the value of their

Speaker: NA
Text: realised asset. So it is an incentive program for them to do that, but it is not just done willy-

Speaker: NA
Text: nilly. The asset recycling initiatives must demonstrate a clear net positive benefit to the states

Speaker: NA
Text: and the nation and enhance long-term productivity and the productive capacity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. Also, where possible, the private sector should be involved to leverage the public

Speaker: NA
Text: sector money that is going into the project and add it to private capital as well. This

Speaker: NA
Text: leveraging of $50 billion of federal capital, added to state capital, together with private capital

Speaker: NA
Text: investment should support funds of up to $125 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is for solid state infrastructure. It is not the back-of-the-poster infrastructure that is

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered willy-nilly, such as the pink batts fiasco or the overpriced school halls fiasco where

Speaker: NA
Text: instead of the Keynesian economic multiplier effect we had an economic dividing effect.

Speaker: NA
Text: Good, solid taxpayer money went into overpriced and very ineffective school halls. It was the

Speaker: NA
Text: odd school infrastructure project that delivered value for money. These projects that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraging the states to be involved in will deliver long-term, solid infrastructure. There will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be any 'cash for clunkers' in this scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: We will have real, lasting infrastructure, such as the Pacific Highway duplication, which

Speaker: NA
Text: will start soon in the Lyne electorate and head further north to the Queensland border. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to deliver, because all of the products that we ship in and out of the Lyne electorate will

Speaker: NA
Text: be coming and going on efficient freeways. It is going to reduce travel times, making

Speaker: NA
Text: transport costs cheaper. It is going to bring more tourists into the Lyne electorate. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: this huge, burgeoning south-east Queensland market of potential tourists who will come

Speaker: NA
Text: further south if they are not caught in traffic jams and on single-lane, winding and dangerous

Speaker: NA
Text: highways. You can see what has happened with the freeway coming through the Tweed down

Speaker: NA
Text: to Ballina and Byron Bay; it has opened up exponentially to the south-east Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: market. We want it to keep coming down to Coffs Harbour and then down to Port Macquarie.

Speaker: NA
Text: Already the tourism market in our area has changed because of the duplication south of the

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate from Sydney. We now have not only week-long tourists, we also have people who

Speaker: NA
Text: come for three days or two days because it is within a threeor four-hour zone of Sydney, or

Speaker: NA
Text: even closer if you are coming up from Newcastle or the Central Coast.

Speaker: NA
Text: As for other solid infrastructure that will be delivered out of this fund, we have the Roads

Speaker: NA
Text: to Recovery funding. In the Lyne electorate we have a lot of very poorly maintained roads

Speaker: NA
Text: which certainly can do with the Roads to Recovery funds that they are going to get out of this

Speaker: NA
Text: process. $16 million of federal money-up to $17½ million if you include the GST-is

Speaker: NA
Text: coming out of this to fund repairs to the Bucketts Way. If you add the Thunderbolts Way,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is another linkage into the Gloucester Valley, there is another $3½ million, so that is

Speaker: NA
Text: about $20 million of road infrastructure delivered locally into areas in the Lyne electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: These will not be like the school halls and the pink batts infrastructure that disappeared into

Speaker: NA
Text: the ether. This will be lasting infrastructure which will deliver long overdue benefits in the

Speaker: NA
Text: local economy as well as the state-to-state commerce that I have mentioned with the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway. So I commend this bill to the parliament because of all the potential benefits that

Speaker: NA
Text: will flow from asset recycling. The state government in New South Wales will be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver new schools and new hospitals because of the benefit they will gain from recycling the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: value of the money that they realise out of this asset recycling process. I commend the bill to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House.

Speaker: Dr LEIGH
Text: Fraser) (19:24): The Harvard philosopher Michael Sandel once said that he

Speaker: NA
Text: was for a market economy but not for a market society. I think that is a good way of

Speaker: NA
Text: characterising the differences between the two sides of the House on the question of

Speaker: NA
Text: privatisation. The perspective of the Liberal and National parties has always been a

Speaker: NA
Text: theological belief in the value of privatisation. Those on that side of the House believe in a

Speaker: NA
Text: market society. They believe that inherently privatisation is always good.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those of us on this side of the House take a much more pragmatic view to privatisation. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was the Hawke government that privatised Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank, but it has

Speaker: NA
Text: also been Labor which has stood up against bad privatisations. We have to admit in a debate

Speaker: NA
Text: like this that there is such a thing as a bad privatisation. Privatisation of the British rail

Speaker: NA
Text: network is a classic example, a privatisation which ended up with consumers bearing higher

Speaker: NA
Text: prices and getting inferior services. So when we are considering privatisations, it must be on a

Speaker: NA
Text: case-by-case basis. Yes, we should look at the revenue that flows from privatisation but we

Speaker: NA
Text: also need to consider the situation of the asset. Is it a natural monopoly? Is it the kind of thing

Speaker: NA
Text: where there is going to be contestability in the market? Is the asset itself a natural role for

Speaker: NA
Text: government or is it something where we might expect the private sector to get more

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiencies? These are the questions that this side of the House asks on an issue like

Speaker: NA
Text: privatisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the heart of this Asset Recycling Fund Bill is the notion that an incentive payment of

Speaker: NA
Text: around 15 per cent of the value of the asset multiplied by the share of that sale price that is

Speaker: NA
Text: invested by this state into certain other assets should be returned to the state as an incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: payment. But as a number of University of Queensland economists, Flavio Menezes and John

Speaker: NA
Text: Quiggin chief among them, have highlighted, it is quite unclear whether this incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: payment is of appropriate size. One of the things it depends on is whether companies are in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact going to pay company tax revenue which is of that scale.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me step back for a moment. The notion of paying an incentive payment has at its heart

Speaker: NA
Text: the principle that a government entity does not pay company tax. Once the asset is sold to

Speaker: NA
Text: private investors, they begin to pay company tax. The Commonwealth gets company tax and

Speaker: NA
Text: returns a portion of that to the state. But that argument only holds if the company actually

Speaker: NA
Text: pays a reasonable rate of tax. If it has very large deductions, and we have seen some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: potential loopholes in the company tax system arising in the debate over the base erosion and

Speaker: NA
Text: profit shifting, then it is not going to be the case that the Commonwealth gain in company tax

Speaker: NA
Text: is 15 per cent of the sale price of the asset. We need to be very clear that this is only a very

Speaker: NA
Text: small share of what states have had ripped away from them by this Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: government-$80 billion ripped out of schools and hospitals as a result of this latest budget-

Speaker: NA
Text: and it will be a very small share of that which states see returned to them in the form of this

Speaker: NA
Text: incentive payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The idea of an incentive payment is not new. It has been floating around in the ether of

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury and Finance for nigh on two decades just waiting for a buyer. The idea found a

Speaker: NA
Text: gullible buyer in the form of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer who, when they walked

Speaker: NA
Text: into office, bought an idea which had been considered and rejected by the Keating

Speaker: NA
Text: government, the Howard government, the Rudd government and the Gillard government. So

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: you cannot help thinking that the Abbott government is somewhere in the position of

Speaker: NA
Text: someone who finds themselves having inadvertently purchased the Sydney Harbour Bridge.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have bought an idea which so many others had rejected. And the reason they have

Speaker: NA
Text: bought this idea goes back to that Michael Sandel distinction between a market economy and

Speaker: NA
Text: a market society.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you believe in a market society, if you believe that the private sector always does things

Speaker: NA
Text: better than the public sector, then invariably you are going to be tempted to pay states to

Speaker: NA
Text: privatise. But if you take a more pragmatic approach to privatisations, as we on this side of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House do, then I think you are much more likely to be sceptical of privatisations, to want

Speaker: NA
Text: to see the business case for a privatisation, to take the view that if it does not stack up on its

Speaker: NA
Text: own merits then the federal government should not be paying the states to privatise an asset

Speaker: NA
Text: that they would not otherwise have privatised.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate interrupted.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. BC Scott) (19:30): Order! I propose the question:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tertiary Education

Speaker: Ms VAMVAKINOU
Text: Calwell) (19:30): I rise to emphasise the importance of investing

Speaker: NA
Text: properly in universities and tertiary education and ensuring that access to higher education is

Speaker: NA
Text: determined by ability and not family income. I do so because it is one of my key

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments as a Labor member of parliament. I do so because I have had an overwhelming

Speaker: NA
Text: number of pleas to defend and extend our support for universities from my constituents. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: so because access to quality higher education is one of the most fundamental requirements for

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring equality of opportunity and fulfilment of personal potential. And I do so because it is

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the most fundamental foundations for a progressive, dynamic and growing economy

Speaker: NA
Text: and nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sadly, this government's first budget ignores all these factors and instead marks the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: fair and affordable higher education, and it is a betrayal of Australian students and their

Speaker: NA
Text: families. This budget will mean spiralling university fees for young people and demonstrates

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government has broken its promise not to increase fees or to cut funding to higher

Speaker: NA
Text: education. Not only has university funding been cut but student debt will skyrocket. Women

Speaker: NA
Text: and students from lower-income families, as the people of my electorate understand all too

Speaker: NA
Text: well, will be the hardest hit as they are made to shoulder a larger burden of university costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: These measures will be disastrous for our nation as a whole but they will cause a

Speaker: NA
Text: disproportionate amount of pain and disadvantage in my electorate in particular. In an area

Speaker: NA
Text: where families struggle to cover the costs of everyday life, where low-skilled jobs are

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming ever harder to find and keep-in part because of this government's contempt for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian manufacturing sector-affordable access to tertiary education is a vital key to the

Speaker: NA
Text: future for so many young people. It is not surprising, therefore, that I have been overwhelmed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the number of calls, messages and letters I have received from my constituents, anxious

Speaker: NA
Text: about the future of tertiary education under this government. Our investment as a nation in

Speaker: NA
Text: higher education is not only vital as a means of giving young people, regardless of

Speaker: NA
Text: background, the tools for productive, creative and rewarding careers but also vital to our

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: future as a clever, competitive and productive nation. Our health as an economy and as a just

Speaker: NA
Text: society depends on the quality of our knowledge, our research and our innovation, much of

Speaker: NA
Text: which is developed in universities, research centres and other higher institutions.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have heard a great deal about 'lifters and leaners' from this government, about the end

Speaker: NA
Text: to the age of entitlement and other such cliches to justify the withdrawal of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth from the bulk of its responsibility to build and maintain a fair, progressive

Speaker: NA
Text: and inclusive society. It has been argued that the burden of spending cuts must be fairly

Speaker: NA
Text: shared across the community. But we need to be careful that a sector as vital to this nation as

Speaker: NA
Text: tertiary education and research is not made to shoulder an unfair burden in this regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: Universities are already struggling to provide teaching and support. It is inevitable that further

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts will translate into staff reductions, larger class sizes, axing of subjects and whole courses,

Speaker: NA
Text: and, of course, cutting back on research.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the previous Labor government, despite the pressures and debates about adequate

Speaker: NA
Text: funding models, we were at least clear in our support for university education. Greatly

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing the number of Commonwealth supported places and encouraging greater

Speaker: NA
Text: participation in tertiary education by students from disadvantaged backgrounds has always

Speaker: NA
Text: been central to the Labor Party. If the parliament agrees to the current government's proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to HECS fees and student support, we will seriously undermine the ability of students

Speaker: NA
Text: from disadvantaged communities to attend university.

Speaker: NA
Text: My electorate of Calwell, one of the most disadvantaged in the country, also has one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: lowest rates of tertiary education participation. The funding cuts to universities and changes to

Speaker: NA
Text: HECS would obviously exacerbate this worrying trend and further entrench generational

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantage. I speak for a great many Australians in my electorate and elsewhere in saying

Speaker: NA
Text: that proper levels of investment in our greatly valued tertiary institutions are imperative if we

Speaker: NA
Text: are to be a fair, competitive and clever country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Durack Electorate: Wiluna

Speaker: Ms PRICE
Text: Durack) (19:35): I spent a very cold night on the edge of the desert last week

Speaker: NA
Text: when I met with various stakeholders and residents in one of Western Australia's most remote

Speaker: NA
Text: towns, Wiluna-and may I say I had the best sleep I had had in 18 months. Wiluna was once

Speaker: NA
Text: a thriving regional hub and is where my mother spent her childhood. Sadly, times have

Speaker: NA
Text: changed, and Wiluna is often now forgotten, particularly by government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Wiluna is located 1,200 kilometres from Perth. Its closest regional centre is Kalgoorlie,

Speaker: NA
Text: some 500 kilometres away. When you look up the word 'isolated' in the Australian dictionary,

Speaker: NA
Text: the town of Wiluna would best meet its description. According to 2011 census data, 1,150

Speaker: NA
Text: people live in the town. However, this data is largely skewed due to a large proportion of fly-

Speaker: NA
Text: in fly-out miners and medical staff and a general underrepresentation of Aboriginal peoples in

Speaker: NA
Text: official records. It is a town often characterised by chronic homelessness, poor health and

Speaker: NA
Text: wellbeing, alcoholism, violence, poverty and poor education outcomes. However, despite the

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges this town faces daily, I was humbled by the residents' tenacity and their desire not

Speaker: NA
Text: only to improve the town but to see it thrive.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although Wiluna is listed as 'very remote' on the Accessibility/Remoteness Index for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, the town has largely been forgotten in its delivery of key services, such as housing,

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare and road infrastructure. Its isolation means that the town has very little access to

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: goods and services or opportunities for social interaction. Meekatharra is often referred to as

Speaker: NA
Text: its sister town, despite being about 180 kilometres away on the Goldfields Highway. The

Speaker: NA
Text: connection between these two towns is vital, particularly for the provision of medical

Speaker: NA
Text: services, with the Meekatharra hospital delivering key emergency and outpatient care in the

Speaker: NA
Text: region.

Speaker: NA
Text: For all other medical services Wiluna relies on FIFO doctors and other medical

Speaker: NA
Text: professionals at the Ngangganawili Aboriginal Health Service Community. NAHS plays a

Speaker: NA
Text: very important role in providing comprehensive primary health care services to Wiluna and

Speaker: NA
Text: surrounding areas, but the importance of having access to hospital services, particularly in a

Speaker: NA
Text: town that has prevailing health concerns, cannot be taken lightly. It is also important to note

Speaker: NA
Text: that NAHS is the sole provider of medical services to the town, and aids both Indigenous and

Speaker: NA
Text: non-Indigenous people equally, making it a very unique organisation, being funded equally by

Speaker: NA
Text: the state and federal governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Wiluna is situated on the edge of the desert at the gateway to the Canning Stock Route and

Speaker: NA
Text: Gunbarrel Highway. It should be a key tourism access point. However, due to the prevalence

Speaker: NA
Text: of very dangerous road conditions, Wiluna is often bypassed by tourists, further reducing its

Speaker: NA
Text: future economic viability. In particular, the upgrading of the Goldfields Highway between

Speaker: NA
Text: Wiluna and Meekatharra is vital for the town's future. It is currently the only section of the

Speaker: NA
Text: state highway that is largely unsealed, creating adverse impacts on safety due to dust and road

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions, on access to the town, and on its amenity and transport efficiency. It has seen

Speaker: NA
Text: many fatalities and numerous accidents.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Goldfields Highway is considered a key strategic freight, tourist and inter-town route,

Speaker: NA
Text: yet little has been done to seal this section of road, which floods in minor weather conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: and blocks all access to the town. The need to upgrade the road between Wiluna and

Speaker: NA
Text: Meekatharra has been accepted by the Western Australian state government for well over a

Speaker: NA
Text: decade, with $70 million promised to seal the road in 1998. Sadly, this never eventuated. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 2012, $20 million was however dedicated by the state government and the main roads

Speaker: NA
Text: department for the construction and sealing of passing lanes and floodways, but this was only

Speaker: NA
Text: for very small sections.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having an entire town cut off from medical services is simply not acceptable in today's

Speaker: NA
Text: society. Medicines are often transported from Meekatharra via mail using this unreliable and

Speaker: NA
Text: unsafe transport route. I will be pushing for my state and federal government colleagues to

Speaker: NA
Text: make this road a priority, by ensuring Wiluna's collaborative voice is heard.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thanks to NAHS CEO Richard Whittington, Shire of Wiluna CEO Andrea Nunan,

Speaker: NA
Text: President Jim Quadrio, Gillian and Malcolm Marchant from the Gunbarrel Laager Traveller's

Speaker: NA
Text: Rest and Art Gallery Manager Heather Charlton, together with Bernie Weller and Greg and

Speaker: NA
Text: Fran Weller, for helping me to organise this trip. I thank them for their hospitality.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Ms OWENS
Text: Parramatta) (19:40): It is not just the unfairness of the budget that hangs

Speaker: NA
Text: around the neck of the government, nor the canyon between what they promised prior to the

Speaker: NA
Text: election and what they delivered. It is also that when you try to work out why they have been

Speaker: NA
Text: so savage in cuts to the vulnerable, yet so generous in other areas, it is almost impossible to

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: see any reason. It is the contradictions in this budget as well as the unfairness and dishonesty

Speaker: NA
Text: that cause such outrage.

Speaker: NA
Text: They say they are concerned about the number of people who will be on the pension in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2050, but they delay the very increases in super that would reduce reliance on the pension,

Speaker: NA
Text: resulting in more people needing the pension. Then they reduce indexation of the pension

Speaker: NA
Text: itself. They say they are concerned about health care costs, but rather than try to keep people

Speaker: NA
Text: healthy and out of the medical system, they cut funding to preventative health, making it more

Speaker: NA
Text: likely that people will need to see a doctor, and then when they do they slug them with a GP

Speaker: NA
Text: tax. If someone delays visiting a doctor as a result of the GP tax and gets more sick down the

Speaker: NA
Text: track, they have cut funding to hospitals.

Speaker: NA
Text: They say they are building the infrastructure of the 21st century, yet they have walked

Speaker: NA
Text: away from a high-quality NBN and spend their time re-announcing road projects that were

Speaker: NA
Text: funded or even begun before they were in government. They have cut all funding to urban rail

Speaker: NA
Text: projects, so if you live in the city you are more likely to have to drive, and when you do, they

Speaker: NA
Text: charge you more for the petrol.

Speaker: NA
Text: They say they want young people to work, yet they have cut the youth programs that help

Speaker: NA
Text: get vulnerable young people back into school or work. Then, when they cannot get back on

Speaker: NA
Text: track, they slug them with a six-month delay for the dole. They removed the cap on fees so

Speaker: NA
Text: that universities can charge whatever they like, supposedly so that there will be more places,

Speaker: NA
Text: but in doing so they put the cost out of reach for many people-more places, but less

Speaker: NA
Text: affordable.

Speaker: NA
Text: They say they are about getting women into work, and they introduce an expensive paid

Speaker: NA
Text: parental leave scheme, but at the same time they reduce assistance for child care for the low-

Speaker: NA
Text: and middle-income families. They increase support for time off, but effectively reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: support for returning to work after parental leave.

Speaker: NA
Text: They say they are open for business and they say they are about growth, but they

Speaker: NA
Text: downgrade the growth figures, trash-talk the economy and cut the very things that make us

Speaker: NA
Text: grow, including support for commercialisation, innovation, science and R&D.

Speaker: NA
Text: They say they want to reduce debt, yet they happily increase family debt through student

Speaker: NA
Text: loans and brag about giving trade support loans to 16-year-olds who are still in school.

Speaker: NA
Text: Apparently, government debt is bad but all other debt is good.

Speaker: NA
Text: They say they are about small government, yet they abolish the bodies that bring state and

Speaker: NA
Text: federal responsibilities together and thus push the tasks back to be duplicated by eight

Speaker: NA
Text: governments. They make federal government smaller by making state and territory

Speaker: NA
Text: governments bigger. Less cost for them, more for everybody else.

Speaker: NA
Text: They say that we all have to do the heavy lifting, but poorer families carry the biggest

Speaker: NA
Text: burden and could lose up to 15 per cent of their disposable income in four years time. They

Speaker: NA
Text: say they are about bringing the budget back under control, yet in question time in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: sitting week even the Treasurer acknowledged that the fiscal consolidation achieved in his

Speaker: NA
Text: first budget is less than that of previous Labor governments-a mere 1.1 per cent of GDP

Speaker: NA
Text: over three years-even compared with his own massaged MYEFO. Relative to what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Immigration and Border Protection confirmed were the last independent

Speaker: NA
Text: projections in PEFO, the deficit is actually bigger over the forward estimates, not smaller.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: They say they are about reducing debt, yet remarkably the budget fails to arrest the rise in

Speaker: NA
Text: net government debt, which is forecast to be higher as a share of GDP in 2017-18 than it is

Speaker: NA
Text: today. They say the budget had to be repaired, yet as a proportion of GDP they are a bigger

Speaker: NA
Text: spending government than Labor was in its previous three years. The spending of 24.6 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of GDP averaged over the last three years of Labor will rise to an average of 24.9 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent over the forward estimates and in 2017-18 will still be 24.8 per cent, which is higher than

Speaker: NA
Text: that of the last Labor government.

Speaker: NA
Text: They say all the pain is about fiscal consolidation, but their own figures show it is fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: expansion, not consolidation. They say they are about reducing taxes, yet the tax-to-GDP ratio

Speaker: NA
Text: will rise from 21.4 per cent in the last full year of Labor to 23.2 per cent over the forward

Speaker: NA
Text: estimates, making them a higher taxing government than any Labor government back to 1970.

Speaker: NA
Text: They say it is tough love, but there is certainly no love-and, while it is tough on the

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable and on lowand middle-income earners, they have made no discernible dent in the

Speaker: NA
Text: bottom line. Tough love, but for what outcome? It is a budget of extraordinary contradictions.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a budget of pain for no purpose. It is very much all pain and no gain.

Speaker: NA
Text: Edith Cowan University

Speaker: Mr GOODENOUGH
Text: Moore) (19:45): With 24,000 students, Edith Cowan University is

Speaker: NA
Text: the cornerstone of the Joondalup Learning Precinct-a leader in the fields of research,

Speaker: NA
Text: innovation and enterprise initiatives. I acknowledge the exemplary work of Professor

Speaker: NA
Text: Margaret Jones, Director of the Office of Research and Innovation, and Neil Butler,

Speaker: NA
Text: Community Partnerships Adviser, in promoting three leading research institutes based on

Speaker: NA
Text: campus.

Speaker: NA
Text: ECU's Security Research Institute is one of the leading cybersecurity and digital forensic

Speaker: NA
Text: groups in the world, recognised for its expertise in human, physical and aviation security. The

Speaker: NA
Text: institute consistently delivers quality outcomes in computer and digital forensics, network and

Speaker: NA
Text: wireless security, information warfare, physical security and risk management. The institute

Speaker: NA
Text: was recognised in 2009 by the Australian Computer Society as a centre of expertise in

Speaker: NA
Text: security. The group's other achievements include a digital forensics tool developed with the

Speaker: NA
Text: WA Police to assist with cybercrime, preliminary crime scene investigation, disaster victim

Speaker: NA
Text: identification and evidence tracking.

Speaker: NA
Text: Established in 2003, the university's Electron Science Research Institute has grown into a

Speaker: NA
Text: world leader in fundamental and applied research in nanophotonics and materials science.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rapidly establishing a reputation for excellence in new functional materials, optoelectronics

Speaker: NA
Text: and microfabrication research, the institute has worked with industry to develop a suite of

Speaker: NA
Text: novel prototypes, including a multilaser optoelectronic plant identification sensor engine for

Speaker: NA
Text: the agri-bio industry; magneto-optic thin films of world record visible range performance; an

Speaker: NA
Text: energy-producing transparent glazing system; and, most notably, 10 gigabit per second chip-

Speaker: NA
Text: to-chip optical interconnects, which earned the institute's director, Kamal Alameh, the 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: WA Inventor of the Year award.

Speaker: NA
Text: Edith Cowan University's Health and Wellness Institute houses an innovative

Speaker: NA
Text: multidisciplinary research team in exercise medicine dedicated to investigating the extent to

Speaker: NA
Text: which exercise can be employed in cancer management to materially improve patient

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes. The group's unique convergence of clinical patient care, exercise oncology and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: innovation in health interventions has underpinned their achievements in cancer research.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most notably, their multifaceted research program has been the direct result of work in

Speaker: NA
Text: prostate cancer, enabling direct translation of their research findings into practical outcomes

Speaker: NA
Text: for patient benefit and the design and implementation of clinical and community based cancer

Speaker: NA
Text: survivorship programs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Research is supported by a high level of collaboration between cancer specialists with

Speaker: NA
Text: distinguished international reputations in the fields of clinical exercise science, radiation

Speaker: NA
Text: oncology, urology and molecular biology. Collaborative partnerships with leading clinicians

Speaker: NA
Text: at several major metropolitan hospitals and universities, nationally and internationally, have

Speaker: NA
Text: expanded the pool of multidisciplinary expertise. During the past five years the institute has

Speaker: NA
Text: recorded over 150,000 patient contacts. Ongoing research will further support the community,

Speaker: NA
Text: with the institute examining the role of exercise in various areas, such as men receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: therapy for prostate cancer; neoadjuvant chemoradiation in patients with rectal cancer, breast

Speaker: NA
Text: cancer and related lymphoedema; cancer patients with advanced bone metastatic disease;

Speaker: NA
Text: patients with lung cancer and mesothelioma; and depression in later life.

Speaker: NA
Text: In summary, continued support, recognition and investment by the federal government will

Speaker: NA
Text: allow these exciting fields of research and innovation to flourish, creating a wide array of

Speaker: NA
Text: career pathways and providing the highly skilled and educated workforce required to build a

Speaker: NA
Text: stronger economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Autism

Speaker: Ms CHESTERS
Text: Bendigo) (19:49): Tonight I share with the House a desperate plea for

Speaker: NA
Text: change from my community. Parents at Bendigo schools are calling for increased funding to

Speaker: NA
Text: help deal with the growing number of students with autism going through the mainstream

Speaker: NA
Text: schooling system.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will share with you a couple of local stories. A mother of a 12-year-old boy on the

Speaker: NA
Text: spectrum said that not enough is being done to cater for students with autism in our schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: She said that her family has been through hell and back, fighting the education system to get

Speaker: NA
Text: the appropriate strategies in place so her son can cope with school. She does not blame the

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers but rather a lack of understanding about autism. She says that she knows her son can

Speaker: NA
Text: misbehave and she is not saying that he is easy to deal with. But what he is going through, as

Speaker: NA
Text: a young man, is just heartbreaking-and our system should be there to support him. Along the

Speaker: NA
Text: way, Michelle has been told her expectations for her son are too high. But, she says:

Speaker: NA
Text: To me this is ridiculous, because I have met police officers and solicitors with autism and, if they can

Speaker: NA
Text: do it, it just proves that, with the right education balance, with funding within our system, anything is

Speaker: NA
Text: possible for these children.

Speaker: NA
Text: And Michelle is right.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many schools in my electorate have spoken out about not only the challenges but the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits associated with having children with special needs in mainstream schooling.

Speaker: NA
Text: Classroom aids, further special needs training for teachers and individual learning plans are

Speaker: NA
Text: just some of the areas that they say need extra funding to help students with autism in

Speaker: NA
Text: Bendigo. Most schools admit that a lack of government funding is putting a strain on their

Speaker: NA
Text: school and on their school budget-and they are right.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Camp Hill Primary School Assistant Principal, Chris Baker, said that whilst there are

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges, children with autism are also helping to foster a greater understanding and

Speaker: NA
Text: acceptance amongst the students. He said it can be really positive to have students, but he also

Speaker: NA
Text: said that they are lucky enough to have an autism coach funded by the education system. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is the problem. Schools should not have to be lucky to get the resources they need to support

Speaker: NA
Text: the students. St Joseph's Primary School Principal, Nick Taggart, agrees that funding is

Speaker: NA
Text: creating problems but he said his school is doing what it can to ensure that everybody's needs

Speaker: NA
Text: are met. Nick is right. Funding continues to be a challenge at these schools. Every school

Speaker: NA
Text: council, every principal, I met with has said there is a growing funding crisis in their budget

Speaker: NA
Text: to help students with autism in their school community.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have heard stories of students being locked up in principals' offices. I have heard stories

Speaker: NA
Text: of students being restrained because they have had a meltdown in the classroom. I have heard

Speaker: NA
Text: stories of students being sent home after two hours of schooling, and students being left at

Speaker: NA
Text: home and not being able to access main stream schooling, because they simply cannot find a

Speaker: NA
Text: school that will accept their child who has autism.

Speaker: NA
Text: This may be considered the pointy end of a system that is struggling. It is becoming an

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing issue, with parents speaking to me in my office. Families with older children on the

Speaker: NA
Text: spectrum are finding that waiting lists are growing and that life is becoming increasingly hard

Speaker: NA
Text: for their children. Further, specific funding required for students with autism is tightening,

Speaker: NA
Text: meaning fewer students are benefiting. Quite often, if children are not diagnosed early

Speaker: NA
Text: enough, they miss out on a package and then packages for older children are fewer and fewer.

Speaker: NA
Text: With five to 10 students with autism in most public and Catholic schools in the Bendigo

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, it reminds all of us of why we need Gonski and why the election promises broken

Speaker: NA
Text: on budget night-the trashing of Gonski-has really hurt the schools in Bendigo.

Speaker: NA
Text: Students with disabilities were forgotten on budget night. The government has broken its

Speaker: NA
Text: promise to students with a disability to deliver the Gonski loading for 2015. The budget failed

Speaker: NA
Text: to outline any new funding for students with a disability. It is not fair that these students, their

Speaker: NA
Text: families and schools, in Bendigo, go without. The community is fighting back, and I will fight

Speaker: NA
Text: with them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign Policy

Speaker: Dr HENDY
Text: Eden-Monaro) (19:55): I am rising today to make brief comments on some

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign policy issues. This week the Prime Minister returned from what I regard as a highly

Speaker: NA
Text: successful overseas trip, involving visits to Indonesia, Europe, Canada and the United States.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first duty of any Australian government is to secure its borders and that means

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring strong defence capabilities and maintaining strong, constructive and stable

Speaker: NA
Text: international relations. The trip began with a visit to Batam Island to meet the Indonesian

Speaker: NA
Text: president, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono. The last government left Australia with a legacy of

Speaker: NA
Text: distrust vis-a-vis our relationship with Indonesia. The live-cattle export-ban fiasco was the

Speaker: NA
Text: icon issue. However, there were other problems as well and the Prime Minister and Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister have had to do a lot of fence mending so that our relationship with our near

Speaker: NA
Text: neighbour can get back onto an even keel. That was done in spades at this recent meeting, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister has gone a long way to getting it back on track.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: From that series of meetings, the Prime Minister travelled to Europe to participate in the

Speaker: NA
Text: anniversary celebrations for the D-day landings of 6 June 1944. Some 2,500 Australians,

Speaker: NA
Text: mostly airmen, participated in that watershed event and 18 paid the ultimate sacrifice. The

Speaker: NA
Text: commemoration of the allies' triumph on D-day is also a significant part of Australia's history

Speaker: NA
Text: and the part we played in defeating Nazi and other fascist aggressors in the Second World

Speaker: NA
Text: War.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister also took the opportunity to visit and pay respects at the grave sites

Speaker: NA
Text: related to the terrible battles of the Somme and the last days of World War I near Villers-

Speaker: NA
Text: Bretonneux. A number of years ago I also visited Villers-Bretonneux and attended the

Speaker: NA
Text: magnificent but tremendously sad Australian war memorial, near the town. While in France,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister was able to have important meetings with the President of France,

Speaker: NA
Text: Francois Hollande; the Chancellor of Germany, Angela Merkel; and the Prime Minister of

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Britain, David Cameron. They are the three principal leaders of the European Union

Speaker: NA
Text: which, taken as a whole, is our biggest trading partner and the cultural beacon for the

Speaker: NA
Text: overwhelming majority of the Australian population.

Speaker: NA
Text: From there, the Prime Minister had very warm and constructive meetings in Canada with

Speaker: NA
Text: its Prime Minister, Stephen Harper. Amongst other things, Prime Minister Harper praised the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian government's policy of abolishing the carbon tax. In the United States the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's trip was a triumph. Not only did he have meetings with President Obama and other

Speaker: NA
Text: senior figures in the administration-such as Treasury secretary, Jacob Lew, and Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary, Chuck Hagel-but also he met key congressional leaders. For example, he met the

Speaker: NA
Text: two most senior Democrat and Republican senators, respectively-Senator Harry Reid and

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Mitch MCConnell. He also met the two principal leaders of the US House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives-Speaker John Boehner and Democrat Minority Leader, Nancy Pelosi. He

Speaker: NA
Text: also met the Federal Reserve chair, Janet Yellen, and the IMF managing director, Christine

Speaker: NA
Text: Lagarde.

Speaker: NA
Text: The meetings with the President were very important and ranged over trade, defence,

Speaker: NA
Text: intelligence and energy-efficiency issues. The US complimented the Australian government

Speaker: NA
Text: on increased Defence spending in the recent budget and Australia reiterated its support for the

Speaker: NA
Text: US's ongoing 'pivot' to the Asia-Pacific. The issue of China was raised. As the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: has said, we must welcome China's economic success. However, as I have previously noted,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia must not resile from condemning any unilateral actions that jeopardise peaceful

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution of territorial disputes in the South China Sea and the East China Sea.

Speaker: NA
Text: Equally, the talks covered the aggressive behaviour of Russia in the Ukraine. Again, this is

Speaker: NA
Text: an area where unilateral action has not been conducive to regional security. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister also discussed recent developments in Iraq, where Sunni militants are posing an

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing threat to regional security in the Middle-East. The President has said that barring

Speaker: NA
Text: putting troops on the ground no other options are off the table. The Prime Minister has noted

Speaker: NA
Text: that as a strong ally Australia is in close consultation with our US partners. Let us hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: military action can be avoided.

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker, this burgeoning crisis simply highlights the importance of our strategic

Speaker: NA
Text: alliances and Australia's engagement in key world events, not least through our membership

Speaker: NA
Text: of the UN Security Council. It shows the Australian people that Defence and international

Speaker: NA
Text: relations are in safe and sure hands.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate interrupted.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. BC Scott): Order! It being 8 pm, the debate is

Speaker: NA
Text: interrupted.

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 20:00

Speaker: NA
Text: NOTICES

Speaker: NA
Text: The following notices were given:

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: any further motions necessary to conclude consideration of the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 2014-2015,

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Appropriation Bill (No. 6) 2013-2014, and then the bill being considered in detail for a period not

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: any questions being put without further debate on any further motions necessary to conclude

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday, 18 June 2014

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. BC Scott) took the chair at 09:30.

Speaker: NA
Text: CONSTITUENCY STATEMENTS

Speaker: NA
Text: Isaacs Electorate: City of Greater Dandenong

Speaker: Mr DREYFUS
Text: Isaacs-Deputy Manager of Opposition Business) (09:30): I would like

Speaker: NA
Text: to congratulate the City of Greater Dandenong, which last night in Parliament House was

Speaker: NA
Text: presented with the National Award for Local Government in the category of Multicultural

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia-Strength in Diversity. The National Awards for Local Government are an annual

Speaker: NA
Text: celebration of Australian local government achievements. Through the awards, the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government celebrates local government projects that are innovative, deliver better outcomes

Speaker: NA
Text: for communities, have the potential to be rolled out across the country and make a meaningful

Speaker: NA
Text: difference. In particular, I would like to congratulate Mayor Jim Memeti and Councillors

Speaker: NA
Text: Youhorn Chea, Angela Long and Matthew Kirwan, who, together with Jackie Gatt, the

Speaker: NA
Text: council's officer, were in Canberra to receive the award for the council's 'Racism. Get Up.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speak Out' program. It was a pleasure to see them all here.

Speaker: NA
Text: At a council meeting on 26 June last year, the Greater Dandenong City Council

Speaker: NA
Text: unanimously pledged support for the National Anti-Racism Strategy's campaign 'Racism. It

Speaker: NA
Text: Stops with Me.' The campaign, launched by the Australian Human Rights Commission in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2012, has been underpinned by key research findings which suggest that one in seven

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian says that they experience discrimination because of their colour or background;

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately one in five Australians says they have experienced race hate talk, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: verbal abuse, racial slurs or name calling; around one in 10 Australian says they have

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced race-based exclusions in the workplace or social events; and more than one in 20

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians says they have been physically attacked because of their race.

Speaker: NA
Text: The campaign, embraced by the City of Greater Dandenong in the form of its 'Racism. Get

Speaker: NA
Text: Up. Speak Out' program, aims to raise awareness about racism and its effect on individuals

Speaker: NA
Text: and communities; give individuals and organisations tools and resources to take practical

Speaker: NA
Text: actions against racism; and empower individuals and organisations. It was for this bold and

Speaker: NA
Text: innovative campaign that the council won its national award last night.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, I note that, on 29 April this year, the City of Greater Dandenong made a formal

Speaker: NA
Text: submission opposing the Abbott government's attack on the provisions of the Racial

Speaker: NA
Text: Discrimination Act, provisions that protect our communities against racist hate speech. I

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate the council for emphatically rejecting Senator Brandis's view that 'people do

Speaker: NA
Text: have a right to be bigots'. In its cover letter, the council said:

Speaker: NA
Text: As a Victorian municipality with sixty per cent of residents born overseas, the City of Greater.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dandenong celebrates diversity and proactively seeks to address local racial discrimination. … Anti-

Speaker: NA
Text: racism is a matter of strong sentiment in this municipality.

Speaker: NA
Text: The council also pointed out:

Speaker: NA
Text: Within Greater Dandenong, those most affected by this amendment would include Aboriginal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Torres Strait Islanders, people from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds and members of

Speaker: NA
Text: certain religious groups, many of whom experience discrimination on a regular basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I again congratulate the City of Greater Dandenong council for the local government award

Speaker: NA
Text: they won and for their strong opposition to the government's proposed changes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dawson Electorate: Medical Workforce

Speaker: Mr CHRISTENSEN
Text: Dawson-The Nationals Deputy Whip) (09:33): I rise to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: about the issue of doctor shortages in the Whitsundays. It seems strange that such a beautiful

Speaker: NA
Text: area and one of the greatest tourism destinations in the world cannot seem to attract enough

Speaker: NA
Text: local GPs. But that is the situation, and I have spoken about the impact of this issue on several

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions in this place. Today I want to focus on some good news and suggest a better path

Speaker: NA
Text: for tomorrow.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Whitsundays have now been declared a district of workforce shortage, which opens the

Speaker: NA
Text: door for foreign-trained doctors in the Whitsundays to apply for an exemption under section

Speaker: NA
Text: 19AB(3) of the Health Insurance Act 1973. As a result, we hope to see one of the doctors who

Speaker: NA
Text: has left the region because of issues there, Dr Solgi, return to the Whitsundays with his wife,

Speaker: NA
Text: Shiva, who is also a doctor. She had to leave because she was not allowed to work in the same

Speaker: NA
Text: practice with her husband because of the restrictions that will now be removed because of this

Speaker: NA
Text: DWS declaration. As I said have said, they have not been able to do that because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: restrictions in the act, restrictions which could only have been overcome with this DWS. So

Speaker: NA
Text: the declaration is welcome for the overworked doctors currently operating in the Whitsundays

Speaker: NA
Text: and for the residents who need and deserve proper health care.

Speaker: NA
Text: But I do question the process by which these declarations were made. I note the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Health website outlines the information used in making these determinations,

Speaker: NA
Text: including:

Speaker: NA
Text: The latest Medicare billing statistics, which account for all active Medicare billing and therefore give an

Speaker: NA
Text: accurate indication of the geographic distribution of doctors across Australia …

Speaker: NA
Text: I am afraid that does not give an accurate indication at all. The data is converted into full-time

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent doctors to work out a ratio, which caters for many doctors working part time but

Speaker: NA
Text: does not account for few doctors working far too many hours. Dr El-Baky, from 121 Medical

Speaker: NA
Text: Centre in the Whitsundays, advised me yesterday that his practice had 30,786 patients on the

Speaker: NA
Text: books, cared for by himself and two part-time GPs. That figure only includes patients who

Speaker: NA
Text: have presented in the past two years, which suggests the formula is not working in the real

Speaker: NA
Text: world.

Speaker: NA
Text: The department's second source of information is ABS census data, which is supposed to

Speaker: NA
Text: give an indication of the geographic distribution of the Australian population. That census, a

Speaker: NA
Text: snapshot in time, is a poor indication of how many people are in need of a doctor in an area

Speaker: NA
Text: where tourism is the biggest, and almost only, industry. International tourists get sick, but

Speaker: NA
Text: they are not covered by Medicare. In the Whitsundays, with only a small resident population,

Speaker: NA
Text: they see 600,000 interstate visitors a year. If 10 per cent of those visitors need to see a doctor

Speaker: NA
Text: on their holidays, that is an extra 60,000 patients. The Whitsundays see a high turnover of

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors at the Proserpine Hospital, and, with their Medicare provider numbers attached to the

Speaker: NA
Text: region, it creates an impression that there are a lot more GPs then there actually are. So this

Speaker: NA
Text: flawed data does not account for the reality. I think the system needs to be reviewed or the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister given power to intervene. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Domestic Violence

Speaker: Mr WATTS
Text: Gellibrand) (09:36): I rise to speak again in this place about the stain of

Speaker: NA
Text: men's violence against women, and family violence more generally in our community. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: been just over one month since I last spoke about family violence in this place, after the

Speaker: NA
Text: community of Sunshine in my electorate was shaken by the murder of Fiona Warzywoda.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the media headlines have abated, it is important that we do not forget the ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: scourge of family violence in our community, that we do not forget that what White Ribbon

Speaker: NA
Text: calls the 'dark secret of Australian society' still lingers silently in the homes of our family, our

Speaker: NA
Text: friends and our neighbours across the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Extrapolated from 2013 data, since I last spoke in this place there would have been at least

Speaker: NA
Text: 5,000 further incidents of family violence in Victoria. There would have been over 1,000

Speaker: NA
Text: breaches of intervention orders, where we have failed to protect those in our society who most

Speaker: NA
Text: need it. Given that incidents of family violence in Victoria continue to rise, these

Speaker: NA
Text: extrapolations are likely to be conservative. Community legal centres in Victoria have

Speaker: NA
Text: reported that family violence currently accounts for over 50 per cent of the work of their

Speaker: NA
Text: lawyers. This is particularly true for Melbourne's west, where services addressing family

Speaker: NA
Text: violence have noticed a 35 per cent rise in demand for their services in recent years.

Speaker: NA
Text: This debate is one that is too important to let slip from yesterday's headlines into obscurity,

Speaker: NA
Text: into the file of problems often acknowledged but rarely acted upon. That is why, with other

Speaker: NA
Text: members in Melbourne's west, I am organising a forum with members of our local

Speaker: NA
Text: communities and stakeholder groups to ensure that the issue is firmly kept on the agenda. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are talking to the communities of Hobsons Bay, Brimbank, Maribyrnong and Wyndham to

Speaker: NA
Text: share ideas and to coordinate a response so that we know what is needed to prevent the

Speaker: NA
Text: incidence of family violence in Melbourne's west from rising any further.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why I welcome the announcement by the Victorian Leader of the Opposition,

Speaker: NA
Text: Daniel Andrews, to create a royal commission into domestic violence under a future Andrews

Speaker: NA
Text: government in Victoria. This announcement was one that brought tears to the eyes of victims

Speaker: NA
Text: of domestic violence in Victoria. It is an acknowledgement that a holistic response to family

Speaker: NA
Text: violence is required, ranging across health, housing, education, employment, policing, justice

Speaker: NA
Text: and our community services. But it is also an acknowledgement that a government response

Speaker: NA
Text: must be given the highest possible priority by government, to ensure that change will be both

Speaker: NA
Text: effective and permanent. Daniel Andrews should be commended for having such bold vision

Speaker: NA
Text: on this issue, and his leadership should be supported by all of us at the federal level.

Speaker: NA
Text: I speak today to reaffirm that family violence must stay on Australia's national political

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda. Long after the headlines have died down and the crowds of mourners from the latest

Speaker: NA
Text: tragedy have dissipated, there are still family members who are piecing their lives together

Speaker: NA
Text: after the loss of a mother, a sister, an aunt or a daughter. It is for them, and for all the women

Speaker: NA
Text: and girls in our society, that we must make sure that efforts to address domestic violence do

Speaker: NA
Text: not abate. We must do all that we can to ensure that the light of political attention remains on

Speaker: NA
Text: the dark secret of family violence in our society.

Speaker: NA
Text: Battle of Cocos

Speaker: Mr SIMPKINS
Text: Cowan) (09:39): I welcome the opportunity to speak today on an issue

Speaker: NA
Text: that I am sure you are very keen on as well, Mr Deputy Speaker Scott. We are rapidly

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: approaching the 100th anniversary of the declaration of war for World War I. In the early

Speaker: NA
Text: months of the war, in 1914, a very important battle took place, which we should keep in our

Speaker: NA
Text: minds, particularly those of us from Western Australia, although it took place a fair distance

Speaker: NA
Text: off our shores. I refer to the engagement between the HMAS Sydney, a light cruiser, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: German cruiser the SMS Emden.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the start of the war, the German East Asia Squadron were ordered back to Germany to

Speaker: NA
Text: act in Europe. They left behind the Emden, which was going to act as a commerce raider. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the first two months of the Emden operating independently, some 25 ships were sunk in the

Speaker: NA
Text: region, and others were damaged. At one point, on 8 November 1914, the captain of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Emden, Karl von Mueller, decided that they would disable the Australian transmission station

Speaker: NA
Text: on Direction Island in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands group. Just before a landing party of about

Speaker: NA
Text: 50 troops were able to achieve that, a distress signal was sent out. It was very fortunate that

Speaker: NA
Text: the convoy of the first Australian troops on their way to Egypt, accompanied by the HMAS

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney, was nearby, and Sydney was able to be dispatched to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.

Speaker: NA
Text: At 9.15 on the morning of 9 November 1914, Emden was engaged by the Sydney. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: disabled by the Sydney and later in the morning surrendered. It was a great win for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Navy. Whilst 160-odd Germans were killed, four Australians were killed and 16

Speaker: NA
Text: were injured on the Sydney. It was the first real win of the Australian armed forces in World

Speaker: NA
Text: War I. On 8 and 9 November this year, on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, there will be a great

Speaker: NA
Text: commemoration of this most important event in Australian military history.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bendigo Electorate: Kalydeco

Speaker: Ms CHESTERS
Text: Bendigo) (09:42): I rise today to raise the case of two constituents

Speaker: NA
Text: living in my electorate-27-year-old Brett Bell and six-year-old Amelia MCCrohan-and

Speaker: NA
Text: their families. Both Brett and Amelia have a rare form of cystic fibrosis. Both spoke to me

Speaker: NA
Text: about their wishes and their calls on the government to work with the manufacturer of the

Speaker: NA
Text: very important life-saving drug Kalydeco. Kalydeco was listed on the PBS in November last

Speaker: NA
Text: year, but it was listed with quite strict recommendations. Because of those recommendations,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is still not available in this country. I support the calls for the government to reinvest

Speaker: NA
Text: funding that has been made available through price disclosure in the PBS. This funding that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been made available to the government through price disclosure should go towards

Speaker: NA
Text: funding new medicines such as Kalydeco.

Speaker: NA
Text: Kalydeco does radically change people's lives. That has been demonstrated in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States and countries in Europe. All Amelia and Brett are calling for is for Australia to have

Speaker: NA
Text: the same requirements for the drug Kalydeco as those countries do. What does it mean for

Speaker: NA
Text: young Amelia, who is six years old? This drug could mean, if she starts taking it now, that she

Speaker: NA
Text: could live life like a normal six-year-old and could go on to live a long life. Right now, the

Speaker: NA
Text: life expectancy for someone with cystic fibrosis is low. For some, it is to their early teens. For

Speaker: NA
Text: some, it is to their late 20s. That is it. They have a life where, once they hit their late teens,

Speaker: NA
Text: they start to get quite ill. It must be so frustrating for Amelia's parents to know that there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: drug available in other countries that could help their little girl. All they want is for her to live

Speaker: NA
Text: a good life. Knowing that this drug is available in other countries and not in Australia is quite

Speaker: NA
Text: frustrating for them. So I call on the health minister, Peter Dutton, to work with Vertex and

Speaker: NA
Text: PBAC to avoid getting bogged down in price negotiations and bring about the listing and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: delivery of this drug Kalydeco so that the sufferers of this particular form of cystic fibrosis

Speaker: NA
Text: can receive the support that they need.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bradfield Electorate: 40K Foundation

Speaker: Mr FLETCHER
Text: Bradfield-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Communications) (09:45): I am pleased to rise to pay tribute to the impressive work of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 40K Foundation, an organisation which was established by a man named Clary Castrission,

Speaker: NA
Text: who grew up in my electorate of Bradfield. Just a few weeks ago I was able to attend an event

Speaker: NA
Text: held at the home of Dr Rick and Amanda Porter in Gordon in my electorate where there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: briefing provided to supporters of the work of the 40K Foundation.

Speaker: NA
Text: This extraordinary organisation was conceived of by a group of young Australians and was

Speaker: NA
Text: triggered by a visit that some of them took to India. They were struck by the poverty that they

Speaker: NA
Text: came across there and, with the enthusiasm of youth, they decided they would fund the

Speaker: NA
Text: construction of a new school. In fact, they came up with the name 40K because they estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: that building the school would cost $40,000. The school has been built in a community

Speaker: NA
Text: outside of Bangalore. It ended up costing some 10 times more than their initial estimate but is

Speaker: NA
Text: now operational and serves over 200 children. It is called the Banyan school.

Speaker: NA
Text: The work of Clary Castrission and the other young Australians involved in the 40K

Speaker: NA
Text: Foundation in achieving this is really quite remarkable. But they have not stopped there. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are evolving what they are doing towards being a social enterprise which works to deliver

Speaker: NA
Text: educational opportunities to children in India who otherwise would not get them. Their

Speaker: NA
Text: current model is to deliver teaching in English and mathematics into a range of villages in

Speaker: NA
Text: India. They use tablet computers to deliver the education. They have a model where they find

Speaker: NA
Text: somebody in each village who can help with the administration but who does not do the

Speaker: NA
Text: teaching because the teaching is provided by the device and by the children teaching

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other thing they do is charge a small amount to parents for children to have this

Speaker: NA
Text: educational opportunity because they want to provide something that is sufficiently valued by

Speaker: NA
Text: the parents that they will pay a small but material amount for the education of these children.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a very impressive venture conceived by a group of young Australians, many of them

Speaker: NA
Text: from my electorate of Bradfield, that began as a purely charitable operation. It is evolving into

Speaker: NA
Text: a sustainable social enterprise applying business principles to address a social problem-in

Speaker: NA
Text: this case children in India not getting the education that would change their lives. It aims to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide that education for a tangible and significant number of children.

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennedy Electorate: Ethanol

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Text: Kennedy) (09:48): I rise to give notice that the little tiny party that I

Speaker: NA
Text: represent will be moving in the state parliament in Queensland for the introduction of ethanol.

Speaker: NA
Text: We will be moving exactly the same legislation that was moved by the LNP when they were

Speaker: NA
