Text: in opposition in Queensland. So in opposition they were all for ethanol but when they get into

Speaker: NA
Text: government they are against it-a rather fascinating proposition. It could only be termed

Speaker: NA
Text: cowardice and betrayal of your electorate if you say that you are for it and get up and give all

Speaker: NA
Text: the speeches. Our state leader has informed me that he will be standing up and giving the

Speaker: NA
Text: same speech that was given by the LNP spokesman when he was moving the legislation,

Speaker: NA
Text: when he was in opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: But for an exercise in arch hypocrisy, I can assure the members of parliament representing

Speaker: NA
Text: ethanol areas that every one of their newspapers will be carrying an article saying: 'Are you,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Member of Parliament, going to vote for this legislation or not?' It is over to you. You

Speaker: NA
Text: have a state election on in five or six months time and let all the people know.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why is this so relevant, particularly in the sugar industry areas and in the area of Dalby?

Speaker: NA
Text: Because, as you are well aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, in the sugar industry we get $420 a

Speaker: NA
Text: tonne if it goes into an ethanol stream; we only get $320 a tonne if it goes into a sugar stream.

Speaker: NA
Text: These figures are all available because the government has just completed the $2.5 million

Speaker: NA
Text: study, the Pentland Project-announced last week. It is the government's own figures I am

Speaker: NA
Text: quoting here.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why is every country on earth on ethanol? Every single one of the European Union

Speaker: NA
Text: countries signed up for 15 per cent. These places are all on ethanol: India; China; Indonesia;

Speaker: NA
Text: Thailand; Philippines; all of the Americas, with the exception of Venezuela; all of Central

Speaker: NA
Text: America; all of the North American countries; all of the South American countries. The entire

Speaker: NA
Text: world is on ethanol except for the oil producing countries and Africa and Australia. Why are

Speaker: NA
Text: they all doing it? The reason they are doing it is in this report. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Aston Electorate: Roads

Speaker: Mr TUDGE
Text: Aston-Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister) (09:52): Traffic

Speaker: NA
Text: congestion in Melbourne, and in my electorate particularly, is getting worse every year. We

Speaker: NA
Text: all know the situation of being stuck in traffic, looking at the cars in front of us and feeling as

Speaker: NA
Text: if we are not moving anywhere. This clearly has a social impact on families, because it means

Speaker: NA
Text: time away from home. But it also has an economic impact. It is estimated that traffic

Speaker: NA
Text: congestion in Melbourne costs $2.7 billion and that will rise to about $6 billion by 2020 if

Speaker: NA
Text: ameliorating action is not taken.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fortunately, action is being taken at both state and federal levels. I would like to take this

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to outline some of the initiatives which will particularly impact residents in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate. Residents of my electorate, like other outer suburban electorates, are particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: impacted because a lot of the population growth is in those areas, and because there are so

Speaker: NA
Text: few other public transport options.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first initiative I would like to mention is the East West Link. We have now put in

Speaker: NA
Text: through the federal budget an extra $1.5 billion, bringing the total contribution to $3 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: towards the East West Link. That will take not only pressure off the Eastern Freeway and

Speaker: NA
Text: provide routes across to the western parts of Melbourne; it will also take pressure off the

Speaker: NA
Text: Monash Freeway which so many of constituents in the southern parts of my electorate use.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, I want to mention a few local roads that I have made commitments to fight for. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to update the House on those. I will begin with Napoleon Road. That is one that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been badly in need of an upgrade. I am pleased to report that the budget allocated $81,900

Speaker: NA
Text: in black spot funding to make significant improvements and add four turning lanes to

Speaker: NA
Text: Napoleon Road, which will increase the safety and amenity of that road. I would further like

Speaker: NA
Text: to suggest that Police Road needs to be extended through to Churchill Park Drive. I

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned this during the campaign and I have begun some discussions in relation to this. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: a difficult and complex problem because there are so many stakeholders-different councils

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: and various levels of government are involved-but it is something we need to progress in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to take pressure off Bergins Road.

Speaker: NA
Text: I continue to press for the most dangerous part of the Stud Road bus lane to be removed-

Speaker: NA
Text: between the Burwood Highway and Boronia Road. And, finally, I continue to press for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Rowville rail, which is a project that is badly overdue. Fortunately, we now have the

Speaker: NA
Text: feasibility study-the first and second stages-in, and progress is being made.

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia

Speaker: Ms RISHWORTH
Text: Kingston) (09:55): I rise today to talk about an issue that is of great

Speaker: NA
Text: concern to me. I am pleased that I have been joined by my South Australian colleagues here

Speaker: NA
Text: in the chamber, because I know it is of deep concern to them. My concern is about this

Speaker: NA
Text: government's lack of vision for jobs in South Australia. This government has shown a

Speaker: NA
Text: complete contempt for South Australia and for the jobs in our state.

Speaker: NA
Text: It should be no surprise that in this budget there is no new money for jobs. You only have

Speaker: NA
Text: to look back at how this government has approached South Australian jobs to see how they

Speaker: NA
Text: abandoned Holden and the car manufacturing industry in South Australia. This government

Speaker: NA
Text: abandoned not only Holden but every single one of the component manufacturers in South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, with a token effort of $20 million to try and help component manufacturers adjust.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is not enough money to help with the many thousands of jobs in auto components

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, this budget contains more cuts to jobs, which does not fill South Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: with any confidence. In the budget it was announced that 140 people who work in the Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Workforce Australia in South Australia will have their jobs cut. Indeed, people are being

Speaker: NA
Text: made redundant as we speak.

Speaker: NA
Text: The jobs of some of our top military scientists and engineers based at the Defence Science

Speaker: NA
Text: and Technology Organisation in Adelaide are being cut. Many jobs are now at risk. We also

Speaker: NA
Text: need to add this government's decision not to commit to building ships in Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government is not committing to the 12 submarines which are so critically important to jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: in South Australia. That puts at risk the jobs of approximately 1,100 workers currently

Speaker: NA
Text: working at ASC in Adelaide; it also puts at risk potential future jobs-the jobs that could

Speaker: NA
Text: come from a boom in submarine building in South Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government has shown contempt for South Australia and for jobs. I am appalled. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: glad the minister has just come into the chamber because I call on the government to seriously

Speaker: NA
Text: consider the impact that their decisions and this budget is having on jobs in South Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and on future jobs in South Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government is telling young people to either earn or learn. Where is their industry

Speaker: NA
Text: plan to ensure that jobs in South Australia grow? Where is their plan for future manufacturing

Speaker: NA
Text: in South Australia?

Speaker: NA
Text: The South Australian government is taking the lead on this, and I call on the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government to be upfront and to partner with the South Australian government and the South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people to promote manufacturing and jobs in South Australia. Please do not

Speaker: NA
Text: abandon South Australia in their time of need.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Surf Life Saving Central Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (09:58): Today, I rise to acknowledge the incredible work done

Speaker: NA
Text: by thousands of lifesavers right across the Central Coast community. There are 15 clubs on

Speaker: NA
Text: the coast, including eight in my electorate of Robertson, and they form an army of red-and-

Speaker: NA
Text: yellow volunteers, who, in the past 75 years, have helped to make the Central Coast beaches

Speaker: NA
Text: among the safest in the world. Lifesaving on the Central Coast has been around for 68 years,

Speaker: NA
Text: now.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was delighted to learn of this season's statistics from Surf Life Saving Central Coast: 956

Speaker: NA
Text: lives saved, 37,322 preventative actions taken, more than 1,000 first aid cases, and no lives

Speaker: NA
Text: lost. There are more than 8,000 members on the coast, with 2,000 patrolling the sand and the

Speaker: NA
Text: water for around 94,000 hours every season. Every single member is deserving of praise but

Speaker: NA
Text: today I want to make mention of a number who received awards at the Central Coast's Life

Speaker: NA
Text: Saving Awards of Excellence on Saturday night. They include Robert Powell from Umina,

Speaker: NA
Text: Assessor of the Year; Jane Davis from Ocean Beach, for Trainer of the Year; Lynn Smith,

Speaker: NA
Text: who won the Administrator Award; and Peter Lambeth, who received the Lifesaver of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Year Award.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Ocean Beach club also won the patrol championships and first aid awards. Avoca

Speaker: NA
Text: Beach had two major winners: Damien Benson, Coach of the Year, and Kevin Bootle, who

Speaker: NA
Text: collected the President's Award. From Terrigal, Cath Wilson won the award for SurfCom

Speaker: NA
Text: Operators, Tim Schofield was Open Athlete of the Year and Paul Lemmon was Masters

Speaker: NA
Text: Athlete. Junior Lifesavers of the Year were Jackson Heinze from Terrigal and Jasmine

Speaker: NA
Text: Darwin, who is based at Umina Surf Life Saving Club. They are both outstanding young

Speaker: NA
Text: people of our future. Champion Lifesaver awards were given to Jemma Smith, Teigan Miller

Speaker: NA
Text: and Jack Waining from Umina; and Jason, Jordan and Shelley Smith from Ocean Beach. The

Speaker: NA
Text: overall point score for the Champion Lifesaver Award went to Avoca, and Umina won Club

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Year. Special mention must be made of the President of Surf Life Saving Central Coast,

Speaker: NA
Text: Stuart Harvey, CEO Chris Parker and also Marie Ward and Jonathan Donnelly for their hard

Speaker: NA
Text: work and support for our community.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to the Terrigal club, I declare an interest. My husband and I have recently joined

Speaker: NA
Text: and we were honoured to complete the bronze medallion a couple of months ago. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: joined a patrol and, I have to say, it is one of the most rewarding experiences I have had. The

Speaker: NA
Text: sense of teamwork and connection and desire to make a difference is something that really

Speaker: NA
Text: binds the surf-lifesaving volunteer community together.

Speaker: NA
Text: Volunteers on the Central Coast beaches and, indeed, in New South Wales and right

Speaker: NA
Text: around Australia give of themselves tirelessly, week after week, month after month, year after

Speaker: NA
Text: year, with one aim in mind: to keep our local residents safe, to keep our beaches safe and to

Speaker: NA
Text: keep the thousands of tourists who visit the Central Coast safe in the water over summer and

Speaker: NA
Text: on the weekends. Today I pay tribute to all of our surf-lifesaving volunteers for what has to be

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the most honourable roles you can have-that of seeking to serve and to save lives.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. BC Scott): Order! In accordance with standing order

Speaker: NA
Text: 193 the time for constituency statements has concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS

Speaker: NA
Text: Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2014-2015

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration in Detail

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry Portfolio

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure, $4,202,817,000

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE (Groom-Minister for Industry) (10:01): Thank you for this

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to discuss the substantial, significant budget for Australian industry. This budget

Speaker: NA
Text: sets out a policy framework for Australian industry, manufacturing, energy and resources,

Speaker: NA
Text: skills and training, and science not just for the forward years but for the decades ahead. It sets

Speaker: NA
Text: a clear path to sustainability, new investment and jobs growth, and provides new

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities in markets for Australian ideas and products. Our approach underpins a new era

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australia which faces up to our challenges, embraces our strengths and accepts our

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for forging a new direction. We have the opportunity to reposition Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: industry towards the jobs and sectors of the future, while increasing the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: advance value-adding manufacturing. This future will be built around new ways of sharing

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge and know-how and greater links-I emphasise: greater links-between science,

Speaker: NA
Text: research and industry itself. In fact, we will be putting science and research at the centre of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry portfolio.

Speaker: NA
Text: This budget represents the hard work of a government that will not shirk its responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: to restore the nation's finances after Labor's debt and deficit disaster of the last six years; but it

Speaker: NA
Text: is also a budget that signals a clear new direction for Australian industry towards a future of

Speaker: NA
Text: new opportunities, new markets, new jobs and a new era of confidence in our ability and

Speaker: NA
Text: integrity. We have made it clear that no longer will industry policy be based around handouts,

Speaker: NA
Text: bandaid solutions and throwing around taxpayers' money willy-nilly without any strategic

Speaker: NA
Text: focus or long-term benefit to the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian businesses are characterised by a world-class standard of entrepreneurship. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have a stellar record of sparking great ideas and turning those great ideas into real-world

Speaker: NA
Text: applications. We do our Australian businesses a great disservice if we advocate a handout or

Speaker: NA
Text: government led-mentality. The government's role is to create the right policy framework and

Speaker: NA
Text: settings to unleash the creativity, ingenuity and practicality of Australians and their

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses. We have a role as a government to be the catalyst, not the gatekeeper.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are investing in national productivity gains and skilled workers of the future through a

Speaker: NA
Text: $1.9 billion Trade Support Loans scheme which will encourage apprentices to take up a trade

Speaker: NA
Text: but, far more importantly, to finish that trade. Fifty per cent completion rates are simply not

Speaker: NA
Text: acceptable, particularly for young people who need a future that is secure with the training

Speaker: NA
Text: they need. We want to turn out people who can take real jobs and have a secure future. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: putting in place a skills and training network that delivers the trained workers that Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses are calling out for, not simply training young people for the sake of training.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I mentioned, the government will be putting science and research at the centre of

Speaker: NA
Text: industry policy, and we are developing a strategic approach to science policy which will adopt

Speaker: NA
Text: a whole-of-government outlook to ensure that all portfolios work together to focus on our

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: resources and delivering future jobs. That is all portfolios of government, not just my own

Speaker: NA
Text: very diverse portfolio.

Speaker: NA
Text: The budget includes an investment of $1.4 billion in the resource sector, centred around the

Speaker: NA
Text: $100 million exploration development incentive, which is otherwise known as a flow-through

Speaker: NA
Text: shares scheme, something the Labor Party promised but in six years of government never

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered. We want to make it crystal clear that we support the energy and resources sector. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is one of our economy's most significant job drivers, and the private sector investment and

Speaker: NA
Text: national revenue of our country depends on it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Beyond the big headlines, of course, we also want to support our communities by getting

Speaker: NA
Text: rid of the carbon tax, the mining tax and red and green tape. We want to stop the constant tax

Speaker: NA
Text: grabs we saw from those opposite during their time in government that attacked the resources

Speaker: NA
Text: sector as if it were an ATM, never giving it any credit or security for its future. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: government is about forging new links between industry research and science, and that is

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly what we will do.

Speaker: Mr GRAY
Text: Brand) (10:06): I thank the minister for his introductory comments. The

Speaker: NA
Text: partnership between resources and science is important, and in Australia we are blessed with

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the great institutions that do support the interaction of science and our resources

Speaker: NA
Text: sector. The most important of those, we believe, is Geoscience Australia. I ask the minister to

Speaker: NA
Text: outline to the House the impact of the budget cuts on Geoscience Australia and its interactions

Speaker: NA
Text: with its counterpart organisations in the states and territories.

Speaker: NA
Text: Geoscience Australia provides a significant body of precompetitive data that helps inform

Speaker: NA
Text: explorers and the industry on the prospectivity and, most importantly, helps to drive the

Speaker: NA
Text: exploration sector in the most meaningful possible way. The discovery of the Gawler Craton

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred out of the PACE program in South Australia, which grew out of the insights that

Speaker: NA
Text: have grown from Geoscience Australia. Geoscience Australia's role in supporting science in

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding the interaction of water and coal gas extraction is something in which our

Speaker: NA
Text: community has a great deal of confidence. Geoscience is not simply a Canberra based

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation. It is a world-leading organisation that has been consistently supported by

Speaker: NA
Text: successive governments, so I am enthusiastic to understand the minister's views and intent

Speaker: NA
Text: behind the cuts to Geoscience Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also have in our country at the moment a significant and growing issue on the east

Speaker: NA
Text: coast, and that is gas supply-the extraction of gas from coal seams to support the domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: gas supply needs of the east coast. I would like to know from the minister what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth is doing to assist that industry to grow. We hear many poorly-thought-

Speaker: NA
Text: through arguments that associate the export gas industry with increasing prices on the east

Speaker: NA
Text: coast. We know our gas prices are being internationalised, but the renovating impact of that

Speaker: NA
Text: LNG investment, in particular in the minister's home state of Queensland, has had a

Speaker: NA
Text: significantly beneficial impact on gas supply. But there are clouds over how advantageous

Speaker: NA
Text: that resource could be for Australia and the lack of willingness in some jurisdictions to see

Speaker: NA
Text: that gas extracted in a safe way. I stress the word 'safe' because that relates organically to my

Speaker: NA
Text: previous question about Geoscience Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: These things are connected not just by ideas but they are connected organically-the foot

Speaker: NA
Text: bone connects to the shin bone connects to the knee bone. Good science, through Geoscience

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, gives our community confidence that we know what we are doing. Good science

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: underpins community confidence that gas extracted from coal seams can be done in the best

Speaker: NA
Text: possible way. On this side of the House we strongly stand for good science not as a dalliance

Speaker: NA
Text: but for good science underpinning good industrial and environmental management practices.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to hear from the minister specifically about the cuts to Geoscience Australia-

Speaker: NA
Text: how those cuts will improve the operation of Geoscience Australia; and the measures that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government will practically take to assist increased gas recovery from the east coast into our

Speaker: NA
Text: pipeline network in the east coast to drive our domestic markets?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE (Groom-Minister for Industry) (10:11): Can I thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Brand for his questions and also of course for his contributions when the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party was last in government towards supporting the resource sector. He was at times a lone

Speaker: NA
Text: voice there but he punched well above his weight. So I thank him for that. He gave the

Speaker: NA
Text: resources sector some glimmer of hope in what was a very bleak time for them when, as I say,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party treated the resource sector as a punching bag and source of money or an ATM

Speaker: NA
Text: whenever they ran short.

Speaker: NA
Text: In answer to his specific question in relation to Geoscience Australia, as the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Brand knows, I am a great supporter of Geoscience Australia-and he was when he was

Speaker: NA
Text: minister and Martin Ferguson before him. We have moved to ensure that, in terms of their

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term appropriations, they have a very secure and solid future. I will confirm, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: that there was a $27-million reduction under section 31 funding from $62 million in the 2013-

Speaker: NA
Text: 14 budget to $35 million in 2014-15. There was also a $1.937-million efficiency dividend

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed on Geoscience Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: More to the question, though, we do not expect there to be any long-term impact on

Speaker: NA
Text: Geoscience Australia. There have been some voluntary redundancies that have been taken,

Speaker: NA
Text: but as part of the overall efficiency which we need to achieve from our departments,

Speaker: NA
Text: Geoscience Australia is certainly able to assist in that regard. I have total confidence that

Speaker: NA
Text: Geoscience Australia has the resources it needs to do the job that Australia needs it to do. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: a pre-eminent organisation globally, it is well respected internationally and we certainly need

Speaker: NA
Text: to make sure that it continues to do that work.

Speaker: NA
Text: In regard to coal seam gas and the way that industry is progressing in eastern Australia, I

Speaker: NA
Text: have played an active role in trying to assist that industry to overcome some of the myths and

Speaker: NA
Text: blatant lies that are spoken about it. Along, as I say, with members from the opposition, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have from time to time needed to explain to our colleagues exactly what is going on in that

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. It is an industry which has enormous potential. As you, Deputy Speaker Scott, know

Speaker: NA
Text: more than anyone else in this parliament, it can bring about enormous beneficial change in the

Speaker: NA
Text: communities it is involved in. In your electorate of Maranoa and in my electorate of Groom,

Speaker: NA
Text: we have seen 4½ thousand farmers sign up to coexistence agreements with coal seam gas

Speaker: NA
Text: operators. I will give an example of the impact of that for individual farmers. I am sure Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Thompson will not mind me mentioning his name again, or this number, which he stated in

Speaker: NA
Text: public. One of the Deputy Speaker's constituents, Peter Thompson, and his wife, Nikki, have

Speaker: NA
Text: said publicly that they will receive $6 million from coal seam gas companies in return for

Speaker: NA
Text: allowing those companies to operate on their properties. The reality is that that $6 million is

Speaker: NA
Text: without any investment from the Thompsons or any requirement for the Thompsons to be

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in any work or labour or any risk in terms of capital investment. It is changing the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole economic and social landscape of that region.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Farmers are cooperating and science is being heavily involved to ensure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: underground aquifers are not affected. The cooperation that has been going on between the

Speaker: NA
Text: state government, the local governments, people like Ray Brown from the Western Downs

Speaker: NA
Text: shire and, of course, the Commonwealth government has been exemplary. Unfortunately, that

Speaker: NA
Text: is not the case in other states. At the moment, we are seeing a moratorium in Victoria. Perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: after the election, again with some encouragement from the Commonwealth government and

Speaker: NA
Text: some assistance from both sides of the House federally, we can encourage some development

Speaker: NA
Text: in that regard. In New South Wales I am more pessimistic. I am unsure how we can progress

Speaker: NA
Text: that issue. I have made a number of attempts, and I did, for a short time, consider a coal seam

Speaker: NA
Text: gas working group to assist there. But I have abandoned that idea.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: competitiveness by supporting business improvement and promoting economic growth

Speaker: NA
Text: through commercialisation of new ideas. I want to ask about the government's commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: industry policy-more specifically, the delivery of the new Entrepreneurs' Infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: Program through a single business service initiative. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be

Speaker: NA
Text: aware, unemployment in my region increased to over nine per cent under the previous Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government, during the Rudd-Gillard-Rudd years. It is absolutely essential that we do things

Speaker: NA
Text: to help the economy in the regions, so, Minister, I ask you to list the programs and the new

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives that the coalition government is providing for industry to help drive

Speaker: NA
Text: competitiveness and create jobs of the future. Also, focusing on the Entrepreneurs'

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure Program, would you tell me the rationale for the creation of this new and

Speaker: NA
Text: innovative program? What are the primary objectives and components of the program? How

Speaker: NA
Text: much funding will it receive? What progress is being made in the establishment of the EIP?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE (Groom-Minister for Industry) (10:17): I thank the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Hinkler for his question. I know that, in the short nine months that he has been there, he

Speaker: NA
Text: has had an enormous impact in terms of encouraging new businesses and new industries to

Speaker: NA
Text: that region. He has certainly ensured that businesses in Hinkler-or potentially in Hinkler, or

Speaker: NA
Text: if he can steal them from anywhere else-are aware that he is more than welcoming of new

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses in his electorate. He is making sure that the 'open for business' sign is well and

Speaker: NA
Text: truly illuminated both here and overseas.

Speaker: NA
Text: In answering the member for Hinkler's questions, I will say how important it is that we

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to see businesses established and that we attract not only businesses from Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: but also foreign investment. Innovation in Australia is a very, very high priority for this

Speaker: NA
Text: government, as it was last time I held this portfolio, between 2001 and 2007. We want to

Speaker: NA
Text: invigorate people to commercialise their good ideas. A good idea is worth nothing until it is

Speaker: NA
Text: turned into a commercial opportunity, until it is turned into a job opportunity for people-and,

Speaker: NA
Text: in this case, the people of the seat of Hinkler in particular.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are investing more than $2.25 billion in industry programs over the forward estimates,

Speaker: NA
Text: and this will deliver real outcomes and real jobs. We are certainly not abandoning the

Speaker: NA
Text: industries that those opposite would want you to believe we are. In terms of supporting

Speaker: NA
Text: industries, we have stood behind industries, we are adjusting industries and we are offering

Speaker: NA
Text: industries new opportunities.

Speaker: NA
Text: The range of programs to assist that innovation, create jobs and provide a streamlined and

Speaker: NA
Text: focused approach to industry policy include, as the member mentioned: the Entrepreneurs'

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure Program, some $484 million manufacturing worth of funding; the

Speaker: NA
Text: Manufacturing Transition Program, some $50 million worth of funding; the growth fund to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist those involved in the auto industry to transition to new long-term jobs, a total of $155

Speaker: NA
Text: million of which the Commonwealth government contributed $101 million; the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's National Industry Investment and Competitiveness Agenda, which will be

Speaker: NA
Text: announced in the months ahead; and the Industry Skills Fund, which, again, is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: important area in giving business the skills they need and their employees the skills they need

Speaker: NA
Text: to be competitive in an evolving and developing industry framework, some $476 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some might say the Trade Support Loans is the jewel in the crown of the training support

Speaker: NA
Text: area, some $1.9 billion of trade support loans. People wanting to do apprenticeships and

Speaker: NA
Text: certain traineeships will be able to access loans of up to $20,000 interest-free and adjusted

Speaker: NA
Text: with CPI annually.

Speaker: NA
Text: The response from industry once we explained the Trade Support Loan scheme to them has

Speaker: NA
Text: been excellent. I was actually out in my electorate last Friday doing that and the response was

Speaker: NA
Text: overwhelmingly positive. The cost of providing those loans interest-free is around $480

Speaker: NA
Text: million in the forward estimates. As well as that, we have got: the Geelong Region and

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne North Investment Fund, some $54 million and we are well through that; the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmanian Investment Fund of $11 million; and the Automotive Transition Transformation

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme for the auto industry, exclusively for the auto industry, some $550 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member asked about the Entrepreneurs' Infrastructure Program. The new program,

Speaker: NA
Text: aimed at supporting the commercialisation of good ideas, establishes and delivers a

Speaker: NA
Text: straightforward, proactive and effective approach to industry policy through a substantive and

Speaker: NA
Text: more efficient implementation platform which is known as the single business service. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: provide market and industry information and advice to business. It will offer business

Speaker: NA
Text: management advice and skills. Experienced private sector business advisers will give access

Speaker: NA
Text: to research and innovators to re-engineer business operations. It will also connect them to

Speaker: NA
Text: supply chains and potential markets as well as commercialisation advice.

Speaker: Mr GRAY
Text: Brand) (10:23): Thank you for your observations about Geoscience Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Could I ask you to be more specific. You referenced almost $30 million in cuts to Geoscience

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. You may need to take this on notice, but just how many jobs have been axed in

Speaker: NA
Text: Geoscience Australia? What were the skills that were lost? What work areas have been

Speaker: NA
Text: affected? What is the ongoing program of graduate recruits into Geoscience Australia? These

Speaker: NA
Text: things are important as I know the minister would understand a healthy and vital Geoscience

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia does require consideration of its structures, of its work programs and of its future

Speaker: NA
Text: skill base.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to ask the minister about the review of the Renewable Energy Target.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, we understand that review is taking place chaired by Mr Dick Warburton, a fine

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian and a very significant Australian business leader. I have had the pleasure of

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting with Mr Warburton to discuss that review. But if the minister as the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Energy could advise the House on when we can expect the report of the review on the RET

Speaker: NA
Text: that would be great greatly appreciated. If a date and a time cannot be provided then at the

Speaker: NA
Text: very least give an indication of when we can expect that review to be presented because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of the month of August and the casting of the renewable credit numbers for the

Speaker: NA
Text: next year.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE (Groom-Minister for Industry) (10:24): I thank the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Brand for his question. I will take parts of his question on notice. In terms of the specific

Speaker: NA
Text: skills that have been removed, I will give the member for Brand the detail of that but I will

Speaker: NA
Text: have to take that part of his question on notice, as I will the part on the graduate program. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: my understanding that there is no effect on the graduate program, but I will supply him with

Speaker: NA
Text: further detail in regards to that.

Speaker: NA
Text: In regards to the actual staff movements, as of 30 May 2014 62 staff have departed

Speaker: NA
Text: Geoscience Australia. By 30 June this year a total of 76 employees will have departed. By the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of December this year a total of 85 employees will have departed. Five employees have

Speaker: NA
Text: elected to seek redeployment and have commenced their retrenchment period. Nine staff have

Speaker: NA
Text: been offered voluntary redundancies and are yet to indicate their preference to exit or seek

Speaker: NA
Text: employment. Existing and projected average staffing levels at Geoscience Australia are 716 in

Speaker: NA
Text: the year 2013-14 and 620 in the year 2014-15. As I said, though, I am entirely confident that

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be no effect on the capacity of Geoscience Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: In response to the member for Brand's question regarding the Renewable Energy Target, I

Speaker: NA
Text: take this opportunity to remind the House both of the coalition's commitment to renewable

Speaker: NA
Text: energy and, more importantly, of the fact that we are the fathers of this scheme. We

Speaker: NA
Text: established the Mandatory Renewable Energy Target. Senator Robert Hill, who was the

Speaker: NA
Text: environment minister at the time, implemented this. It has given an enormous boost to the

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation of renewable energy in Australia. We have seen projects built around

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia off the back of the scheme. In terms of Australia's percentage of renewable energy

Speaker: NA
Text: vis-a-vis the rest of the world, we can certainly hold our heads up.

Speaker: NA
Text: In regards to the member for Brand's specific question about the review, he is quite right:

Speaker: NA
Text: Dick Warburton is an excellent choice as chairman as someone who has enormous respect in

Speaker: NA
Text: the business community as he has been involved in business a very long time and has been

Speaker: NA
Text: very successful at it. He and his equally as qualified committee are currently considering the

Speaker: NA
Text: impacts of the Renewable Energy Target on Australia's competitiveness and our ability to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to maintain a target for renewable energy going forward. It is my understanding that

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee will release their modelling towards the end of this month and that they then

Speaker: NA
Text: will work from that point to prepare the report for government, which we would expect to

Speaker: NA
Text: receive some time after that-perhaps in the next few months.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not expect the government to be long in responding to that review. In terms of my own

Speaker: NA
Text: time lines, I need to hand down an energy white paper this year. I need to be able to be

Speaker: NA
Text: confident that, firstly, the Labor Party has seen the error of its ways-and it is still not too late

Speaker: NA
Text: yet-and will support the rescinding of the carbon tax. I need to see the carbon tax dealt with

Speaker: NA
Text: before I can have any forward concept on where energy policy is going in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hopefully that will occur in the next sitting of the Senate in early July. I also need to know

Speaker: NA
Text: where the government intends to set its policy in relation to renewable energy. We expect to

Speaker: NA
Text: see a response to the renewable energy review sooner rather than later, perhaps by the third or

Speaker: NA
Text: fourth quarter of this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure Program. I want to ensure that the minister is aware of some of the absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: valuable additions from the Hinkler electorate to manufacturing. We are the biggest producer

Speaker: NA
Text: of heavy vegetables in Australia. All of our agriculturalists know that farm gate returns are

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: simply not high enough so we need those value-added products to increase not only

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity but the return to our farmers to make them viable. Inside my electorate, Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: we have opportunities for macadamias and sweet potatoes. We already have organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: like Austchilli with David and Trent De Paoli. They are a major exporter of chilli, basil and

Speaker: NA
Text: avocado products all over the world. These secondary level manufacturers help our local

Speaker: NA
Text: producers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other thing the minister may not be aware of is that the Bundaberg port is completely

Speaker: NA
Text: underutilised. The opportunities in Bundaberg and in the Hinkler electorate are quite simple.

Speaker: NA
Text: Land is cheap. We have lots of it. There is a lay-down area in Bundaberg as big as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Brisbane port. We could build container ports, build industry or do anything but we need that

Speaker: NA
Text: seed funding to help those things along. Certainly it is low risk. We are below the Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef and are in a low cyclone risk area. There are opportunities there.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bundaberg Foundry, for example, located in Bundaberg just celebrated 125 years of

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing. It is still there but it is under pressure from the carbon tax and from red and

Speaker: NA
Text: green tape. They are struggling. Electricity costs are up $1 million. Minister, if you can name

Speaker: NA
Text: a foundry in Australia that is making $1 million a year, I would be very interested.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Entrepreneurs' Infrastructure Program is incredibly important. Minister, further to my

Speaker: NA
Text: last question on the government's commitment to industry policy and, more specifically, the

Speaker: NA
Text: delivery of the new Entrepreneurs' Infrastructure Program through the single business service

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative, will you advise what the government is doing to ensure that there is smooth

Speaker: NA
Text: transition from the closure of existing programs to the launch of the new Entrepreneurs'

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure Program? Is there a date by which the program will be functioning? Is the

Speaker: NA
Text: government on track to meet that date? How will businesses, particularly SMEs, interact and

Speaker: NA
Text: gain access to the new Entrepreneurs' Infrastructure Program-businesses like Hervey Bay

Speaker: NA
Text: seafood and the Hervey Bay scallop, who could certainly do with an automated shucking

Speaker: NA
Text: machine even though something that would work functionally has not been built yet? How

Speaker: NA
Text: does this new initiative simplify the process for business to seek support? What has the

Speaker: NA
Text: reaction been from major stakeholders to this budget measure?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE (Groom-Minister for Industry) (10:32): I again thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Hinkler and say how impressed I am by the support he gives businesses in his

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate and his knowledge of the issues that they face. I have had the opportunity to visit

Speaker: NA
Text: the city of Bundaberg on numerous occasions. In fact, I remember going there when I was

Speaker: NA
Text: quite young and I remember my attraction to it when I was an older person-fortunately, I

Speaker: NA
Text: managed to break that habit and I do not drink Bundaberg Rum anymore. It is a great product

Speaker: NA
Text: and I certainly do not bemoan it. It has made Bundaberg very famous. The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Hinkler asked me about the Entrepreneurs' Infrastructure Program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE: I hear interjections from the other side about handouts. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: we need to be very clear about these programs and how they work. They work to give

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses a hand up and not a handout. I know the Labor Party are infamous for spraying

Speaker: NA
Text: money around with gay abandon and very little purpose. One of the great problems we have

Speaker: NA
Text: had since we took government is dealing with the bandaids they had applied to various

Speaker: NA
Text: industries. I can ask them what commitments and long-term benefits they achieved for the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of dollars they gave to Alcoa or for the millions of dollars that they gave to GMH to

Speaker: NA
Text: stay in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our programs are specifically targeted at producing results. The government's decision to

Speaker: NA
Text: implement the new Entrepreneurs' Infrastructure Program took into consideration the existing

Speaker: NA
Text: status of all current programs that are planned to be phased out of operation. It was almost a

Speaker: NA
Text: grab bag of programs, some of which you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would be shocked to know

Speaker: NA
Text: actually never came into operation. Money was allocated, announcements were made,

Speaker: NA
Text: launches were relaunched but nothing ever happened. I know, you, particularly, Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker Scott, would be shocked by that, knowing the value of money! The reality is, though,

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are going to ensure that there are well-targeted programs. To ensure that no business

Speaker: NA
Text: misses out this government has made provision for Commercialisation Australia to operate

Speaker: NA
Text: through until 31 December 2014 and deal with all applications formally lodged before the

Speaker: NA
Text: close of business in 2014.

Speaker: NA
Text: Additionally, Enterprise Connect will run on a business-as-usual basis until the end of this

Speaker: NA
Text: current financial year and any smallto medium-business owners that were dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: either Commercialisation Australia or Enterprise Connect will be able to be transferred across

Speaker: NA
Text: to the new Entrepreneurs' Infrastructure Program from early in the new financial year to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure there is a seamless transition.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Hinkler asked me about the start-up dates in relation to the Entrepreneurs'

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure Program. In line with 2014-15 budget commitments, the Entrepreneurs'

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure Program will operate from 1 July 2014. Its interaction with SMEs and access by

Speaker: NA
Text: SMEs is very simple: business will be able to gain access and interact with the Entrepreneurs'

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure Program in person, on the phone or via the internet or email. Throughout this

Speaker: NA
Text: month of June all details of the program will be placed on the Department of Industry's

Speaker: NA
Text: website.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was asked how this program works in comparison to previous programs. The reality is, as

Speaker: NA
Text: I have just mentioned, there was when we inherited government an overlapping plethora of

Speaker: NA
Text: small grants and entitlements that were not targeted towards any specific outcome. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: sitting about getting the economic settings right, getting rid of red tape and equipping

Speaker: NA
Text: business by giving them the market, information and skills they need. We must remember that

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's legacy is one of indecision and change. In the last three years, in fact, there were 14

Speaker: NA
Text: ministers through the former Department of Industry, Innovation, Climate Change, Science,

Speaker: NA
Text: Research and Tertiary Education-and you wonder why small business was glad to see them

Speaker: NA
Text: go.

Speaker: Mr WATTS
Text: Gellibrand) (10:37): I have a number of questions for the minister about the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of the budget on the auto manufacturing sector. I do thank the minister for inviting me

Speaker: NA
Text: to attend with him the Altona Toyota manufacturing plant in my electorate. I genuinely thank

Speaker: NA
Text: him for that. I am just regretful that future invitations will not be able to be extended for

Speaker: NA
Text: members for Gellibrand, as the Toyota plant will be ceasing operations in future as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: the actions of this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: A recent report from Adelaide University stated that Australia was expected to suffer a fall

Speaker: NA
Text: in national employment of around 200,000 as a result of the planned closure of auto

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing between now and 2017 and that the greatest job losses will be in Victoria, with

Speaker: NA
Text: an estimated decline of close to 100,000 jobs. How can the minister justify over $1 billion in

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts to the automotive industry in the budget when the government is well aware that these

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts are putting hundreds of thousands of Australian jobs at risk?

Speaker: NA
Text: The automotive firms and component manufacturers have repeatedly advised the

Speaker: NA
Text: government of the serious consequences of cutting funding from the Automotive

Speaker: NA
Text: Transformation Scheme at what is an already difficult time for manufacturing and supply

Speaker: NA
Text: chain workers. So why is the government cutting over $900 million from the Automotive

Speaker: NA
Text: Transformation Scheme when the minister is well aware that, if passed, these cuts will

Speaker: NA
Text: intensify the financial pressure on the hundreds of firms in the supply chain, firms which have

Speaker: NA
Text: already factored ATS funding into their long-term business and investment decisions?

Speaker: NA
Text: According to the Prime Minister's announcement, the government's so-called $155 million

Speaker: NA
Text: Growth Fund has been set up for firms and employees in South Australia and Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: affected by the closure of local manufacturing operations. In April this year an independent

Speaker: NA
Text: study projected that auto closures would result in over 32,000 jobs lost in New South Wales,

Speaker: NA
Text: over 30,000 in Queensland, as well as over 11,000 in WA and almost 500 in the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory. This is on top of the 23,000 jobs at risk in South Australia and almost 100,000 jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: in Victoria. Economic modelling forecasts a negative annual shock of $29 billion or more by

Speaker: NA
Text: Can the industry minister please outline how this so-called growth fund will have any

Speaker: NA
Text: chance of helping auto workers in New South Wales, Queensland, WA and the NT, not to

Speaker: NA
Text: mention how, with just $100 million in Commonwealth funding, this program will have any

Speaker: NA
Text: impact on the 200,000 jobs at risk on a national level.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE (Groom-Minister for Industry) (10:39): I thank the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Gellibrand for his question and assure him that, if there are future opportunities-and

Speaker: NA
Text: there should be between now and 2018-for visits to the Altona plant, I will invite him. He

Speaker: NA
Text: did, after all, get the best start to life that anyone could get in Australia, by being born in

Speaker: NA
Text: Toowoomba, and I am sure that, deep down somewhere, there is a lot more good that we can

Speaker: NA
Text: make of that. His choice in politics may have been dubious, but I am sure his heart is made of

Speaker: NA
Text: gold.

Speaker: NA
Text: Regarding decisions made by Australian car manufacturers to cease operation, I draw to

Speaker: NA
Text: point the member for Gellibrand's assertions that our government was in any way responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: for those decisions, most particularly the decision of Toyota. Having known the Toyota

Speaker: NA
Text: management for as long as I have, dating back to 2001, when I was the minister for industry

Speaker: NA
Text: then, I can assure the member for Gellibrand that the government were given very clear

Speaker: NA
Text: indication by Toyota that, in spite of everything we had done and would do, they had made

Speaker: NA
Text: their decision to close. That decision was extremely difficult. The heads of Toyota, both here

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia and Japan, came up to Canberra especially to talk to me about that and to also

Speaker: NA
Text: meet with the Prime Minister and explain that decision, but it is a simple fact that, in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to manufacturing cars in Australia, it is virtually impossible to compete. It needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: remembered, and perhaps lamented, that the industry arrived at the point under the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government where it required $5,784 per vehicle, plus tariffs, to continue to operate in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am an optimist. I have spent a lot of time in farming, where you have to be an optimist. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, I was a farmer longer than I have been a politician. If I looked at a component of my

Speaker: NA
Text: farming operation where taxpayers had to contribute that proportion, which is almost 15 and,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: in some cases, 20 per cent of the value of the vehicle, I would say, 'There is no hope.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, though, as I say, we lament it, there was no way in which Toyota, Holden,

Speaker: NA
Text: Ford and Mitsubishi-some of whom made those decisions when the Labor government was

Speaker: NA
Text: in power, some of whom made them since we came to power, but the result is the same-

Speaker: NA
Text: could continue. They all arrived at the same conclusion, and that was that the industry could

Speaker: NA
Text: no longer manufacture vehicles in Australia without long-term, substantial government-

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayer funded subsidies. Unfortunately, because of the complete and absolute mess that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party left the finances in, the money that we would be paying the auto industry would

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be borrowed by taxpayers from overseas, and that is just sheer insanity. So, whilst we

Speaker: NA
Text: lament that the car industry has made those decisions, we as pragmatic, rational people

Speaker: NA
Text: understand why it made those decisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: To assist the industry-and our understanding is that there are substantial numbers but

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly nowhere near the numbers that the member pointed out in that report; let us say the

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers are somewhere between 20,000 and 25,000 people to find new work-we have

Speaker: NA
Text: established a $155 million growth fund in conjunction with the South Australian and

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian governments and the auto industry. There will be $30 million made available for a

Speaker: NA
Text: skills and training program to assist workers to find new jobs outside the industry. There will

Speaker: NA
Text: be a $15 million automotive industrial structural adjustment fund, a $20 million automotive

Speaker: NA
Text: diversification fund for component manufacturers to go into other areas, a $60 million next-

Speaker: NA
Text: generation manufacturing investment program to bring new businesses to those regions and a

Speaker: NA
Text: $30 million regional infrastructure fund to put new regional infrastructure in for communities.

Speaker: Mr CHRISTENSEN
Text: Dawson-The Nationals Deputy Whip) (10:45): Thank you,

Speaker: NA
Text: minister, for your statements here this morning. I would ask a couple of questions. One is in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to ARENA. I understand that a billion dollars worth of taxpayer funds have been

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to nearly 200 ARENA projects across a suite of renewable energy types. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: aware that a billion dollars of government funding has been matched with a further $1.8

Speaker: NA
Text: billion, I believe, taking the investment in renewables to $2.8 billion as a result of that

Speaker: NA
Text: program. In Queensland we have over $55 million of ARENA funds that have been invested

Speaker: NA
Text: in six different projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has made it very clear, and rightly so, that we are facing a budget

Speaker: NA
Text: emergency careering towards $667 billion worth of debt, right now resulting in a billion

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars of interest every month, which could blow out to $3 billion. We understand that

Speaker: NA
Text: savings need to be achieved to return that budget back to surplus. What are your plans, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister, in relation to ARENA but more so in relation to the 200 projects that were supported

Speaker: NA
Text: under this program? I know that when those opposite were in charge of it there were certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: some high-level failures, probably due to lack of oversight by the former government of those

Speaker: NA
Text: projects. I know a couple of them are sitting at the bottom of the ocean. I am looking at how

Speaker: NA
Text: the government is going to actually deliver real, good outcomes for renewables with this

Speaker: NA
Text: investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also want to ask-and I know the member for Hinkler has asked a couple of questions on

Speaker: NA
Text: it-about the great Entrepreneurs' Infrastructure Programme. It is a brilliant scheme as far as I

Speaker: NA
Text: can see, taking the best of all of the programs that were there and rolling them into one, so

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is almost one point of entry for industry and business. You know, minister-because

Speaker: NA
Text: you have been to my electorate a number of times and spoken with local businesses there-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: about the downturn and the impact that has had on the local economy in the Mackay region.

Speaker: NA
Text: That downturn in coalmining has cost thousands upon thousands of jobs but has also seen a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant shift in the way business has to be done locally and what the local manufacturing

Speaker: NA
Text: industry is doing. They were always engaged with the mining sector, but now the taps have

Speaker: NA
Text: turned off somewhat they have to look elsewhere. I am interested to see how that

Speaker: NA
Text: Entrepreneurs' Infrastructure Programme will assist them in that transition to other industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that is going to pay big dividends, just having had a look at the cursory information on

Speaker: NA
Text: it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other side might have been content with just leaving coalmining to wither and die, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that they are not our thoughts on the coal sector. We think it has a bright future. I

Speaker: NA
Text: notice that one of the significant policies you are going to be implementing is the minerals

Speaker: NA
Text: exploration tax incentive program. I am wanting to know a little bit about what the

Speaker: NA
Text: government is going to be doing to reboot the mining sector as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE (Groom-Minister for Industry) (10:48): I thank the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Dawson for his question. Mackay is certainly a wonderful city. Its people are particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful. There is one in particular my daughter thinks is particularly, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful, although he has moved to Brisbane-I have no idea why; perhaps it is to be close

Speaker: NA
Text: to my daughter. But, seriously, my daughter Kate spent some three years in Mackay. She

Speaker: NA
Text: enthused about the city, and more about the fact that it was a city that was prepared to take on

Speaker: NA
Text: the challenges. The region around it, of course, is well known. I am sure the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Hinkler is aware that it is well known as a very prosperous cane-growing region. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: their good years and their bad, like the coal industry, but there has been a substantial industry

Speaker: NA
Text: built up around it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have had the pleasure of accompanying the member for Dawson to the Racecourse Sugar

Speaker: NA
Text: Mill, where there is an excellent renewable energy project going on. The cogeneration project

Speaker: NA
Text: relies, as I say, on the mandatory renewable energy target. I understand it also had some

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance from the government at the time. Prior to losing government in 2007 I had been up

Speaker: NA
Text: there and talked with their officials. So wherever you go you see great industries but you also

Speaker: NA
Text: see renewable energy industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: ARENA has, as the member for Dawson alluded to, allocated in excess of $1 billion for

Speaker: NA
Text: renewable energy projects in Australia. That is over 200 projects supported by taxpayers, with

Speaker: NA
Text: a further $1.8 billion being leveraged from the private sector. So there is approaching $3

Speaker: NA
Text: billion in projects as a result of the renewable energy programs that have been put in place.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our government will absolutely honour those contracts. Where those projects go on and

Speaker: NA
Text: succeed, we will obviously applaud their success. If projects fail then obviously we will take

Speaker: NA
Text: that money back into the pot. But we certainly expect some great results from those programs

Speaker: NA
Text: that have already been funded under ARENA.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those opposite have made many mischievous and incorrect claims. and I will address a

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of them later, if time permits. Contrary to the claims we hear from those opposite,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is not walking away from renewable energy. In fact, we as a government are very

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to renewable energy. As I said in answer to a question from the member for Brand,

Speaker: NA
Text: we were the government who began substantive funding of renewable energy and also

Speaker: NA
Text: established the renewable energy target.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: By way of information, renewable energy is currently contributing around 10 per cent-

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps more, in fact, depending on how you do the sums and analyse the economists'

Speaker: NA
Text: predictions-of Australia's energy mix and is assisting not only in ensuring energy security

Speaker: NA
Text: but also addressing some of the short-term peak demand loads, particularly on hot days in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, through the very significant rollout of solar panels. Again, that is a program that the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition began in its last term.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am asked about specific programs. I will just name a few. There are $80 million worth of

Speaker: NA
Text: investments encompassing nine projects in the ACT; $310 million invested in 49 projects in

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales; $250,000 invested in a single project in the Northern Territory; $6 million

Speaker: NA
Text: invested in a project in Tasmania; and $140 million in nine projects in South Australia, which

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure will please the member for Wakefield; $84 million invested in nine projects in

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria; and $17 million invested in three projects in Western Australia. As well as that,

Speaker: NA
Text: there have been multiple scholarships and fellowships, totalling around $90 million, awarded.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps later in the session I might be able to highlight a couple of individual programs.

Speaker: Mr CHAMPION
Text: Wakefield) (10:53): Like the member for Gellibrand, I have also been

Speaker: NA
Text: on a tour of a car plant with the minister. I thank him for inviting me at the time, along with

Speaker: NA
Text: quite a few Liberal senators. The member for Hindmarsh was there as well. The rhetoric was

Speaker: NA
Text: somewhat different then, somewhat more optimistic about the car industry's prospects at that

Speaker: NA
Text: time. Sadly, that has proved not to come to fruition.

Speaker: NA
Text: A government member interjecting-

Speaker: Mr CHAMPION
Text: A Labor government would have saved it. But I do not propose to

Speaker: NA
Text: redebate those issues or, for that matter, to give the minister an excuse to give us the lecture

Speaker: NA
Text: about industry assistance only to be followed by government backbenchers asking for grants

Speaker: NA
Text: or tax exemptions for particular industries. It is an interesting approach that the government

Speaker: NA
Text: takes.

Speaker: NA
Text: What I am concerned about, and this is a genuine concern, is the $155-million growth fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am concerned about its adequacy. Another of the things I am concerned about is obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: the closure of Holden components industry will devastate the northern suburbs of Adelaide,

Speaker: NA
Text: and Elizabeth in particular. I am interested to know if the minister, his office or his

Speaker: NA
Text: department have had discussions with the local councils of the City of Playford or the City of

Speaker: NA
Text: Salisbury. In particular, have they had any discussions about local projects like the City of

Speaker: NA
Text: Playford's sports precinct, which is interrelated with the proposal to have a health precinct at

Speaker: NA
Text: Lyell MCEwin Hospital? Both these local projects would produce jobs for the local area.

Speaker: NA
Text: When Holden closes, I am concerned we will have an empty site sitting down there on

Speaker: NA
Text: Philip Highway and it may well be empty for some time. I would be interested to know if the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister is having discussions with General Motors Holden about that site, about its future. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would also be interested to know if the minister has formed a committee with unions, local

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, Holden, the South Australian government and the federal department-as was done

Speaker: NA
Text: with Bridgestone-to help manage the process of skills acquisition of employees being made

Speaker: NA
Text: redundant at General Motors Holden or any of the component companies that supply it and to

Speaker: NA
Text: push job service agencies to get jobs for those redundant employees. It was a very important

Speaker: NA
Text: thing when Bridgestone closed. I would be interested to hear the minister's thoughts about

Speaker: NA
Text: that.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Most of my concerns are of a local nature. We can debate the events last year. I can tell you

Speaker: NA
Text: the effect of them will be catastrophic in my community. I really genuinely would like to hear

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister's thoughts about how my local community can be assisted out of this $155-

Speaker: NA
Text: million growth fund. I do not think it is adequate and I have great fears that the money will be

Speaker: NA
Text: spent in places other than the northern suburbs of Adelaide, in places other than the

Speaker: NA
Text: communities affected.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Zappia interjecting-

Speaker: Mr CHAMPION
Text: My colleague the member for Makin inquires how much will be

Speaker: NA
Text: actually allocated to South Australia. They are my concerns and I would be interested to hear

Speaker: NA
Text: by the minister's thoughts on them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE (Groom-Minister for Industry) (10:57): I thank the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for his question. I plead guilty to being optimistic. As I said: farmer by nature, optimistic by

Speaker: NA
Text: nature. If you go into government, as I know the Labor Party does so regularly, and take a

Speaker: NA
Text: disastrous view of everything, be pessimistic and say it is a catastrophe then what will

Speaker: NA
Text: happen, of course, is what we saw under the previous government-the confidence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: community business community falls, consumer confidence falls, the economy spirals down

Speaker: NA
Text: and then the Labor Party drops back to its old form. There is no problem small enough that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party cannot throw a huge amount of money at to try and fix with no strategy, no

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes, no guidelines et cetera. So when the Labor Party sees a problem, the first thing

Speaker: NA
Text: they say is 'throw as much borrowed taxpayers' money as you can possibly get your hands on

Speaker: NA
Text: at it as quickly as possible'. As the member for Dawson said, why do we wonder why we are

Speaker: NA
Text: heading towards $667-billion worth of debt? Why do we wonder why in the six short years

Speaker: NA
Text: that Labor was in government they spent $181 billion more than they earned? In their forward

Speaker: NA
Text: estimates there was a further $123 billion in losses going forward. If they were a company,

Speaker: NA
Text: their shareholders would have shut them down if ASIC had not done it first.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am asked about the Future Fund and how it will work and what consultations we have had

Speaker: NA
Text: with industry and the unions. As the member quite rightly identified, when it comes to solving

Speaker: NA
Text: the issues in relation to the car industry I am bipartisan in my approach. As he quite rightly

Speaker: NA
Text: said, I invited all those who are interested in being part of a solution to come along and see

Speaker: NA
Text: what we can do. The Premier of South Australia was there, and there were senators from both

Speaker: NA
Text: sides. As the member well knows, there were also trade unions there. I see trade unions as

Speaker: NA
Text: playing an important role in the transition of the car industry. I just hope that their leaders are

Speaker: NA
Text: more optimistic and more helpful than those who sit opposite and bleat and scream and call

Speaker: NA
Text: for us to throw more and more money at a problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: There will be significant skills programs to assist those workers, and I know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: automotive companies will be involved. I have had extensive discussions with all three

Speaker: NA
Text: companies. I know that the programs that Ford is running, and the associated programs that

Speaker: NA
Text: are running in Geelong and North Melbourne to attract new businesses to those regions, have

Speaker: NA
Text: been very successful. I give the Labor Party its dues: they established that fund and set up a

Speaker: NA
Text: framework for it to work under. We, as a government, have ensured that the framework has

Speaker: NA
Text: been adhered to and that the corporate governance of those schemes has been successful.

Speaker: NA
Text: We hope that we will have the support of the trade unions and the support of the South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian government. And-who knows?-perhaps the opposition, when they realise that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are here to help the people they represent and not just whinge, will get behind these

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: programs. I am more than comfortable to have the unions involved in assisting. I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the unions are involved very well. They have been positive. Yes, they have stood up

Speaker: NA
Text: for their members. As an ex-union leader, I know that that is what they should do. But they do

Speaker: NA
Text: need to accept the reality. Unlike those who sit opposite, at times I think the unions do

Speaker: NA
Text: understand. The best thing they can do for the workers in the car industry is to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: they transition to new and better jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: To answer the member's question, as we put together these programs within these

Speaker: NA
Text: companies I would welcome union involvement. I would welcome the involvement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: local federal members and the state members and senators if they think there are things in

Speaker: NA
Text: those programs, particularly about reskilling people, that we can do better. I would be happy

Speaker: NA
Text: to see them involved.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs ANDREWS (MCPherson) (11:02): I have a question for the minister in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: vocational education and training, the reforms to that sector and also the establishment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: VET Reform Taskforce. But let me start by saying that I am very positive about the changes

Speaker: NA
Text: that are being proposed and being talked about in this sector. I could not be more pleased that

Speaker: NA
Text: this government has been especially proactive in the area of VET.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our national competitiveness, in my view, and our productivity is very dependent on us

Speaker: NA
Text: having a very strong VET sector. We need to make sure that our workforce of the future has

Speaker: NA
Text: skills that make them job ready so that when they enter the workforce they are ready to be

Speaker: NA
Text: productive and to be contributors on the first day that they enter the workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: Across Australia our VET students deserve to know that they are receiving quality training

Speaker: NA
Text: and that what is being provided to them is going to meet their needs and will also meet the

Speaker: NA
Text: future needs of their employers. The providers need to know that they will be treated fairly in

Speaker: NA
Text: the provision of the training that they will be delivering to the sector. So we need to take this

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to put a magnifying glass over the VET sector and look at what reforms are

Speaker: NA
Text: needed to make sure that this sector is viable in the future. It is certainly no easy task, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: must commend the minister on the action that he has taken to date in that sector. He has been

Speaker: NA
Text: especially proactive and has set up a number of mechanisms where he can get support and

Speaker: NA
Text: input directly from those who know best-those in the industry. He has embarked on a

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation process, first hand, with the sector by establishing a number of workshops

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the country to engage with the people who actually know best-training

Speaker: NA
Text: providers, industry representatives, employers and students-to find out what is needed to

Speaker: NA
Text: reform this sector in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: I attended workshops in Darwin and in Brisbane and also had the opportunity just recently

Speaker: NA
Text: to facilitate workshops with the member for Grey in Port Pirie and Whyalla, with the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Forrest in Bunbury and also with the member for Robertson in Gosford. The workshops

Speaker: NA
Text: that were run were certainly eye opening. At each of these sessions in different parts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: country we heard of similar problems with the VET sector relating to the duplication in

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations and administration amongst jurisdictions; inconsistency in auditing; the capacity

Speaker: NA
Text: of the system to meet the current skill needs of the industry; and what was particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning was what seems to be an increased focus on qualifications rather than the quality

Speaker: NA
Text: of the training in the sector and, as a result, the quality of the qualifications.

Speaker: NA
Text: These sessions were not just about understanding what the issues are, they were also about

Speaker: NA
Text: finding ways for the sector to grow and to prosper. The outcomes-the information that came

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: from those sessions-have been forwarded through so they will be part of the changes for

Speaker: NA
Text: future consideration. I would certainly like to thank everyone who was involved in those

Speaker: NA
Text: workshops. I would like to thank all of the members for the work that they put in to make sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that those who attended were quite representative of the various parts of the sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: So my question to the minister is: can the minister outline for members the action that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government is taking to ensure that the future of our nation is not just about building

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure and building the systems to support that but is also about building the skills of

Speaker: NA
Text: our people, particularly those in the VET sector?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE (Groom-Minister for Industry) (11:06): I want to thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for MCPherson not only for her question but also for the great job, not only

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting my portfolio in the area of skills and training but, in fact, right across government.

Speaker: NA
Text: She is an incredibly hard-working local member. She has a great practical background from

Speaker: NA
Text: being an engineer by trade and she is one of those people who is set on producing outcomes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for MACPherson has certainly continued that attitude since she came into

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament. Again, I thank her for the work that she has done.

Speaker: NA
Text: She is quite right: as she and I, my office and my department travel around Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: looking at the issues in relation to skills, training, traineeships and apprenticeships we are at

Speaker: NA
Text: times dismayed by the attitude of some people in relation to making sure that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: producing people who are employer ready. That is, people who are skilled up and ready to go

Speaker: NA
Text: into the workforce not only to secure a long-term future for themselves in their chosen

Speaker: NA
Text: profession-I am sure that that profession may change in time, and we all see that even

Speaker: NA
Text: amongst our families-but also making sure that when young people and mature apprentices,

Speaker: NA
Text: who play an important part in our training system, are turned out onto the street looking for a

Speaker: NA
Text: job that there is a job that they can go straight into.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for MCPherson is right that there has been too much of an attitude-I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that it is overwhelming, but I am saying it is prevalent-where there has been training

Speaker: NA
Text: for training's sake. There has also been an attitude that the only way you can go forward in

Speaker: NA
Text: this world is to go to university and get a degree. I remember very, very vividly the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party giving Brendan Nelson an absolute flogging because he had the courage to say in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House, and I remember him saying it when he was the education minister, that a trade is

Speaker: NA
Text: worth every bit as much as a degree. I remember the Labor Party pillorying the then Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Education, Science and Training, Brendan Nelson, for saying that a trade is worth as much

Speaker: NA
Text: as a university degree. I assure those opposite that I believe that as well, and that the people

Speaker: NA
Text: on this side of the chamber believe that too.

Speaker: NA
Text: An honourable member interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE: Well, if you believe it you should say it a bit more so that the

Speaker: NA
Text: young people in your electorate actually believe that their future can be achieved just as well

Speaker: NA
