Text: as any university graduate's by being a tradesperson or trainee, getting a skill and filling an

Speaker: NA
Text: occupation. Do not give them false hope-we hear too often from those opposite that, if it

Speaker: NA
Text: does not go to plan, the government will just subsidise you or pick you up.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for MCPherson has identified a key area that we will fix, and that is

Speaker: NA
Text: inconsistency in auditing. In fact, we see a whole opportunity within the skills space to

Speaker: NA
Text: streamline it. The member for MCPherson and other members of my committee, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: headed up by the member for Dawson, are working with us and with the people out there in

Speaker: NA
Text: the RTOs, the apprenticeship centres and the skills areas to make sure that we streamline this

Speaker: NA
Text: area so that, when we spend money, we actually get results. As I said earlier, in the area of

Speaker: NA
Text: innovation, when we came into office, we found a whole string of programs that in fact had

Speaker: NA
Text: money allocated to them but had never even been implemented. When I asked the department

Speaker: NA
Text: what these schemes did, they said, 'Minister, they haven't started yet, so we can't actually tell

Speaker: NA
Text: you.' What outcomes did they produce? Zero.

Speaker: NA
Text: Any discussion on skills would be incomplete without me mentioning the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction of Trade Support Loans. These loans, which I mentioned earlier, provide the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity for a four-year apprentice to borrow up to $20,000 and, at completion, have

Speaker: NA
Text: $4,000, or 20 per cent, of that loan written off as an incentive. To receive that loan interest

Speaker: NA
Text: free until he or she repays it is a huge incentive. In fact, it is worth probably over $12,000, or

Speaker: NA
Text: more than double the previous Tools for Your Trade scheme. We see from this scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: tremendous support coming back from the trainee community. As I said, I saw it myself in my

Speaker: NA
Text: own electorate. This is a great opportunity for young people to do their trades and be

Speaker: NA
Text: successful.

Speaker: Mr ZAPPIA
Text: Makin) (11:12): Minister, firstly, thank you for your introductory statement.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have noted your response to the questions from this side. As you would probably be aware,

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing in this country has fallen in terms of employment percentage throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia from about 26 per cent 50 years ago to around eight per cent at the moment. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: very likely those numbers are going to fall even further as a result of losses in the auto

Speaker: NA
Text: industry over the next few years, losses perhaps in the defence industry if decisions are not

Speaker: NA
Text: made sooner rather than later, and losses that will arise, I believe, from the Abbott

Speaker: NA
Text: government's cut to renewable energy programs in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that in this budget there is about $7 billion of cuts in higher education, science and

Speaker: NA
Text: research, industry and innovation, of which about $3 billion comes from your own

Speaker: NA
Text: department. Given that we hope for a successful future in manufacturing-and I think there is

Speaker: NA
Text: a general consensus that that will be underpinned by advanced manufacturing-and given the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's recent comments whilst overseas that science and innovation is effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: the key to our future, which I agree with, how can you justify not only the cuts to your own

Speaker: NA
Text: department of $3 billion but the $7 billion in cuts across the science and research

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations, which, undoubtedly, go to the heart of innovation in this country?

Speaker: NA
Text: I heard your responses to questions from the member for Brand earlier on. In particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: you made the comment that you believe that Geoscience Australia still will have the capacity

Speaker: NA
Text: to function and to carry out its responsibilities. I ask also: with the cuts that that organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: is going to receive, in conjunction with my earlier questions how can you assure us that

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations like Geoscience Australia and other similar organisations that will be subjected

Speaker: NA
Text: to these cuts will be able to carry out the work that they do and support industry in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country as they do?

Speaker: NA
Text: I particularly also note the programs that the previous government had in the way of direct

Speaker: NA
Text: industry assistance, which amounted to some $800-plus million. Those programs have been

Speaker: NA
Text: cut by almost 50 per cent. I noted your comments about the entrepreneurial funding program,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I understand that, but the bottom line is: how do you justify all of those cuts and still

Speaker: NA
Text: expect that there will be able to give industry the support it needs both in science and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: innovation and in direct assistance to be able to go into the future and perhaps rather than fall

Speaker: NA
Text: in numbers grow in numbers and grow in capacity?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE (Groom-Minister for Industry) (11:15): I thank the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Makin for his question. Can I just say from the outset that, if he does not accept that there

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to be cuts to the budget, then is he continuing the old Labor way of continuing to run

Speaker: NA
Text: deficits? In my time in parliament I have never seen a Labor surplus. The reality is that there

Speaker: NA
Text: are members of this parliament who have never seen a surplus in their life from Labor. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the reality. If the member for Makin says we shouldn't make cuts in this area he needs to now

Speaker: NA
Text: stand up and say where he will make those cuts. If he doesn't, we just assume that Labor will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue on their way with $123 billion worth of deficits in the forward estimates, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: continuation of the debt blowing out to $667 billion, and with the continuation of the pressure

Speaker: NA
Text: that that creates in terms of our economy. He knows and I know that that position is nowhere

Speaker: NA
Text: near sustainable.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to correct the member for Makin in terms of his statement that we have cut the

Speaker: NA
Text: science and research budget. We have not cut the science and research budget. Can I read for

Speaker: NA
Text: him from our budget papers that the appropriation available to the science and research areas,

Speaker: NA
Text: including science agencies such as Geoscience Australia and CSIRO, stands at $5,849

Speaker: NA
Text: million, and that the increase in the budget-increase in the budget-is in fact $16.8 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: So even at a time where I accept we have to have some austerity measures, even at a time

Speaker: NA
Text: where I accept we have to refocus the programs that the previous government was operating,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is an increase. As I have pointed out on numerous occasions during this session,

Speaker: NA
Text: programs were never actually implemented. Some programs never got past the great launch

Speaker: NA
Text: and potentially relaunch and the great talk that went on about programs that never actually

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered a thing.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, yes, we have cut some of those programs, and yes we have put in place a far more

Speaker: NA
Text: focused system of $484 million for the Entrepreneurs' Infrastructure Program, a program

Speaker: NA
Text: where we take the best of Enterprise Connect and Commercialisation Australia and we put it

Speaker: NA
Text: into the Entrepreneurs' Infrastructure Program. This is a program where we make sure that we

Speaker: NA
Text: are giving business what they need to be competitive, to be innovative, to get into global

Speaker: NA
Text: supply chains, to be involved in the new industries and to give their workers sustainable jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: On top of that of course we have got the industry skills program which further assists those

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses to ensure that they, the business, and their employees have the skills that they need

Speaker: NA
Text: to make the adjustments in front. That is $1 billion worth of programs for innovation, for

Speaker: NA
Text: skilling, for competitiveness, for getting involved in new products, for collaborating with

Speaker: NA
Text: existing businesses-a set of programs that will ensure businesses the opportunity to be

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive in the long term.

Speaker: NA
Text: But for the benefit of the member for Makin can I just highlight a few areas where we have

Speaker: NA
Text: actually spent new money in the areas of science and research. There is $65.7 million to

Speaker: NA
Text: operate and maintain the CSIRO's new vessel, RV Investigator. I know those on this side of

Speaker: NA
Text: the chamber will not be surprised to hear this, but only the Labor Party could build a boat and

Speaker: NA
Text: not put any money in there to use it. So the boat was going to sit there at port-like a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: their programs: set up with great fanfare, moored to the dock but not operate. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: actually put some money in to make sure that that boat gets out to sea and does something.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: We put $31.6 million into the operation and maintenance of the OPAL nuclear research

Speaker: NA
Text: facility. It is a great facility. It is making great advances in nuclear medicine, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: something we need to continue to do. We have put $28 million into continued investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: Questacon through science for Australia's future to ensure that Australia's children are as

Speaker: NA
Text: excited as much by science as I am.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Text: O'Connor) (11:20): Mr Deputy Speaker Porter, as a former Treasurer of

Speaker: NA
Text: the great state of Western Australia, you would well understand the importance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: resource sector. Minister, you would know that the mining sector contributes about 10 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of our GDP, directly employs 270,000 Australians and supports work and income for

Speaker: NA
Text: another 800,000. The Bureau of Resources and Energy Economics released their resources

Speaker: NA
Text: and energy major projects report last month that showed that in the last 12 months a record

Speaker: NA
Text: $57 billion worth of resource projects had been finalised in Australia, with a significant

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in production. I understand this includes 215 million tonnes of iron ore, 43 million

Speaker: NA
Text: tonnes of coal and more than 1,100 petajoules of gas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over recent years it is clear that Australians have benefited from the jobs and growth

Speaker: NA
Text: flowing from the high levels of investment in the resource sector, but the Bureau of Resources

Speaker: NA
Text: and Energy Economics also reports that Australia's resource sector is moving into a new

Speaker: NA
Text: phase of sustained output and production following the peak of the current resources

Speaker: NA
Text: investment cycle. The resources sector will continue to drive our economy through this new

Speaker: NA
Text: phase, but it is essential that we do not become complacent. These production phase figures

Speaker: NA
Text: highlight the importance of setting the right policy framework to encourage future investment

Speaker: NA
Text: in the resources sector. There is a need for ongoing progress in removing barriers to

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in the resources sector to encourage investment and confidence, to get rid of the

Speaker: NA
Text: reams of red tape and remove tax slugs that compromise productivity and competitiveness.

Speaker: NA
Text: This output phase will last for decades, delivering sustained and substantial economic benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australian workers and local communities as well as boosting national revenue. Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: what is the government doing to ensure a long and sustainable future for the resources

Speaker: NA
Text: industry?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE (Groom-Minister for Industry) (11:22): As the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Connor noted, both Deputy Speaker Porter and he took a vital interest in the development

Speaker: NA
Text: of the resources industry in their previous times. The member for O'Connor has a very strong

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in the resources sector not only because he is the member for O'Connor. Some people

Speaker: NA
Text: would argue that O'Connor is at the heart of the history of the Australian resources industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The centre for that is in Kalgoorlie, which I have had the opportunity to visit. The Mining

Speaker: NA
Text: Hall of Fame in Kalgoorlie is certainly an apt reminder of the huge debt we owe to the miners

Speaker: NA
Text: and resource investors of Australia going right back to the 1800s.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also congratulate the member for O'Connor for his transition to politics. He has a

Speaker: NA
Text: background a little similar to mine. We were both farmers once. I guess he is still more active

Speaker: NA
Text: than I am-in fact, I am sure he is; these are no longer the hands of a farmer. I am sure the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for O'Connor still delights in getting out in the paddock and driving the harvester or

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps crutching a few sheep if he is having a really good day. I congratulate him on his

Speaker: NA
Text: transition to politics and for his advocacy not only for the industries in his electorate but for

Speaker: NA
Text: all members of the seat of O'Connor.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: He was quite right when he talked about the importance of the resource sector. The

Speaker: NA
Text: resource sector contributes around 10 per cent of our GDP, employs over one-quarter of a

Speaker: NA
Text: million Australians and indirectly provides income to another 800,000, so over one million

Speaker: NA
Text: people rely on the resource sector for their income and their living. As I said earlier, the

Speaker: NA
Text: resource sector is heaving a huge sigh of relief that the coalition have come back into

Speaker: NA
Text: government and that we have relieved them from the burden of the last six years when they

Speaker: NA
Text: were used as a punching bag by people like the member for Lilley, who constantly attacked

Speaker: NA
Text: successful Australian resource figures. Then, when he had finished degrading their characters

Speaker: NA
Text: quite unfairly, he went on to empty their pockets with things like the ill-fated mining resource

Speaker: NA
Text: rent tax, which had about five iterations. In the end, as we know, it was a great tax introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Treasurer that actually raised no money at all. It chased away billions of dollars worth

Speaker: NA
Text: of investment but did nothing.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for O'Connor asked me what we are going to do to support the resources

Speaker: NA
Text: sector. Apart from putting the 'open for business' sign up, apart from reducing red tape and

Speaker: NA
Text: green tape and introducing the one-stop shop, we are going to remove the carbon tax, which

Speaker: NA
Text: will give them a huge boost, and we are also going to remove the mining tax. It will be

Speaker: NA
Text: interesting to watch those people opposite vote against those measures when they know that

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Australia want them removed and they know that the people of Australia depend

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Australian resource industry and industry in general being competitive.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for O'Connor also asked me what policy initiatives we are going to take,

Speaker: NA
Text: which gives me the opportunity to answer the latter part of the member for Dawson's

Speaker: NA
Text: question. We are going to introduce a $100 million Exploration Development Incentive,

Speaker: NA
Text: previously known as flow-through shares. I think it was the member for Wakefield who said it

Speaker: NA
Text: was a subsidy. That just highlights how little those who sit opposite know about the resource

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. The exploration incentive allows individual entities, mum-and-dad Australians, to

Speaker: NA
Text: invest in the R&D, the research and development, of the resource industry in Australia. What

Speaker: NA
Text: better way is there to do it and say to them: 'If you put your money at risk then, just as we do

Speaker: NA
Text: in the research and development area where we provide a tax incentive for people to do that,

Speaker: NA
Text: we will provide you with a tax incentive to invest in one of Australia's great sectors, the

Speaker: NA
Text: resource sector.' So we are putting in place an Exploration Development Incentive and I look

Speaker: NA
Text: forward to returning to Kalgoorlie with the member for O'Connor where I campaigned with

Speaker: NA
Text: him and we promised that if we got into government we would introduce this scheme. Unlike

Speaker: NA
Text: those who sit opposite, we will do that. We will go back to the drilling sheds, where we stood

Speaker: NA
Text: with people who had put their whole livelihoods at risk to go out and explore for minerals,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we will say, 'We promised and we delivered,' unlike those who sit opposite.

Speaker: Ms BIRD
Text: Cunningham) (11:27): Minister, I am happy if you want to take these questions

Speaker: NA
Text: on notice to give as much opportunity as possible for people who want to ask you questions. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to get some information on the Industry Skills Fund that is in the budget papers. I

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge that its arrival has heralded the demise of $1 billion worth of programs and I

Speaker: NA
Text: note that the minister indicated earlier that some of his thinking was informed by the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: some of those programs both had not started and had no enrolments. One would think that

Speaker: NA
Text: would be a fairly logical consequence of not having started, but I would appreciate it if the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister could indicate which of the programs that have been cut had not started and which

Speaker: NA
Text: had had nil outcomes. Secondly, in relation to the replacement Industry Skills Fund, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: industries listed as targeted in the budget papers, in particular, health and biomedical

Speaker: NA
Text: products, and I would like to know if that will also encompass skills programs with a broader

Speaker: NA
Text: health workforce. I am particularly interested in the emerging areas of employment

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity into the future around issues such as aged care, disability care and the health

Speaker: NA
Text: sector care workforce in general. They had a significant take-up of the National Workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: Development Fund, so whether they are still going to be able to participate in the new fund

Speaker: NA
Text: would be useful information. I am also asking for that information in relation to the ICT

Speaker: NA
Text: sector, because the emerging ICT industry sector jobs have been important as well for many

Speaker: NA
Text: regional areas, including my own. How is the minister going to determine what exactly will

Speaker: NA
Text: be targeted under that program in terms of industry sectors?

Speaker: NA
Text: The budget paper indicate that there are 121,500 training places and, it says, 74,300

Speaker: NA
Text: support services, including mentoring and foundation skills. Is it intended to operate two

Speaker: NA
Text: separate programs for those numbers or is the 74,300 within the 121,500 and is it a joint

Speaker: NA
Text: program? What exactly is envisaged in that part of the industry skills fund? I am happy for

Speaker: NA
Text: you to answer those questions now or to take them on notice, Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE (Groom-Minister for Industry) (11:29): I thank the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for her question and I will have to take it on notice, unfortunately. I thank the shadow minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for her positive attitude to the changes that are going on within this portfolio. I know there are

Speaker: NA
Text: areas she disagrees with but she is happy to sit down and talk about it. I am happy to supply

Speaker: NA
Text: all that information. The skills fund guidelines are still being finalised but when they are I will

Speaker: NA
Text: be happy to provide you with a full briefing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Bird interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr IAN MACFARLANE: Very soon is the answer to that, hopefully by 30 June.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Services Portfolio

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure, $9,606,728,000

Speaker: Mr NEUMANN
Text: Blair) (11:31): One of the biggest surprises for the aged care sector

Speaker: NA
Text: coming out of the budget was the cessation of the aged care payroll tax supplement from 1

Speaker: NA
Text: January 2015 as found on budget paper No. 2, page 189. It effectively ended the doctrine of

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive neutrality in the sector between the for-profit providers and the not-for-profit

Speaker: NA
Text: providers. It ripped away $652.7 million over four years from the sector. It was a bit of a

Speaker: NA
Text: shock because there was no consultation or sector support for it. The CEO of Benetas, Sandra

Speaker: NA
Text: Hills, expressed in a letter to me on 4 June the following:

Speaker: NA
Text: The greater issue is the impact that the removal of the payroll tax supplement will have on investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: the sector. Aged care in Australia must have a mix of providers to ensure we remain a competitive,

Speaker: NA
Text: innovative industry that offers the highest quality of services available. Removal of this payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement will seriously threaten some providers resulting in less competition across the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: She goes on to outline her concerns about the impact on organisational cash flow, future

Speaker: NA
Text: investment, staffing, skills retention and artificial wage constraint.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have a few significant questions for the minister. What modelling was undertaken into the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact on the aged-care sector of this budget measure on viability of providers, their

Speaker: NA
Text: profitability, jobs, workforce and investment? In particular, what has the modelling revealed

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: about the impact on independent providers, small providers and those in rural and regional

Speaker: NA
Text: areas? If no modelling was undertaken, why not?

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand also there has been some redirection of the workforce supplement into some

Speaker: NA
Text: sweeteners for the viability supplement. Within a few weeks of the budget, leading aged-care

Speaker: NA
Text: services provided some details of the impact on specific providers including in regional

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, which saw that particular provider receive an additional $2,900 in the viability

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement but lose $100,000 to $120,000 in the payroll tax supplement. I am sure they can

Speaker: NA
Text: provide you with the details.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would be interested to know how you intend to deal with the significant impost on the

Speaker: NA
Text: sector. The inaugural report of the Aged Care Financing Authority from 30 June 2013 reports

Speaker: NA
Text: the average net profit before tax across the sector is just 5.6 per cent. How does the

Speaker: NA
Text: government expect the sector to remain viable with this further impost? Has the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken any specific modelling into the impact on residential pricing? If not, why not? If

Speaker: NA
Text: he has done modelling, what does that show?

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like the minister to explain why the payroll tax supplement is being ceased on 31

Speaker: NA
Text: December 2014. Why is it that the minister has actually ended the principle of competitive

Speaker: NA
Text: neutrality which has been accepted by both sides of parliament since 1988? I refer also to the

Speaker: NA
Text: comments of Louis Dudley, the managing director of Bupa care services, he said recently:

Speaker: NA
Text: I have to go to each of the state governments now and discuss with each one, one at a time, which really

Speaker: NA
Text: is increasing red tape, and that's the opposite of what the government was trying to achieve nationally.

Speaker: NA
Text: How does the end of competitive neutrality sit with the policy of your government in the

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction of red tape as well?

Speaker: NA
Text: You would appreciate, of course, that, according to ACFA, we will need to build an

Speaker: NA
Text: additional 80,000 aged-care places over the next decade. This involves an extra $25 billion,

Speaker: NA
Text: according to ACFA. You would be aware, Minister, that the surprise budget announcement

Speaker: NA
Text: actually forced one provider, Japara Healthcare, to halt trading. I wonder how you expect the

Speaker: NA
Text: sector to cope with the increased investment they need to build residential aged-care

Speaker: NA
Text: placements and capital infrastructure in the decades ahead.

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Menzies-Minister for Social Services) (11:35): Payroll tax is

Speaker: NA
Text: essentially a state tax. States impose a variety of taxes, including payroll tax. So, effectively,

Speaker: NA
Text: this supplement was the Commonwealth transferring funds to the various states around

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia via the aged-care sector. It is this government's belief that states are responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: their own tax measures, including payroll tax, and that this is a matter, therefore, for the

Speaker: NA
Text: states. On that basis, the Commonwealth decided that in future we are not going to

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement-we are not going to, in effect, provide a subsidy to-the states in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: their taxes. That is a matter entirely for the states.

Speaker: Mr LAMING
Text: Bowman) (11:36): Minister, would you clarify something for many people

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate who have been receiving and expressing great concern about some Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party material that was circulated, focused on the pension in particular. I understand there

Speaker: NA
Text: have been some flyers put out by Labor Senator Cameron saying, quite inaccurately, that

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners will lose the seniors supplement. That has now been clarified as not true in that

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not even receive this supplement.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously, it is an appalling campaign and the misinformation has caused great concern. It

Speaker: NA
Text: really does reflect an opposition party with no ideas for the future, no clue, no platform of

Speaker: NA
Text: their own and no alternative budget. We know that pensions will continue to increase twice

Speaker: NA
Text: every year and into the future, even with the re-indexation changes in 2017 locking them into

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of living, but the scare campaign evidently has had its effect. It has caused great

Speaker: NA
Text: concern about the impact on the pension supplement. Could you confirm the status of that

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement in the budget and whether it will be increasing at all in the future?

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Menzies-Minister for Social Services) (11:37): I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bowman for his question. Indeed, I have seen the flyer that he refers to. Indeed, I have it in

Speaker: NA
Text: my hand at the present time. This is a flyer which is authorised and printed by Senator Doug

Speaker: NA
Text: Cameron, 5 Raymond Road, Springwood, New South Wales.

Speaker: Mr Laming
Text: Is that the only Doug Cameron, or could it be-

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: I do not think there are two Senator Doug Camerons, no. Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Cameron, who happens to also be the shadow minister for human services, I believe, put out

Speaker: NA
Text: this flyer, in which he said, amongst other things: 'Age pensioners lose $876.20 per annum

Speaker: NA
Text: seniors supplement.' One would hope that the shadow minister for human services would

Speaker: NA
Text: actually know the facts of who receives what. Presumably, he has now sought to clarify that.

Speaker: NA
Text: To come to your question, the age pension will continue to go up and so will the pensioner

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement. Indeed, in March of this year, the age pension increased by $15.70 for singles

Speaker: NA
Text: and by $11.90 for each member of a pensioner couple. That was three months ago. In three

Speaker: NA
Text: months time, in September, the age pension will increase again, as it will in March and

Speaker: NA
Text: September of 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018-and I could keep going, but I will not take up the

Speaker: NA
Text: time of the chamber-continuing for years into the future. In addition to that, the pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: will keep the energy supplement, which is up to $361 per annum for singles and up to $546

Speaker: NA
Text: per annum for couples. In addition to that, if the Labor Party would finally see some reason

Speaker: NA
Text: and allow the repeal of the carbon tax, pensioner households would be also better off as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of that measure passing the Senate. In addition to that, the pension supplement will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue into the future. Currently that is worth up to $1,635.40 for singles and up to

Speaker: NA
Text: $2,464.80 for couples. The pension supplement will also increase in future.

Speaker: NA
Text: So in relation to pensioners-contrary to what the Labor Party around the country is

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking to mislead people about-pensions will continue to increase in March and September

Speaker: NA
Text: of each year, not just this year but each year into the future. The pension supplement will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to be paid and that, too, will increase. As I said, the pensioners will keep their energy

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement of $361 per annum for singles and $546 per annum for couples, and if the carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: tax is repealed there will be an average benefit per household in Australia of some $550. That

Speaker: NA
Text: will vary according to the configuration of the household, but none the less that would be an

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage for pensioners as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: A division having been called in the House of Representatives-

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 11:41 to 12:02

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Now, I can just wrap up in summary by saying that for pensioners, the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension will continue to increase. It will go up twice a year in March and September of each

Speaker: NA
Text: year. The pensioner supplement will continue and pensioners will continue to get paid the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: energy supplement. And if the Labor Party would get out of the way they would have a major

Speaker: NA
Text: saving through the repeal of the carbon tax.

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: Jagajaga) (12:02): I just draw the minister's attention to the remarks that

Speaker: NA
Text: he made on Gold Coast ABC radio, where it he actually said that he is making changes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner supplement and is actually seeking to remove it. So either the minister does not

Speaker: NA
Text: know what he is talking about-

Speaker: NA
Text: A government member interjecting-

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: I am actually quoting the minister on ABC radio on the Gold Coast.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now, obviously-

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Randall): Order! The member for Jagajaga is on her feet

Speaker: NA
Text: and she is entitled to be heard in silence.

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: The minister has already indicated that he does not understand the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget, and he has just tried to say, as he said in question time this week, that pensioners are

Speaker: NA
Text: better off under this government. I have to say to the minister that that will come to haunt

Speaker: NA
Text: him. The Assistant Minister for Social Services, Senator Fifield, actually said in Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: estimates just a little while ago, 'The decision to cut the indexation of the pension was put in

Speaker: NA
Text: place in an effort to slow the rate of pension increase.'

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure the minister is aware of the report done by the Australian Council of Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Service that shows that pensioners will be around $80 a week worse off over the next 10

Speaker: NA
Text: years. That is $80 a week over 10 years and, of course, that is because, as the minister himself

Speaker: NA
Text: knows-

Speaker: NA
Text: A government member interjecting-

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: I will just remind the minister of a quote I have from him from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hansard of 20 September 2011 about the importance of using male total average weekly

Speaker: NA
Text: earnings to index pensions instead of using the CPI. At that time the minister-though he was

Speaker: NA
Text: not the minister then-said, 'This enabled pensioners to keep ahead of cost-of-living

Speaker: NA
Text: increases.' Exactly right. The minister got it back in 2011. Now, of course, what we see in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget papers on page 203 is that the government is going to take $449 million off

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners. That is what the budget papers say, and this was confirmed just yesterday by

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Cormann when he said that the budget cuts will result in a cut to the pension.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question to the minister is: who is right-the budget papers, which say a cut to the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension of $449 million; Senator Cormann, who says that the cuts will result in a reduction in

Speaker: NA
Text: the rate of increase to the pension; or Senator Fifield, saying that the cuts to the indexation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the pension have been put in place in an effort to slow the rate of pension increase? I would

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest to the minister that all of those comments by his colleagues are correct. What is the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister going to say to correct the misleading comments that he made on ABC radio and that

Speaker: NA
Text: he made in the parliament this week?

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Menzies-Minister for Social Services) (12:06): The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member opposite should quote the entire radio interview and not excerpts from it, because if

Speaker: NA
Text: she quotes the entire radio interview she will see that I pointed out when I came back to that

Speaker: NA
Text: matter that it was the senior supplement. So she should be more accurate in what she says. I

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: ask this question rhetorically: if it is good enough for the Labor Party when in government to

Speaker: NA
Text: index family tax benefit part A by the CPI why is it not appropriate to index pensions and

Speaker: NA
Text: other payments by the CPI as well? There is a great deal of hypocrisy-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Macklin: I rise on a point of order. This is an opportunity for us to ask questions about

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget. The point of order is that these budget papers-which is what this is all about-

Speaker: NA
Text: says that there is a cut of $449 million. That is a cut to the pension, and it is time the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: faced up to it.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The member for Jagajaga is reiterating the question; it is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order.

Speaker: Mr Nikolic
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker, if I could, I would like to respond. Yet again, the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Jagajaga stands up with these ridiculous debating points.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Resume your seat, Member for Bass. That is not a point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order either. Does the minister wish to continue?

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Yes. First of all, she is inaccurate about the quotation in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: radio interviews. Secondly, the Labor Party come in here feigning indignation about indexing

Speaker: NA
Text: payments to the CPI when they themselves in government, when-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Macklin interjecting-

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: the person on the other side interjecting was the relevant minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: indexed family tax benefit part A by the CPI. That is the reality.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Macklin interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Minister, please resume your seat. This is not going to satisfy

Speaker: NA
Text: any elicitation of information if we have a continual argy-bargy across the chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Macklin interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Member for Jagajaga, you have asked your question. I ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister to resume when there is silence.

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: The Labor Party and the member who was just speaking continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: argue mischievously that this government are going to cut pensions, that we are reducing

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions. Can I point out to the honourable member opposite that, in March this year-and as

Speaker: NA
Text: far as I recall we were in government in March of this year-the age pension increased by

Speaker: NA
Text: $15.70 for a single pensioner. How can an increase be a cut? This reminds me of Lewis

Speaker: NA
Text: Caroll-this is Alice in Wonderland stuff coming from the honourable member opposite. In

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor language, a $15.70 increase for single pensioners is somehow a cut and an $11.90

Speaker: NA
Text: increase for each on a couple pension is somehow a cut. Go out on the street and ask ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, 'If we give you an extra $11.90, is that an increase or a decrease?' The reality is it

Speaker: NA
Text: is going to be an increase.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I have learnt the rule that we are not to use props in this place or the other place.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: I have already ruled and asked the member for Jagajaga not to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue using props, and I hope she takes that admonition.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: What was the indexation for the $11.90 increase for each pensioner in a

Speaker: NA
Text: couple and the $15.70 increase for single pensioners in March? CPI, the consumer price

Speaker: NA
Text: index. The increase that occurred in March occurred according to the consumer price index.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are saying that in the future we propose to index this, as the Labor Party did when in

Speaker: NA
Text: government, for family tax benefit part A according to the consumer price index. The Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party are running around this country trying to scare pensioners by saying that there is going

Speaker: NA
Text: to be no increase in the age pension. There was an increase in the age pension three months

Speaker: NA
Text: ago and there will be another one in another three months time. This great lie from the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party will be found out when pensioners get their next increase in September.

Speaker: Mr NIKOLIC
Text: Bass) (12:11): Before I ask the minister a question I want to reflect on the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Jagajaga's recent visit to Launceston where she continued her all-scare-and-no-

Speaker: NA
Text: substance campaign about concessions for pensioners-subsequently found to be false with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Premier of Tasmania saying that the Commonwealth contribution was only relatively

Speaker: NA
Text: small and would be covered in full. She talked to pensioners in Bass about pension cuts that

Speaker: NA
Text: were not true. Yet again we saw the member for Jagajaga engaging in her mendacious

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign, which is all scare and no substance. We see it on display again.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Randall): Order! We have a question coming. He has

Speaker: NA
Text: five minutes.

Speaker: Mr NIKOLIC
Text: If I could just thank the minister. During almost all of the 43rd Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: I was a full-time candidate down in Bass and his door was always open to talk about issues of

Speaker: NA
Text: substance. One of the issues we talked about and that I campaigned strongly on before the last

Speaker: NA
Text: election that always attracted a great deal of interest in northern Tasmania was indexation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the income thresholds for the Commonwealth seniors health card. I can recall talking to large

Speaker: NA
Text: groups of people, including with people from the Association of Independent Retirees. There

Speaker: NA
Text: was a great deal of interest in this issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister's office staff were always very welcoming and were ready to provide us with

Speaker: NA
Text: details in relation to these matters. I was able to report to the Association of Independent

Speaker: NA
Text: Retirees that the coalition had made a very strong commitment to index the income thresholds

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Commonwealth seniors card. If I recall correctly, we made the same strong

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment at both the 2010 and 2013 elections. How refreshing to see that that promise has

Speaker: NA
Text: translated to a budgeted measure in this year's budget. This measure improves the lives of

Speaker: NA
Text: many Australian senior citizens and it does so in a way that is intended to be fair, clear and

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent. I know the government is being as generous as it can be at this time, given the

Speaker: NA
Text: wider national social context of strong fiscal restoration and recovery.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Macklin interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Member for Jagajaga, please!

Speaker: Mr NIKOLIC
Text: It is necessary that we engage in a process of strong fiscal recovery,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially after a government that delivered $191 billion in deficits in their six years of

Speaker: NA
Text: government and $123 billion of deficits projected across the forward estimates. We borrow $1

Speaker: NA
Text: billion every month just to pay the interest on our debt. That is why we have to engage in that

Speaker: NA
Text: strong process of fiscal restoration and recovery.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Our indexation promise is reflective of a government that has both a heart and a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: social conscience. It is matched by a strong desire to help, assist and support all seniors, both

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners and self-funded retirees alike. Our decision to index the Commonwealth seniors

Speaker: NA
Text: health card is important in my electorate of Bass but will no doubt resonate across the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Does the minister have any estimate of how many people will specifically benefit from this

Speaker: NA
Text: measure and how many new cardholders the government expects over the years as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: this measure?

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Menzies-Minister for Social Services) (12:14): I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bass for his comments and his questions. Indeed, it was my pleasure to spend some time with

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Bass during the time leading up to his successful election. I wish him great

Speaker: NA
Text: success and longevity in continuing to represent the constituents of Bass. I look forward to

Speaker: NA
Text: working with him for many years into the future to ensure that the good citizens of Bass are

Speaker: NA
Text: well and truly represented in this place.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yes, I can say to the member for Bass this measure has been budgeted for. The estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: are that by 2018 there will be nearly 27,000 additional cardholders because of these measures.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is interesting the Labor Party is very silent on this measure. There is reason for that-in

Speaker: NA
Text: their whole six years in government they did not index it once. No wonder there is silence

Speaker: NA
Text: coming from the other side.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Macklin interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The member for Jagajaga's comments are unhelpful.

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: So 27,000 additional cardholders benefit under this measure. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: something which is to the advantage of many senior Australians and something which, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure, the member for Bass and the other members of the chamber-on this side at least-are

Speaker: NA
Text: very proud of.

Speaker: Mr NEUMANN
Text: Blair) (12:16): I was recently in the member for Bass's electorate and

Speaker: NA
Text: about 100 people were worried about things like senior supplements, age pensions and aged

Speaker: NA
Text: care. There were 100 people in the Launceston town hall. I do not think there would be many

Speaker: NA
Text: votes for him at the next election when it comes to those people.

Speaker: NA
Text: My question is to the minister on aged care. Minister, one of the first things you did when

Speaker: NA
Text: you came to power was to disable-

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! Member for Blair, I cannot hear your question. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is disorder. I would ask everybody to be silent so we can hear the member for Blair.

Speaker: Mr NEUMANN
Text: the workforce supplement, which had been accessed to the tune of about

Speaker: NA
Text: $100 million by aged-care providers. The supplement was for consultation and negotiation in

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with aged-care sector to make sure that we had the workforce of the future with

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate remuneration for nurses, carers, IT professionals and administrators of the aged

Speaker: NA
Text: care-sector. Minister, one of the first things I would like you to do is explain how you will

Speaker: NA
Text: address the growing pressures in the aged-care workforce. We assume you know about the

Speaker: NA
Text: 2010 intergenerational report which showed we need a 300 per cent increase in workers to

Speaker: NA
Text: care for our ageing population by 2050. There are low wages, a lack of career pathways and a

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of professional development being experienced by the sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I am eager to know how your government intends to ensure the workforce is there. We see

Speaker: NA
Text: a 25 per cent turnover in this sector; about 96 per cent of the people working in the sector are

Speaker: NA
Text: 45 years of age and older; and about 75 per cent are from migrant backgrounds with 35 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent having lived in Australia for only five years or less. Minister, would you please explain

Speaker: NA
Text: how giving the workface supplement to aged-care providers with no conditionalities on

Speaker: NA
Text: salaries, professional development, career paths or training will have anything to do with

Speaker: NA
Text: addressing these alarming workforce concerns? Ian Yates, from the Council of the Ageing,

Speaker: NA
Text: stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: Giving aged-care providers back the aged care workforce supplement over five years will do nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: for the development of the aged care workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, in February this year you met with stakeholders in what was the forerunner to the

Speaker: NA
Text: aged-care sector committee. You said you would undertake a stock take of workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: development projects. I ask the minister to provide details of that stock take and outline which

Speaker: NA
Text: projects have been cut in the budget, which you intend to propose to cut and which will

Speaker: NA
Text: remain. How will you address these specific concerns and additional pressures the sector is

Speaker: NA
Text: experiencing in regional and rural areas?

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like the minister to outline what alternatives to removing all conditionality

Speaker: NA
Text: were considered by the government. What recommendations did the aged-care sector

Speaker: NA
Text: committee make to you? Further, Minister, you answered none of my questions on modelling

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning the aged care payroll tax supplement and addressed none of the issues I raised

Speaker: NA
Text: previously except to say that payroll tax was a matter for the states. In fact, your government

Speaker: NA
Text: has breached the long-held bipartisan approach to the issue of competitive neutrality in the

Speaker: NA
Text: aged-care sector in an unsurprising move, I would say, because your government has had no

Speaker: NA
Text: regard for the aged-care sector since it has been elected.

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Menzies-Minister for Social Services) (12:20): The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member opposite has a very short memory. As I recall-and I was about and he was not-it

Speaker: NA
Text: was the Howard government that actually moved the very substantial changes to aged care in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. It took it out of a cottage industry and into the modern, sophisticated sector that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: today. I encourage the honourable member opposite to have perhaps a closer check with the

Speaker: NA
Text: history of what has happened in this regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: Coming to the question of the Aged Care Workforce Supplement, I can tell the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member opposite that the five years from 2013-14, $1.5 billion will be redirected to providers

Speaker: NA
Text: through a number of measures. Firstly, a 2.4 per cent increase in care subsidies and grant

Speaker: NA
Text: payments for eligible aged-care programs from 1 July 2014. All programs previously eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: for the workforce supplement will receive this funding. These increases are on top of normal

Speaker: NA
Text: indexation and will replace payments that would have been available under the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce supplement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, a 20 per cent-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Neumann interjecting-

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Does the honourable member want to listen to the answer or not?

Speaker: Mr Neumann
Text: I want to know what answer you are-

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: I suggest you just be quiet and I will give you the rest of the answer!

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: A 20 per cent increase to the viability supplement will be provided to improve the capacity

Speaker: NA
Text: of over 950 services in regional, rural and remote areas to provide quality aged-care services.

Speaker: NA
Text: All services currently receiving the viability supplement will receive this increase.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thirdly, additional payments will also be made to providers who committed to wage

Speaker: NA
Text: increases under the previous workforce supplement and who are financially disadvantaged by

Speaker: NA
Text: the re-purposing of this funding and, fourthly, for funding already paid for the workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement in 2013-14 through the transitional arrangements. The government will also roll

Speaker: NA
Text: the conditional adjusted payment paid in residential care into basic care subsidies, including

Speaker: NA
Text: Aged Care Funding Instrument care subsidies. Providers will continue to receive the 8.75 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent as part of the basic subsidy but will no longer need to complete the annual declaration or

Speaker: NA
Text: annual staff training statements.

Speaker: NA
Text: We will strengthen and expand the positive aspects of the cap by ensuring that all providers

Speaker: NA
Text: in programs that will receive the 2.4 per cent funding increase will now participate in the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Aged Care Workforce Census and Survey, which occurs every three to four years.

Speaker: NA
Text: And from 2015-16, financial reporting and programs receiving the 2.4 per cent funding

Speaker: NA
Text: increase will be reviewed and, where relevant, strengthened based on advice from the Aged

Speaker: NA
Text: Care Financing Authority. For 2014-15, providers will be still be required to provide financial

Speaker: NA
Text: statements as per current arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: As to the workforce requirements, this government is well and truly aware of the workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements. The basic foundation of this budget is one which actually recognises the ageing

Speaker: NA
Text: of the population in Australia. It recognises the ageing of the population in Australia, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: is going to have a very significant impact on this country. Not only are there going to be

Speaker: NA
Text: larger numbers of older Australians, largely more dependent than those who are in the

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce, there is also going to be a shrinkage of the growth of the workforce in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you look at the major measures in this portfolio, for example, the measures to take the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension age up to 67 by 2023-which I admit the Labor Party was moving to-and to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue that trajectory to 70 by 2035 are a recognition of the ageing of the population.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the age pension was set in place in this country over a century ago -and there were

Speaker: NA
Text: questions about this earlier-average life expectancy was less than 60. As I recall, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: about 55 for men and about 59 for women. So this is recognition, if you like, of the major

Speaker: NA
Text: demographic shift-the seismic shift in the demography of this country-which will occur

Speaker: NA
Text: over the next 10 or 15 years. That is why we are doing things as we are in relation to the age-

Speaker: NA
Text: pension age in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is, equally, why we are saying to people under 30 that 'we expect you to earn or learn'. If

Speaker: NA
Text: you do not meet the exemptions, which means you are not a full-time parent, or you are not

Speaker: NA
Text: incapable of working for 30 hours or more a week, or you are not in training or in a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: other exemptions-in other words, if you are capable of working full-time-then we expect

Speaker: NA
Text: that you are in a job. But if you are not in a job and you are under 30, and you are not within

Speaker: NA
Text: the exemptions, then because of this demographic shift our expectation is that you should be

Speaker: NA
Text: in training to get the job that you can have in the future because we will need every worker

Speaker: NA
Text: we can find in the future. So far as the aged-care workforce is concerned, that is something

Speaker: NA
Text: which is continuing to be monitored by the expert advisory committee, which advises

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Fifield in that regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Randall): As we are moving from the Social Services

Speaker: NA
Text: section of this portfolio at 12.30 to the Human Services segment, out of goodwill I call the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Franklin, and the first person to be called to speak on Human Services will be

Speaker: NA
Text: from the government side.

Speaker: Ms COLLINS
Text: Franklin) (12:25): My questions relate to both, with a bit of a crossover, if

Speaker: NA
Text: that is okay. My question is about the Newstart measures for the under 30s, how they are to

Speaker: NA
Text: apply and what is going on with this measure. I am particularly concerned about the

Speaker: NA
Text: revelations in Senate estimates where the social services department confirmed that, with

Speaker: NA
Text: penalties, some people will actually be up to 11 months with no payment whatsoever. Can the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister confirm that that is the case and explain to me how those penalties have come about

Speaker: NA
Text: and how we end up with 11 months with no payment?

Speaker: NA
Text: I am also very particularly concerned about how this would apply to, say, a young woman

Speaker: NA
Text: under 30 who does not meet one of the exemptions but who finds herself in the early stages of

Speaker: NA
Text: pregnancy. Will she be exempt or will she face somewhere between six and 11 months of no

Speaker: NA
Text: payment whilst she is pregnant? What sort of analysis has the department or the government

Speaker: NA
Text: done of services that these people will need to rely on? I understand that there is some

Speaker: NA
Text: emergency relief money that has been quarantined but that this is not new money or

Speaker: NA
Text: additional money; it is actually existing money within the budget that has been put aside.

Speaker: NA
Text: What sorts of services and support are in place for these people to survive from six to 11

Speaker: NA
Text: months with no money, particularly pregnant young women who may be caught up in this

Speaker: NA
Text: measure? We are very concerned on this side of the chamber about how this will apply and I

Speaker: NA
Text: would appreciate the minister giving a detailed and frank answer.

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Menzies-Minister for Social Services) (12:27): As the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member opposite points out, there are a range of exemptions that apply to this earn-or-learn

Speaker: NA
Text: measure: those with a work capacity of less than 30 hours a week, principal carers or parents

Speaker: NA
Text: with 35 per cent or more care of a child, part-time apprentices, Disability Employment

Speaker: NA
Text: Services clients, and stream 3 and 4 job seekers under employment services. They are the

Speaker: NA
Text: ones who have the most difficulty in obtaining a job. So, as I said, this applies primarily to

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are capable of working full time-they are capable of working more than 30

Speaker: NA
Text: hours a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Collins interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! The member for Franklin has asked her question.

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: There are provisions that relate to pregnant women at the present time.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I recall those-but I am happy to come back to the honourable member with more detail-

Speaker: NA
Text: they relate to the six-week period prior to giving birth, where there are exemptions in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to the obligations of a person in those circumstances. Those provisions will continue to apply,

Speaker: NA
Text: but, if there is any further detail I can provide to the honourable member, I am happy to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide it after this.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Randall): It being almost 12.30, the Federation Chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: will now consider the Human Services segment of the Social Services portfolio in accordance

Speaker: NA
Text: with the agreed order of consideration.

Speaker: Mr NIKOLIC
Text: Bass) (12:28): I again follow up with the minister on the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: seniors health card. The indexation of income thresholds for the card is obviously something

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that seniors advocates have been calling for for a long time. I am very pleased that the

Speaker: NA
Text: measures have been finally put into the budget, something that those opposite had six years to

Speaker: NA
Text: do and never did. These measures will benefit seniors every year into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: One other issue that has been brought up consistently within my electorate is the portability

Speaker: NA
Text: of this card. Many self-funded retirees travel overseas to see friends and family and, despite

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that they do not receive income support payments, they are still limited to six weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: before their card gets cancelled. That means that they have to reapply. It is a fairly long,

Speaker: NA
Text: bureaucratic process, I am told, and results in some administrative overhang that, frankly,

Speaker: NA
Text: many think is not necessary. I would be interested to know: has the government considered

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter of extending the portability period of the Commonwealth Seniors Health Card in

Speaker: NA
Text: this budget?

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Menzies-Minister for Social Services) (12:29): Again, I commend the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bass for his interest on behalf of constituents in his electorate in relation to this

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstance. Indeed, we have had representations about this matter and have taken those

Speaker: NA
Text: representations into consideration. As a result of that, we have announced some changes in

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget. Indeed, as I recall, one of the bills that were introduced into the parliament this

Speaker: NA
Text: morning covers this matter. Portability will be increased from six weeks, as it currently is, to

Speaker: NA
Text: 19 weeks in the budget legislation. That is more than a threefold increase in the portability

Speaker: NA
Text: time, going from six to 19 weeks, and that will commence from 1 January 2015. So, from the

Speaker: NA
Text: beginning of next year, there will be this increased portability period which will benefit those

Speaker: NA
Text: people in that situation. It promotes greater certainty in their circumstances, and it reduces red

Speaker: NA
Text: tape for the government, so it is a win-win situation both for those who are the recipients of

Speaker: NA
Text: this increased portability and for the government in terms of reducing red tape and the

Speaker: NA
Text: bureaucracy in relation to this matter. It acknowledges the contribution that self-funded

Speaker: NA
Text: retirees have made to this nation, the fact that they have saved and worked throughout their

Speaker: NA
Text: entire lives. Self-funded retirees are a minority of the people in retirement in Australia. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the reality of the situation. This is a modest measure, indeed, but nonetheless a measure which

Speaker: NA
Text: seeks to recognise their great contribution over a long period of time.

Speaker: Dr CHALMERS
Text: Rankin) (12:31): I want to clarify some matters for a lot of people in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate who will be showing up at Centrelink offices and other government offices

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the electorate. I have a low-SES community, and a lot of people show up in

Speaker: NA
Text: person, so this has relevance to the Human Services part of the portfolio as well as the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Services part of the portfolio. I remind the minister that ACOSS described this budget as a

Speaker: NA
Text: budget to divide the nation, and I also remind him that this year there has been a really

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial drop-off in consumer confidence. Part of the reason for the drop-off in consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence was that the minister was running around the country, really from Christmas

Speaker: NA
Text: onwards, talking about some sort of welfare crisis in the country, and a lot of people in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate certainly take deep offence at that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Nikolic interjecting-

Speaker: Dr CHALMERS
Text: There is not a budget crisis either. These sorts of matters are probably

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond the member for Bass, Deputy Speaker, but let me try and explain it to you anyway.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, I am interested in particular by the HILDA Survey that was put out by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne institute very recently, which showed that all the language around the welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: crisis in this community is rubbish. It was just designed to scare people, to concoct this budget

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: emergency that does not exist, this big con, so that you can swing the axe harder at people in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate by constructing this fake emergency, this welfare crisis. I remind him that

Speaker: NA
Text: HILDA said that, in 2001, 23 per cent of working age people in Australia received a welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: payment each week. In 2011, that had dropped to 18½ per cent. That is one fact. The other

Speaker: NA
Text: fact is that welfare spending in Australia accounted for just 8.6 per cent of GDP in 2013,

Speaker: NA
Text: compared to the OECD average of 13 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: So my first question is: why does the minister think he knows more than the credible

Speaker: NA
Text: people who put together the HILDA Survey? On what planet is this minister more credible

Speaker: NA
Text: than the people who put together the HILDA Survey? That is my first question. The second

Speaker: NA
Text: one relates to this whole thing-and, again, people will be fronting up to offices that he, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister, administers and asking this question. They heard the Prime Minister say that there

Speaker: NA
Text: would be no changes to pensions. Of course, there were. And now they hear the minister say

Speaker: NA
Text: and they hear the Prime Minister say that the pension has not been cut. My second question to

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister, then, is: if the pension has not been cut, why do you claim on page 203 of your

Speaker: NA
Text: own budget papers-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Nikolic interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Randall): Member for Bass, please!

Speaker: Dr CHALMERS
Text: This bloke should have someone read the budget papers to him. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: happy to do that. The quote is:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government will achieve savings of $449.0 million over five years by indexing pension and

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent payments and Parenting Payment Single by the Consumer Price Index (CPI).

Speaker: NA
Text: If there is no cut to the pension, where are you getting this $449 million from? If that figure is

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong, will you issue a correction?

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Menzies-Minister for Social Services) (12:34): There is a crisis all

Speaker: NA
Text: right. It is the crisis that your former employer, the member for Lilley, left this country in.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the reality of the crisis-a debt of $667 billion. Talk about a crisis-$667 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Chalmers interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Member for Rankin, you have asked your question.

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Were you the chief adviser for voodoo economics to your previous

Speaker: NA
Text: employer?

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Chalmers interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Member for Rankin, you have asked your question. If you

Speaker: NA
Text: want an answer, allow the minister to answer.

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: So far as the age pension is concerned, I refer the honourable member to

Speaker: NA
Text: page 69 of the portfolio budget statement, which shows, in relation to the age pension-this

Speaker: NA
Text: comes back to the member for Jagajaga's questions as well-under, 'Expenses for income

Speaker: NA
Text: support for seniors', age pension 2013-14, $39 billion; 2014-15, $41 billion; 2015-16, $44.5

Speaker: NA
Text: billion; 2016-17, $47.5 billion; 2017-18, $49.5 billion. In other words, it is going from $39

Speaker: NA
Text: billion to $49 billion, end of story.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Chalmers interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Member for Rankin, I did ask you to give the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: courtesy. The minister has concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare is welfare, the coalition believe that the best form of welfare is a job. A job brings

Speaker: NA
Text: something to a person's life that welfare can never do. It brings responsibility,

Speaker: NA
Text: accomplishment, social encouragement and, of course, financial benefits. These facts are true

Speaker: NA
Text: for all Australians and, in particular, for people with disability. Australians with disability

Speaker: NA
Text: experience significantly lower workforce participation rates than Australians without

Speaker: NA
Text: disability. This means that Australians with disability do not get to experience the benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: that a work life brings to one. Part of the reasons for this is that the DSP has been designed,

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively, as a set-and-forget payment. People with a disability apply for the DSP, they get it

Speaker: NA
Text: and then we forget about them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was pleased to see in the budget that the government is taking action to ensure that people

Speaker: NA
Text: with disability on the DSP are no longer forgotten. The members opposite asked me about my

Speaker: NA
Text: constituents. Unlike some of the members opposite, I came to this place directly from the real

Speaker: NA
Text: world. I used to act invariably for people at the lowest end of the socioeconomic spectrum. I

Speaker: NA
Text: spent the majority of my professional life working for people on legal aid. I want to give an

Speaker: NA
Text: example of one such constituent, whom I have maintained an excellent relationship with,

Speaker: NA
Text: whom I had the pleasure of acting for in Mount Gambier. For current purposes, I will

Speaker: NA
Text: fictionally refer to him as 'Vince'.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was acting for Vince in the Mount Gambier Magistrates Court. Courts, like this place, are

Speaker: NA
Text: open to the public and to other people about to appear before magistrates. On this occasion, I

Speaker: NA
Text: was presenting a guilty plea on behalf of Vince. Amongst other things, I made clear to the

Speaker: NA
Text: magistrate Vince's mild intellectual disability and that he was on the disability support

Speaker: NA
Text: pension. Vince was built like the proverbial. In the gallery at court, awaiting proceedings, was

Speaker: NA
Text: a significant employer in Barker. After I finished on that day, I got a phone call from this

Speaker: NA
Text: employer, who said, 'Tony, that lad of yours that you acted for today-does he want a job?' I

Speaker: NA
Text: said, 'Of course he does, but you've heard both his legal predicament and the issues with his

Speaker: NA
Text: intellectual disability.' This employer said to me, 'Tony, I'm happy to offer him a job.' I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to report that that individual, many years later, remains in that employment. From

Speaker: NA
Text: time to time, we catch up and he says to me, 'You know, I never thought I'd work. I thought

Speaker: NA
Text: I'd be on the disability support pension my whole life.'

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an example of two things: some people who are on the disability support pension,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly people under the age of 35, as Vince was, have the capacity to work, but, more

Speaker: NA
Text: importantly, it indicated to me that there are employers who are ready, willing and able to

Speaker: NA
Text: offer employment to people with disability and give to them the dignity of employment that I

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to. So, Minister, I ask this question: could you outline the government's policy to

Speaker: NA
Text: improve the social and economic participation of people with disability in our community?

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Menzies-Minister for Social Services) (12:39): I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Barker for his question, and I commend him on his humanitarian outlook, which I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: very impressed with, both in terms of his past life as a lawyer in Mount Gamier, and in the

Speaker: NA
Text: qualities that he brings to his representation of the people of Barker. Indeed, I recall that

Speaker: NA
Text: during last year's Pollie Pedal I had a forum with the Prime Minister and with a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: disabled people and young carers in Barker. One of the announcements in the budget-of

Speaker: NA
Text: bursaries for young carers-directly arose out of that meeting that we had in Mount Gambier

Speaker: NA
Text: in the member's electorate just on a year ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Representations like those that the member for Barker brings to this place about real issues

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning real people are things which we in this government are listening to, and we will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to do so. I was in the electorate of Logan in southern Brisbane last week, where I

Speaker: NA
Text: saw a very impressive operation employing disabled people, where a person who had worked

Speaker: NA
Text: in the abattoirs there had set up a commercial lawn-mowing business. All the people

Speaker: NA
Text: employed in that commercial lawn-mowing business are disabled. In that operation he

Speaker: NA
Text: employs something like a dozen or 15 people driving commercial lawnmowers. He has vast

Speaker: NA
Text: contracts throughout the area for councils, parks and gardens, and things like that. All of those

Speaker: NA
Text: young people, under the age of 35, had moved from being on the disability support pension,

Speaker: NA
Text: onto full-time employment. That just shows that, if we have the desire, there is a way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which we can assist many disabled people.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I meet with disabled people around this country-as we all have, over a long period

Speaker: NA
Text: of time-they invariably say that they would like to work. People want to participate. They

Speaker: NA
Text: want to be part of the life of this country. They want to be part of the economic life of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. So we need to find ways to encourage them to do that.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the measures in this budget is aimed directly at doing that. We are talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: young people under the age of 35, who are on the DSP and who are capable of working more

Speaker: NA
Text: than seven or eight hours a work-so they can do some work-who are not manifestly

Speaker: NA
Text: disabled. We are not referring to people who quite clearly cannot work but people who are

Speaker: NA
Text: capable, maybe, of doing some part-time work. In the past there has been a requirement that

Speaker: NA
Text: they have a participation plan but there was no requirement for them to follow it up. There

Speaker: NA
Text: was no requirement to go and do some work experience if that was what was in the

Speaker: NA
Text: participation plan. There was no requirement to undertake some form of training if that was

Speaker: NA
Text: what was in the participation plan. So in this measure we are proposing that people on DSP,

Speaker: NA
Text: under 35, who are capable of doing some part-time work, should have a participation plan and

Speaker: NA
Text: that we should follow up that participation plan with them. In that way we would encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: them to get into work if that is what they are capable of.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is not going to affect their DSP, so they will still have that safety net. I remember the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes we made back in 2005 in relation to DSP. One of the things that people were

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned about was that if employment did not work out for them the safety net would still

Speaker: NA
Text: be there. That is something which I think is very important in this regard.

Speaker: Ms ROWLAND
Text: Greenway) (12:43): The items I would like to raise, please, relate to

Speaker: NA
Text: clarifying the status and delineation of some specific grants that fall within the minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: purview. As I am sure the minister is well aware, some of these programs have moved

Speaker: NA
Text: between portfolios-possibly between Human Services, Social Services and Immigration.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have had the pleasure of travelling around many parts of the country visiting a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: migrant resource centres and settlement service providers, and I am sure we all agree that

Speaker: NA
Text: these organisations do outstanding work in our community, particularly in helping new

Speaker: NA
Text: arrivals establish themselves in our community. These organisations give the new arrivals not

Speaker: NA
Text: only a sense of inclusiveness but a very real connection to their new country. The strong

Speaker: NA
Text: message I am receiving from many of these organisations is that there is currently a lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: clarity or certainty in relation to some specific grants in the settlement and multicultural

Speaker: NA
Text: services space in particular. I have conveyed these concerns to the minister's parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: secretary. The response I received was pre the budget, which is why I am seeking an update

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: now. I wrote to the parliamentary secretary on 1 April stating that several multicultural

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations and migrant resource centres had contacted me expressing concern about the

Speaker: NA
Text: future of the Settlement Grants Program. I asked if the parliamentary secretary could confirm

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Settlement Grants Program was safe and would not be removed or have substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: amounts of funding cut from it in the upcoming budget. I said this information would be

Speaker: NA
Text: greatly appreciated so these organisations could be assured this program would continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: operate. The parliamentary secretary replied on 7 May. The primary paragraph in that

Speaker: NA
Text: response said: 'As you would be aware, the Australian government is committed to reviewing

Speaker: NA
Text: all spending across government. As soon as the Department of Social Services is in a position

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide advice on the future funding arrangements it will do so without delay.'

Speaker: NA
Text: I note there was a document that was released with the budget and that the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Services and the government are working on new ways of delivering grant funding in a

Speaker: NA
Text: range of areas. But I am sure, as the minister will appreciate, this uncertainty is not beneficial

Speaker: NA
Text: to many of these organisations around the country who are trying to plan for the future,

Speaker: NA
