Text: including for their existing staff and their future staffing levels. So I am seeking some clarity

Speaker: NA
Text: on these matters that can be communicated to these people. As an example, I note the

Speaker: NA
Text: Settlement Council of Australia commentary on the budget. The council said in a newsletter

Speaker: NA
Text: that its members were eagerly awaiting the announcement of the federal budget this year to

Speaker: NA
Text: gain clarity on the funding of settlement services within the portfolio of the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Services. DSS yesterday, in line with the budget announcement, released information

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled 'DSS Grants-A New Way of Working', which I have alluded to. The council says

Speaker: NA
Text: there are significant cuts to the Strengthening Communities program, which was concerning,

Speaker: NA
Text: and refers to DSS program information on the settlement services within the new grant

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements with the grant structure including longer grant terms, simplified reporting and

Speaker: NA
Text: acquittal processes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The DSS website states they will be offering extensions to the majority of existing service

Speaker: NA
Text: providers with agreements due to finish by 30 June 2014. The feedback I keep getting is about

Speaker: NA
Text: people not knowing, beyond that date, about what is going to happen from that time forward.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Settlement Council's newsletter says the council looks forward to working with the

Speaker: NA
Text: government and DSS to understand and implement the new grant arrangements within the

Speaker: NA
Text: settlement sector. It also says greater security of funding will enable the settlement sector to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to build on the proud record of the world's leading service delivery to newly arrived

Speaker: NA
Text: migrants and refugees. I would reiterate those remarks.

Speaker: NA
Text: My question to the minister is about the Strengthening Communities line item in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. Can the minister detail all the specific grant programs and funding items impacted by

Speaker: NA
Text: the $33 million cut to the Strengthening Communities line item as stated on page 98 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Services portfolio budget statement? As I said, many stakeholders are saying it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: clear to them what individual line items are included in that funding envelope so that they can

Speaker: NA
Text: plan for the future, particularly beyond this financial year.

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Menzies-Minister for Social Services) (12:48): What we have sought

Speaker: NA
Text: to do with program grants is to reduce the number of areas so that a smaller number of areas

Speaker: NA
Text: include all the various program grants in the future. In relation to settlement services, they

Speaker: NA
Text: will continue. Indeed, the funding for future years will be greater than it has been for this

Speaker: NA
Text: year, which you will see if you look again at page 98 of the portfolio budget statement which

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: you referred to. Settlement services are safe as part of the change bringing settlement services

Speaker: NA
Text: and multicultural matters from the immigration department into the Department of Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Services. This is the new structure, if I can be permitted for a moment to show this to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member, and we can provide a copy of it if the honourable member does not have

Speaker: NA
Text: it. It shows quite clearly that settlement services is part of this new structure. What we are

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to do is to reduce red tape to cut down and make more efficient the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: programs are operating.

Speaker: NA
Text: My recollection is that the grants round under DSS will open on 19 June this year, so there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be the opportunity for organisations to apply for grants under that. Part of what we are

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to do, not immediately in every area but over time, is to have grants that go for a longer

Speaker: NA
Text: time in terms of years so there is a great deal more certainty for the organisations and the staff

Speaker: NA
Text: employed by those organisations in the future.

Speaker: Ms ROWLAND
Text: Greenway) (12:50): Thank you for that, Minister. My question was that

Speaker: NA
Text: I would just like to know-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Randall): You cannot have supplementaries.

Speaker: Ms ROWLAND
Text: My question was what the specific items-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: No, sorry. You cannot ask a further question.

Speaker: Ms ROWLAND
Text: It is the same question.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: No, you have asked your question in your time.

Speaker: Ms HENDERSON
Text: Corangamite) (12:50): The National Disability Insurance Scheme is

Speaker: NA
Text: arguably one of the most significant programs in the history of the Australian government. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is with great celebration in my community in Geelong and in Colac that we have begun to roll

Speaker: NA
Text: out the NDIS.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, I was in Colac on Friday and visited the new office of the Colac National Disability

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Scheme and I met with the National Disability Insurance Agency area coordinator,

Speaker: NA
Text: Schree Barry. It really is wonderful to see the investment that is happening in the Colac

Speaker: NA
Text: community and across the Greater Geelong region in my electorate of Corangamite. I am a

Speaker: NA
Text: passionate supporter of the NDIS and this government is a passionate supporter of the NDIS.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have supported the NDIS at every step of the way and we remain committed to rolling out

Speaker: NA
Text: the NDIS in full.

Speaker: NA
Text: It really is fantastic to see that already the NDIA and the scheme that underpins the NDIA

Speaker: NA
Text: are helping some 2,700 people in the Barwon region in the trial that is being conducted in

Speaker: NA
Text: Barwon. In Colac alone there are about 340 people who have done their plans and are in the

Speaker: NA
Text: process of having these important disability services delivered, obviously, to people with a

Speaker: NA
Text: disability and their families.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is making a profound difference. There are six people working in Colac and there are

Speaker: NA
Text: another five people to come. The Colac Herald did a terrific little article about the new office

Speaker: NA
Text: that is opening today, and that is a great investment. So there is great excitement in Colac

Speaker: NA
Text: about the investment that the federal government is making in the National Disability

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, it was with great pride on 30 April that Prime Minister Tony Abbott, along with

Speaker: NA
Text: Premier Denis Napthine, officially opened the new national headquarters of the NDIA. The

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: NDIA will generate about 450 direct jobs in total for Geelong by 2019-20. Already there have

Speaker: NA
Text: been some 125 jobs created and that number is expected to rise to 300. So not only is this a

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful scheme for people with a disability, their families and their carers; it is also

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful for jobs in our region-it is so positive for jobs in our region.

Speaker: NA
Text: Already we are seeing what a difference this is making. A number of weeks ago I visited

Speaker: NA
Text: Kids Plus Foundation in Geelong. This is a wonderful agency, giving help to young children

Speaker: NA
Text: and to babies, principally those with cystic fibrosis and other similar conditions. Up until

Speaker: NA
Text: recently they have had no government funding and now with parents coming along with their

Speaker: NA
Text: NDIS packages under the trial they are getting incredible help. So it is wonderful to see what

Speaker: NA
Text: a significant difference this is making in the Corangamite community and across the Greater

Speaker: NA
Text: Geelong region.

Speaker: NA
Text: And let us not forget that from 1 July 2014, NDIS trial sites will be in place across all

Speaker: NA
Text: states and territories except Queensland. Queensland will join the NDIS in 2016. New NDIS

Speaker: NA
Text: trials in Western Australia, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory will

Speaker: NA
Text: assist around 14,000 people with permanent and significant disability, and more than 35,000

Speaker: NA
Text: people with disability will be assisted through the NDIS trials. Once fully rolled out, the

Speaker: NA
Text: NDIS will assist around 460,000 Australians with a permanent and significant disability, at a

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of $22 billion. So this is a wonderful initiative. I am so proud that we are funding this

Speaker: NA
Text: program and that we are getting on with the job of looking after people with a disability.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask the minister today to confirm the government's commitment to the NDIS over the

Speaker: NA
Text: forward estimates and confirm that this is a fully funded policy. Can the minister also confirm

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government has reversed the previous government's decision to apply the efficiency

Speaker: NA
Text: dividend to NDIS support packages and the second development fund?

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Menzies-Minister for Social Services) (12:55): I commend the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Corangamite for her great interest in the NDIS-the National Disability

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Scheme. The location of the NDIA-the authority which is responsible for the

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme-is in Geelong. Her electorate of Corangamite includes part of the great city of

Speaker: NA
Text: Geelong, a very impressive and booming city in Victoria as far as a number of these sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: services is concerned. Her consideration for this is something which is very significant.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Corangamite talked about Colac. I travel everywhere by bike, and the last

Speaker: NA
Text: time I was in Colac I was on my bike as well. Indeed, I met with a group of carers and a group

Speaker: NA
Text: of people interested in disability there. We met at one of the motels in Colac on a Saturday or

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunday morning. There was a large group of people there who were very concerned about

Speaker: NA
Text: these issues regarding disability. On that occasion the Prime Minister and I spent some time

Speaker: NA
Text: with them listening to their stories and what they were concerned about. This was at a time

Speaker: NA
Text: before the NDIS had actually been thought of and brought into operation. It is for those sorts

Speaker: NA
Text: of people, their families, their carers and their friends that the NDIS is a scheme whose time

Speaker: NA
Text: has come.

Speaker: NA
Text: I pay tribute to the previous government for their commitment to the NDIS. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: something that has been bipartisan in Australia. It is one of those things which happens only

Speaker: NA
Text: every so often in this country where a major social change has come about. We are in the

Speaker: NA
Text: throes of the implementation of it. It is going to take a number of years. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member talked about the trials which are occurring in the Barwon region in Victoria and

Speaker: NA
Text: elsewhere around the country. The whole purpose of those trials is to provide us with the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: information that can help us to roll out this scheme in a way that will work for the people that

Speaker: NA
Text: is aimed to work for.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Productivity Commission identified some hundreds of thousands of people who this

Speaker: NA
Text: was intended to apply to. The reality in Australia is that, if you are injured as a result of a

Speaker: NA
Text: vehicular accident, state accident compensation schemes around the country apply to those

Speaker: NA
Text: people. But, if you have a disability through some other cause-through no fault of your

Speaker: NA
Text: own-the reality was that you were not in the same situation as an individual or as family and

Speaker: NA
Text: friends of people injured in that sort of accident. This is aimed at providing equality of

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment, if I can put it that way, and equality of outcomes in terms of the care that can be

Speaker: NA
Text: provided for people who have a disability.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a very important development and it is going to take time. There is a parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: committee that oversees this process, which the Labor Party, the coalition and others are

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in, because we believe-and we argued this for a long time in the parliament-that

Speaker: NA
Text: this is too important to just be the subject of partisan politics. That is why when we were in

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition we threw our support behind this proposal and that is why now in government we

Speaker: NA
Text: are fully committed to the rollout of it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Corangamite mentioned the efficiency dividend. The reality is that there

Speaker: NA
Text: was an efficiency divided applied to the NDIS and this was something which we thought was

Speaker: NA
Text: inappropriate in relation to a commitment to rolling out this scheme. In this budget, the

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiency dividend of $44.9 million-which was effectively a cut to the NDIS-has been

Speaker: NA
Text: reversed. I think that is a clear indication that this government is fully committed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: rollout of the NDIS.

Speaker: NA
Text: If anybody anywhere in Australia ever suggests that the coalition is not committed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: NDIS, they are, frankly, telling porkies. We are committed to the NDIS. We will see it rolled

Speaker: NA
Text: out. We do not underestimate the difficulties involved in the rollout of this scheme. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: why the trial sites are so important to provide the learnings for us over the next few years as

Speaker: NA
Text: to how this can best work. Already there are some results in from the first couple of quarters

Speaker: NA
Text: from various trial sites around the country. Some of those results have been mixed. What we

Speaker: NA
Text: have to learn from that is whether or not, for example, the results which are not as good as we

Speaker: NA
Text: might have thought are simply a product of the start-up of a new system and whether or not

Speaker: NA
Text: these things will be ironed out over time or whether they are longer term issues that need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed in terms of how the system is put into operation. But I assure the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Corangamite, who is a great supporter of the NDIS, and all members of this House and the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament and the people of Australia that the coalition is 100 per cent committed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation of the National Disability Insurance Scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proceedings suspended from 13:00 to 15:59

Speaker: NA
Text: Education Portfolio

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure, $1,329,516,000

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Ewen Jones): The question is that the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure be agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms KATE ELLIS (Adelaide) (16:00): To clarify, I understand that we will be covering

Speaker: NA
Text: higher education, schools and early childhood in the next hour and a half. We propose that we

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: will commence with higher education for the first 45-odd minutes before moving to schools

Speaker: NA
Text: and child care.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have a number of questions to put to the minister about these appalling attacks on our

Speaker: NA
Text: university and higher education sector. Of course, the Australian public know all too well that

Speaker: NA
Text: they were promised no cuts to education, but in higher education alone we know that this

Speaker: NA
Text: package is such a shambles that it is cutting some $5.8 billion from higher education. We also

Speaker: NA
Text: know that, whilst the education minister repeatedly refers to expanding opportunities for

Speaker: NA
Text: 80,000 extra students, there is no new funding for 80,000 new students-not at all. What the

Speaker: NA
Text: government is planning to do is extend government subsidies to more students by spreading

Speaker: NA
Text: less money more thinly across a greater number of students. This is a preposterous policy

Speaker: NA
Text: position which the minister has put forward. We certainly welcome the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: reiterate some of the concerns which have been raised in the sector but also to ask some

Speaker: NA
Text: questions on how this will be implemented.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to share some of the views not just of students, parents and grandparents but of vice-

Speaker: NA
Text: chancellors within the sector already. We know that they have come out in waves against

Speaker: NA
Text: these higher education changes, arguing particularly that these changes will hurt their

Speaker: NA
Text: students. The Vice-Chancellor of the University of Adelaide, in the great electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide, which I am so lucky to represent, says that aspects of these changes are

Speaker: NA
Text: unworkable, they are unduly harsh and:

Speaker: NA
Text: The compounding interest here [means] we might deliver debts to students of $70,000, $80,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: $100,000 and no-one here wanted that.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have also, of course, seen the HECS architect, Dr Bruce Chapman, warning that changes

Speaker: NA
Text: could lead to profiteering and stating:

Speaker: NA
Text: If universities have price discretion they will all take it … and could actually end up charging more than

Speaker: NA
Text: what it actually costs-

Speaker: NA
Text: to deliver that education.

Speaker: NA
Text: The University of Canberra's vice-chancellor, Stephen Parker, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: I also think it is unethical for a generation of leaders who by and large benefited from free higher

Speaker: NA
Text: education to burden the generations behind them …

Speaker: NA
Text: The Swinburne University vice-chancellor trashed this package when she said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Deregulation will inevitably lead to much higher fees for our students. Over time, full fee deregulation

Speaker: NA
Text: will lead to a higher education system characterised by the 'haves' and the 'have nots'.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are many, many other stakeholders who have given damning appraisals of this

Speaker: NA
Text: ludicrous policy put forward by the education minister, but I will not take up the time of the

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber at this point to share all of these many quotes. What I will instead do is ask some

Speaker: NA
Text: questions of the minister, which I hope that he will be able to address in his next contribution.

Speaker: NA
Text: How does the government justify higher education deregulation in the face of so much

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition? Has the government done any modelling on the impact of deregulated higher fees

Speaker: NA
Text: on students and on the broader economy here in Australia? Does the government envisage

Speaker: NA
Text: universities will use the international student fee rate as their maximum rate and has this been

Speaker: NA
Text: included in modelling? If some universities charge much higher fees than other so-called less

Speaker: NA
Text: prestigious universities, does the government concede that this will lead to a two-tiered

Speaker: NA
Text: system and price students out of certain universities? Doesn't this challenge Australia's current

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: system of fair and equitable access to education? It is unthinkable that the government can, on

Speaker: NA
Text: the one hand, argue that some universities' fees may go up and, as they like to keep saying,

Speaker: NA
Text: that some universities' fees may go down and, on the other hand, not concede that this leads to

Speaker: NA
Text: our national system becoming a two-tiered system at least. I would like to know whether this

Speaker: NA
Text: is the minister's view? And, if not, what modelling has been conducted on the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: education sector, in Australia, that he can fall back on to guarantee that that will not be the

Speaker: NA
Text: case?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow minister's opening remarks were not so much a question as they were a political

Speaker: NA
Text: statement. But I will pick up some of the things that she said in her speech. I am sure then that

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the coalition might want to make a contribution and I will respond to those as

Speaker: NA
Text: well.

Speaker: NA
Text: The shadow minister asked a series of loaded questions. Let me explain a little bit about the

Speaker: NA
Text: education package in the budget. First of all, there are no cuts to education in this budget-

Speaker: NA
Text: none whatsoever. Over the next four years, higher education increases every year to the point

Speaker: NA
Text: where we will have $900 million more in spending over the next four years in higher

Speaker: NA
Text: education. And there are some elements of the new spending proposals that the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister did not touch on. Obviously, we were met with several funding cliffs when we came

Speaker: NA
Text: to power. The National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy was one of those

Speaker: NA
Text: funding cliffs where Labor had extended the scheme for 12 months and it was an ending

Speaker: NA
Text: program. We were faced with letting that program end or finding the money in the budget to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue it because of the very good work that NCRIS does. I am sure that the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide would agree that NCRIS is a very worthwhile scheme to support research

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure. I and, I am sure, the member for Adelaide, have visited some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: outstanding examples of where NCRIS is making a difference to research in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Well, we found that money and we continued to fund NCRIS into the future. We did the

Speaker: NA
Text: same thing with the Future Fellowships program, a program that typically is for mid-career

Speaker: NA
Text: researchers, to ensure that once they have passed through the early stages of being a

Speaker: NA
Text: researcher we do not lose them overseas, poached by excellent universities around the

Speaker: NA
Text: globe-that we can continue to use the skills that they are developing here in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Anyone who attended the Prime Minister's Science Awards at the end of last year would note

Speaker: NA
Text: that a number of the winners were mid-career researchers who had benefited under the Future

Speaker: NA
Text: Fellowships scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor again-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms MACTiernan: This won't lead to their mid-careers because you have cut off the

Speaker: NA
Text: resources-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise the member for Perth from her posters in the last election campaign. I do not think

Speaker: NA
Text: that she would want to be involved in any misleading or deceptive conduct cases. I think she

Speaker: NA
Text: would find herself to be on the wrong side of the law.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms MACTiernan interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaign? They look nothing like you!

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms MACTiernan interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Ewen Jones): Order!

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms MACTiernan interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms MACTiernan interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! The member for Perth! This is the Federation

Speaker: NA
Text: Chamber! The member for Adelaide was listened to in quiet and silence and you can listen to

Speaker: NA
Text: the answer in silence, thank you very much.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Future Fellowships program. I am sure she supports the Future Fellowships program, because

Speaker: NA
Text: I would imagine that UWA-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms MACTiernan interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Perth's electorate. It might be the member for Curtin's electorate, but I am sure she supports

Speaker: NA
Text: mid-career researchers being supported. And I am pleased to say that in the budget process I

Speaker: NA
Text: was able to secure the funds to keep the Future Fellowships program going into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, to clear up the first of the member for Adelaide's assertions about cuts to higher

Speaker: NA
Text: education: spending on higher education increases in this budget. The total higher education

Speaker: NA
Text: research international and agency spending over the next four years is $48.3 billion, and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing by $900 million. That is an enormous investment by the federal government in

Speaker: NA
Text: higher education and research because we very much value higher education and research.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have, of course, as part of the budget introduced higher education reforms. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: eight key elements and I will touch on a couple. I would have hoped that the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide would support the expansion of the demand-driven system to the sub-bachelor

Speaker: NA
Text: courses-the diplomas and the associate degrees-because that is a new spending measure

Speaker: NA
Text: that is costing the government money. It is costing us $371.5 million over three years. That

Speaker: NA
Text: will give, typically, low-SES students-first-generation university goers-an opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: go to university and to get that pathway into an undergraduate degree that will give them the

Speaker: NA
Text: chance to earn 75 per cent, on average, more over their lifetimes because they have a higher

Speaker: NA
Text: education qualification. So that is just one element of the budget measures. As my time has

Speaker: NA
Text: expired, I might turn to the others the next time I get an opportunity.

Speaker: Ms MACTIERNAN
Text: Perth) (16:10): I have a couple of questions I would like to ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister. It is about the funding cuts to the subsidies for different programs. I must say that I

Speaker: NA
Text: was quite stunned to see the extent of the cuts of the subsidy for both engineering and science.

Speaker: NA
Text: Both of these undergraduate courses have now sustained cuts of 28 per cent. That seems to be

Speaker: NA
Text: a very peculiar position to adopt at a time when I think we would all acknowledge that we

Speaker: NA
Text: need to really ramp up the skills that we have in the nation in engineering and in science. If

Speaker: NA
Text: we are to be a successful nation into the future we are really going to need to skill up in those

Speaker: NA
Text: particular areas. Could you tell us just what your thinking was and what you think the impact

Speaker: NA
Text: might be from these very, very significant cuts to those particular disciplines-bearing in

Speaker: NA
Text: mind that I think you would understand, Minister, that science graduates do not necessarily

Speaker: NA
Text: generate massive income. It is not as if we are going to be seeing enormous earning potential.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, with the 457 visas, even Australian engineering graduates are having trouble earning

Speaker: NA
Text: a decent living these days. I am really concerned about that. I would like you to address what

Speaker: NA
Text: you think and what impact you believe this will have on people electing to go into those areas

Speaker: NA
Text: and indeed the provision of those courses by universities.

Speaker: NA
Text: You were talking of the work you have done to increase the mid-career opportunities for

Speaker: NA
Text: graduates. Could you give us more explanation of why then you have so extensively ramped

Speaker: NA
Text: up the cost of the PhD and master's by research? We have seen a cut to that area of $173

Speaker: NA
Text: million. I understand that this now equates to very, very significant increases in costs to those

Speaker: NA
Text: PhD students. Okay, we have put a little bit of money into the mid-career, but what I am

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned about is that we have really made it much more challenging for people to come in

Speaker: NA
Text: and do undergraduate degrees in science and engineering and then at that next level-those

Speaker: NA
Text: that want to go on to masters and doctorates-are now seeing their fees increased

Speaker: NA
Text: substantially. That is obviously going to be a disincentive and disabler for those people who

Speaker: NA
Text: are not independently wealthy, like so many of the minister's colleagues, apparently. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: ask that you would address those two issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: for Perth asks about what I think will be the impact on universities of the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: deregulatory approach in the budget. The member for Perth has to understand that this is an

Speaker: NA
Text: entire package of reform. There are elements of it in which the taxpayers will be making

Speaker: NA
Text: savings. So the Commonwealth Grant Scheme will be reduced by 20 per cent. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: definitely true. There have to be trade-offs in the budget for expenses to the taxpayer versus

Speaker: NA
Text: savings to the taxpayer. So while we are, as I said before, increasing spending on things like

Speaker: NA
Text: NCRIS and Future Fellowships and the demand-driven system being expanded to the sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: bachelor courses and of course the Commonwealth Grant Scheme being expanded to the non-

Speaker: NA
Text: university higher education providers, there will be a cut of 20 per cent to the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Grant Scheme across the board. I refer the member to the fact that I have established two

Speaker: NA
Text: working groups. One of the working groups will be giving advice to me in the coming weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: about the technical aspects of the clustering arrangements that she talked about. I am looking

Speaker: NA
Text: forward to getting its response.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms MACTiernan: So you actually don't know what the impact will be.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Ewen Jones): Order! You have asked your question.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: young people will get the opportunity to go to university-a lot more, at least 80,000 more.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was the question asked by the member for Perth, and that is the answer. Eighty thousand

Speaker: NA
Text: more people will get to go to university and get the opportunity to improve their standard of

Speaker: NA
Text: living, their health, their longevity and their sophistication, if you like, through education, and

Speaker: NA
Text: they will get a 75 per cent, on average, increase in income. The taxpayer provides, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment, about 60 per cent of the cost of educating a student. The student provides about 40

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. After our reforms, the impact will be that we will be asking students to contribute

Speaker: NA
Text: about 50 per cent of the cost of their education. As Fred Hilmer, from the University of New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales, said, the government will not set these fees. The government will not decide

Speaker: NA
Text: how the universities determine their budgets, their costs and their fees. The universities will

Speaker: NA
Text: decide that.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Perth wants to continue to infantilise the universities. She wants to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to run the universities from Canberra in terms of the demand-driven system. She

Speaker: NA
Text: probably wants to return to the old system of caps on undergraduate courses. She wants to tell

Speaker: NA
Text: the universities how they can much they can charge and how many students they can enrol.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government's view is that we want to give universities the freedom to make these

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions themselves, to set their own fees and to enrol the number of students that they want

Speaker: NA
Text: in sub-bachelor courses and undergraduate degrees. The effect of that is a massive reform of

Speaker: NA
Text: higher education that will have two very significant impacts. Firstly, it will let more young

Speaker: NA
Text: people into higher education. This will particularly help low-SES families and first-generation

Speaker: NA
Text: university goers, because they typically use the sub-bachelor courses as a pathway to an

Speaker: NA
Text: undergraduate degree.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second big impact, which the Labor Party is also opposed to, is that it will give our

Speaker: NA
Text: universities the chance to achieve excellence. It will give our universities the chance to

Speaker: NA
Text: compete with their Asian competitors, the Asian universities, which are improving in quality

Speaker: NA
Text: all the time. We have an international education market, which at the moment is worth $15

Speaker: NA
Text: billion per annum. It was $19 billion under the Howard government. Labor managed to shrink

Speaker: NA
Text: that to $15 billion-quite an achievement in a growing economy-because they do not really

Speaker: NA
Text: support international education. We want to see our universities compete with their Asian

Speaker: NA
Text: counterparts. Five years ago, there were no Chinese universities in the top 200 universities in

Speaker: NA
Text: the world, in the Shanghai Jiao Tong index-none. There are now five universities from

Speaker: NA
Text: China in the top 200. Of the Australian universities, one more has entered the top 200, but all

Speaker: NA
Text: the others' rankings have fallen.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we do not give our universities the chance to achieve excellence, to compete with their

Speaker: NA
Text: Asian competitors, our international education market will fall and it will dry up. I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to be the minister that knows that danger is looming and not do anything about it. So

Speaker: NA
Text: I have made the decision to reform higher education to give more students the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: go to university and to free our universities to be the best they possibly can be and to have the

Speaker: NA
Text: best quality higher education system in the world.

Speaker: Ms SCOTT
Text: Lindsay) (16:18): I have a question for the Minister for Education. Firstly, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to give some context for the minister. As the minister would be aware, Lindsay is

Speaker: NA
Text: home to the University of Western Sydney, consisting of 40,000 students across six

Speaker: NA
Text: campuses, with its chancellery housed within my electorate of Lindsay. This great university

Speaker: NA
Text: prides itself on its vision:

Speaker: NA
Text: To be a university of international standing and outlook, achieving excellence through scholarship,

Speaker: NA
Text: teaching, learning, research and service to its regional, national and international communities,

Speaker: NA
Text: beginning with the people of Greater Western Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure you can see many parallels with what the minister is achieving in the budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: UWS is a very responsible university. It wants to encourage people right across Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney to learn and to enrol in tertiary education and has broadly welcomed the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: measures. As a response to the intense scare campaign conducted by those opposite, UWS has

Speaker: NA
Text: felt compelled to provide further confidence to their student community and has publicly

Speaker: NA
Text: come out to say that they will be freezing and grandfathering course costs to the student

Speaker: NA
Text: community. However, I would like to know how the minister's budget measures will

Speaker: NA
Text: overcome other potential barriers to accessing a tertiary education.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to advise the minister that Lindsay is the fourth youngest electorate in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. It is predominantly made up of many young, aspirational and hardworking families,

Speaker: NA
Text: working to provide a better future for their children, but there are elements of significant

Speaker: NA
Text: disparity in Lindsay. In Glenmore Park, for instance, in the south-west of the electorate, the

Speaker: NA
Text: median income for a couple with children is $2,474, which is higher than the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales average. Further, 33.5 per cent of people are attending some form of educational

Speaker: NA
Text: institution, be it primary, secondary or tertiary, and 11.1 per cent are currently enrolled in

Speaker: NA
Text: university or tertiary education. To the west of my electorate is North St Marys, about 13

Speaker: NA
Text: kilometres from Glenmore Park. The average income there of a household with children is

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,935, which is $539 per week less than in Glenmore Park and lower than the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales average. In North St Marys, 33.8 per cent of people are attending an academic

Speaker: NA
Text: institution. North St Marys is also home to a high school called Chifley College, which is the

Speaker: NA
Text: lowest SES school in the state: Chifley College Dunheven Campus has a lot of Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: children and also refugee children and has many, many challenges. Only 5.1 per cent of this

Speaker: NA
Text: community go on to tertiary education. Let me repeat: in Glenmore Park, 11.1 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: people are currently enrolled in tertiary education; in North St Marys, 5.1 per cent. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: despite North St Marys being closer to the local university campus.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, I understand that with a university education more opportunities become

Speaker: NA
Text: available and your earning potential is substantially higher. In fact, those students will go on

Speaker: NA
Text: to earn 75 per cent more on average than Australians who do not get a higher education

Speaker: NA
Text: qualification. I understand in low-socioeconomic regions there are a range of contributing

Speaker: NA
Text: factors and barriers to accessing education. However, with the disparity I have identified

Speaker: NA
Text: within my own electorate, I think there is a need to make a university education more

Speaker: NA
Text: accessible. Minister, the disparities between the two suburbs could not be clearer. My

Speaker: NA
Text: question is: how will the higher education reforms outlined in the budget increase

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for students in my electorate?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lindsay for her contribution. I can remind her that it was not very long ago that I

Speaker: NA
Text: was out in Western Sydney opening the University of Western Sydney College. Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Shergold, who is the Chancellor of the University of Western Sydney, is the chairman of one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the working groups that are advising the government on the legislative framework for the

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms that we handed down in the budget. He is doing an excellent job, as are all the vice-

Speaker: NA
Text: chancellors and educators who are assisting the government to bring about very far-reaching

Speaker: NA
Text: higher education reform. I can tell her that Greater Western Sydney will be one of the biggest

Speaker: NA
Text: winners from the government's higher education reforms.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the points that the member for Adelaide made before was that she tried to suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that somehow we would be stopping young people from being able to access university

Speaker: NA
Text: through these reforms. What she failed to mention, but I know that the community understand

Speaker: NA
Text: already, is that every single student, whether in Greater Western Sydney or in Walkerville in

Speaker: NA
Text: her electorate, will be able to borrow every single dollar up-front for the fees that they will

Speaker: NA
Text: pay to go to university. No student will be denied the opportunity to go to university because

Speaker: NA
Text: of cost-not one-because every single dollar can be borrowed from the taxpayer under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Higher Education Loan Program, which used to be the Higher Education Contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: Scheme introduced by Labor-by Minister Dawkins in the Keating and Hawke years-when

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: they had some policy consistency and some policy responsibility. That means that no matter

Speaker: NA
Text: how wealthy you are or how poor you are, you will have exactly the same opportunity to go

Speaker: NA
Text: to university in this country. That is why our system is so very different from the system in

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States. To compare the two is a very false comparison and is extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: misleading.

Speaker: NA
Text: It does shock me that, in the electorate of the member for Lindsay, Glenmore Park has 11.1

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent and North St Marys has 5.1 per cent of people enrolled in tertiary education. The

Speaker: NA
Text: University of Western Sydney is an extremely important part of the economic and social

Speaker: NA
Text: fabric of Greater Western Sydney, with its six campuses and it's very determined vision of

Speaker: NA
Text: spreading the benefits of university education to the demographic in that part of Sydney,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is a low-socioeconomic status demographic. Our reforms will mean that people in

Speaker: NA
Text: North St Marys who might not be as well prepared for university education as others and who

Speaker: NA
Text: typically use pathway courses into university will be able to do so because we are lifting the

Speaker: NA
Text: cap on those pathways courses, those diplomas and associate degrees. They will now be under

Speaker: NA
Text: the same demand-driven system as undergraduate degrees. It is costing the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayer to bring that about.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that the people in Western Sydney typically use diplomas and associate degrees

Speaker: NA
Text: that might be offered at places like the UWSCollege at the University of Western Sydney to

Speaker: NA
Text: train themselves to get the skills that are necessary to then go on and earn an undergraduate

Speaker: NA
Text: degree. The Kemp-Norton report that I commissioned earlier this year and that was handed

Speaker: NA
Text: down a couple of months ago said that students who had done those kinds of pathway courses

Speaker: NA
Text: were much less likely to drop out in the first year of an undergraduate degree and that 24 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of students who had not done those courses dropped out in the first year of an

Speaker: NA
Text: undergraduate degree.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I sat down to think about reform of higher education I decided that I wanted to

Speaker: NA
Text: establish an equitable higher education system that gave those people who were less likely to

Speaker: NA
Text: go to university a greater chance to go to university. When I was at school I assumed that I

Speaker: NA
Text: would go to university, and I did go to university because I went to an academic school and I

Speaker: NA
Text: had every single advantage that a young person could have. So when I sat down I did not

Speaker: NA
Text: decide to have a higher education system that advantaged people like me; I decided that I

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted a higher education system that advantaged people from low-SES backgrounds. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: why we are expanding the Commonwealth Grant Scheme to non-university higher education

Speaker: NA
Text: providers. That will help TAFEs educate more young people to get the same opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have had in life, to get the start that they need. That is the answer to the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Perth's questions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms KATE ELLIS (Adelaide) (16:28): Knowing that the minister has had a bit of trouble

Speaker: NA
Text: with some of the detail around the higher education policy-he is not quite clear on who it

Speaker: NA
Text: will affect and when it will affect them-I thought it would be worthwhile going through the

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts that are included in the higher education budget before asking the minister some

Speaker: NA
Text: questions on one particular one. We have seen in this budget some $5.8 billion in cuts to

Speaker: NA
Text: higher education and university research: $3.2 billion in cuts, by taking the scalpel to HECS,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's highly successful and internationally renowned income contingent contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: system; $1.9 billion in cuts to universities by reductions in government core subsidies; $202

Speaker: NA
Text: million in cuts by indexing university grants to CPI; $172 million in cuts to fund, promote and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: reward universities for enrolling low-SES students; $173 million in cuts for the training of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's research students, the scientists and academics of tomorrow; a $75 million cut to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Research Council; and a $31 million cut to the national regulator.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question I have is particularly about the consequences of these cuts. I want to focus on

Speaker: NA
Text: the $3.2 billion cut from HECS.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is clear the government does not know the consequences of this most radical

Speaker: NA
Text: transformation to our higher education system in Australia for 30 years, and we heard that in

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister's non-answer to the member for Perth's question about science and engineering

Speaker: NA
Text: students. We know that the government is flying blind when it comes to the impact of its

Speaker: NA
Text: higher education package on students and on their families. We know that the peak body,

Speaker: NA
Text: Universities Australia, has asked the government to rethink the design of loan repayments and

Speaker: NA
Text: its cuts to the sector. We also know that Bank of America Merrill Lynch chief economist Saul

Speaker: NA
Text: Eslake has warned of the consequences of higher interest rates on student loans, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: for women. Mr Eslake said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The prospect orfrepaying university loans whilst raising a family might deter women, while many other

Speaker: NA
Text: prospective students would weigh up the costs against the benefits of education.

Speaker: NA
Text: He stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: It would be irrational for people not to consider the cost in relation to their working life in the same way

Speaker: NA
Text: as when you borrow to buy a house.

Speaker: NA
Text: The changes to HECS will have a compounding effect on students paying extra in fees plus

Speaker: NA
Text: extra in HECS repayments and will start them off on their working lives with a huge debt

Speaker: NA
Text: burden hanging over their heads, a debt burden which I have absolutely no doubt will deter

Speaker: NA
Text: many people from taking up the opportunity of higher education.

Speaker: NA
Text: Universities Australia has modelled the potential costs of engineering and nursing degrees.

Speaker: NA
Text: They found that at the medium-fee increase scenario with a four per cent interest rate, an

Speaker: NA
Text: engineering graduate working full-time faces a HELP debt of between $98,952 and $113,169

Speaker: NA
Text: and would repay it over a period of 20 to 25 years. This is compared with $46,000 to $49,000

Speaker: NA
Text: debt and 14 to 18 years repayment under the existing arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know when we look at a nursing graduate that the estimates are equally frightening.

Speaker: NA
Text: The changes to HECS will force university graduates to pay more and to pay sooner. The

Speaker: NA
Text: threshold will be lowered, forcing graduates to pay sooner but will be coupled with increases

Speaker: NA
Text: on HECS bills from higher degrees and increased interest rates. Modelling done on the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes has been published in the Financial Review showing repayment amounts and times

Speaker: NA
Text: will soar, with a typical female taking up to 25 years to repay an engineering degree.

Speaker: NA
Text: My question to the minister is: will the government provide data based on the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: higher education system's modelling which they looked at before taking such a radical reform

Speaker: NA
Text: process? Will they provide the data on the effect of the latest fee hikes which were announced

Speaker: NA
Text: in the budget? What will the effect be on Australian students and students who will not

Speaker: NA
Text: become students as a result of these despicable measures?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: carefully to the member for Adelaide's latest contribution. I must say, I find it hard to believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that she can reconcile a statement that we are cutting higher education with the facts that are

Speaker: NA
Text: found in the budget papers that clearly indicate that far from cutting higher education, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing spending on higher education by $900 million over the forward estimates. And

Speaker: NA
Text: then I realised that it is possible that the member for Adelaide thinks that an incoming

Speaker: NA
Text: government simply spends on top of what the previous government did. It is possible that the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Adelaide thinks-and she gave a litany of particular programs-that the new

Speaker: NA
Text: government keeps all the previous government's programs and then just adds its own on top

Speaker: NA
Text: of that, which would obviously be pretty costly.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 2007, I think she will find that when Labor last, unhappily, won office for six years, they

Speaker: NA
Text: did not just leave the previous Howard government's policies in place and then just add their

Speaker: NA
Text: own on top. They removed many of the Howard government programs. The one in education

Speaker: NA
Text: that leaps to mind was the vouchers for literacy and numeracy. That was an extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: successful program for young people learning how to read and how to count.

Speaker: NA
Text: Putting that to one side, it can only be reconcilable with her complete lack of understanding

Speaker: NA
Text: of how government works in Australia. I will not get personal because the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide has tried to avoid being personal, but I would point out that she probably needs a bit

Speaker: NA
Text: of a refresher course in how government works. She also said that we were cutting the HECS

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. I remind her that it is now called the HELP scheme. Putting that to one side, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Higher Education Loan Program is not a program that can be cut because it is a loan program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whoever turns up to ask for a loan from the taxpayer to go to university, and is given an

Speaker: NA
Text: undergraduate course, is able to access the loan program. That is why, while the current

Speaker: NA
Text: HELP debt for the Commonwealth is about $30.1 billion, it will rise to $51 billion or $52

Speaker: NA
Text: billion over the coming years. It is not a program that can be cut; it is a program that can be

Speaker: NA
Text: paid back at a fairer interest rate-for example, at the 10-year government bond rate rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than CPI, which is an indexation rather than an interest rate. It is not a program that can be

Speaker: NA
Text: cut, so whichever staff member gave the member for Adelaide that advice before she came

Speaker: NA
Text: into the chamber to contribute should probably be dealt with by her.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Adelaide also talked about modelling. There is a lot of speculation around

Speaker: NA
Text: the fee rises or fee falls after deregulation of the higher education system. There is a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: speculation; much of it is based on hysteria and scaremongering. I refer the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide to the excellent statement by Fred Hilmer, the Vice-Chancellor of the University of

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales. He says:

Speaker: NA
Text: It is up to universities, not Canberra, to decide what fees should apply to which courses.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said about the very modelling the member for Adelaide cited:

Speaker: NA
Text: The modelling released today by Universities Australia on the impact on fees of changes to cluster

Speaker: NA
Text: funding rates is based on a fundamental misunderstanding of the way the system works …

Speaker: NA
Text: The University of New South Wales is a member of Universities Australia, so it must have

Speaker: NA
Text: taken Professor Hilmer quite a lot of courage to publicly point out the massive failure in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Universities Australia modelling.

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer the member for Adelaide to some excellent modelling that has been done, and which

Speaker: NA
Text: was in The Australian higher education supplement, which is at the back of the paper. In case

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Adelaide does not know where it is in The Australian newspaper, it is after

Speaker: NA
Text: the business section. She will find it in that part of the newspaper. Andrew Trounson has

Speaker: NA
Text: written an excellent piece, in which he has suggested that fee rises could be as low as $2,163 a

Speaker: NA
Text: year in those courses where fees do rise. So, before the member for Adelaide quotes the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: speculative modelling or returns to the National Tertiary Education Union's modelling, she

Speaker: NA
Text: might like to go and have a look at the higher education supplement of The Australian. She

Speaker: NA
Text: will find there, that very good piece by Andrew Trounson.

Speaker: Dr HENDY
Text: Eden-Monaro) (16:37): As the minister knows, my electorate of Eden-

Speaker: NA
Text: Monaro is a rural electorate in the south-east corner of New South Wales. In our electorate we

Speaker: NA
Text: have some 10,553 primary school students and we have some 911,000 secondary school

Speaker: NA
Text: students. We have heard from Labor that there have been cuts to expenditure on schools in

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales and across the country, but my understand is that we are actually boosting

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure on schools. I would be interested to know, over the course of the next four years

Speaker: NA
Text: of the forward estimates, how much school expenditure will be increasing in New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales. I would also like a general assessment of the spending on independent schools and

Speaker: NA
Text: Catholic schools if the minister has that data to hand. My understanding is that, as opposed to

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Labor opposition have been saying, there has been an increase in spending on

Speaker: NA
Text: schools in New South Wales for both state and private schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that you well know, Minister, that I was formerly the chief executive of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. As such, I am particularly interested in skills

Speaker: NA
Text: and training issues. I note that ACCI put out a 2013 pre-election survey in which they

Speaker: NA
Text: canvassed the opinion of employers on the state of the vocational education and training

Speaker: NA
Text: market. ACCI found that, even though the unemployment rate was relatively higher in recent

Speaker: NA
Text: years, more than in four in five, or 82 per cent of, businesses remain concerned with

Speaker: NA
Text: recruiting employees with appropriate skills, while 68.9 per cent of businesses were

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned with recruiting employees with a good level of literacy and numeracy. Further,

Speaker: NA
Text: ACCI found that businesses rated employee productivity performance as their second highest

Speaker: NA
Text: concern, and they noted:

Speaker: NA
Text: This finding is closely related to the Cost of Training Employees which is rated as the third highest

Speaker: NA
Text: concern.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was a survey done in May 2013. That is a legacy that the former Rudd-Gillard-Rudd

Speaker: NA
Text: government left this government to fix.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am interested to know the nature of the integrated policy framework that we are putting in

Speaker: NA
Text: place with regard to vocational education and training to deal with these problems. I note, for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, that we are introducing what I regard as an excellent program of trade support loans

Speaker: NA
Text: of $20,000 for apprentices. I would like to understand more fully from you, Minister, how

Speaker: NA
Text: that deals with the sort of legacy that we have had to fix in this budget for 2014.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Eden-Monaro for his contribution. I might start with his last question first, if he

Speaker: NA
Text: does not mind. Yes, we did inherit a very poor legacy from the previous government around

Speaker: NA
Text: the outcomes for students at school level then going on to have difficulty in vocational

Speaker: NA
Text: education and training-a very difficult legacy. In fact, the OECD PISA study released last

Speaker: NA
Text: year in December showed again that Australia has fallen not just in relative terms against the

Speaker: NA
Text: other nations in the OECD in literacy and numeracy but in real terms. This is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental problem. I do not blame any particular state Labor or Liberal government for

Speaker: NA
Text: that. This has been a decline over 10 years, but it happened at the same time as a massive

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in spending. There was a 42 per cent increase in spending in schools over 10 years;

Speaker: NA
Text: over the same 10 years, there was a significant decline in the outcomes for our students.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: When we came to power, having seen that legacy, we set about doing a few very important

Speaker: NA
Text: things. We decided to focus on the things that really mattered-not just more money in

Speaker: NA
Text: schools, which Labor is obsessed with, but the fundamental root problems in schools in the

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes for students. We identified those as being, firstly, an improvement in teacher

Speaker: NA
Text: quality. The OECD said that, in eight out of 10 reasons why a student does well or badly in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, the classroom to which they were allocated had the biggest impact. One out of 10

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons was low SES and one out of 10 reasons was every other factor. So we wanted to

Speaker: NA
Text: address teacher quality, and what we can do at the federal level, of course, is address the

Speaker: NA
Text: training of teachers in universities. That is why we have established the Teacher Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministerial Advisory Group, to advise me about how to improve teacher training at university

Speaker: NA
Text: and do an international benchmarking study.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms MACTiernan interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: schooling, more autonomy at the local level has a real impact on the expectations of students

Speaker: NA
Text: about what they might go on to do. I have seen the member for Perth support many of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's measures around direct instruction or around independent public schools and I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure she would want to support that, but, rather than be distracted, we have put $70

Speaker: NA
Text: million aside to expand independent public schooling in Australia. I must say, we are close to

Speaker: NA
Text: securing all jurisdictions being able to take part in that particular program, because we want

Speaker: NA
Text: more autonomy at the local level.

Speaker: NA
Text: We identified, as you did in your address, that the curriculum is an issue in schools. Rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than accept mediocrity or failure, we decided that we would have a deep look at the national

Speaker: NA
Text: curriculum by appointing two very eminent people to conduct a study of the curriculum and

Speaker: NA
Text: its robustness. We wanted to determine whether it is useful for students and whether it

Speaker: NA
Text: produces the kinds of outcomes that employers need in gaining skills and knowledge, because

Speaker: NA
Text: being at school is not just about gaining skills; it is about gaining both skills and knowledge.

Speaker: NA
Text: And we want to improve the parental engagement in students' education. In Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia we have found that the more autonomy there is in a public school, the more engaged

Speaker: NA
Text: parents are with their children's education. Therefore, the Independent Public Schools

Speaker: NA
Text: Initiative really dovetails into our initiatives around parental engagement. The budget has $1

Speaker: NA
Text: million a year for ARACY, to assist us with good research and good methods to achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: better outcomes for students.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Eden-Monaro also asked about the misconception that we have cut

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for schools. We have massively increased funding for schools-an 8.7 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: increase this financial year; 8.9 per cent the following year, 8.9 per cent the following, and 6.6

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent in 2017-18. We have increased funding. This stands in stark contrast to Labor in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pre-election Economic and Fiscal Outlook, which cut $1.2 billion from schools, which would

Speaker: NA
Text: have left Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory short-Queensland by

Speaker: NA
Text: $794 million, WA by $120 million, and the Northern Territory by $272 million. We have put

Speaker: NA
Text: that back into the system. In the member's state of New South Wales, spending will increase

Speaker: NA
Text: by 6.7 per cent, 7.8 per cent, 9.4 per cent and 5.7 per cent over the next four years. So New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales will be another big winner from the government deliberately living within our

Speaker: NA
Text: means, but being fiscally wise and full of rectitude.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Ms HALL
Text: Shortland-Opposition Whip) (16:46): One of the less-known budget

Speaker: NA
Text: measures that have slipped through without much public attention is cuts, in the education

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio, to published career resources. I am particularly concerned about the cut to the Job

Speaker: NA
Text: Guide and the fact that it is no longer being printed or on the website, and about myfuture.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Job Guide will be funded up to the 2015 edition, and myfuture will be funded up to

Speaker: NA
Text: December 2014. These job guides are invaluable resources for career and vocational

Speaker: NA
Text: counsellors, both in schools and in TAFE colleges. Back in the Howard government days, Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Brendan Nelson, as Minister for Education, Science and Training, helped to bring in some

Speaker: NA
Text: really good policy reforms in the career development area.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst on one hand this government say they are about creating jobs and opportunities for

Speaker: NA
Text: young people, they are taking away the tools that will assist in doing that. My question,

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, is: what is the rationale for this? What are you putting in place to replace these

Speaker: NA
Text: really valuable resources, which I have used in a previous life? And how do you expect to

Speaker: NA
Text: help young people to find work and to undertake appropriate courses of study without having

Speaker: NA
Text: resources available for those people and for counsellors to provide counselling and advice on

Speaker: NA
Text: careers and education?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Shortland for her question. I am sure it is a well meant one, because the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Shortland is a conscientious local member of parliament. The myfuture and Job Guide,

Speaker: NA
Text: which the member refers to, were left unfunded by the previous government beyond the 2014-

Speaker: NA
Text: 15 financial year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Hall: They could have been refunded.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's decision was that myfuture and Job Guide would not be continued to be

Speaker: NA
Text: funded after 2014-15. We did that, firstly, because we are in a budget emergency which

Speaker: NA
Text: requires us to make difficult decisions about what should and should not continue to be

Speaker: NA
Text: funded. Secondly, we did that because, with respect to those two particular measures that

Speaker: NA
Text: some students use to decide their careers and their futures, there is a plethora of information

Speaker: NA
Text: now available for young people, particularly provided by the private sector. Therefore the

Speaker: NA
Text: question has to be whether the government should be spending taxpayers' money on myfuture

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Job Guide when the private sector has been filling that space extremely successfully

Speaker: NA
Text: for the last 10 years. For example, there is information about careers on state and territory

Speaker: NA
Text: websites-Victoria and Western Australia have their own dedicated career websites, two state

Speaker: NA
Text: government portals for advising young people about their careers. But other examples in the

Speaker: NA
Text: private sector include Seek, CareerLounge, My Career, Career Hunter, Student Edge,

Speaker: NA
Text: SkillsOne and Hobsons Course Finder. So there are many different places that students can

Speaker: NA
Text: get the advice that they need about future careers. Of course, young people these days use

Speaker: NA
Text: social networking, social media, to find out a great deal about the careers that they might wish

Speaker: NA
Text: to pursue. So I am confident that myfuture and Job Guide will be quite correctly replaced by

Speaker: NA
Text: the private sector filling that space, as they have already been doing in the last 10 years, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that where the private sector is doing a job equally or better than the government, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: the wrong use of taxpayers' funds to replicate what the private sector can do as well if not

Speaker: NA
Text: better.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Ms SCOTT
Text: Lindsay) (16:51): My electorate of Lindsay is in the outskirts of Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: Being in the outskirts of Sydney one of the biggest challenges we have is that two-thirds of

Speaker: NA
Text: our working population have to commute every single day for jobs-one-third all the way

Speaker: NA
Text: into the city and one-third into greater Western Sydney. The Abbott government is already

Speaker: NA
Text: contributing a lot of resources and a lot of funding to assist the north-west and the south-west

Speaker: NA
Text: growth sector-$3.5 billion in fact to actually build some major construction work that will

Speaker: NA
Text: be in the south-west of Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also have within the electorate of Lindsay one of the colleges of TAFE New South Wales,

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Sydney Institute. The Western Sydney Institute of TAFE has some 94,000 students

Speaker: NA
Text: in it that they provide every year qualifications to within Australian frameworks. They all also

Speaker: NA
Text: offer open training and distance learning opportunities for people there as well. So as Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney grows there is a growing demand on workplace jobs, actual jobs, that are going to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide solutions for people to be ready to go-vocational jobs. But the Western Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Institute of TAFE is also really wonderful in the way it works with the University of Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney providing its crucial gateway courses. So people who have not necessarily got the

Speaker: NA
Text: best UAI can gateway from TAFE into university, which I think is a really fabulous initiative

Speaker: NA
Text: that these two training organisations do together-to provide vocational outcomes for people

Speaker: NA
Text: right across Western Sydney. When we look at all this together, my question to the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: is: why is the government extending Commonwealth subsidies to private universities and the

Speaker: NA
Text: non-university higher education institutions?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: for Lindsay has identified a very excellent part of the higher education reforms that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: proposing, and that is to give more young people from areas like Western Sydney the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to use different pathways into higher education. The Commonwealth Grant

Speaker: NA
Text: Scheme has been applied to the 39 universities for many decades. The government's decision

Speaker: NA
Text: has been that we want to expand that to the non-university higher education providers, many

Speaker: NA
Text: of which are very high quality and are offering as good if not better courses and career

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for young people. When we come to decide the amount that should be funded to

Speaker: NA
Text: those different institutions that are non-university, the percentage that we pay them might well

Speaker: NA
Text: be lower than what universities are paid. That is why we have a working group advising us on

Speaker: NA
Text: what, for example, that percentage should be, because universities do research. Being a

Speaker: NA
Text: university, one of the definitions is that they do research as well as teaching, whereas a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: the non-university higher education providers, like TAFEs, do not do research but do teaching

Speaker: NA
Text: and do it very well.

Speaker: NA
Text: The ones in Western Sydney, like the TAFE that the member for Lindsay talked about, will

Speaker: NA
Text: be big winners in the government's higher education reforms. They will be big winners

Speaker: NA
Text: because some of their courses will be funded under the new demand-driven system for

Speaker: NA
Text: diplomas and sub-bachelor courses, so there will be an injection of funds to TAFEs through

Speaker: NA
Text: that method. They will also be winners because, for the first time, they will be able to access

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Grant Scheme, and that will give them an opportunity to get an injection

Speaker: NA
Text: of funds that way. Around Australia-certainly in my state of South Australia-state

Speaker: NA
Text: governments have been cutting TAFE funding. So they have very much welcomed the

Speaker: NA
Text: decision by the government to expand that.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I was very pleased to see in The Australian Financial Review on Monday an article by Tim

Speaker: NA
Text: Dodd about this very subject that the member for Lindsay raises, headed 'SA Labor backs

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition on higher education funding'. The article reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: SA Higher Education Minister Gail Gago said on Saturday the federal government's plan to recognise

Speaker: NA
Text: and fund sub-bachelor degrees delivered by the SA TAFE system was welcome.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, the same thing would apply to the TAFEs in Greater Western Sydney. The article

Speaker: NA
Text: goes on:

Speaker: NA
Text: "The extension of funding of sub-bachelor program's to TAFE SA and other registered higher education

Speaker: NA
Text: providers provides an opportunity for TAFE SA to access Commonwealth funding for its diploma and

Speaker: NA
Text: advanced diploma courses on an equal footing with universities," she said.

Speaker: NA
Text: "TAFE SA already works closely with a number of universities in terms of providing opportunities for

Speaker: NA
Text: students to transfer to university and have recognition for their studies in TAFE SA and the recognition

Speaker: NA
Text: and funding of these sub-bachelor programs delivered by TAFE SA is welcome."

Speaker: NA
Text: This is not a Liberal minister. This is a minister in a Labor state government, in the state from

Speaker: NA
Text: which the member for Adelaide, the shadow minister, comes. I do not think they are from the

Speaker: NA
Text: same faction, though. I think Gail Gago is in the left and the member for Adelaide is in the

Speaker: NA
Text: right. I am not sure. They do not tend to talk closely in South Australia, but I am sure the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Adelaide can inform us. In any event, this is a minister in a state Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government who is supporting the federal government's proposals. Why is she doing that?

Speaker: NA
Text: Because they are good proposals. They are very good, and Gail Gago has worked out that

Speaker: NA
Text: what the government is doing is expanding opportunity to a great deal more students around

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to get a higher education qualification. This will mean that students in Greater

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Sydney will have the chance to go to university, get a degree or a diploma or do a

Speaker: NA
Text: course, and then go on to earn 75 per cent more, $1 million more, over their lifetime than

Speaker: NA
Text: people without a higher education qualification.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the time available to me, I will not try and start a new subject, but I might get a chance

Speaker: NA
Text: to comment on it in a minute. There are many, many Australians who are pleased to support

Speaker: NA
Text: students at university by subsidising their education. At the moment, they subsidise it 60 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. As only 40 per cent of Australians have a university degree, that means that a great

Speaker: NA
Text: majority of the population are subsidising students to get the chance to earn 75 per cent more

Speaker: NA
Text: than them over a lifetime. It is a generous act on behalf of the Australian taxpayer. Rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than whingeing about it, the member for Adelaide should be thanking the taxpayers of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia for the subsidies that they provide to students around the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms KATE ELLIS (Adelaide) (16:58): Can I just point out that we were, 15 minutes ago,

Speaker: NA
Text: due to commence questioning on the schools budget. On this side, we have a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: important questions about school funding, school cuts, youth programs, chaplains and the

Speaker: NA
Text: curriculum review. I know that this government have a shameful record on education. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that they do not want accountability about this appalling record when it comes to education,

Speaker: NA
Text: but perhaps they could stop wasting time with these ridiculous dorothy dixers taking up every

Speaker: NA
Text: moment that is available.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Ewen Jones): Order, members on my right!

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms KATE ELLIS: I will be asking the minister questions. We know that the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: outlines $80 billion in cuts to schools and hospitals. Its estimates also reveal that $30 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: of these cuts will come from schools. We saw that in this exchange between Senator Wong

Speaker: NA
Text: and Mr Ray, deputy secretary of Treasury, in an estimates hearing:

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator WONG: Can you confirm that, with that figure, broadly you are looking at around 30 for

Speaker: NA
Text: schools and 50 for hospitals?

Speaker: Mr Ray
Text: It is a little bit under 30 for schools and a bit over 50 for hospitals.

Speaker: NA
Text: So it is $80 billion in cuts to schools and hospitals, confirmed by this government's own

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury department.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now, with school cuts, this means that the game is up for this government. The public

Speaker: NA
Text: service has confirmed the biggest-ever cuts to schools that we have seen in this nation, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: know that there will be devastating consequences: less disability support, subject choices

Speaker: NA
Text: drastically limited, school support officers and teachers' assistants cuts, sport and music

Speaker: NA
Text: programs cut, remedial support cut and class sizes increased. But the government has made

Speaker: NA
Text: these cuts without any understanding of the impacts. We know that Senate estimates revealed

Speaker: NA
Text: that despite starting work on its $80 billion cuts to schools and hospitals before Easter, the

Speaker: NA
Text: government still has no idea of the impact on the classroom and had not done the work to look

Speaker: NA
Text: at the potential impact.

Speaker: NA
Text: The education department could not say how many schools would close or how many

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers would be sacked or give any indication of the impact on students. It is absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: frightening that the government would make the largest-ever cuts to our schools with no idea

Speaker: NA
Text: of the consequences.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before the election, Tony Abbott promised that there would not be cuts to education but

Speaker: NA
Text: now it is clear that he simply does not care what damage these cuts will do. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: have walked away from the commitments that they have made time and time again, including

Speaker: NA
Text: the so-called 'unity ticket' before the election-and didn't they pull one over the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: public with that!

Speaker: NA
Text: What we do know is that the Liberal state governments have said that they do care about

Speaker: NA
Text: these huge cuts from the Abbott government. We have seen New South Wales, Victoria, ACT

Speaker: NA
Text: and SA all commit to meeting their responsibilities under the six-year Gonski agreements-

Speaker: NA
Text: something that this government has failed to do. We have seen New South Wales Liberal

Speaker: NA
