Text: Premier Mike Baird say that education cuts were 'a kick in the guts'. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: … what services would they like us to cut …. you cannot outsource your problems to the states …

Speaker: NA
Text: Similarly, we have seen the New South Wales education minister, Adrian Piccoli, speak out

Speaker: NA
Text: against these cuts to education. We have seen the Victorian Treasurer, Michael O'Brien, say:

Speaker: NA
Text: When we handed down the Victorian budget last Tuesday we put extra money into Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitals and extra money into Victorian schools. We didn't put that extra money in so that the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government can take money out.

Speaker: NA
Text: And we have seen the Queensland Treasurer, Tim Nicholls, say that the federal budget was an

Speaker: NA
Text: attack on Queensland's health and education services.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have also seen the New South Wales Nationals' conference just last weekend call for

Speaker: NA
Text: the government to fund the full six years of the Gonski review. And we have seen these

Speaker: NA
Text: attacks to the indexation of schools, which the now minister himself said, in opposition, were

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: a 'frightening prospect'-to have indexation of three per cent. He is now happy to see

Speaker: NA
Text: indexation of just 2.5 per cent moving forward.

Speaker: NA
Text: So my questions in relation to these huge funding cuts are: how many Liberal and National

Speaker: NA
Text: backbenchers have raised concerns about the breaking of the Gonski agreements and the $30

Speaker: NA
Text: billion cuts to schools? How can the government justify making $30 billion in cuts to schools

Speaker: NA
Text: without any assessment of the impact they will have? Can the minister guarantee that no

Speaker: NA
Text: school will close as a result of these cuts? Or can the minister outline exactly how much

Speaker: NA
Text: worse off each school will be because of these cuts? On what evidence about the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: delivering high-quality school education did the minister base the government's school-

Speaker: NA
Text: funding model from 2018, which will index funding at just 2.5 per cent? And can the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: justify a school-funding model that cuts funds to schools in real terms and which schools have

Speaker: NA
Text: warned will lead to reduced programs and quality, and higher fees?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: know where one begins with the member for Adelaide asking me dorothy dixer questions and

Speaker: NA
Text: then accusing the government of doing the same thing, because the consideration-in-detail

Speaker: NA
Text: process is supposed to be an opportunity to elicit detail out of the budget-out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriations. The member for Adelaide has chosen to give set piece speeches in each of her

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions, with all the rhetoric that she could really save for Q&A or 7:30 or even in

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament speaking on the bills, rather than wasting the time of the Federation Chamber in

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration in detail by giving rhetorical speeches and not actually asking questions.

Speaker: NA
Text: So if she has run out of time and not managed her time well it is because she has wasted

Speaker: NA
Text: the time of consideration-in-detail process by giving pointless and asinine speeches about the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's policies rather than actually asking questions. I suppose it is because she does

Speaker: NA
Text: not have as much experience in the opposition as she should have. But, nevertheless, I will

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to help her with the misunderstanding that she has about how the school funding

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements work.

Speaker: NA
Text: School funding agreements go for four years with the states and territories and the non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government sector-whether that is the Catholics or the independents. The forward estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: go for four years as well. So there is a coincidence: there is a four-year funding agreement;

Speaker: NA
Text: there are four years of forward estimates. Over the forward estimates, spending on schools

Speaker: NA
Text: increases very substantially. As I said in response to the member for Eden-Monaro's

Speaker: NA
Text: questions, spending in all schools, including recurrent and capital spending, over the next four

Speaker: NA
Text: years is: an 8.7 per cent increase in 2014-15; 8.9 per cent in 2015-16; 8.9 per cent, again, in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2016-17; and 6.6 per cent in 2017-18. So there are no cuts to school education in the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government's budget. In fact, the opposite is true. We are increasing spending and we have

Speaker: NA
Text: our own programs such as: programs like the independent public schools initiative costing

Speaker: NA
Text: $70 million; programs like the response to whatever the curriculum review hands down;

Speaker: NA
Text: programs like $1 million a year to help us with parental engagement; and when the TEMAG,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Teacher Education Ministerial Adviser Group, hands down its report to me, funds have

Speaker: NA
Text: been set aside to be able to respond to that. So we are increasing spending.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Labor Party's rhetoric is not matched by the reality of how they behaved in

Speaker: NA
Text: government. In the Pre-Election Economic and Fiscal Outlook, the previous minister, the now

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition, ripped $1.2 billion out of schools. So, ironically, while the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister pretends that they were funding a new school funding model, in fact in Western

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory they were defunding the school funding

Speaker: NA
Text: model. It took me as the Minister for Education not only to deliver a national agreement on

Speaker: NA
Text: the national school funding model over four years, bringing the Northern Territory,

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland and Western Australia into the model, but also to find the $1.2 billion so that the

Speaker: NA
Text: model would work. And I did so.

Speaker: NA
Text: Beyond the next four years, the member for Adelaide likes to raise fantastic figures. I will

Speaker: NA
Text: tell her that in 2017 we will sit down with all the jurisdictions and renegotiate a new school

Speaker: NA
Text: funding agreement. That will lead to more money in 2018 and more money in 2019 because

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously spending will increase on schools in line with the CPI and enrolments. But I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that the Labor Party can continue to pretend that the rivers of gold, the fantastic amounts

Speaker: NA
Text: of money that they used to talk about in government, will ever materialise, in spite of what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition said on 31 March in Perth in answer to a question from a journalist:

Speaker: NA
Text: JOURNALIST: You have committed and you still will commit to the next election for those years five

Speaker: NA
Text: and six?

Speaker: NA
Text: SHORTEN: Yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: JOURNALIST: That will cost I think about $7 billion additional is that what you're prepared for that?

Speaker: NA
Text: SHORTEN: We budgeted for this when we were in Government and furthermore, what does it cost

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia if we short change our kids?

Speaker: NA
Text: He likes that kind of rhetoric. Unfortunately, this was not followed up. On 22 May at Moonee

Speaker: NA
Text: Ponds he was asked: 'If you're bent on restoring this funding, what's the solution for finding

Speaker: NA
Text: the savings to provide it, or would it be deficit funded?' Mr Shorten said:

Speaker: NA
Text: We'll reveal all our policies in good time before the next election.

Speaker: NA
Text: So he has stepped away from that commitment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs PRENTICE (Ryan) (17:08): My question is to the minister. Minister, I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunate to have an institution, namely the University of Queensland, in the electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Ryan. The university over the years has-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Kate Ellis interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs PRENTICE: We are on education. You wasted all that time. That is not my fault.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Kate Ellis interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs PRENTICE: Stop interrupting, you are wasting time again. You are deliberately

Speaker: NA
Text: wasting time. You do not want answers. Let me ask my question.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Mitchell): Order! The member for Adelaide has had her

Speaker: NA
Text: chance. The member for Ryan has the call and will be heard.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Kate Ellis: Excuse me, we divided up the time so that the first 45 minutes was on

Speaker: NA
Text: higher education and the second was on schools.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The member for Adelaide will resume her seat. The member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Ryan has the call, this is consideration in detail on education, and she will be able to ask

Speaker: NA
Text: her question-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Kate Ellis interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: in silence!

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs PRENTICE: I was saying, Minister, that the university has produced many

Speaker: NA
Text: outstanding graduates who are now leaders in their fields-in every aspect of business,

Speaker: NA
Text: governance and the different aspects of the lives that we lead. They are very impressive. The

Speaker: NA
Text: University of Queensland, through its research, is now in the top 10 per cent of universities in

Speaker: NA
Text: the world for the commercialisation of research projects. I would like you to elaborate, please,

Speaker: NA
Text: on that.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs PRENTICE: That interjection is just completely off the planet.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Kate Ellis interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs PRENTICE: I really object to the opposition deliberately wasting our time when we

Speaker: NA
Text: have serious questions. Minister, how are the policies and measures that you have introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: helping the University of Queensland rate even higher across the world?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that the member for Ryan finally got her chance to ask a question in spite of the interference

Speaker: NA
Text: being run by the member for Adelaide. The member for Adelaide knows that members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government can ask any question they like during the 1½ hours of consideration in detail for

Speaker: NA
Text: education. She is welcome to divide up the time for higher education, schools and child care.

Speaker: NA
Text: She may well ask a question on child care, next, to the excellent assistant minister. But I

Speaker: NA
Text: would point out that she used most of that first hour asking about universities and then ran out

Speaker: NA
Text: of time for schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not the time manager for the member for Adelaide-that is a matter for her-but she

Speaker: NA
Text: does not get the chance, also, to tell the members of the government what they can ask

Speaker: NA
Text: questions about. If she casts her mind back to 7 September last year, she might notice that

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor did not win the election. That is why members of her party are sitting on that side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. So she gets to ask the questions that she wants to ask, and members of the government

Speaker: NA
Text: get to ask the questions that they want to ask. If she does not like the process she should not

Speaker: NA
Text: take part in the process, because there are lots of members of the government who would like

Speaker: NA
Text: to ask questions and would like to hear the answers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Ryan asked about the University of Queensland, an excellent university in

Speaker: NA
Text: both research and teaching. I can tell her that in the budget, research funding over four years,

Speaker: NA
Text: including for ARC and AIATSIS, is $11 billion. So we are massively investing in research in

Speaker: NA
Text: this budget. I have spoken earlier in the consideration in detail about how we faced funding

Speaker: NA
Text: cliffs for the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy and the Future

Speaker: NA
Text: Fellowships program. I found money for both of those programs, in spite of Labor only

Speaker: NA
Text: funding them for 12 months. Those were more of the landmines that Labor left for the

Speaker: NA
Text: incoming government, because even they had worked out that the public had lost faith in them

Speaker: NA
Text: as a government. They left two funding cliffs in NCRIS and the Future Fellowships, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: found the money and funded it.

Speaker: NA
Text: So we are actually investing more money in research over the next four years, and

Speaker: NA
Text: universities like the University of Queensland will benefit from that, because they have an

Speaker: NA
Text: excellent reputation in research. That is why I can tell the member for Ryan that Michael

Speaker: NA
Text: Gallagher, the Executive Director of the Group of Eight, gave an excellent speech at the

Speaker: NA
Text: EduTECH Higher Education Leaders Congress in Brisbane on 4 June 2014. I recommend it to

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Moreton because it was in his city. And I recommend it to the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide, who might not have had the opportunity to read it. Right at the end of that speech-

Speaker: NA
Text: if she only wants to read one paragraph-on page 17 of 17, Michael Gallagher said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The 2014 Higher Education Budget reforms are necessary. They are logical, coherent, sustainable,

Speaker: NA
Text: equitable and inevitable … My guess is that the detractors of micro-economic reform in Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: higher education industry will find themselves on the wrong side of history in resisting efficiency

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement and innovation, as they will be in opposing the redistributive measures of the package

Speaker: NA
Text: and, curiously, supporting socially regressive subsidies from general taxpayers to more advantaged

Speaker: NA
Text: segments of the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, I can tell the member for Ryan, that is exactly where Labor has found

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves in this debate. They have found themselves on the wrong side of history. They

Speaker: NA
Text: have found themselves supporting socially regressive subsidies from general taxpayers to

Speaker: NA
Text: more advantaged segments of the community. They have found themselves opposing the

Speaker: NA
Text: redistributive measures of the package, like the expansion of the demand driven system to the

Speaker: NA
Text: sub-bachelor courses, and the expansion of the Commonwealth Grant Scheme to non-

Speaker: NA
Text: university higher education providers and the Commonwealth scholarships fund. This is the

Speaker: NA
Text: biggest Commonwealth scholarships fund in Australia's history and will give many, many

Speaker: NA
Text: more students in both regional and rural Australia, as well as the cities, the chance to go to

Speaker: NA
Text: university.

Speaker: NA
Text: Research universities like UQ will benefit substantially from what their own Group of

Speaker: NA
Text: Eight describes as a 'logical, coherent, sustainable, equitable and inevitable' package of higher

Speaker: NA
Text: education reform. It will allow them to put more effort and their own money into research and

Speaker: NA
Text: to determine the areas of research that they are best at and the courses that they offer that are

Speaker: NA
Text: their highest quality courses and fund and support those, rather than simply have every

Speaker: NA
Text: offering in order to be able to chase the revenue, which is how the previous government had

Speaker: NA
Text: established the university system. That is why these higher education reforms will make a

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial difference to young people from low socioeconomic status backgrounds in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular and allow universities like UQ to compete with their Asian counterparts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms KATE ELLIS (Adelaide) (17:15): Knowing how desperate the government are to

Speaker: NA
Text: avoid accountability on schools and education questions, I am going to ask a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: questions on both schools and child care and ask that those which the government does not

Speaker: NA
Text: answer in this place be taken on notice.

Speaker: NA
Text: My first point is around the school chaplains program. I note that the budget allocated $245

Speaker: NA
Text: million for the National School Chaplaincy Program but that this minister decided to declare

Speaker: NA
Text: that this funding would only be available for religious chaplains and that welfare officers and

Speaker: NA
Text: other qualified counsellors would not receive funding under this program. We note that there

Speaker: NA
Text: are many indications of the government's hypocrisy-firstly, that it talks about school

Speaker: NA
Text: autonomy on one hand and on the other hand says that it will not give principals the option of

Speaker: NA
Text: deciding that a welfare officer is best for them. How does the government justify cutting

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for qualified welfare staff that so many schools rely on? Has the government

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken an impact assessment of this change? I also note that the minister was bragging

Speaker: NA
Text: about reducing compliance on these school chaplains. How will the government ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: the program standards and safeguards will be maintained? Why didn't the government consult

Speaker: NA
Text: with school principals and parents before making this decision? How many schools will lose

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare officers as a result of this government's decision? If the government needs to take this

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: on notice, I understand, but can it provide a list of each school which previously had access to

Speaker: NA
Text: a non-religious welfare officer under this program?

Speaker: NA
Text: I also have a range of questions around the almost $1 billion in cuts to child care which this

Speaker: NA
Text: government has announced, including the $157 million cuts to family day care. Why did the

Speaker: NA
Text: government refuse to consult with the family day care sector before deciding to axe this

Speaker: NA
Text: essential support, which Family Day Care Australia estimates will make families have to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: an extra $35 a week in their family day care fees? What plans does the government have to

Speaker: NA
Text: make up for any loss of supply due to the cutting of these funds? Has the government

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken any analysis on the areas of Australia that are most likely to be impacted by the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes? How will the government provide assurances that services have educators in areas

Speaker: NA
Text: where family day care is critically important?

Speaker: NA
Text: Regarding the appalling changes to and attacks against the means-tested childcare benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: which this government is so proudly bragging will only impact people who earn $42,000 or

Speaker: NA
Text: more, how can the government continue to push for a paid parental leave scheme that will

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver $50,000 cheques to millionaires whilst cutting the existing childcare benefit that

Speaker: NA
Text: people who earn just $42,000 a year rely upon? How will the government save $230.4 million

Speaker: NA
Text: from these measures if it is continuing to try and argue that black is white and this is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: savings measure and a cut? I ask the government to provide the House with a breakdown of

Speaker: NA
Text: how this figure of 500,000 families that will be worse off as a result of this measure was

Speaker: NA
Text: calculated. If the government has done no such analysis on the impact on families of various

Speaker: NA
Text: income levels, will it at least now do it and provide it to the House as this bill goes through?

Speaker: NA
Text: Regarding preschool, I notice that the government are backing away from support for

Speaker: NA
Text: universal access in our preschool system, citing that they do not want to undermine the

Speaker: NA
Text: Productivity Commission report, yet they are very happy to undermine and pre-empt that

Speaker: NA
Text: report when it comes to slashing childcare benefit and childcare rebate for hundreds of

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of Australian families. I ask: will the minister guarantee the continuation of federal

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for preschools? Will the minister make a commitment to an ongoing partnership with

Speaker: NA
Text: state and territory governments to fund preschool programs?

Speaker: NA
Text: I will also go to the Minister for Education when it comes to his attacks on all of the youth

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment prevention programs which are so critically important in our schools at a time

Speaker: NA
Text: when the government is at the same time attacking Australians for being too reliant on

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare and threatening to leave young people with absolutely nothing to live on for six

Speaker: NA
Text: months. Why is it that every youth unemployment prevention program is being cancelled in

Speaker: NA
Text: his portfolio?

Speaker: NA
Text: I also note the Prime Minister's recent comments about industry involvement in schools. I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the government: if trades in schools and linking with industry is so important to jobs and

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's future productivity then why are trades training centres and partnership brokers

Speaker: NA
Text: programs, which are providing an effective way of bringing industry in and of providing a

Speaker: NA
Text: pathway to work experience and employment beyond school, all being cut by this government

Speaker: NA
Text: that promised no cuts to education and seems to delight in delivering record cuts in that same

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio? (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: not take five minutes so that the Assistant Minister for Education will have the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: respond on childcare issues. I am hoping the member for Adelaide will regard that as a

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: helpful proposal because if she speaks again that means that the assistant minister will not get

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to respond at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: The shadow minister asked about Youth Connections. Youth Connections was a program

Speaker: NA
Text: that had 74 per cent of its participants aged under 17. It is therefore the responsibility of the

Speaker: NA
Text: states and territories to provide that kind of assistance that Youth Connections provided. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was duplicating effort. There are lots of great programs, Commonwealth programs, state

Speaker: NA
Text: programs and territory programs but it is not the Commonwealth's responsibility to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: them all. The states and territories have to take responsibility for the things that are their area

Speaker: NA
Text: of responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: Too often the great chasm between Labor and Liberal is shown up in just this kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: example where, in Labor's world, the Commonwealth should pay for and do everything. If

Speaker: NA
Text: they have to borrow the money from overseas, they have no problem with that. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: conservative Liberal and Nationals parties' world, we need to live within our means and we

Speaker: NA
Text: need to pay back the debt. Areas that are properly the responsibility of the states and

Speaker: NA
Text: territories should be delivered by the states and territories. That goes for the school chaplaincy

Speaker: NA
Text: program as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: The school chaplaincy program was initiated by the Howard government. It was a

Speaker: NA
Text: chaplaincy program. When the Labor Party came to office there was quite a tussle between

Speaker: NA
Text: Julia Gillard as the then Minister for Education and the Prime Minister at the time, Mr Rudd.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Rudd supported the chaplaincy program. Julia Gillard opposed the chaplaincy program.

Speaker: NA
Text: She wanted to kill the chaplaincy program. Kevin Rudd saved the chaplaincy program. The

Speaker: NA
Text: compromise between these two individuals was that it would be expanded to welfare officers

Speaker: NA
Text: and counsellors. Welfare officers and counsellors in schools are quite properly the domain of

Speaker: NA
Text: state and territory governments. Now that we are in government, we have returned the

Speaker: NA
Text: chaplaincy program to which original intention, which is a chaplaincy program.

Speaker: NA
Text: If states and territories want to continue to fund welfare officers and counsellors then they

Speaker: NA
Text: are perfectly at liberty to do so. I would welcome them doing so but that is a decision that

Speaker: NA
Text: they should make and not be infantilised by the Commonwealth making these decisions on

Speaker: NA
Text: their behalf. I will end on that note and allow the Assistant Minister for Education the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to respond.

Speaker: Ms LEY
Text: Farrer-Assistant Minister for Education) (17:23): I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide, the shadow minister, for her questions. I am happy to address some of the key

Speaker: NA
Text: points she has raised. The answers to all of those questions she raised around childcare benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: and childcare rebate could be found in the speech I made to the House both on the

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction of the bill earlier last week and the summing up speech this afternoon. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: happy to go over them again in the order that they were asked. I will address first the family

Speaker: NA
Text: day care matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is interesting because the shadow minister was in fact the minister in 2012 when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian National Audit Office did an audit of the Community Support Program, which

Speaker: NA
Text: assists family day care. This was a program that was only in existence after 2006 following

Speaker: NA
Text: which it exceeded its budget allocation significantly year after year. In fact, it was spiralling

Speaker: NA
Text: out of control in excess expenditure. So the Audit Office highlighted problems and

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended a review. The minister, now the shadow minister, sat on her hands and did

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing. It was a part of Labor's mess that we had to clean up on coming to government.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The shadow minister asks about consultations with the secretary. I am happy to inform her

Speaker: NA
Text: that yesterday I had a very wide-ranging, productive discussion following on from earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: conversations, earlier discussions and earlier meetings between ourselves, the department and

Speaker: NA
Text: the sector. But I would like to let the shadow minister know that yesterday I had a particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: productive session with family day care stakeholders. The reality is that although this is a

Speaker: NA
Text: budget measure this year, this is not coming in for 12 months. There are no changes for 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months and we will work together with the sector to support and to have strong family day

Speaker: NA
Text: care. With no changes for 12 months, the transition is workable, manageable and well-

Speaker: NA
Text: supported by the sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: Remember that Labor did nothing to fix this problem. There were several problems that

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor did nothing to fix, but the main problem that we dealt with in the House today was the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill that we put through the lower House that paused the thresholds for the childcare benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: and the childcare rebate. Speaker after speaker, including the shadow minister in her question

Speaker: NA
Text: just now, referred to these changes as 'cuts'. In fact, they are not cuts. It is disingenuous, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: misleading and it is scaremongering to the parents of Australia to describe something that

Speaker: NA
Text: pauses a threshold, which is a level of income at which you qualify for a certain benefit, as a

Speaker: NA
Text: cut when it simply is not.

Speaker: NA
Text: People listening to the member for Adelaide would assume that the hourly rates of child

Speaker: NA
Text: care benefit that they are entitled to in the various circumstances they have their children in

Speaker: NA
Text: are actually going to reduce. In fact, they are not. They are going to increase. That is because

Speaker: NA
Text: the quantum of that subsidy directly to the parents will continue to be indexed. The shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister knows that. In making political point after political point and rhetorical flourish after

Speaker: NA
Text: rhetorical flourish, she is in fact simply stating untruths.

Speaker: NA
Text: The sheer hypocrisy of the stance that has been taken by Labor really is-and I know it is

Speaker: NA
Text: an overused word-breathtaking. That is because contained in the bill that went through the

Speaker: NA
Text: House today was the measure to pause the child care rebate. This was a measure that was

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced by Labor in its last budget. It was desperate to find savings. It knew that the sixth

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus that it predicted was not going to happen. There were six non-surpluses in a row. So it

Speaker: NA
Text: pulled savings out of midair-savings from everywhere. There were $106 million in savings

Speaker: NA
Text: from pausing the child care rebate. They paused the child care rebate for six years, but they

Speaker: NA
Text: did not actually put the legislation through to effect that. We were left to do the dirty work

Speaker: NA
Text: and to pick up the pieces.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said in the House today, it gives me no pleasure to be bringing in the savings that we

Speaker: NA
Text: know, as a responsible government, that we have to make. It gives me no pleasure at all, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: perfectly understand that the job has to be done. By putting in place Labor's own measure-

Speaker: NA
Text: which it did not have the guts to legislate and then made excuses about-and another sensible,

Speaker: NA
Text: moderate measure that simply lasts for three years until we get the budget back under control,

Speaker: NA
Text: we are participating in putting Australia back on a sustainable path. If anybody is interested in

Speaker: NA
Text: the child care needs of the modern economy in which we all live and work, then they must

Speaker: NA
Text: surely be interested in the health of that economy, in the productivity of that economy, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: participation of women in the workforce, in the health of families and in the quality of child

Speaker: NA
Text: care for children. All of these things are front and centre.

Speaker: NA
Text: I acknowledge that all members of the House want those things. We completely disagree

Speaker: NA
Text: on how we will get there. We absolutely take responsibility for the work that we are doing,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the Productivity Commission inquiry that we are having and the new policy ideas that will

Speaker: NA
Text: come in just a few months, which will look into bringing in legislation with new initiatives

Speaker: NA
Text: next year. There is an exciting future. I do hope that the shadow minister is not going to hold

Speaker: NA
Text: us back.

Speaker: NA
Text: An honourable member interjecting-

Speaker: Dr HENDY
Text: Eden-Monaro) (17:28): I do not have four minutes! In Eden-Monaro, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is a rural seat, we have some 2,000-plus preschool students. That is 5.7 per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: population, so it is larger than the national average. I understand that, through the course of

Speaker: NA
Text: the last six years, childcare fees have increased by some 53.2 per cent overall. That is just a

Speaker: NA
Text: shocking figure. I want to ask the assistant minister what we are doing to rein in that sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: increase and what is the state of the Productivity Commission review?

Speaker: Ms LEY
Text: Farrer-Assistant Minister for Education) (17:29): In the interests of time and

Speaker: NA
Text: following on committees and considerations, can I say to the member for Eden-Monaro that I

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate him on his representation of a diverse rural seat and acknowledge that the

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers of rural and regional members on our side of the parliament mean that we do

Speaker: NA
Text: understand the needs of rural and regional child care. It is going to be extremely important

Speaker: NA
Text: with our Productivity Commission review. I will specifically tasked the Productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission to look at rural and regional models of child care that work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yes, it is a shocking legacy and really summed up, as the member for Eden-Monaro has, in

Speaker: NA
Text: one sentence: costs went up 53 per cent coupled with out-of-pocket expenses for families that

Speaker: NA
Text: went up 40 per cent. What a shameful legacy left by Labor. I am already working with my

Speaker: NA
Text: state and territory counterparts to reduce the regulation and red tape that surrounds child care

Speaker: NA
Text: operators and surrounds family day care, and out-of-school care and adds to cost but does not

Speaker: NA
Text: add to quality. We are focusing on the relationship between the educator and the child, the

Speaker: NA
Text: early learning, the nurturing, the care but not all the book work. We believe that that will help

Speaker: NA
Text: relieve the upward pressure on costs. We look forward to your participation in the

Speaker: NA
Text: consultations that the Productivity Commission will have in the weeks and months ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Environment Portfolio

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure, $1,723,004,000

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Flinders-Minister for the Environment) (17:31): Let me make this point to

Speaker: NA
Text: begin with: the meta-position for this budget is framed by six consecutive deficits which had

Speaker: NA
Text: accrued to a total of $240 billion of funds that were spent over and above that which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian government received in revenue. Just to remind the House: $27 billion, $54 billion,

Speaker: NA
Text: $47 billion, $43 billion, $18 billion and $49 billion. That is the massive national task against

Speaker: NA
Text: which this budget is framed. So each and every portfolio has had to work to find greater

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiencies. This portfolio has been part of that process.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: However, I am absolutely delighted that all up in a very difficult and

Speaker: NA
Text: challenging budget environment so as future generations would not have to pay back the

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption of this generation, we have been able to secure $3.5 billion of new expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: programs. There is $2.55 billion for the Emissions Reduction Fund. This is a fund which will

Speaker: NA
Text: actually reduce emissions. It is about doing things where you pay on achievement. It is not

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: about the $30 billion of funds which were paid out by the previous government without in

Speaker: NA
Text: most cases any test whatsoever. I will remind the member for Moreton that in fact there was

Speaker: NA
Text: $9.2 billion being paid to zinc, aluminium, cement, general manufacturing firms with no

Speaker: NA
Text: strings attached by their government. The second thing is, they were paying-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Hawke): Order, Member for Moreton!

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: The second thing is they were paying $5.5 billion to brown coal generators

Speaker: NA
Text: with no strings attached. I want to repeat that: they were paying $5 billion to one small sector

Speaker: NA
Text: with no strings attached. That is probably the largest transfer of funds in Australian history to

Speaker: NA
Text: one small sector of the economy within one short period of time. There was $1.3 billion of

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidies to the coal sector when they said that they were clamping down on emissions, none

Speaker: NA
Text: of which made sense. By contrast, the first of our major new expenditure items compares with

Speaker: NA
Text: a $30 billion set of transfer payments from the Commonwealth to firms under the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: government. We spend $2.55 billion, we withdraw a $30 billion set of transfers from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth to the private sector, which in almost every case were being done with no

Speaker: NA
Text: strings attached whatsoever.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second of the significant areas of new expenditure is $525 million over four years for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Green Army. This is a project aimed at achieving two simple things. Firstly, it is about

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that there is employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: An opposition member interjecting-

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Actually your side is giving bipartisan support, dummkopf. It is about

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that there is bipartisan support-

Speaker: NA
Text: An honourable member interjecting-

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: I am pleased to hear that-for a program which provides employment and

Speaker: NA
Text: does good local environmental things. That could be boardwalks, riverbank restoration,

Speaker: NA
Text: riparian recovery, sand dune restoration or protection of threatened species, whether it is

Speaker: NA
Text: habitat restoration or breeding programs-practical things.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third of the areas in which there has been a significant contribution in this budget is a

Speaker: NA
Text: global figure of more than $500 million for two capital equipment programs-for the

Speaker: NA
Text: acquisition of a supercomputer for the Bureau of Meteorology, which is about better advice

Speaker: NA
Text: with regard to cyclones, floods and fires, and for the acquisition of a new icebreaker, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: critical national infrastructure not just for research but for upholding our position and

Speaker: NA
Text: maintaining our bases in our Antarctica, without which we would place at risk our sovereign

Speaker: NA
Text: claim over the Australian Antarctic Territory. Both of those items were unfunded. They were

Speaker: NA
Text: not given funding by the previous government. Both were overdue. Both have been funded.

Speaker: NA
Text: The final figure will be determined through a tender process, but I can safely say that,

Speaker: NA
Text: between the two, we have provisioned over $500 million. All up, it has been a very effective

Speaker: NA
Text: budget round, against a difficult national backdrop.

Speaker: Mr BUTLER
Text: Port Adelaide) (17:36): I thank the minister for his opening, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: his reference to the Emissions Reduction Fund. The Prime Minister in the parliament earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: this month, and during his trip to North America, in particular, sought to equate the Emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: Reduction Fund and the direct action policy of the new government to the Clean Power Plan

Speaker: NA
Text: announced recently by President Obama. Can the minister outline the similarities?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Flinders-Minister for the Environment) (17:36): I would be delighted to.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first thing is that the American program sets out a simple proposition: it allows us to

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce emissions without a carbon tax, without a cap-and-trade scheme, without an emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: trading scheme. In fact, the last time that there was an attempt to introduce such a scheme in

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States, when all three arms of the American system were aligned on a party

Speaker: NA
Text: basis-a Democrat congress, a Democrat Senate and a Democrat presidency-one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: leading Democrat candidates for the Senate, Joe Manchin, from West Virginia, took the cap-

Speaker: NA
Text: and-trade bill, tied it to a tree and shot it. That was really the last time that we saw any action

Speaker: NA
Text: in the United States towards a cap-and-trade scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: By contrast, what we see now is that the White House plan, which we endorse and support

Speaker: NA
Text: and value and appreciate, as a critical global contribution, takes a very different approach. It

Speaker: NA
Text: does not, to the best of my knowledge and reading, mention cap-and-trade, an emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: trading scheme or a carbon tax at any point in the documentation. I stand to be corrected, but

Speaker: NA
Text: on my reading that is a very clear position. Beyond that, what does it seek to do? It seeks to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage two primary things. It seeks to encourage energy efficiency and the cleaning-up of

Speaker: NA
Text: coal fired power stations. Compare that with the carbon tax that we currently have in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. What you see here is a transfer of $5½ billion from the taxpayer to the brown coal

Speaker: NA
Text: generators, largely within Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, in the United States the system is very clear: they are seeking to clean up the

Speaker: NA
Text: power stations, to provide incentives to engage in gasification, drying, potentially carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: capture and, most likely, reuse. They are also looking at cleaner transmission. They are also

Speaker: NA
Text: looking at general plant efficiency. All of these things are precisely the outcomes which we

Speaker: NA
Text: are considering under the Emissions Reduction Fund. It will depend upon proposals that are

Speaker: NA
Text: the most cost-effective and the cheapest, but it is absolutely clear that the power sector is

Speaker: NA
Text: already looking at those sorts of options.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other thing I want to say about the United States is: we have long said that you cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: have an effective functioning global agreement without an agreement between the US, China,

Speaker: NA
Text: India and the EU. So what we see in the United States is a fundamental step towards an

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement at the end of 2015 at the Paris UNFCCC conference. This is something to be

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome and embraced. But let us not kid ourselves that this is anything other than an

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative to a carbon tax. The White House papers could not be clearer that this is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: carbon tax. They do not make any mention of a carbon tax, a cap-and-trade or an emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: trading scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other point I want to make here is sometimes there is reference to China as if China

Speaker: NA
Text: had a broad based functioning carbon tax. Let me give three examples: the city of Shenzhen

Speaker: NA
Text: gives away 100 per cent of its permits for free-in other words, there is no charge; the city of

Speaker: NA
Text: Shanghai gives away 100 per cent of its permits for free; and the city of Beijing gives away

Speaker: NA
Text: 99.9 per cent of its permits for free. The difference between what we have here in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and what we see in China is the difference between a bowling ball and a pea.

Speaker: Mr COLEMAN
Text: Banks) (17:41): I am pleased to have the opportunity to ask a question

Speaker: NA
Text: of the minister this afternoon about the Bureau of Meteorology. I was pleased to hear him

Speaker: NA
Text: make reference to its important role in his opening remarks. The Bureau of Meteorology plays

Speaker: NA
Text: a critical role right across the nation. Australians of all walks of life rely on the bureau for

Speaker: NA
Text: their day-to-day weather forecast. Importantly, it also plays a role in forecasting extreme and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: unexpected weather events and, indeed, emergencies which we see in our nation whether they

Speaker: NA
Text: relate to flooding or extreme heat-which can lead to fire-or other extreme forms of

Speaker: NA
Text: weather. The bureau plays a critical role in ensuring that Australians are aware of those events

Speaker: NA
Text: in advance to the greatest extent possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bureau is particularly important in rural and regional areas where so much of the

Speaker: NA
Text: livelihood of rural and regional Australians is affected by the weather in farming and in the

Speaker: NA
Text: utilisation of our arable land. The bureau's advice of expected rainfall and temperature

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions is very important to the planning of those businesses.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is also the case that, over the years, weather forecasting technology has improved from

Speaker: NA
Text: the early days where there was probably a very limited reliance on technology to now where

Speaker: NA
Text: in real time on the Bureau of Meteorology website you can observe the different forecasts as

Speaker: NA
Text: they pertain to different postcodes right around the nation in different regions. Again, the

Speaker: NA
Text: atmospheric conditions are so critical.

Speaker: NA
Text: As our population is increasingly concentrated around large metropolitan areas, there is

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously an increased impact from extreme weather events because more people are affected

Speaker: NA
Text: by those events as they occur. The bureau's good work in forecasting those events is well

Speaker: NA
Text: known, which makes it one of the most highly respected institutions in the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Against that background, I did want to ask about the government's efforts in computing

Speaker: NA
Text: technology. I understand that the government has made some moves recently to invest in

Speaker: NA
Text: supercomputing technology, and I am very interested to understand the likely impact of

Speaker: NA
Text: technology on boosting Australia's forecasting capabilities and the benefits that will be

Speaker: NA
Text: derived from that technology more generally.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Flinders-Minister for the Environment) (17:44): To the member for Banks,

Speaker: NA
Text: let me start by acknowledging his fundamental role as one of the lead architects of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Georges River recovery plan. Whilst he was a candidate, he worked hard to recognise that this

Speaker: NA
Text: was a fundamental local environmental issue. It is about the health of the river. It is about the

Speaker: NA
Text: health of the fringing communities. In particular, the green army program was announced at a

Speaker: NA
Text: Georges River site. We committed to a significant Georges River recovery plan and I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: hopeful that, in fact, the green army legislation will pass through the Senate, if it has not

Speaker: NA
Text: already, in the coming hours. The consequence of that will be that this program will be ready

Speaker: NA
Text: to roll out and the Georges River will include some of the first projects in the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having said that, the broader challenge raised by the member is of forecasting for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's urban and regional communities. In Sydney itself, only some years ago there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: massive and catastrophic hailstorm. In Toowoomba and the Toowoomba Range, we

Speaker: NA
Text: witnessed the most tragic of flood events only a few short years ago. The lesson from that is

Speaker: NA
Text: that early warning and early intervention are absolutely critical. So we as a government have

Speaker: NA
Text: provisioned to acquire a new supercomputer. This will be the eighth supercomputer in the

Speaker: NA
Text: series since they first began to be adopted. The hope is that there will be two key steps over

Speaker: NA
Text: the coming two years. Next year, we are due to acquire new satellite capacity, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: following year we are due to acquire a new supercomputer. It was a project that was, sadly,

Speaker: NA
Text: unfunded. It should have been funded. It was overdue to be funded and there was a black hole

Speaker: NA
Text: in the budget. Nevertheless, we have made space in order to find that funding. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: funded it fully. The funding is set aside to ensure that, once the tender process is complete, the

Speaker: NA
Text: supercomputer will be acquired.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Why is it important? It is important for rural communities because it provides early

Speaker: NA
Text: warning in relation to fire, flood and cyclone. In particular, the fire authorities currently use

Speaker: NA
Text: the existing supercomputer to provide early warnings about wind shifts, which are absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental to fighting the fire and even more fundamental to protecting the lives of people

Speaker: NA
Text: in particular communities and firefighters. In the end, there will be fewer lives lost, we hope,

Speaker: NA
Text: as a consequence of this. What is the capacity upgrade? It is a tenfold increase in capacity.

Speaker: NA
Text: That allows us to run more cycles, to look at more activities on a commensurate basis and to

Speaker: NA
Text: give earlier warnings-in short, more data, more frequently, more accurately. That is what the

Speaker: NA
Text: supercomputer is about. For our urban customers, for the population of Australia, they can see

Speaker: NA
Text: if there is the risk of flash flooding, as we saw, tragically, in Toowoomba. If there is the risk

Speaker: NA
Text: of a hail event, precautions can be taken such as placing cars undercover. We cannot stop all

Speaker: NA
Text: of the effects of weather, but we can give people the opportunity to mitigate. That is a quick

Speaker: NA
Text: summary. It is an important acquisition and, at the end of the day, it is about better data for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians and about saving lives.

Speaker: Mr BUTLER
Text: Port Adelaide) (17:48): I ask the minister a couple of questions about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Emissions Reduction Fund. Firstly, can the minister point to any modelling, conducted either

Speaker: NA
Text: internally by the department or under contract by an external organisation, around the likely

Speaker: NA
Text: abatement achieved through the Emissions Reduction Fund and its contribution to the five per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent target? In particular, does that modelling distinguish between abatement that is or is not

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent with internationally agreed methodologies? Regarding the Carbon Farming

Speaker: NA
Text: Initiative legislation that the minister introduced to the parliament today as the vehicle for this

Speaker: NA
Text: fund, obviously this essentially expands the land sector specific framework beyond the land

Speaker: NA
Text: sector to cover a whole range of other sectors that the minister would like to see covered by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Emissions Reduction Fund, including household and community energy efficiency and a

Speaker: NA
Text: range of others.

Speaker: NA
Text: The economics of the potential abatement from these other sectors will obviously be

Speaker: NA
Text: different potentially to the economics of the land sector, yet, as I understand it, the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's intention is to assess all of the sectors on the same lowest-cost model. I am just

Speaker: NA
Text: wondering whether the minister can outline how the government intends to deal with those

Speaker: NA
Text: cost variations between those different sectors; and how an average weighted price disclosure,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is intended to provide the price signal for potential bidders, will have any validity if the

Speaker: NA
Text: contracts are highly variable.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Flinders-Minister for the Environment) (17:50): I am delighted to answer

Speaker: NA
Text: the questions from the member for Port Adelaide. It is good to see him on his feet. He has not

Speaker: NA
Text: actually asked a question in 9½ months in question time, but I have not embarrassed him in

Speaker: NA
Text: public about that fact.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me deal with part 2 of the question first in relation to the Carbon Farming Initiative

Speaker: NA
Text: extensions. The answer is very simple: we are using the lowest-cost purchasing model. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the way to purchase abatement, and we are shamelessly, clearly, openly, purchasing

Speaker: NA
Text: abatement on the lowest cost. That was what we said we would do on 2 February 2010 and

Speaker: NA
Text: we have never deviated from that model. We have continued that through to this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: approach, and the answer is very simple: the clean energy regulator will produce a weighted

Speaker: NA
Text: average price for abatement and the way that purchasing will occur will be up the cost curve.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, as volume needs to be purchased, each successive unit will be acquired and, then at such

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: time as the regulator has acquired all of the units which it needs to acquire, we will see a final

Speaker: NA
Text: price and that weighted average price is released. We are not differentiating by sectors and we

Speaker: NA
Text: have always said we would not do that.

Speaker: NA
Text: As an example, if you have $100 to acquire units, you could acquire on a differentiated

Speaker: NA
Text: basis two units at $50, because you wanted to support a particular sector but you would only

Speaker: NA
Text: get two tonnes of abatement. Or you could acquire 20 units at $5 per tonne, if that were the

Speaker: NA
Text: cheapest. We will without doubt, without question, be purchasing the lowest-cost abatement.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was always our intention and that is how you can get the maximum efficient result for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. I think that that is very important.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, it is important to put this in the context that the world has two primary

Speaker: NA
Text: approaches. One is a carbon tax based system which is, for example, the European system-

Speaker: NA
Text: although they have high caps relative to actual production. They have more than 100 sectors

Speaker: NA
Text: carved out as being trade exposed, and many have said that the net contribution to emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction is likely to be minimal, if not negligible, between now and 2020 such as the head of

Speaker: NA
Text: Point Carbon's research desk-Point Carbon being, arguably, the leading trading house in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the European scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: The alternative scheme, the clean development mechanism, produces abatement as an

Speaker: NA
Text: offset, which is then purchased on a lowest-cost basis. At the moment there are about 1.4

Speaker: NA
Text: million tonnes of genuine abatement credits which are available internationally. The evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: is clear that the clean development mechanism, which is a model for what we are doing here,

Speaker: NA
Text: has produced genuine, low-cost abatement.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second half of the question was in relation to the Emissions Reduction Fund. I will

Speaker: NA
Text: point the member to the work of Energetics. I will also point the member to the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: white paper sets out expectations. The modelling on which that was based is also set out in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of the budget. The budget sets out a projected cash flow.

Speaker: NA
Text: The full $2.55 billion will be available from day one. We have changed. We have made a

Speaker: NA
Text: policy change here: instead of the $2.55 billion being phased over four years, it has all been

Speaker: NA
Text: brought forward and is all available from day one. A projected cash flow has been set out,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is based on, obviously, the analysis of the department. What we cannot do of course is

Speaker: NA
Text: release the projected price, because that is commercial-in-confidence and would prejudice a

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth tender. That work has been done. It has been done not just by us in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: analysis; it has also been done by firms such as Energetics. What does it mean? We will

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve our targets and will achieve them easily. Most significantly, we will achieve them

Speaker: NA
Text: without a carbon tax.

Speaker: Mr IRONS
Text: Swan) (17:54): Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. My question will be to the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister, and I am sure that you would be capable of answering the question, as you indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier, but I will make sure I address it to the minister! It is in relation to the Swan and

Speaker: NA
Text: Canning rivers in Perth, but first I want to provide the minister with some context, obviously,

Speaker: NA
Text: on environmental issues in my electorate of Swan-environmental volunteering and some

Speaker: NA
Text: previous approaches to the environment in my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the minister might know, Swan is like an inland peninsula, surrounded by rivers on

Speaker: NA
Text: three sides while on the eastern side there is a series of small lakes and swamps. It is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: environmentally sensitive area; it is a bit of a jewel in the electorate because there are not

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: many people who are aware of it. But I know that the minister has been down there; he visited

Speaker: NA
Text: it with me some time ago. I do appreciate that and the people of Swan appreciated his taking

Speaker: NA
Text: the time to come and look at that particular jewel down in the electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The people of my electorate interact with the local environment all the time and

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental issues are therefore particularly important in the electorate. I do remember that

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the first times I went down to the Canning River regional area, we were in the process

Speaker: NA
Text: of releasing some swans that had been injured. An environmental group in Victoria Park had

Speaker: NA
Text: retrieved them, saved them and brought them back to health, and we went down one Sunday

Speaker: NA
Text: morning and released them back into the Canning River. The only real negative to that was

Speaker: NA
Text: that about half a dozen planes flew over the top as we were doing it and scared them! But at

Speaker: NA
Text: the same time, the high aircraft usage over that area does have an effect on the environment

Speaker: NA
Text: down there.

Speaker: NA
Text: The wetland areas were degraded over time, which has created many issues. Some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: degradation that we are still dealing with today includes use as a rubbish tip, which was on

Speaker: NA
Text: Burswood Island; dumping of toxic waste at Castledare in Wilson-chemicals being dumped

Speaker: NA
Text: in the area; asbestos being dumped in the area; and all of this, obviously, was not helped by

Speaker: NA
Text: antisocial behaviour like the dumping of shopping carts from the Carousel shopping centre.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has also been an issue with the introduction of non-native species and weeds, which

Speaker: NA
Text: have taken over large areas and which have caused problems for aquatic life in the river

Speaker: NA
Text: systems. They have also reduced the biodiversity. A serious example of this is the hydrocotyle

Speaker: NA
Text: weed, which is one of the things that I showed the minister when he came down and looked at

Speaker: NA
Text: the Wilson Lagoon. That was introduced to the river in the 1980s. For those who do not

Speaker: NA
Text: know, hydrocotyle is an imported pet weed. It was initially in fish bowls but it was released

Speaker: NA
Text: into the local river area, unfortunately. In the right conditions it can double its biomass in

Speaker: NA
Text: three days to a week, creating a green mat over the entire area-particularly on the Wilson

Speaker: NA
Text: Lagoon. Since then it has caused major problems, and periodically there have been very bad

Speaker: NA
Text: years of growth; for example, 1992 and 2013-14 have been extremely bad years.

Speaker: NA
Text: SERCUL, which is one of the local volunteer environmental groups down there-I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister is aware of them-has in the past directed over $77,000 to tackling the

Speaker: NA
Text: hydrocotyle over the past decade. The Two Rivers Catchment Group has directed $27,000 as

Speaker: NA
Text: well over the same time, but a greater investment is needed to finally get on top of this issue

Speaker: NA
Text: because it is causing enormous damage to the environment down there. This was at the heart

Speaker: NA
Text: of our proposal to the minister for the Swan-Canning River recovery program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Much of the work to remediate the environment will need to be done at the local level by

Speaker: NA
Text: local groups. And even when the funding is delivered the larger body of work also tends to be

Speaker: NA
Text: done at the local level. The majority of the action involves weeding, revegetation and removal

Speaker: NA
Text: of the hydrocotyle, which is a pretty difficult issue. I went down there myself with one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Wilson Wetlands groups and with a group of schoolchildren from Wilson Primary School. I

Speaker: NA
Text: put on some waders and went out into the lagoon and removed some of the hydrocotyle in

Speaker: NA
Text: there. It is an extremely long process which will require a lot of time from the local

Speaker: NA
Text: environment groups.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the past, the Howard government's appreciation of the need for environmental action at

Speaker: NA
Text: the local level has been a strong focus. The focus under Labor has been solely on climate

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: change and offshore credits, neglecting on-the-ground action down in the areas. This was

Speaker: NA
Text: epitomised by the reduction that NRM had in their funding under the last government.

Speaker: NA
Text: But just to get on to the question: can the minister outline the government's Coastal River

Speaker: NA
Text: Recovery Initiatives program and the areas that will be targeted? And what funding has been

Speaker: NA
Text: allocated for the Swan-Canning rivers, and how will this improve the environmental health of

Speaker: NA
Text: the waterway?

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Flinders-Minister for the Environment) (17:59): I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Swan for a comprehensive question. All up the government's coastal rivers recovery plan is

Speaker: NA
Text: $9.3 million. Of course, there is $1 million that has been allocated for the Swan-Canning

Speaker: NA
Text: River recovery plan. I will come to that in more detail in just a second. In addition,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly with the member for Boothby here, there is $1 million for the River Torrens. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was a champion and a fighter for that. I also note that the member for Bass, who is here, was

Speaker: NA
Text: an inveterate campaigner for the $3 million for the Tamar River recovery plan. His river was

Speaker: NA
Text: dirtier than yours! So three of the key components of the national coastal rivers recovery plan

Speaker: NA
Text: are represented around the table in the chamber this evening. There was also $3.3 million for

Speaker: NA
Text: Tuggerah Lakes for recovery there as well as $1 million over four years for the Yarra River

Speaker: NA
Text: recovery plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Turning to the Swan and Canning rivers, there are three components which are addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: in the $1 million. Firstly and most significantly is weed removal, eradication and revegetation,

Speaker: NA
Text: as set out by the member. The hydrocotyle, as you have shown me, is a fundamental problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: Both rivers can be threatened by it. Each river has lagoon systems where the water is not

Speaker: NA
Text: running so quickly. I have with you inspected the site and, seen the challenge and it was

Speaker: NA
Text: precisely because of those site visits and the support of the community and the state that we

Speaker: NA
Text: determined that this was a genuine and necessary problem. I know it affects electorates of all

Speaker: NA
Text: persuasions. The Labor-held electorate of Perth will also benefit significantly from this

Speaker: NA
Text: program, as it should. At the end of the day it is about maintaining and improving the health

Speaker: NA
Text: of one of our fundamental urban riparian assets.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second component of the Swan River recovery plan is community education. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: about ensuring that the sorts of shopping trolley issues and urban pollution issues to which the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Swan refers are mitigated-that they are reduced. The lessons around the country

Speaker: NA
Text: are very clear: if you engage your schoolchildren early, if you engage your secondary school

Speaker: NA
Text: students, then you can have an impact on the community as a whole. We cannot guarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: 100 per cent community compliance, because that is the nature of who we are and what we

Speaker: NA
Text: are as a society, but we can make a dramatic difference.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third of the changes is in relation to community action, and that is supporting

Speaker: NA
Text: particular community groups to engage in on-the-ground physical work. It could be

Speaker: NA
Text: replanting, it could be riparian recovery, it may be the development of habitat for threatened

Speaker: NA
Text: species in particular along the Swan and Canning rivers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Only a few short hours ago I did sign-off on a brief allocating the funds to the Perth NRM.

Speaker: NA
Text: But after consultation with the member, the significant condition which I had placed on it is

Speaker: NA
Text: twofold. Firstly, the condition is that there will be zero dollars used by the Perth NRM for

Speaker: NA
Text: administration-100 per cent of the funds, $1 million of the $1 million allocated, must be

Speaker: NA
Text: used for cleaning up river in the three ways outlined. That is a direct consequence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: rightful demands of the member for Swan that every dollar goes to cleaning up the Swan and

Speaker: NA
Text: Canning system.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second condition is that the allocations are notified to myself beforehand. That allows

Speaker: NA
Text: proper consultation and openly I say with the member here to ensure that he and other

Speaker: NA
Text: community representatives believe that all recipient bodies are appropriate bodies with full

Speaker: NA
Text: probity attached to them. We will, of course, do our probity checks but I wanted to make sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is a second line of defence. I thank the member. This program would not have

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred without the support of people such as the member for Bass, the member for Boothby

Speaker: NA
Text: and the member for Swan and this project would certainly not have occurred without the

Speaker: NA
Text: tireless and indefatigable advocacy of the member for Swan.

Speaker: Mr BUTLER
Text: Port Adelaide) (18:04): I want to ask the minister a couple of questions

Speaker: NA
Text: about the National Water Commission, which has been abolished under this budget. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister knows, this is an independent statutory authority that has been in place since well

Speaker: NA
Text: before the election of the Rudd government-I think for 10 years or so-that was set up as

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the intergovernmental agreement with COAG on national water issues. Its functions

Speaker: NA
Text: include triennial assessments of the performance of the states, implementing the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Water Initiative, advising and reporting on performance of the water industry more broadly

Speaker: NA
Text: under the National Water Initiative, delivery of the planning report card on the status of water

Speaker: NA
Text: plans that are in place across the country and delivery of national performance reports on the

Speaker: NA
Text: performance of both urban and rural water utilities. As the minister also knows, the Water

Speaker: NA
Text: Services Association of Australia and the Australian Water Association have both expressed

Speaker: NA
Text: grave concerns about the abolition of the National Water Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of these questions were asked in Senate estimates without any clear answer. I wonder

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the minister can provide some more clarity around which functions currently

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken by the Water Commission will be discontinued. For those that will continue to be

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken, by whom will they be undertaken? If those decisions have not yet been made-if

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister is not able to answer those questions in detail-when will those decisions be

Speaker: NA
Text: made and announced to the parliament and, perhaps more importantly, to the sector and to the

Speaker: NA
Text: community? As I have outlined, the functions of the Water Commission involve very

Speaker: NA
Text: significant interaction with the states and territories but also with the water industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: represented by the two associations I referred to. I wonder whether the minister can detail the

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation undertaken with those bodies prior to the decision to abolish the water

Speaker: NA
Text: commission. Also, what discussions have taken place, in regard to those questions I have

Speaker: NA
Text: raised, with the states and particularly those party to the intergovernmental agreement, since

Speaker: NA
Text: the decision was announced to abolish the Water Commission?

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Flinders-Minister for the Environment) (18:07): In response to the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Port Adelaide's question, let me begin with two overarching principles: I began this

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion of the portfolio budget by framing it in the context of the $240 billion deficit

Speaker: NA
Text: overrun which occurred over the last six years. This is done against the backdrop of an

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinarily expensive national budgetary crisis which we have faced, so it is something

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have always intended to address and which we said we would address. The second

Speaker: NA
Text: background item here is that the Murray-Darling Basin Agreement has been completed. Much

Speaker: NA
Text: of the preparatory work for that has been done by the National Water Commission and we

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen, with the grand achievement of the Murray-Darling Basin Agreement having been

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: endorsed by all relevant states, that we now have an operating system which we can all be

Speaker: NA
Text: proud of.

Speaker: NA
Text: The role of the National Water Commission-as somebody who was integrally involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: helping to establish it-was first and foremost aimed at ensuring that we would reach the

Speaker: NA
Text: Holy Grail of a Murray-Darling Basin agreement. That was its raison d'etre, its purpose, its

Speaker: NA
Text: reason for existence. We have achieved that primary outcome. Institutions at a governmental

Speaker: NA
Text: level are not necessarily meant to live forever. It is sometimes a mark of their success that

Speaker: NA
Text: they have achieved their outcomes. In a government with over 900 different agencies,

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations or commissions, if they can then be slimmed down to a number which might

Speaker: NA
Text: well end up being half of that then I think that is a sign of success.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this particular case, we think that the National Water Commission achieved its

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes. The Murray-Darling Basin Agreement was a fundamental outcome. We are proud

Speaker: NA
Text: of what has happened. I particularly want to congratulate my parliamentary secretary, Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Simon Birmingham, a senator for South Australia. He worked to complete the task which had

Speaker: NA
Text: begun at COAG in 2004 with the Intergovernmental Agreement on a National Water

Speaker: NA
Text: Initiative. That task has been significantly achieved.

Speaker: NA
Text: In terms of the monitoring and reporting, I can make a statement to the parliament that the

Speaker: NA
Text: functions will overwhelmingly be adopted by the Department of the Environment. They will

Speaker: NA
Text: be brought within the relevant water unit. I think they are well-equipped and capable of

Speaker: NA
Text: handling those functions and will do that with great distinction.

Speaker: Mr NIKOLIC
Text: Bass) (18:10): Minister, can I first of all thank you for your commitments

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Tamar River. As I recall, the genesis of the three-year plan that has just been approved

Speaker: NA
Text: in the budget was on a famous day, 4 July 2012, on a very cold morning in Launceston, when

Speaker: NA
Text: there were good discussions with some key stakeholders that have resulted in the plan to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver a healthier Tamar River.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am mindful of the time limitations so I will quickly ask you about the status of the

Speaker: NA
Text: process to procure a new icebreaker to replace the ageing Aurora Australis. Can you outline

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's commitment in the budget to our Antarctic program, update on the status of

Speaker: NA
Text: the icebreaker and explain how the government's commitment to Antarctica will benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania?

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Flinders-Minister for the Environment) (18:11): To the member for Bass, let

Speaker: NA
Text: me make this point. Firstly, as I noted earlier, you were personally an absolute champion, an

Speaker: NA
Text: indefatigable champion, for the Tamar River recovery program. Secondly, as one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmanian team, the member for Bass, along with all others, advocated for the replenishment

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Antarctic program.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are two parts to this: the capital acquisition and the research. The interesting thing is

Speaker: NA
Text: that the need for a new icebreaker was self-evident. The Aurora Australis is the best part of

Speaker: NA
Text: two decades old. It has really reached the end of its operational lifetime, which will be strung

Speaker: NA
Text: out for longer perhaps than it should be, but I am assured that all the safety protocols can be

Speaker: NA
Text: met. Nevertheless, we have needed for some years now a new icebreaker. In this budget we

Speaker: NA
Text: made the commitment to acquire a new icebreaker, and the funding has been set aside. There

Speaker: NA
Text: was a black hole-critical national infrastructure was not funded. It is now funded. The exact

Speaker: NA
Text: amount will be subject to a tender but, as I have said elsewhere and earlier, a global figure of

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: $500 million covers the cost of the icebreaker and the Bureau of Meteorology's

Speaker: NA
Text: supercomputer easily.

Speaker: NA
Text: What will this do? It will allow us to have a world-class research platform. It will allow us

Speaker: NA
Text: to have a world-class logistics and supply vessel. It will enable us to reinforce the bases at

Speaker: NA
Text: Mawson, Davis and Casey. In particular, it will allow us to ensure that our sovereignty is

Speaker: NA
Text: established beyond any point of doubt whatsoever. Under the Antarctic protocols and treaties,

Speaker: NA
Text: what is fundamental is usage, and if you are not maintaining a presence and usage then you

Speaker: NA
Text: place at risk your claim for sovereignty. For all those reasons, the new icebreaker is

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental. But in terms of scientific research we could not have a more valuable

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental platform.

Speaker: NA
Text: This brings me to the second part of our commitment. There are three programs which we

Speaker: NA
Text: have endorsed which are going to assist with the long-term research and logistics capability of

Speaker: NA
Text: our Antarctic program and are all about establishing Tasmania as the global gateway for

Speaker: NA
Text: Antarctic activity. Firstly, we have reaffirmed the $25 million for the cooperative research

Speaker: NA
Text: centre on Antarctica. Secondly, we have established the global gateway partnership between

Speaker: NA
Text: the University of Tasmania, the CSIRO and the magnificent staff at the Antarctic Division-

Speaker: NA
Text: all world-class researchers, but I am particularly proud of the researchers at the Antarctic

Speaker: NA
Text: Division led by Tony Fleming.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third thing we have done is to provide $48 million for the extension of the Hobart

Speaker: NA
Text: runway. That $48 billion serves many purposes. It serves purposes for general commerce,

Speaker: NA
Text: general tourism and general trade within Tasmania, but in particular it equips the runway to

Speaker: NA
Text: be a logistics hub for activity in and out of the Antarctic. When you put the new ship, the new

Speaker: NA
Text: research and the runway together, this is the biggest single investment in Australia's Antarctic

Speaker: NA
Text: program in Australian history. This is a very important step forward. It is critical. It is the

Speaker: NA
Text: right thing to do for the environment. It is the right thing to do economically, because many

Speaker: NA
Text: other countries have expressed deep interest in having Hobart or Tasmania as their logistics

Speaker: NA
Text: hub for Antarctic activities. And it is the right thing to do in terms of our national strategic

Speaker: NA
Text: interest.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just before I conclude, I want to thank all the members of the department and my office

Speaker: NA
Text: who worked on the budget. The department staff were led by Matt Whitfort. He and his team

Speaker: NA
Text: did an extraordinary job during the process of the budget preparation. Within my office, I

Speaker: NA
