Text: want to thank my chief of staff, Wendy Black, and Tamay Rigzin, as well as all the other

Speaker: NA
Text: staff.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Agriculture Portfolio

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure, $485,125,000

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: New England-Minister for Agriculture and Deputy Leader of The

Speaker: NA
Text: Nationals) (18:16): This is my first roll of the dice in the Federation Chamber in this process

Speaker: NA
Text: of the budget. Agriculture has been a vital industry and will be a vital industry for where our

Speaker: NA
Text: economy goes. It is a statement of fact that, if we did not have an agriculture industry, then

Speaker: NA
Text: we would not have the nation that we currently see. This nation was in the past strongly

Speaker: NA
Text: reliant on its development through agriculture, and I believe that that is coming back to the

Speaker: NA
Text: fore again.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been extremely happy with the process that agriculture has been going through since

Speaker: NA
Text: we attained government. I feel there has been a real return to the Australian people because of

Speaker: NA
Text: that. I note with some interest that, in the quarter ending in March, we had a 19.3 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in agricultural income, and it was 19.3 per cent in the same quarter in the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: year. This shows a trend, and this trend is underwritten by a whole range of factors that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have been concentrating on intently.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the issues is re-establishing the live cattle and sheep trade in a form that is bringing

Speaker: NA
Text: real dignity back into people's lives. I was happy to see that in Western Australia the other day

Speaker: NA
Text: they were getting up to $153 for sheep. This brings substantial change to people's lives, who

Speaker: NA
Text: get the dignity of a substantial cheque coming through the door on the sale of sheep. This

Speaker: NA
Text: allows them to reinvest in their property and brings dignity into their lives by allowing them

Speaker: NA
Text: to do some of the things that everybody else takes for granted-maybe it is renovations

Speaker: NA
Text: around the house, maybe it is buying themselves a new car.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the sort of outcome you would expect for people who go through the privations of

Speaker: NA
Text: living remote to many social services. If their job is one where they cannot get all the social

Speaker: NA
Text: services that one would expect, living in an urban environment, then we hope that the quid

Speaker: NA
Text: pro quo is a reasonable return for their endeavours. I am also happy to see that, in the timber

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, we are getting a large pick-up in the export of timber. We had a record number of

Speaker: NA
Text: live cattle moved in April, over 170,000. Prior to that-I think in the month before that-we

Speaker: NA
Text: had a record amount of frozen beef, 108,000 tonnes. When you stack all these things against

Speaker: NA
Text: each other, you can see that agriculture is not only starting to provide a real return to the

Speaker: NA
Text: people on the land but also managing to help our nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will give one classic anecdote about that. Back in the month of January, we suspected that

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation would make a $100 million loss, a $100 million deficit. We actually made a $1.4

Speaker: NA
Text: billion surplus-a $1½ billion turnaround. That was predominantly driven by agriculture. We

Speaker: NA
Text: had an excellent crop coming off in Western Australia-we got about 6.2 million tonnes of

Speaker: NA
Text: that onto the ships-and we had good outcomes in the live cattle trade, the live sheep trade

Speaker: NA
Text: and the export of frozen beef, chilled beef and chilled mutton.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me turn to some other areas. We have managed to finalise a free trade agreement with

Speaker: NA
Text: Korea, which has brought about a substantial reduction in tariffs, especially in the beef sector,

Speaker: NA
Text: and ultimately they will go down to zero. We have finalised a trade agreement with Japan,

Speaker: NA
Text: which has brought about a substantial reduction in tariffs. We are currently in the throes of

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiating the Chinese one. I have had discussions with the Chinese departments, and

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Gao from China was here in the last fortnight. We were very focused on what we are

Speaker: NA
Text: doing there. Some of the increases in exports to China have been incredible. They have been

Speaker: NA
Text: 500 per cent in a year in some sectors. There has been an exponential increase in beef exports.

Speaker: NA
Text: These all augur well for a good outcome.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the back of that we have also had to work closely on drought policy. We have been

Speaker: NA
Text: managing to deliver good outcomes on drought policy, good outcomes on infrastructure and

Speaker: NA
Text: great outcomes with the recent $100 million further investment in research and development

Speaker: NA
Text: in agriculture. That basically takes our total to around $700 million a year. I look forward to

Speaker: NA
Text: participating in this process over the next 45 minutes. We will see how we go.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Text: Hunter) (18:21): This is the Minister for Agriculture's debut in this

Speaker: NA
Text: process, as he mentioned. I congratulate him on his tie. I do not know whether that counts as

Speaker: NA
Text: blue, but it is close enough. May the Blues have a great win tonight!

Speaker: NA
Text: I advise the minister that this should be a pretty painless 45 minutes for him. The minister

Speaker: NA
Text: and I have talked often about our best endeavours to take a bipartisan approach to this

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio. We together believe it is too important an area of public policy to be playing

Speaker: NA
Text: political games with. We are very conscious of the very short political cycle at the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: level-three years-and the need for long-term planning and certainty in this sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am a little bemused though by the minister's own scorecard, claiming that everything that

Speaker: NA
Text: has happened in a positive sense in agriculture over the last 10 months has been due to the

Speaker: NA
Text: good work of the Abbott government. I challenge him throughout these 45 minutes to tell me

Speaker: NA
Text: how the rise in timber exports, the increases in frozen beef exports-and he mentioned that

Speaker: NA
Text: about four times-the bumper wheat harvest and the free trade agreements, signed or

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise, are as a result of anything he has done.

Speaker: NA
Text: He will of course claim some success in the live trade. He is always very keen to mention

Speaker: NA
Text: that. He mentioned that four times as well. I often think that for the minister if it does not moo

Speaker: NA
Text: it does not matter. This is a very diverse portfolio. I understand how important the beef

Speaker: NA
Text: industry is in this portfolio but there are other dimensions, Minister, to the agriculture

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio, including forestry and fisheries, which you decided not to include in the name of the

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister can attempt to claim credit for all of these things but he will need to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: over the next 45 minutes some evidence of something he has done that led to the outcomes he

Speaker: NA
Text: has been talking about. Of course he will say that things have improved in the live trade

Speaker: NA
Text: sector. I have said many times that the pause in the live trade sector was unfortunate and I

Speaker: NA
Text: regret it. I would like to think that, if I were the minister at the time, there would have been

Speaker: NA
Text: other alternatives available to the government. I often also make the point that this country

Speaker: NA
Text: probably would not have the best animal welfare system in the world now-ESCAS-if it

Speaker: NA
Text: were not for the pause. It is doubtful that the industry would have ever embraced ESCAS if

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry had not been paused. Those opposite when they were in opposition always

Speaker: NA
Text: criticised ESCAS, but now in government whenever they are in a battle with those who have

Speaker: NA
Text: as their key focus animal welfare they invoke ESCAS as the great system that Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: possesses now as a defence against those charges.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe the government has got off to a pretty slow start in agriculture, and I am here to

Speaker: NA
Text: help in any way I can. I think the agriculture white paper, while possibly justifiable, presents

Speaker: NA
Text: policy inertia for the country at a time when we are really in a hurry. We have hundreds of

Speaker: NA
Text: reports on reviewing the industry, reviewing our outlook and reviewing where we need to go

Speaker: NA
Text: as a sector. I think it is just time that we got on with it rather than spend a year trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: reinvent all those reports through the white paper. I notice the member for Hume here. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: the author of one of those very good reports. Maybe if the minister had just spoken to the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Hume, we could all have saved some time.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am excited about the Agriculture portfolio and the agriculture sector. I believe that what I

Speaker: NA
Text: have described as the dining boom presents this sector with enormous opportunities. The

Speaker: NA
Text: extent to which we capitalise on those opportunities will depend on how hard we work at

Speaker: NA
Text: those aspirations. We do need strategic plans, proper assessments of where we are going, and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: we need a big injection of infrastructure in our supply chains. The dining boom is not going to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver for Australia because we are lucky. The dining boom will only deliver for Australia if

Speaker: NA
Text: we put in the effort, we have the correct strategic plans, we attract the investment we need in

Speaker: NA
Text: those supply chains and government policy is set correctly. Of course, it will not be just about

Speaker: NA
Text: larger volumes. It cannot be just about volumes. To pluck a number out of the air, we might

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to increase volumes threefold, but that will not bring us the dining boom as I aspire it

Speaker: NA
Text: to be. It is high yields and high-value products which will deliver off the back of the dining

Speaker: NA
Text: boom, and that is where we need to focus. R&D will be very important. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: New England-Minister for Agriculture and Deputy Leader of The

Speaker: NA
Text: Nationals) (18:26): I think it is important to reply in kind at the first available opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: what the shadow minister has brought about. Today one was the monkey grinder and the other

Speaker: NA
Text: was the clown-

Speaker: NA
Text: An honourable member: Organ grinder!

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: Right. But I do commend the shadow minister because I do believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a general view that agriculture policy is similar to defence policy. It has to be

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent. We do not want wild oscillations of policy, because people on farms do not plan

Speaker: NA
Text: for three years, they plan for 30 years, and therefore we need consistency. I am sure the

Speaker: NA
Text: endeavours of both sides will be to make good decisions better rather than make holistic

Speaker: NA
Text: changes that create major uncertainty.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to commend the work that has been done over such a long period of time

Speaker: NA
Text: by John Cobb, who is here today. He has had very strong involvement at a personal level,

Speaker: NA
Text: owning a farm, in agri-politics and also in politics itself. However, I have to take up one thing

Speaker: NA
Text: straightaway. People ask: 'What are some of the major changes?' I will give you a major

Speaker: NA
Text: change between when the Howard government finished and when the Rudd-Gillard-

Speaker: NA
Text: whomever government finished. When the Howard coalition government finished, the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: in agriculture was $3.48 billion. In the last Labor budget it was $1.6 billion. So the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party cut $1.88 billion over their tenure. This is a substantive change for our attention. I look

Speaker: NA
Text: forward to the opposition's policy showing reinvigoration for that. How their policy addresses

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the issues rests a lot on the shadow minister's shoulders. One thing I do want is real

Speaker: NA
Text: competition-competition of ideas-because that helps progress where agriculture goes.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can quickly point to some clear changes. When we came in, we had the concessional farm

Speaker: NA
Text: finance package, which I acknowledge the Labor Party drew up but they just never signed it

Speaker: NA
Text: off. Because it was never signed off, it could not be delivered. We had a package which was

Speaker: NA
Text: not signed off and was not actually designed for the people who were to use it. We had to

Speaker: NA
Text: completely recalibrate it. Because we wanted to get all the states and territories signed off, we

Speaker: NA
Text: had to go around to get them all to sign off. To the extent it was designed, it was inoperable,

Speaker: NA
Text: because it wasn't signed off by all the states and territories. We had to do that and we had to

Speaker: NA
Text: reallocate money. So we had the same amount of money, God bless them, going to

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania-that is fair enough-as we had going to Queensland. One area was in the middle

Speaker: NA
Text: of a drought and the other area wasn't suffering the privations of a drought. We did that. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was the coalition that did that, and the people are getting that money because we organised

Speaker: NA
Text: that.

Speaker: NA
Text: The next thing is we also found money for water-that is definitely something that we did;

Speaker: NA
Text: $10 million-and we have been receiving strong support in that policy initiative, because

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: people like the capacity of getting new watering points out on their place. That is something

Speaker: NA
Text: we did.

Speaker: NA
Text: On 4 March we got the changes to the interim farm family payment, and now over 1,400

Speaker: NA
Text: farming families who have been doing it tough have been receiving payments in access of

Speaker: NA
Text: $900 a fortnight. It is amazing when people say, 'You haven't actually done anything in

Speaker: NA
Text: agriculture. You haven't got any money out.' That is an awful lot of money and it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: going out, and we have been doing that. So we did that.

Speaker: NA
Text: The free trade agreement to Korea was not signed off; we did that-that was another thing

Speaker: NA
Text: we did. The progress that has been made with the ag white paper, which was a clear statement

Speaker: NA
Text: by the coalition of their intent to have a holistic and very discerning view on where

Speaker: NA
Text: agriculture goes and create a policy format that becomes not a direction of the- (Time

Speaker: NA
Text: expired)

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Text: Hunter) (18:31): I will invite the minister before closing tonight to

Speaker: NA
Text: give the parliament an update on the white paper, the timing of the initial paper, the final

Speaker: NA
Text: paper and maybe some information about the process leading up to the completion of that

Speaker: NA
Text: document. I will ask the minister next time he gets to his feet to tell me exactly where. He has

Speaker: NA
Text: cited live trade, timber exports, frozen beef, bumper wheat harvests-and I assume he was

Speaker: NA
Text: referring to WA-and the free trade agreement. I ask him how what he describes as

Speaker: NA
Text: reconfiguration of the concessional loans package brought any of those outcomes; how

Speaker: NA
Text: additional money for water infrastructure, as he calls it, has brought any of those outcomes;

Speaker: NA
Text: how the family payment-and of course there has always been a family payment, Minister-

Speaker: NA
Text: has brought any of those five outcomes; and how the free trade agreement, which is not yet

Speaker: NA
Text: ratified, has brought any of those five outcomes you boasted about and claimed credit for

Speaker: NA
Text: tonight.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have got so many questions to ask. I wasn't sure where to start but you have taken us to

Speaker: NA
Text: the concessional loans scheme, so it is probably as good a place as any. You said, Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: that you reconfigured Labor's concessional loans scheme. It is untrue to say that the states

Speaker: NA
Text: were not signed up. There was one outstanding state, Western Australia, when I left office-

Speaker: NA
Text: and you do not need to look to your advisers; I can confirm that for you, Minister; I can assure

Speaker: NA
Text: you that that is the case. It is true that you took money off some states and transferred those

Speaker: NA
Text: amounts of money to other states-and of course the losers were the smaller states of WA,

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania and South Australia. You say that that was a ridiculous arrangement, because some

Speaker: NA
Text: of those states obviously were not suffering bad drought-partly true, Minister. But you have

Speaker: NA
Text: to recall that the concessional loans scheme wasn't a drought package; it was a drought relief

Speaker: NA
Text: package and, when it was constructed, the farm sector in Australia was not facing severe

Speaker: NA
Text: drought. It was never a drought package. Yes, if drought was one of the reasons farmers were

Speaker: NA
Text: struggling to deal with their debt, then that would feed into that process. So it is wrong to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that, Minister, and you know it is wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: My question to you specifically on this is: what methodology was used to determine which

Speaker: NA
Text: states would receive the amounts taken from the smaller states? What consultation was

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken with the smaller states before that money was taken? More particularly, the money

Speaker: NA
Text: you took away was more than the money you distributed to Queensland and New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales-a substantial difference; $40 million, if I remember correctly. You made a

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment that that $40 million would be put back into the concessional loans system-that

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: is, the original concessional loans scheme. I ask you: has that money been put back; and, if

Speaker: NA
Text: not, do you still guarantee that that $40 million will be returned to that particular package?

Speaker: NA
Text: I take you to your package, Minister, what I call the drought concessional loans scheme,

Speaker: NA
Text: which you implied tonight is assisting farmers as we speak, but, as I pointed out in question

Speaker: NA
Text: time today, on my last advice-and I would be very surprised if it has changed-not one

Speaker: NA
Text: farming family or farm enterprise has been a beneficiary of that drought concessional loan

Speaker: NA
Text: package since its implementation. I remind you that you first announced that scheme late in

Speaker: NA
Text: February. We are now well into June and that has not been bedded down. You stand here and

Speaker: NA
Text: criticise the design of Labor's concessional loans scheme, which, as you know, is flowing to

Speaker: NA
Text: farm enterprises and farm families, and yet your own scheme is not flowing. So I would really

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciate answers to what I think are very, very reasonable questions.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the issue of the transitional or family payment, you know that welfare payment has

Speaker: NA
Text: always been part of drought. It is the one thing that has survived the COAG reforms. You

Speaker: NA
Text: should not claim that that is a big step up by this government. We were happy to support the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes you made and facilitate them to the parliament, but you might tell me whether it is

Speaker: NA
Text: true that those who are in receipt of those payments are therefore denied certain social

Speaker: NA
Text: services under the rural counselling scheme. I was just outside Emerald last week and I was

Speaker: NA
Text: informed that people are being denied certain services under what is generally known as the

Speaker: NA
Text: rural counselling scheme because they have taken up the offer under that family payment

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangement. If you would confirm that for me, it would be very much appreciated.

Speaker: Dr GILLESPIE
Text: Lyne) (18:36): Australia is incredibly fortunate to have a very high

Speaker: NA
Text: status of freedom from a vast array of exotic pests and diseases. If any of those were to

Speaker: NA
Text: establish themselves here in Australia, it would potentially decimate large sections of our

Speaker: NA
Text: primary industry sector. You only have to look at the Varroa mite and the colony collapse

Speaker: NA
Text: disorder that has affected the bee industry overseas and the screw-worm fly, which exists as

Speaker: NA
Text: close as Papua New Guinea. There was an isolated outbreak in Wagga; fortunately, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: snuffed out. Karnal bunt is a fungal disease of wheat found in the USA, and there is a vector

Speaker: NA
Text: insect, the glassy-winged sharpshooter, which introduces Pierce's disease, can decimate the

Speaker: NA
Text: wine and grape industry and is afflicting the North American grape industry. Recently, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have had the Asian longhorn beetle, the brown mulberry longhorn beetle and Japanese soya

Speaker: NA
Text: beetles identified in some wood products. There were some press releases about it. You can

Speaker: NA
Text: see what potentially could have happened to apples, pears and stone fruits. Some months ago,

Speaker: NA
Text: a chocolate banded snail outbreak was also identified. So there are all these exotic pests and

Speaker: NA
Text: diseases.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our overseas colleagues and trading partners say that a lot of this is just a beat-up, but

Speaker: NA
Text: really it is a major threat to our isolated flora and fauna. Minister, in light of these ever-

Speaker: NA
Text: present threats that exotic pests and disease pose to us, how important is it to get the correct

Speaker: NA
Text: government structures and governance in place for our national biosecurity efforts?

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mrs Andrews): I call the minister.

Speaker: Mr Fitzgibbon
Text: Madam Deputy Speaker, I am on my feet at the table. Why would you

Speaker: NA
Text: not be calling me?

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Because the last time you jumped to your feet-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr Fitzgibbon
Text: Madam Deputy Speaker, I am sorry. You must go government then

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Excuse me, the last time you spoke you did not have the call.

Speaker: NA
Text: I had not given the call to you and you had spoken twice. I have given the call to the minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Please resume your seat.

Speaker: Mr Fitzgibbon
Text: If you do not call me, Madam Deputy Speaker-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Resume your seat.

Speaker: Mr Fitzgibbon
Text: You cannot do this.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Resume your seat.

Speaker: Mr Fitzgibbon
Text: No, you must give the opposition the call on this occasion. You might

Speaker: NA
Text: want to seek advice from the clerks. I am happy to give you that opportunity.

Speaker: Mr Joyce
Text: Don't let them bully you, Madam Deputy Speaker.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: I give the call to the minister to respond to questions so far.

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: New England-Minister for Agriculture and Deputy Leader of The

Speaker: NA
Text: Nationals) (18:39): I intend to address some of the issues that were brought up by both the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow minister and the member for Lyne. I have now been advised by the department that,

Speaker: NA
Text: when we had carriage of the concessional farm finance package, there were only three

Speaker: NA
Text: states-Queensland, Western Australia and Victoria-that had signed off on it. The statement

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the shadow minister of 'all but one' is incorrect. We had three. In the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia there are more than three states, last time I checked, so we had to get the others to

Speaker: NA
Text: sign off. We had to progress this deal. There is always an issue with picking up the paperwork

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Labor Party and trying to finish the job off. They never get there. It is always like a

Speaker: NA
Text: packet of poo tickets caught in the corner. You have to try to fix it up, sweep it up together

Speaker: NA
Text: and try to make some sense out of it.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we also had was this complete confusion. Yes, there was a presumption that the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of farmers we had in Tasmania-and Tasmania is a great place-was the same as the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of farmers we had in New South Wales. It was an absurdity. After we got everybody

Speaker: NA
Text: signed off, we had to redesign the whole thing to make it work.

Speaker: NA
Text: With regard to some states, and I refer to Western Australia, they placed conditions on how

Speaker: NA
Text: they were going to lend the money in that concessional farm finance package out. It did make

Speaker: NA
Text: it vastly more restrictive than other states, and it was difficult for those farmers to get access

Speaker: NA
Text: to it. So what did we do? When we got the $320 million package through, we made it so that

Speaker: NA
Text: it was generic-so that people could get an equivalent loan in different states and territories.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the sort of process you do to try to make a program work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Moving on to biosecurity: biosecurity is terribly important. I think that, throughout the

Speaker: NA
Text: room, people understand that if we do not maintain our most competitive advantage-that is,

Speaker: NA
Text: our clean, green image-then we have real concerns. That is why, even in the last week, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have been on the front foot making sure we deal with the detection of three beetles. It might

Speaker: NA
Text: sound innocuous, but they were not George, Paul and Ringo. We had the longhorn beetle, the

Speaker: NA
Text: mulberry beetle and the sawyer beetle and these have the capacity to devastate our timber

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, as they have devastated Canada's. We have been on the front foot. We have been

Speaker: NA
Text: ventilating this issue. We have been making sure that we track it down. We have been getting

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the quarantine in place and collecting all but, we believe, a few pallets that are around

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide. This is where we have to make sure we have the competencies in that field that are

Speaker: NA
Text: so apparent in the Department of Agriculture. I am happy; we stand behind that program and

Speaker: NA
Text: are making sure the Department of Agriculture has a front-line role in all the mechanisms of

Speaker: NA
Text: connection so that we can detect these issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we had an incursion of foot-and-mouth disease, the person who brought it in would

Speaker: NA
Text: probably not even realise they had it. They could have been backpacking in Nepal. If they

Speaker: NA
Text: brought it in, we would have to shut down the beef industry, the sheep industry, the wool

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, live cattle exports-the whole lot. The whole lot would shut down. It is absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: imperative that we keep up our image and we are doing that.

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Text: Hunter) (18:43): That was a filibuster, but I agree with the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: that our clean, green, safe image is our greatest competitive advantage. I challenge the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister when he is next on his feet to tell us what any initiatives of the government-this

Speaker: NA
Text: government-have added, in the course of the last ten months, to biosecurity in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister likes to talk about concessional loans in the areas where he feels confident,

Speaker: NA
Text: and of course he has some advice about three states. My advice was different. We will have to

Speaker: NA
Text: agree to disagree on that, Minister. But you did not answer my specific question, so I am

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore going to come to some conclusions about the answers. You chose not to guarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: this House that the $40 million would be returned to the original concessional loans package;

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore, I can only come to the conclusion that that money is back off to consolidated

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue and will be denied to the farm enterprises of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: You did not deny that no-one in this country is a beneficiary of your drought farm

Speaker: NA
Text: financing package so, on that basis, I assume the answer to that is 'yes'-that is true: no-one is

Speaker: NA
Text: yet a recipient. You did imply that it is all fixed now and ready to go but my advice is still is

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is only Queensland farmers that have access to that scheme, so if you are not prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: to tell me otherwise then I think it is reasonable for me to assume, and for farming families

Speaker: NA
Text: out there across the country to assume, that that is also true. I would invite you to answer

Speaker: NA
Text: those questions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, you did not advise me that consultation was undertaken with the smaller states

Speaker: NA
Text: before that money was ripped away from them so, again, I can only assume that you are

Speaker: NA
Text: confirming by your silence the assertion I have made.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to move on to research and development. I made the point at the end of my opening

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks that it is research and development and innovation that, more than anything, is the

Speaker: NA
Text: extension that will bring us the real opportunities in the dining boom. I do note, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate the government, for fulfilling its election commitment to put an extra $100

Speaker: NA
Text: million into R&D-over a four-year period, I should mark. But that is a welcome thing. I

Speaker: NA
Text: invite more detail from the minister about how that money will be spent, and I also ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister what the net effect of R&D is in agriculture, given that it seems he did enhance R&D

Speaker: NA
Text: spending on one side but cut R&D funding to organisations like RIDC-the Rural Industries

Speaker: NA
Text: Development Corporation-to organisations like the CSIRO and to various CRCs in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. Indeed, this includes certain higher learning institutions. So I do ask the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: whether he can tell us what the net contribution to R&D in the agriculture sector will be as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of those two sides of the formula.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also ask him about another very important area, and that is regional sustainability.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was a great disappointment to me that resource sustainability did not form part of his terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of reference for his agricultural white paper. I just do not understand how you can talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: agriculture's future in this country and the opportunities in Asia without talking about how we

Speaker: NA
Text: produce more food with the same limited and, in some cases depleted, people, land and water

Speaker: NA
Text: resources. That leads me to questions on a bill that has just been introduced today, and that is

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's Carbon Farming Initiative. He might want to address my primary concern in

Speaker: NA
Text: that area, and that is the likely noncompetitiveness of the agriculture sector when bidding for

Speaker: NA
Text: funding under that scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would expect, Minister, that there are many other areas of the economy which will be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to abate carbon much more cheaply and competitively than will the agriculture sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, I am concerned in this reverse auction-type arrangement that the government

Speaker: NA
Text: proposes in the parliament, that the agriculture sector simply is not going to be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: compete for funding under the new Carbon Farming Initiative, and therefore will be cut off

Speaker: NA
Text: from assistance under that scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, I understand that the R&D component of the former regime will be reduced, if

Speaker: NA
Text: not abolished, further undermining the capacity of agriculture to secure credits under that

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. So if the minister could help us better understand that, that would be very much

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciated.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr JOHN COBB (Calare) (18:48): Initially, I mostly want to speak on the APVMA,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is a semiautonomous body but which has the ability to affect agriculture profitability,

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiency, ability to export and what we allow to come into Australia enormously.

Speaker: NA
Text: Twenty-five years ago Australia was the first place that chemical and veterinary medical

Speaker: NA
Text: companies came to get their products registered because if it was accepted here then it was

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted right around the world. It was efficient, it was fast and it was very well-respected.

Speaker: NA
Text: That has changed to an enormous degree. We are now the last place that chemical and

Speaker: NA
Text: veterinary medicines are brought to be registered. It must be remembered that we are not a big

Speaker: NA
Text: market in the scheme of things and a lot of companies feel that they do not need to cater for

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the things that we do need.

Speaker: NA
Text: I realise that, and I appreciate the shadow minister falling in with us on the amendments to

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation that got rid of the issue of having to automatically re-register chemicals on a

Speaker: NA
Text: time frame. That was ludicrous, and it is good to be shot of it. However, that does not make or

Speaker: NA
Text: force the APVMA to meet time frames, which they have never done-they have ignored them

Speaker: NA
Text: in the past. It has not meant that they have to take notice, particularly with chemicals, of

Speaker: NA
Text: countries that are as good as the USA and Canada, who do not want to kill their population or

Speaker: NA
Text: their animals or their plants either. They do very good work. The APVMA is not forced to

Speaker: NA
Text: make use of work they have already done. They always reinvent the wheel-the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: allows them to. But as they have not done it at any time recently why would they want to do it

Speaker: NA
Text: now?

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that the only way that the bureaucracy will do what they do not want to do is if they

Speaker: NA
Text: are forced to by competition. I am interested to know if we as a government are looking at

Speaker: NA
Text: making some of the testing contestable so that outside sources can come and do it-certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: as well and, I am sure, a damn sight faster than the APVMA does. They have enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: ability to help agriculture, which is not actually its job-its job is to protect people-by being

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: fast and efficient, and a hell of a lot faster and more efficient than they are now. The fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: this is totally cost recoverable means that they feel no pressure to get a move on at the best of

Speaker: NA
Text: times.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am very interested to know if we are looking at contestability and what we are doing. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously not good enough for a government to say that this is an autonomous body and they

Speaker: NA
Text: are a creature of government. We either force them to do what they should do well by making

Speaker: NA
Text: it contestable or by legislating to make them. I am very interested to hear where we are going

Speaker: NA
Text: on this. I appreciate the amendments to the legislation, but, to me, one of the biggest things

Speaker: NA
Text: facing agriculture is the bureaucracy and the bodies which we pay for and control working

Speaker: NA
Text: with agriculture and not seeing themselves as regulators and agriculture as their creature.

Speaker: NA
Text: One other question I have is where we are up to in assisting the Queensland government in

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with their issues of Johne's disease in the north with cattle.

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Text: Hunter) (18:52): I take this brief opportunity to simply reinforce the

Speaker: NA
Text: questions that I have put to the minister on the various concessional loans schemes. My

Speaker: NA
Text: additional question is: can the minister advise the House what will happen to the $40 million

Speaker: NA
Text: budgeted this financial year under the Drought Concessional Loans Scheme, given that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: hardly likely that he is going to be able to spend that money this fiscal year?

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: New England-Minister for Agriculture and Deputy Leader of The

Speaker: NA
Text: Nationals) (18:52): To the member for Calare: I would not jump the gun that he has actually

Speaker: NA
Text: got these amendments through the Senate. It is actually stalled in the Senate. We have got

Speaker: NA
Text: ourselves a bit of a-

Speaker: Mr Fitzgibbon
Text: It has stalled in the Senate, Minister? That is news to me.

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: So we have got a few problems over there, and that is not the first piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation that has stalled over there by reason of the Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: I just want to quickly go through a couple of the things that were also brought up by the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Calare. With regard to APVMA, I acknowledge that there is a strong desire in

Speaker: NA
Text: some instances by people wanting the minister to have a greater determination in what is

Speaker: NA
Text: available. This would move away from the belief in the independent scientists having

Speaker: NA
Text: complete oversight. As I have said before, I have to be little bit cautious because, if I had

Speaker: NA
Text: greater oversight, then maybe I would approve the use of DDT. But I do hear what you are

Speaker: NA
Text: saying. We do have the discussions with the independent scientists, especially in more recent

Speaker: NA
Text: times on fenthion, to try to make sure that we can get the greatest amount of information that

Speaker: NA
Text: we can possibly get on how we can work with growers so that we can assist them.

Speaker: NA
Text: If there were to be a greater say for the minister it would require a legislative change and I

Speaker: NA
Text: think quite some discernment into what latitude you gave the minister, because just as you can

Speaker: NA
Text: assist people you could also end up in a position-hopefully neither myself nor the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister but maybe somebody else who has a completely different view on the world-where

Speaker: NA
Text: they would go beyond where the independent scientists wish to be and would start banning

Speaker: NA
Text: things that would otherwise have no reason to be banned.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have had discussions lately at my office with a major chemical provider and it works both

Speaker: NA
Text: ways. He was saying that we were too quick and that it was not given the proper oversight

Speaker: NA
Text: and therefore the major chemical company felt that they were exposed because Australia in

Speaker: NA
Text: some instances is too quick in its registration of chemicals and they did not believe that their

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: intellectual property was well protected in that space. However, I do note and I have noted

Speaker: NA
Text: from my own ministerial advisory council precisely the issues the member for Calare brought

Speaker: NA
Text: up, and that is that people want a greater capacity for APVMA to use existing knowledge as

Speaker: NA
Text: has been determined overseas and also to not completely go back over covered ground in

Speaker: NA
Text: registration of certain chemicals. I am having that discussion with APVMA via my

Speaker: NA
Text: department on precisely that.

Speaker: NA
Text: With the issue of Johne's disease, there has been a request by Queensland for us to include

Speaker: NA
Text: in our levy structure a levy to assist Queensland in the eradication of bovine Johne's disease. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have a hesitancy to do that because, first of all, the Auditor-General has told me to have

Speaker: NA
Text: hesitancy because I am not allowed to. Apart from that, it opens a bit of a Pandora's box that

Speaker: NA
Text: every state then, when they want a levy, will arrive at the door of the federal government to

Speaker: NA
Text: impose it. Queensland has an alternate capacity to create a levy to control bovine Johne's

Speaker: NA
Text: disease themselves. I do not want to start picking up their washing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Going back to the issue of concessional loans, as I have said, Western Australia being a

Speaker: NA
Text: classic example, if on the concessional farm finance package, which I commend the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister for now calling the drought package- (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr TAYLOR
Text: Hume) (18:58): I have spoken many times in this and other chambers

Speaker: NA
Text: about the opportunity in agriculture. I know the minister has spoken about that earlier, as has

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Hunter. In the time that remains, my question for the minister is: how will the

Speaker: NA
Text: agricultural white paper help the farmers of Australia to capture the fast-growing

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities in agricultural markets in Asia?

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: New England-Minister for Agriculture and Deputy Leader of The

Speaker: NA
Text: Nationals) (18:58): I thank the member for Hume, who I know has a very strong and very

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberate understanding and passion in agriculture. The white paper has received close to 680

Speaker: NA
Text: submissions. It has had more submissions to it, I believe, than any other white paper that has

Speaker: NA
Text: ever been-in recent memory, anyhow-before the parliament. So I am informed. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: willing to be corrected, but that is the mail I am getting at this point in time. We have had

Speaker: NA
Text: around 25 face-to-face meetings-

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: Does it? How many has it got?

Speaker: NA
Text: An opposition member: Over a thousand.

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: Okay, I stand corrected. If you are correct, it is 18c.

Speaker: NA
Text: With his information we have the capacity to deliver a policy platform, because ultimately

Speaker: NA
Text: this becomes a policy document. I have carriage of it but I do not have the passage of it

Speaker: NA
Text: through cabinet. It becomes a document of the Prime Minister. As I have said before, if you

Speaker: NA
Text: vote against it, it is called a 'career move'!

Speaker: NA
Text: An honourable member: Stop it!

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: You are using time up! I want to get back to his concessional loan issue-I

Speaker: NA
Text: think it is only fair. With the white paper, we have had the issues paper out, we are eminently

Speaker: NA
Text: about to release the green paper, which is the range of alternatives, and from that we intend

Speaker: NA
Text: the white paper and its conclusion will be drawn down around about November or December.

Speaker: NA
Text: With this it will be able to cover everything from infrastructure, such as we are currently

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: driving towards inland rail, creating greater connectivity between mining infrastructure and

Speaker: NA
Text: agricultural infrastructure. Also as part of that purpose I have been appointed as the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Agriculture to be chairman of the dams committee. We all know that water is wealth and

Speaker: NA
Text: when the Prime Minister decides to have a dams committee and there must be an intention to

Speaker: NA
Text: build dams.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our nation in 1980 had about 4½ megs of storage per person. We are down to around 3½

Speaker: NA
Text: now. If we continue on our way we are going to be down to about 2½ megs of storage in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2050. That is just insufficient. Australia has to take the next step in dams. This will be

Speaker: NA
Text: something that I hope we get, because I know the Australian people want us to take the next

Speaker: NA
Text: step-overwhelmingly. There will always be a contingent that lives with the benefaction of

Speaker: NA
Text: dams and the benefaction of so many resources, but they never want anyone else to advance

Speaker: NA
Text: their position. But I believe this nation in the dams committee, which is also an integral part

Speaker: NA
Text: and is meshed within the white paper, is going to be so very important in advancing

Speaker: NA
Text: agriculture in new parts of this nation, especially in the North.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that the member for Flynn is here. In the Fitzroy catchment are some of the better

Speaker: NA
Text: dam sites in this nation. We have already been dealing with it. One of the biggest inhibitors of

Speaker: NA
Text: us actually progressing the dams issue in so many instances is excessive environmental green

Speaker: NA
Text: tape. We have the engineers that can do it, we have a workman who can do it, we have the

Speaker: NA
Text: plant operators who can do it, we have the farmers who can benefit from it and we have the

Speaker: NA
Text: hydroelectricity we can generate off it. The biggest impediment is ourselves. We have got to

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure that we reduce that impediment-not remove that impediment completely, but

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce that impediment in certain areas to do something that allows us to progress.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the member for Flynn's electorate, Nathan Dam is held up by the boggomoss snail. This

Speaker: NA
Text: boggomoss snail is almost but not quite as powerful as the Booroolong frog, which managed

Speaker: NA
Text: to stop Chaffey Dam for I do not know how many years. But the boggomoss snail has been

Speaker: NA
Text: having a whale of a time and it is holding up a fundamental mechanism for the advancement

Speaker: NA
Text: of the economy in the Fitzroy Basin for both flood mitigation for the development of jobs and

Speaker: NA
Text: also doing something that the Australian people have always wanted to do, and that is move

Speaker: NA
Text: water from one catchment into the Murray-Darling. We can do that. We have the capacity to

Speaker: NA
Text: do that. Likewise, a dam that was in my area on the Apsley River was stopped by Neville

Speaker: NA
Text: Wran. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Federation Chamber adjourned at 19:04.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS IN WRITING

Speaker: NA
Text: Coal Seam Gas

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 173)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister for Industry, in writing, on 28 May 2014:

Speaker: NA
Text: In respect of the coal gas industry stakeholders group announced on 26 September 2013, what (a) are

Speaker: NA
Text: its terms of reference, (b) are the expanded, current and projected financial costs by the Government, (c)

Speaker: NA
Text: is the projected duration for its activities, (d) is the membership and the qualifications and remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: of members, and (e) are the current and future plans for public, private and industry consultations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ian Macfarlane: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: Preliminary work was undertaken in considering the scope of this work and discussions were

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken with potential panel members for advisory panel on New South Wales coal seam gas (CSG).

Speaker: NA
Text: In parallel, the government also released a major study on the Eastern Australian Domestic Gas Market

Speaker: NA
Text: and consulted with stakeholders on potential policy options. In light of this analysis the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: decided not to progress with convening such a panel or finalising its terms of reference and other

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Force Survey

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 176)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kelvin Thomson: MP asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment,

Speaker: NA
Text: in writing, on 3 June 2014:

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the level of unemployment in the (a) aviation sector, and (b) trucking industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member's question:

Speaker: NA
Text: According to estimates from the Labour Force Survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of

Speaker: NA
Text: Statistics, in 2013 (latest available data), there were approximately:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) 2000 people who were unemployed and who reported that their most recent job in the past two

Speaker: NA
Text: years was in Air and Space Transport; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) 7300 people who were unemployed and who reported that their most recent job in the past two

Speaker: NA
Text: years was in Road Freight Transport.
